1 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Grandview Heights City School Dist. Board of Education v. Morton


No. 74-1087


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 2d 151; 339 N.E.2d 663; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 602; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 454



December 17, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relator is the board of education of the Grandview Heights City School District, a district which includes, in addition to the city of Grandview Heights, the village of Marble Cliff and a portion of the city of Columbus.

Respondents are the city solicitor, mayor, president of council, and members of council, of the city of Grandview Heights.

By letter dated January 28, 1974, the board of education, acting through the Superintendent of Schools, requested legal advice on specific questions from respondent city solicitor. On January 31, 1974, the city solicitor declined to advise the board. On October 2, 1974, the solicitor reaffirmed that position, in a formal opinion addressed to the mayor of Grandview Heights. That opinion stated, in part:

"* * * the city of Grandview Heights has neither the obligation nor the right to furnish free legal services to the board of education of the Grandview Heights School District."

Relator, in the present mandamus action, seeks an order to require respondent city solicitor to provide free legal services to relator, and to require respondent city officials to so order respondent city solicitor. The cause is before this court [***2] upon the pleadings, an agreed statement of facts, and memoranda of law.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator board of education sought a writ of mandamus to require respondent city solicitor to provide free legal services to the board of education, and to require respondent city officials to so order the city solicitor.


OVERVIEW: The board of education requested legal advice on specific questions from the city solicitor. The city solicitor declined to advise the board. The board of education sought a writ of mandamus to require the city solicitor to provide free legal services to the board of education, and to require the city officials to so order the city solicitor. Allowing the writ, the court held that Grandview Heights, Ohio Charter § 43, read in conjunction with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3313.35, obligated the city solicitor to provide free legal services to the board of education. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3313.35 was not unconstitutional. The court found that respondents relied upon dicta in their argument that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3313.35 was unconstitutional. The court noted that the cases relied upon by respondents did not support respondents' proposition that Ohio Const. art. I, § 19, which precluded the taking of private property for public use without compensation. In addition, the court found that respondents contended that providing free legal services to the board of education would be a taking of public, not private, money.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the board of education a writ of mandamus to require the city solicitor to provide free legal services to the board of education, and to require the city officials to so order the city solicitor.

 

2 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Herrick v. Kosydar


No. 75-52


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 2d 128; 339 N.E.2d 626; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 599; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 442



December 17, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is a class action brought on behalf of former state employees, entitled to benefits under either the Public Employees Retirement System or the State Teachers Retirement System, who retired prior to October 16, 1972. On that date, R. C. 145.56 and 3307.71 were amended to provide that the right of a person to a pension or retirement allowance is subject to the state income tax. Plaintiffs brought this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County seeking a declaratory judgment that the amendments to R. C. 145.56 and 3307.71 are unconstitutional, a permanent injunction to prevent the levying or collection of the tax, and a refund of taxes already collected. The Tax Commissioner and the State Treasurer were named in the action as defendants.

The commissioner moved to dismiss the action for lack of jurisdiction over the subject matter, lack of jurisdiction over the person, and for failure to state a claim upon which relief could be granted, pursuant to Civ. R. 12. The trial court granted the motion, holding that the claim was exclusively within the jurisdiction of the Tax Commissioner by way of administrative hearing [***2] and appeal to the courts under R. C. Title 57, and that plaintiffs' claim for an injunction was not within the court's jurisdiction by virtue of R. C. 5703.38.

The Court of Appeals reversed that judgment.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant tax commissioner appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals, Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's dismissal of a class action by plaintiffs, former state employees, seeking a declaratory judgment that the amendments to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 145.56, 3307.71, were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The employees were state retirees who sought a declaration as to their liabilities when the law was changed to provide that their pensions were subject to state income tax. The commissioner sought dismissal of the action for lack of jurisdiction over the subject matter and over the person, and for failure to state a claim pursuant to Ohio R. Civ. P. 12. The trial court granted the commissioner's motion, holding that the employees' claims were exclusively within the jurisdiction of the commissioner by way of administrative hearing and appeal to the courts. The appellate court disagreed with the trial court. The court held that declaratory judgment was a proper means to adjudicate the rights and status of the parties when the controversy presented was a real and justiciable one. The court found that speedy relief was necessary to preserve the employees' right to refuse to pay the taxes mandated by statute. Administrative proceedings in the case would be futile because an administrative agency was without jurisdiction to determine the constitutional validity of a statute and administrative remedies would require an estimated 40,000 claimants to file separate refund applications.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment reversing the dismissal of the employees' declaratory judgment action.

 

3 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland Board of Education v. Cuyahoga County Board of Revision


No. 75-174


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 2d 83; 337 N.E.2d 786; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 587; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 326



November 26, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On December 14, 1973, the Fullwell Motor Products Company purchased real estate in the Cleveland taxing district of Cuyahoga County for $ 650,000. Based upon the sale, the Cleveland Board of Education, appellant herein, filed a complaint with the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision, pursuant to R. C. 5715.19, seeking to increase the 1973 taxable value of that property. By letter, appellant requested that the board of revision compute the taxable value by multiplying the fair market value, stipulated to be $ 650,000, by 33.4 percent, the common level of assessment of real property in Cuyahoga County for the tax year 1970 (the year of the last complete general reappraisal of real property in that county).

On September 16, 1974, the board of revision found the 1973 taxable value to be $ 198,000, which was computed by multiplying the fair market value by the 1973 Cuyahoga County common level of assessment of 30.6 percent.

The Board of Tax Appeals, upon appeal, finding no error in the decision of the board of revision, determined the taxable value by using the 1973 Cuyahoga County common level of assessment of 30.6 percent.

The cause is now before [***2] this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner challenged the order of a board of tax appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the method of appellee county board of revision in calculating the taxable value of the owner's property.


OVERVIEW: The issue on appeal was whether the decision of the board of tax appeals, which applied a common level of assessment to determine the taxable value of the owner's property, was unreasonable or unlawful. The owner contended that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5715.012 and 5715.19 caused statewide non-uniformity and could not be applied. The court affirmed and held that the board of tax appeals had the mandatory duty, in the exercise of its supervisory power under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.01 (1969), to take such steps necessary to effect an orderly correction of any inequalities in the percentage of true value at which all real property and all classes thereof were assessed for taxation. The court held that the fairest and most equitable procedure for complying with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.011 was to stagger statewide implementation of the board of tax appeals' uniform valuation rules over a six-year cycle beginning in the tax year 1972. The court held that the existing staggered sexennial reappraisal and the concomitant duties of the board of tax appeals during that reappraisal period were valid.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the board of tax appeals.

 

4 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Whitman


No. 74-556


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 2d 58; 337 N.E.2d 773; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 582; 73 Ohio Op. 2d 283



November 19, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This is an appeal from an August 17, 1973, order by the Ohio Director of Environmental Protection, acting upon a complaint filed by one Harvey A. Immerman, directing the city of Cincinnati to add fluoride to its water system as required by R. C. 6111.13. In the case of Crotty v. Cincinnati (unreported, case No. A-244304, decided July 15, 1971), a declaratory judgment action in the Common Pleas Court of Hamilton County, R. C. 6111.13 was held to be unconstitutional, and the city of Cincinnati was permanently enjoined from fluoridating its water supply system under that statutory provision. The Attorney General of Ohio was given notice of the proceeding, but was not made a party and did not participate in the action. The Director of Health (predecessor to the Director of Environmental Protection's enforcement responsibilities under R. C. 6111.13) was also not made a party.

The Environmental Board of Review affirmed the order of the Director, and the Court of Appeals affirmed that order of the Board.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed [***2] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a ruling by the Ohio Environmental Board of Review affirming an order of appellee Ohio Director of Environmental Protection directing the city to add fluoride to its water system as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 6111.13.


OVERVIEW: Contrary to an injunction issued by a court of common pleas in another action, the Director ordered the city to fluoridate its public water, as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 6111.13, the board of review affirmed his ruling, and the court of appeals affirmed the board's ruling. The court affirmed and found that the injunction was void because the court of common pleas lacked jurisdiction to issue it. Because the Director was a necessary party to the action in which the injunction was issued, his absence from that action deprived the common pleas court of the jurisdiction to render an enforceable declaratory judgment and to enjoin the city from instituting the fluoridation.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

5 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Primes v. Tyler


No. 75-61


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 2d 195; 331 N.E.2d 723; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 561; 72 Ohio Op. 2d 112



July 23, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Plaintiff George Primes III, appellee herein, and defendant Donald G. Tyler, appellant herein, are part of a group of weekend golfers who travel to various golf courses by way of an informal car pooling arrangement, where the golfer who arranges the tee times with the golf course also arranges who should drive as he contacts the other riders. That determination (who drives) depends on the proximity of the selected golf course to the homes of the riders.

No payment has ever been made nor has any gasoline ever been purchased by anyone for the driver. No set arrangements regarding transportation have ever been worked out on a regular or definite basis.

On the day of the collision, May 29, 1972, Tyler picked up Primes at his home, and, en route to the golf course, failed to complete a turn at an intersection, and collided with a telephone pole, causing injury to Primes.

Primes filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas, which alleged that he was a "paying passenger" and that Tyler was guilty of ordinary negligence. Tyler's answer denied both allegations.

At the conclusion of the plaintiff's case, the court [***2] sustained defendant's motion for a directed verdict, and entered judgment for defendant.

Upon appeal, that judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Judges Victor, Mahoney and Doyle), which found that the evidence would not support a finding that plaintiff was a "paying passenger" and thus the Ohio guest statute, R. C. 4515.02, would apply to preclude liability, but that such statute is unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection guarantees of the Ohio and United States Constitutions. The Court of Appeals certified its judgment to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant driver sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which reversed a decision of the trial court in favor of the driver in an action by appellee passenger for damages sustained in a car accident.


OVERVIEW: The parties were part of a group of golfers that carpooled together to various golf courses. The accident that gave rise to this action occurred while the parties were carpooling. The passenger alleged that he was a paying passenger of the driver in order to avoid Ohio's guest statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4515.02, which extended immunity to drivers for damages incurred by guests in automobile accidents. The trial court granted a directed verdict to the driver on the grounds that the passenger was a mere guest. The lower appellate court reversed on the grounds that the guest statute was unconstitutional. The court affirmed the decision of the lower appellate court and found that the guest statute violated the equal protection guarantees of the state and federal constitutions. The purpose of the guest statute was to prevent fraudulent lawsuits and to preserve the hospitality of the host-driver. However, the statute did nothing to prevent a guest from bringing a false claim to avoid the statute and that the availability of liability insurance made preserving hospitality moot. Thus the classification scheme created by the guest statute served no compelling governmental interest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower appellate court's decision in favor of the passenger.

 

6 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Berisford v. Sells


No. 74-307


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 2d 205; 331 N.E.2d 408; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 562; 72 Ohio Op. 2d 117



July 23, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Belmont County.

On August 14, 1966, plaintiff, Martha Berisford, appellant herein, and defendant, Mary Sells, appellee herein, were returning to resume classes at Ohio University in Athens following a weekend visit to their homes in Martins Ferry, when, after driving through a six-inch deep hole covered by an accumulation of water, Sells lost control of the car, which crossed the highway and plunged into a roadside ditch, causing injuries to Berisford.

An informal arrangement existed among certain Martins Ferry girls attending Ohio University to ride together whenever going to or from Athens. Appellant has contended throughout the proceeding that she had entered into an ongoing agreement to pay for her transportation.

Berisford's amended complaint, filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Belmont County, alleged that Sells had been guilty of ordinary negligence, and that recovery should be had under the first claim which alleged an agreement to pay for the ride, or under the second claim which failed to allege payment but described herself as a "passenger."

Defendant moved to dismiss the second claim for the reason that R. C. 4515.02 precluded [***2] recovery under that claim in the absence of an allegation of payment for the ride or defendant's willful and wanton misconduct. The court granted the motion to dismisss the second claim without stating reasons therefor.

At trial, plaintiff moved to reinstate the second claim, urging that the guest statute is unconstitutional, and that, therefore, her allegations stated a claim upon which relief could be granted in the absence of the statute. The motion was summarily overruled.

After the court overruled motions for directed verdict, the jury returned a general verdict in favor of the defendant.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals rejected plaintiff's contention that the guest statute is unconstitutional, ruled that plaintiff's failure to comply with Civ. R. 51 precluded an attack on alleged omissions in the court's charge to the jury and affirmed the judgment in favor of defendant.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff passenger appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Belmont County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court jury verdict in favor of defendant driver in the passenger's action against the driver for negligence in causing the passenger's injuries in a one-car automobile accident. The passenger contended that the guest statute that had precluded her recovery was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Two girls were in a one-car accident on their way back to college after a visit home. One was a paying passenger of the driver. The passenger filed a negligence action against the driver, alleging that her negligence in speeding was the cause of the passenger's injuries. A jury found in favor of the driver and the passenger appealed, contending that the guest statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4515.02, that prohibited her recovery from the negligent driver was unconstitutional. The court of appeals affirmed the judgment and ruled that § 4525.02 was not unconstitutional. On further appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals that affirmed the jury verdict, but found that a determination of the constitutionality of § 4515.02 was not required to reach that result where the general jury verdict had not been tested by interrogatories to determine the rationale for the verdict.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals that affirmed the trial court verdict in favor of the driver in the passenger's negligence action.

 

7 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ohio Public Interest Action Group, Inc. v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 74-1032


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 2d 175; 331 N.E.2d 730; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 559; 72 Ohio Op. 2d 98



July 16, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

In September 1972, appellant, Ohio Public Interest Action Group, Inc., filed a complaint with appellee, Public Utilities Commission, pursuant to R. C. 4905.26, naming as respondents seven electric utility companies. In its amended complaint, appellant prayed for the commission to "take the following action":

"1. Order all respondents engaged in advertising to immediately cease all advertising and promotional practices whatsoever which directly or indirectly encourage the demand for, or the use or consumption of, electrical power in the state of Ohio.

"2. That in the alternative, respondents be ordered to immediately cease to include monetary expenditures for said advertising and promotional practices in the category of operating expenses in the Annual Reports filed with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio and thereby prohibiting the cost for said advertising and promotional practices from being passed on to the consumer.

"3. That respondents refund to their consumers on a pro-rated basis all expenses incurred by the respondents and charged to the consumer for advertising and promotional activities since energy conservation was [***2] recognized as an issue of national concern; to wit: Earth Day, in March of 1970, the exact amount of which is not known to the complainant but will be determined by the evidence, and is approximately $ 75,000,000 (seventy-five million dollars).

"4. Order respondents to adopt and implement a program whereby electrical power conservation must be considered at all levels of corporate activity including rate making, and the hiring and promotion of employees and officers.

"5. Undertake an investigation to discover any other activities of respondents which encourage the demand for, or the use or consumption of, electrical power in the state of Ohio, and issue appropriate orders to encourage conservation of electrical power and minimize environmental harm.

"6. Condition any further remedy or rate relief requested by respondents on maximum efforts by respondents to encourage conservation of electrical power and minimize environmental harm.

"7. Take any other imaginative and appropriate action to encourage respondents to conserve electrical power and minimize environmental harm.

"8. That claimant and the class action claimants shall have all costs, expenses and fees, including reasonable [***3] attorneys fees and such other and further relief as the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio shall deem just and proper."

Subsequently, the commission consolidated the instant cause with its own case, entitled, "In the Matter of the Commission investigation of promotional activities of electric companies in Ohio," and conducted hearings on the matters raised in the complaint.

During the course of the commission proceedings, the General Assembly enacted Amended Substitute House Bill 206. Section 9 of that Act reads:

"No state agency, board, or commission shall limit or restrict the right of any public utility to engage in and promote area development or to advertise, except as otherwise expressly provided by law or by rules properly adopted in accordance with law and in effect on March 1, 1974."

On August 22, 1974, the commission entered in its journal the following entry in response to a motion to dismiss filed by intervenor, Ohio Association of Broadcasters:

"(1) The Ohio Association of Broadcasters filed with the commission a motion to dismiss the above three cases on April 29, 1974.

"(2) The commission has previously entered entries and orders in the above matters [the consolidated [***4] cases] and held hearings with a view to determining the appropriateness of advertising and other promotional activities for electric and gas utilities.

"(3) The Legislature has enacted Sub. H. B. 206, establishing the Energy Emergency Commission, which provides in Section 9:

"No state agency, board, or commission shall limit or restrict the right of any public utility to engage in and promote area development or to advertise, except as otherwise expressly provided by law or by rules properly adopted in accordance with law and in effect on March 1, 1974.

"This statute, when it becomes effective, prohibits the commission from proceeding further in these matters, and therefore, they should be dismissed.

"(4) Although the instant cases are dismissed, Section 9 does not apply to commission determination of the reasonableness of the type of expenses under question here in rate proceedings.

"Therefore, it is,

"Ordered, That the above-entitled matters hereby are dismissed."

From the foregoing order of the commission, appellant perfected an appeal to this court.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant public interest group sought review of an order from appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which granted appellee broadcasters association's motion to dismiss proceedings that concerned the appropriateness of advertising and other promotional activities for electric utility companies.


OVERVIEW: The public interest group filed a complaint with the Commission concerning the appropriateness of advertising and other promotional activities for electric utility companies. The Commission subsequently consolidated the complaint with its own case and subsequently dismissed the proceedings upon the motion of the broadcasters association pursuant to Amended Substitute H.B. 206, § 9 (Ohio 1974). On appeal, the court affirmed the Commission's order. The court found that the proceedings under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.26 did not come within the exceptions enumerated in Amended Substitute H.B. 206, § 9 (Ohio 1974). The court determined that the general savings clause contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1.58 was not applicable because Amended Substitute H.B. 206, § 9 (Ohio 1974) did not repeal Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.26. The court concluded that Substitute H.B. 206, § 9 (Ohio 1974) did not violate constitutional provisions that prohibited retroactive legislation. The court found that Substitute H.B. 206, § 9 (Ohio 1974) did not conflict with any constitutional inhibitions and that the Commission did not err in failing to consider the public interest group's request for attorney fees.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's order against the public interest group that granted the broadcasters association's motion to dismiss the proceedings concerning the electric utility companies' advertising and other promotional activities.

 

8 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Beatty v. Alston


No. 74-811


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 2d 126; 330 N.E.2d 921; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 551; 72 Ohio Op. 2d 70



July 9, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In June 1973, appellant was tried before a jury in the Franklin County Municipal Court on a charge of petty larceny. Judge G. W. Fais presided at the two-day trial, which terminated with a verdict of guilty. Sentencing was continued pending a presentence investigation, and appellant was allowed to remain at liberty under bond.

When appellant did not appear for sentencing on the scheduled date, Judge Fais ordered a bond forfeiture and issued a warrant for appellant's arrest.

On February 23, 1974, appellant was arrested by Columbus police officers upon the basis of this warrant and three others pertaining to traffic offenses.

Appellant was brought before Judge Bruce Jenkins of the Franklin County Municipal Court on February 25, 1974, at the regular session of morning arraignment court. Judge Jenkins' docket apparently listed not only the three traffic violations, but also the fact that appellant had not yet been sentenced on the petty larceny conviction. During the course of the proceedings before Judge Jenkins, one of the traffic charges was dismissed, appellant entered a plea of no contest to the other two, was found [***2] guilty and fined, and a sentence of $ 50, plus costs, was imposed for the petty larceny conviction.

Later that same day, Judge Fais discovered that Judge Jenkins had sentenced appellant on the petty larceny conviction. Judge Fais immediately vacated that sentence and ordered appellant brought before him for sentencing. On February 27, 1974, over the objection of appellant's counsel, Judge Fais imposed a sentence for the petty larceny conviction of 60 days in the workhouse and a fine of $ 200, plus costs.

Appellant was incarcerated, and he promptly sought release through the present habeas corpus action initiated in the Court of Common Pleas for Franklin County.

Appellant's complaint alleges, in pertinent part: "That the action of * * * [Judge] Fais setting aside the order of Judge Jenkins was without foundation in law and was and is void ab initio, for lack of jurisdiction."

The Court of Common Pleas refused to issue the writ, and that court's judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals. The cause, which allegedly involves a substantial constitutional question, is now before this court both as a matter of right and pursuant to a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION:  [***3] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) denying is application for a writ of habeas corpus seeking release from incarceration following a conviction of petty larceny.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was convicted of petty larceny, and was released on bond pending sentencing. Appellant failed to show, and an arrest warrant was issued. Appellant was arrested for unrelated traffic violations, and was brought before another trial court judge. The trial court judge in the petty larceny action vacated the sentence issued in the traffic violation action, and imposed his sentence for the petty larceny offense. Appellant was incarcerated, and filed an application for habeas corpus contending that the action of the petty larceny trial judge was without foundation in law and was ab initio for lack of jurisdiction. The court of common pleas refused to issue the writ, and the refusal was affirmed by the court of appeals. Appellant sought review of the decision, and the court determined that it was proper. The court held that under the instant facts, and pursuant to the authority vested in the trial judge by Ohio R. Crim. P. 25(B), the petty larceny judge's actions in vacating the traffic offenses judge's sentence and in imposing sentence on appellant were legally proper.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was affirmed.

 

9 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Voinovich v. Board of Park Comm'rs


No. 74-897


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 511; 330 N.E.2d 434; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 525; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 506



June 25, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

In May 1974, the Board of Park Commissioners of the Cleveland Metropolitan Park District, appellee herein, filed applications with the Cuyahoga County Auditor, appellant herein, for real property tax exemptions for the 1974 tax year and for remission of delinquent real property taxes, penalties, and interest for two parcels of land owned by the appellee. The remission sought for parcel No. 649-28-1A began with the 1933 tax year, for a total of $ 72,580.20. The remission sought for parcel No. 649-28-1B began with the 1966 tax year, for a total of $ 1,579.75. Both remission applications were based upon R. C. 5713.08 and the provisions of Amended House Bill No. 355 (effective November 21, 1973). The auditor recommended that the exemptions and remissions in both cases be granted.

The applications were then filed with the Board of Tax Appeals on May 16, 1974, for its consent. At a hearing held on July 12, 1974, before the Board of Tax Appeals, appellant contended that Amended House Bill No. 355 was unconstitutional.

On September 4, 1974, the Board of Tax Appeals, granted the applications, finding that the real property in question was entitled [***2] to the tax exemptions and remissions as requested in the applications.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee park board filed an application with appellant county auditor for real property tax exemptions for a tax year and for remission of delinquent real property taxes, penalties, and interest for two parcels of land it owned based on Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.08 and Am. H.B. 355, Gen. Assem. (Ohio 1973) (No. 355). The Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) found the property was entitled to the tax exemptions. The auditor appealed.


OVERVIEW: The auditor claimed that No. 355 was unconstitutional. The court affirmed. Prior to the enactment of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.081, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.08 allowed the auditor to remit delinquent general taxes, penalties, and interest in certain cases without any limitation as to years. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.081 provided that the Board had no authority to remit more than one year's delinquent taxes. No. 355 suspended the operation of § 5713.081 for a temporary period, which allowed the park board to take advantage of the law in effect and available to all other taxpayers in the same class prior to the enactment of § 5713.081. As such, No. 355 was nondiscriminatory legislation, which did not violate Ohio Const. art. I, § 2, or Ohio Const. art. II, § 28, or the Fourteenth Amendment. No. 355 did not give an advantage to delinquent taxpayers that was unavailable to other taxpayers in the same class, and was, therefore, constitutional.


OUTCOME: The decision of the Board of Tax Appeals was affirmed.

 

10 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Rankin-Thoman, Inc. v. Caldwell


Nos. 74-441, 74-471


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 436; 329 N.E.2d 686; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 512; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 411



June 11, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The issues raised by these appeals are identical.

The facts in case No. 74-441 are:

On February 27, 1973, the State Fire Marshall of Ohio adopted the rules and regulations which comprise the Ohio Fire Code. Section 14.6 of that Code requires the installation of a household fire warning system in all dwellings of more than one unit, from and after the effective date of the regulation.

On March 9, 1973, appellant, Rankin-Thoman, Inc., an Ohio corporation, filed two actions in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. The first, a declaratory judgment action, is not before this court. The second, an appeal pursuant to R. C. 119.11 from the adoption of the regulations, was dismissed by the Court of Common Pleas for lack of jurisdiction. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment dismissing the appeal.

The facts in case No. 74-471 are:

On May 8, 1973, the Chief of the Division of Forestry and Reclamation adopted rules and regulations pertaining to stripmining and the reclamation of mined land.

On May 22, 1973, appellants, American Electric Power Company and others, filed an appeal pursuant to R. C. 119.11 from the [***2] adoption of the regulations, alleging that they were unreasonable and unlawful. The Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment dismissing the appeal.

The causes are now before this court pursuant to the allowance of motions to certify the records.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, an Ohio company and an electric company, each sought review of a ruling from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgments dismissing appellants' application for review pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 119.11 from appellees, a State Fire Marshall's and a Chief of the Division of Forestry and Reclamation's, adoption of certain rules and regulations.


OVERVIEW: The Marshall adopted the rules and regulations of the Ohio Fire Code. Subsequently, the Ohio company filed a declaratory action in the trial court. In addition, the Ohio company filed an appeal pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 119.11 from the adoption of the regulations. The trial court dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction and the court of appeals affirmed. The Chief adopted the rules and regulations pertaining to strip-mining and the reclamation of mined land. The electric company appealed pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 119.11 from the adoption of the regulations, claiming that they were unreasonable and unlawful. The trial court dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction and the court of appeals affirmed. The court affirmed, finding that Ohio Rev. Code § 119.11 was unconstitutional because it was in violation of Ohio Const. art. IV, § 4(B). Further, the court found that the invalidity of Ohio Rev. Code § 119.11 did not render prospective relief from the enforcement of an administrative rule impossible.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

11 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Union Camp Corp., Harchem Div. v. Whitman


No. 74-661


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 441; 329 N.E.2d 690; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 513; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 414



June 11, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On January 21, 1974, the Director of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, appellee herein, without conducting an adjudication hearing, adopted certain regulations dealing with air quality standards and emission controls.

Shortly thereafter, appellant instituted an appeal to the Environmental Board of Review and moved for a hearing de novo pursuant to R. C. 3745.05. The board denied appellant's motion and ordered the parties to appear for a hearing based upon materials certified to the board by appellee.

Appellant appealed to the Court of Appeals, seeking a ruling on the denial of its motion for a de novo hearing. Appellee contended that the board's order denying appellant's motion for a de novo hearing was interlocutory, and not a final order reviewable by the court.

In dismissing appellant's appeal, the Court of Appeals stated that Fortner v. Thomas (1970), 22 Ohio St. 2d 13, 257 N. E. 2d 371, precluded its consideration of any appeal from the Environmental Board of Review involving the reasonableness and lawfulness of regulations promulgated by the director.

The cause is now before this court [***2] pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which dismissed its appeal of a decision by the Environmental Board of Review denying its motion for a hearing de novo pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3745.05 of appellee the Director of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency's decision to adopt certain regulations dealing with air quality standards and emission controls.


OVERVIEW: The corporation claimed that it had a right to a de novo hearing before the Board pursuant to § 3745.05. The appellate court dismissed the appeal holding that it was precluded from considering any appeal from the Board that involved the reasonableness and lawfulness of regulations promulgated by the Director. The court reversed. The fact that courts would not aid in making or revising rules of administrative officers, boards, or commissions, but would be confined to deciding whether such rules were reasonable and lawful as applied to the facts of a particular case, did not make a sweeping eradication of the protection against significant bureaucratic abuse, which was derived from judicial scrutiny of the activities of regulatory agencies. The issue of whether the rules promulgated by the Director were the result of bureaucratic abuse could not be determined on the record. Section 3745.05 required the Board to conduct a hearing de novo in an appeal from an order of the Director. The determination of that issue, and whether the denial of the hearing was not an appealable order, were issues for the appellate court to consider on remand.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate court was reversed and the cause was remanded.

 

12 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Burger Brewing Co. v. Thomas


Nos. 74-477, 74-492


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 377; 329 N.E.2d 693; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 505; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 366



June 4, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On June 16, 1970, the Ohio Liquor Control Commission adopted, at the request of the wholesale beer distributors, a regulation designated LCc-1-73. The stated purpose of the regulation was "To Curtail the Practice of 'Special Sales,' Whether Initiated by Breweries or Wholesale Distributors." Shortly thereafter a number of breweries holding permits to manufacture and distribute beer and malt beverages in Ohio commenced court attacks upon the validity of the regulation, such court proceedings culminating in the decision of this court in Burger Brewing Co. v. Liquor Control Comm. (1973), 34 Ohio St. 2d 93.

For a full delineation of the issues in Burger and the holdings of the Court of Common Pleas and the Court of Appeals, reference is made to the statement of facts therein. In the part of the decision here pertinent, this court, in Burger, reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals insofar as it held that a declaratory judgment action could not be utilized for a determination of the validity of the regulation and remanded the cause to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings.

Upon remand, the parties [***2] reasserted their basic claims. In substance, the brewers claimed, (1) the adoption of the regulation was beyond the power of the commission and (2) the trial court erred in holding the regulation was reasonable and lawful in part. The Wholesale Beer Association of Ohio, joined by the commission, asserted error of the trial court in holding part of the regulation unreasonable and unlawful.

The Court of Appeals held that the commission lacked authority to promulgate the rule, and, by reason of mootness, did not reach or pass upon the issue of reasonableness.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of the motions by the Wholesale Beer Association of Ohio and the Liquor Control Commission to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, Ohio Liquor Control Commission (commission) and wholesale beer association, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which held, on remand, the commission lacked authority to promulgate LCc-1-73, a regulation that was intended to curtail the practice of special sales by appellee breweries.


OVERVIEW: The commission promulgated a regulation that was implemented to curtail the practice of special sales of beer and malt beverages and that specifically regulated the pricing and marketing systems of malt beverages. The breweries filed an action attacking the validity of the regulation. The wholesale beer association, joined by the commission, asserted that the trial court erred in holding that part of the regulation was unreasonable and unlawful. The court of appeals held that the commission lacked authority to promulgate the regulation and found that the regulation was a price-fixing effort. Upon further review, the court affirmed the decision and held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4301.03, 4301.10 provided no express grant of authority for the commission to adopt regulations in the area of pricing of the malt beverage industry. The court held that it was evident that the general assembly had not specifically expressed an intention that the commission have such authority. Further, because there was no express grant, there was no implied grant as well. Because the court found that the commission was without authority to adopt the rule, it did not reach the issue of reasonableness.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, which held that the commission lacked authority to promulgate a regulation that was intended to curtail the practice of special sales by the breweries.

 

13 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kettering v. Baker


No. 74-487


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 351; 328 N.E.2d 805; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 498; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 322



May 28, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

Roland Vernell Baker, appellant herein, was arrested in the city of Kettering on October 13, 1972, at 3:20 a. m., for driving a vehicle upon a public street while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage. Kettering Patrolman David W. H. Woolf testified that he had followed the appellant some considerable distance after first observing appellant's automobile traveling in such a manner as to straddle two lanes of eastbound traffic. The arresting officer turned on the red light on top of his cruiser and the two blinking red lights in the grill as well as a "yelper" which changes tone second to second. Appellant did not stop but continued eastbound to the intersection of Marshall and Stroop Roads where he came to a sudden, jerky stop for a red light with the police cruiser, lights and "yelper" fully activated, stopped behind him. When the light changed, appellant proceeded to turn right whereupon he noted the police cruiser in pursuit and pulled over to the right curb, with the patrolman stopping again a short distance behind him. After some fumbling, the appellant produced his driver's license, whereupon he was invited [***2] out of his vehicle -- stumbling as he exited. The patrolman testified that there was an odor of an alcoholic beverage on appellant's breath and that his speech was slurred. At this point, Kettering Patrolman James G. Knickle arrived, and the appellant was requested to perform some manual dexterity tests consisting of the finger-to-nose and heel-to-toe exercises, neither of which he satisfactorily passed. The testimony revealed that appellant's eyes were bloodshot and his clothing somewhat disheveled. Thereupon he was transported to the Montgomery County Jail, where he was advised "that he could, at his own expense, and on his own time, he could have the Breathalyzer test or a blood analysis taken." Appellant did not request any test. The city of Kettering did not use or perform either of these procedures inasmuch as the Kettering Municipal Court had ruled that the Breathalyzer "was not a valuable asset in determining the amount of alcoholic content in a person's blood." At the close of the city's case, which consisted of the testimony of the two policemen, a motion to dismiss or direct a not guilty verdict was made and denied upon the alleged insufficiency of the evidence.

Counsel [***3] for appellant then renewed his previous written motion to dismiss "for the reason that the failure of the police department to have available and provide for him [appellant] a place or provide a test [breathalyzer or blood] for him was a denial of his constitutional rights," which motion was also denied.

Appellant, without presenting any evidence, rested. The case was given to the jury which returned a verdict finding Roland Vernell Baker guilty of driving while under the influence of alcohol. A motion for a new trial was denied. The Court of Appeals affirmed and this court allowed a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's conviction for driving while under the influence of alcohol. Defendant argued that the charges against him should have been dismissed because the police department failed to have available and provide defendant a breathalyzer or blood test.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued on appeal that the implied-consent statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.191(A), provided for mandatory administration of a blood or breathalyzer test to any person arrested for operating a motor vehicle upon the public highways in Ohio while under the influence of alcohol, and that the failure to give the tests was a denial of defendant's constitutional rights. The court disagreed and noted that the implied-consent statute and the trial of a charge relating to the operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol were not interdependent but rather were separate and distinct, each having its own consequences that might or might not be related. The evidence at trial showed that the police officers advised defendant that the opportunity to be tested would be provided at defendant's own expense and that defendant did not request a test. The court held that § 4511.191(A) did not entitle anyone to the administration of the tests by the city or any arresting officer.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment and upheld defendant's conviction for driving while under the influence of alcohol.

 

14 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Holderbaum v. Watkins


No. 74-541


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 372; 328 N.E.2d 814; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 504; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 333



May 28, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

In January 1969, appellee, Herman Holderbaum, was indicted by the Summit County Grand Jury for assault with intent to kill. Upon a suggestion of insanity, he was referred to the Lima State Hospital for a psychiatric examination. Subsequently, the Court of Common Pleas determined that appellee was insane and unable to stand trial, and, pursuant to R. C. 2945.38, committed him to the Lima State Hospital "until * * * restored to reason."

On July 5, 1973, appellee was returned to the trial court as "restored to reason," and able to stand trial on the indictment. On September 23, 1973, he waived his right to trial by jury, and on October 26, the court found him not guilty by reason of insanity. Thereafter, in accordance with R. C. 2945.39's presumption of continuing insanity, appellee was indefinitely committed to Lima State Hospital, to remain there until sane.

On April 10, 1974, appellee filed a petition pro se in the Court of Appeals for Allen County, seeking a writ of habeas corpus releasing him from Lima State Hospital. The appellant, Superintendent of Lima State Hospital, filed a return of writ, admitting appellee was [***2] sane and not dangerous, but requesting that his release be conditional, as provided by R. C. 2945.39. The proposed conditions would have required appellee, for a period of one year, to obtain, and reside with, a sponsor; to report monthly in writing to the appellant; to seek and attempt to retain employment; to refrain from using alcoholic beverages or drugs without a physician's prescription; and to obtain follow-up psychiatric care at an appropriate out-patient clinic.

On May 1, 1974, the Court of Appeals determined that appellee was sane, and for that reason entitled to an unconditional release from custody. The court held further "that so much of R. C. 2945.39 as purports to permit conditions to be placed on such release is contrary to the constitutions of the state of Ohio and the United States."

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

15 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Schwing


No. 74-375


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 295; 328 N.E.2d 379; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 494; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 288



May 21, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This appeal arose out of an incident occurring at The Ohio State University College of Law on May 18, 1972. A meeting had been arranged at the college to hear speakers discuss proposed changes in the Ohio Criminal Code. After this meeting came to order, a number of persons entered the room and began yelling and chanting, directing their remarks to Franklin County Municipal Judge G. W. Fais, a scheduled speaker at the meeting. The record indicates that the entire group was chanting "Fuck Fais." The testimony of Officer Rayburn of the Columbus Police Department indicates that the appellant was among those in the group chanting. Officer Rayburn also testified that he saw appellant's actions and heard appellant yell at Judge Fais, calling him a "goddamn pig and mother fucker." Other witnesses also identified the appellant as among the group. Additional testimony indicated that the group held Judge Fais and indicated an intent to keep him in the room. The record also shows that one of the law students present yelled at appellant to let Judge Fais go and then hit appellant when he refused to do so. Judge Fais testified that [***2] he could not identify the appellant nor did he hear appellant directly address any remarks to him. Officer Rayburn subsequently obtained warrants for appellant's arrest. Appellant was charged with violating three misdemeanor sections of the Ohio Revised Code (1973): R. C. 2901.25, menacing threats; R. C. 2905.301, obscene language; and R. C. 3761.11, disturbing a lawful assembly.

The case was tried to a jury in the Franklin County Municipal Court on December 12, 1972. The jury found appellant guilty of violating R. C. 2905.301, obscene language, and R. C. 3761.11, disturbing a lawful assembly, and not guilty of the charge of making menacing threats. Judgment was entered upon the verdicts. Whereupon, appellant perfected an appeal to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Appellant based his appeal on the constitutionality of the statutes in question. Appellant maintained that R. C. 2905.301 was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, as applied, and denied him due process of law. The Court of Appeals upheld the constitutionality of this statute on the basis that the language in question constituted "fighting words," which were not protected under the First Amendment to the [***3] United States Constitution. In so doing, the Court of Appeals also ruled that the trial judge's instruction as to what constituted obscene language was merely harmless error.

Similarly, the Court of Appeals held that R. C. 3761.11 was carefully and narrowly drawn and was directed to specific conduct.

Both statutes under which appellant was convicted have since been repealed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which convicted him of obscene language in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2905.301 and disturbing a lawful assembly in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 3761.11 (repealed 1974).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was among those in a group chanting expletives at the municipal judge who was a speaker at a meeting regarding proposed changes in the Ohio Criminal Code. The appellate court affirmed defendant's convictions. The appellate court upheld the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code § 2905.301on the basis that the language in question constituted "fighting words," which were not protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. It also ruled that the trial court's instruction as to what constituted obscene language was merely harmless error. On appeal, the court reversed. The court found that the language used by defendant was identical to language previously found not to be obscene as a matter of law. The court determined that the appellate court's affirmance on a "fighting words" theory not only denied defendant due process but also rendered § 2905.301 overly broad and vague in its application to the language in question. As to defendant's conviction for violating Ohio Rev. Code § 3761.11, the court found that the trial court's charge to the jury regarding the statute improperly failed to narrow the scope of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

16 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Driscoll v. Austintown Associates


No. 74-204


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 2d 263; 328 N.E.2d 395; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 489; 71 Ohio Op. 2d 247



May 14, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

Appellants are the owners of a tract of realty in Austintown Township, Mahoning County. The entire tract contains approximately 20.588 acres, but only a 13-acre section is involved in this appeal.

On November 18, 1968, appellants' predecessor in title, Willowcrest Land Co., Inc., filed an application with the Austintown Township Zoning Commission for a rezoning of the 13-acre section from Residence R-2 to Residence R-3. The building of multi-family dwellings is an impermissible use under Residence R-2 zoning, but a permissible use under Residence R-3 zoning.

The procedure for disposing of applications for rezoning is set forth in R. C. 519.12, and this procedure was followed in this case. First, Willowcrest's application was reviewed by the Mahoning County Planning Commission, which recommended its approval. The Austintown Township Zoning Commission then considered the application at a public hearing; the zoning commission recommended that the application be disapproved. Finally, the Austintown Township Board of Trustees conducted a public hearing on the proposed rezoning. At the conclusion of this hearing, the board [***2] voted to accept the zoning commission's recommendation that the application be denied.

On March 17, 1969, the corporation filed a declaratory judgment petition in the Common Pleas Court of Mahoning County, alleging that no economically feasible use of the land could be made under Residence R-2 zoning and that, therefore, the refusal of the township trustees to rezone the property amounted to a taking of property without due process of law. The petition sought an order that the "action of the [defendant] board of trustees in refusing to grant the requested zone change be declared unconstitutional, illegal and void; that the defendant zoning inspector be ordered to issue the necessary permits to plaintiff [Willowcrest] to erect apartment buildings * * * as permitted in a Residence R-3 zone * * *."

On June 2, 1971, the Court of Common Pleas filed a judgment entry which gave Willowcrest the relief it sought. This judgment was not appealed.

By mid-1973, appellants had secured the necessary building permits and had commenced clearing and grading operations preparatory to the construction of apartment buildings. On June 5, 1973, appellees instituted the present litigation by filing [***3] a complaint for injunction. Appellees consisted of the township trustees and other individuals described in the complaint as "owners and occupiers of land adjacent to and neighboring the lands hereinafter described (the 13-acre tract) * * *." The complaint alleged that use of the property was restricted by a Residence R-2 zoning classification, that the 1971 declaratory judgment action was void and of no force and effect, and that use of the land for multi-family dwellings therefore violated the township zoning ordinance. Additionally, several of the appellees alleged that they were the owners of land for the benefit of which there existed certain restrictive covenants pertaining to a portion of appellants' property, and that the covenants would be violated if appellants were allowed to erect apartment buildings. The complaint demanded preliminary and permanent injunctions prohibiting appellants from violating the zoning ordinance and the restrictive covenants.

The Court of Common Pleas dismissed the complaint, ruling that the restrictive covenants were not being violated and that the doctrines of res judicata and estoppel by judgment prevented appellees from attacking the [***4] validity of the 1971 declaratory judgment order.

The Court of Appeals affirmed that portion of the trial court's judgment relating to the restrictive covenants, but reversed that portion pertaining to the validity of and appellees' right to contest the declaratory judgment order. The Court of Appeals, claiming that it was rendering "the judgment which the Common Pleas Court should have rendered," enjoined appellants from using their property in any manner not permitted by Residence R-2 zoning.

Both sides have appealed to this court, and a motion to certify the record was granted.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellees, township trustees and neighboring owners and occupants, sought an injunction on appellant landowners' construction of apartment buildings. The Court of Appeals for Mahoning County (Ohio) affirmed a ruling that the restrictive covenants were not being violated, reversed a finding that a prior declaratory judgment ordering the issuance of the necessary permits to the landowners was valid, and issued the injunction. All parties appealed.


OVERVIEW: The trial court's judgment ordering the issuance of permits to allow the construction of apartments on the landowners' property after a request for rezoning was denied was not appealed. The appellate court accepted two of the arguments raised by the township trustees and neighboring owners and occupants as to why the declaratory judgment was void and subject to collateral attack but, on appeal, the court rejected all four of their reasons. The court held that the Declaratory Judgment Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Chapter 2721, permitted actions contesting the constitutionality of township zoning ordinances and that the availability of an Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Chapter 2506 action to review the denial of a variance did not preclude such a declaratory judgment action. The court further held that the neighboring owners and occupants were not necessary parties to the declaratory judgment action because they may have had a practical interest in the outcome of the action, but they had no legal interest in the outcome. Finally, the court held that the failure to seek a variance prior to instituting the declaratory judgment action was not a jurisdictional defect.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's finding that the restrictive covenants were not violated and reversed the portion of the appellate court's judgment finding that the declaratory judgment order was invalid. The court further reversed the portion of the appellate court's judgment that restrained the landowners from constructing apartments on their property and reinstated the trial court's judgment denying injunctive relief.

 

17 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Forest City Enter. v. Eastlake


No. 73-901


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 187; 324 N.E.2d 740; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 446; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 384



March 19, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

Appellant is an Ohio corporation, and the owner of an 8-acre parcel of real property in Eastlake, Ohio. On May 18, 1971, appellant applied to the Eastlake Planning Commission for the rezoning of its property from industrial to multi-family, high-rise use. The Planning Commission approved the application, and on December 28, 1971, the Eastlake City Council amended Eastlake's comprehensive zoning ordinance to permit the requested use.

On April 6, 1972, appellant applied to the Planning Commission for parking and yard approval, a preliminary step to obtaining a construction permit. The Planning Commission denied the permit because appellant had failed to obtain voter approval of council's amendment to the comprehensive zoning ordinance, as required by Section 3, Article VIII of the Eastlake City Charter. 1 That provision requires any ordinance which changes existing land use to be approved by a 55 percent vote in a city-wide election, the cost to be borne by the applicant-landowner.


1 On May 18, 1971, appellant made application to the Planning Commission for rezoning. While appellant's application was pending, initiative petitions were circulated, and a proposal requiring voter approval of all land use changes placed on the ballot. On November 2, 1971, Section 3, Article VIII of the Eastlake charter was adopted.

Subsequently, appellant's application was approved by the Planning Commission, and on December 28, 1971, city council amended the comprehensive zoning ordinance.

In the Court of Common Pleas, appellant contended that because Eastlake's charter was amended while appellant's application for rezoning was pending, the charter amendment did not apply to appellant. The trial court rejected this contention, and appellant neither assigned the ruling as error nor argued it upon appeal.

 [***2] In May 1972, such an election was held, but the ordinance rezoning appellant's property failed to obtain the requisite 55 percent of the votes cast.

Subsequently, appellant filed a declaratory judgment action in the Court of Common Pleas, asserting that Section 3 of Article VIII was unconstitutional. Appellant contended that the voter-approval requirement, as a prerequisite to any land use or zone change, denied appellant due process of law, and further, violated the referendum provisions of the Ohio Constitution. Appellant also attacked the validity of the provision requiring 55 percent approval, and the provision requiring that election costs be borne by the applicant-landowner.

The Court of Common Pleas upheld the validity of the voter approval and 55 percent requirements, but held the provision requiring an applicant-landowner to pay the election costs unconstitutional. Upon appeal and cross-appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record. 2


2 Appellee did not file a cross-appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals. Thus, the Eastlake charter provision requiring an applicant-landowner to bear the costs of the mandatory election is not before us.

 [***3]



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner challenged the judgment and order of the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio), which affirmed the validity of a voter approval provision in appellee city's charter that was applied to the property owner's request for a zoning permit.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's application for rezoning of its property for multi-family, high-rise use was approved by the city's planning commission. The city council amended the city's comprehensive zoning ordinance to permit the requested use. However, the property owner's application for parking and yard approval was denied because it failed to obtain 55 percent voter approval of the city council's amendment, as required by the city's charter. The property owner sought declaratory judgment that the charter provision was unconstitutional. The trial court upheld the provision for voter approval and the appeals court affirmed. On motion to certify the record, the court reversed and held that the property owner was denied due process. The city council, by appropriate legislative action, permitted the use of the property. However, no standards were established to insure that the referendum in which the property owner was required to obtain the consent of 55 percent of the voters would be reasonable, rational and not arbitrary. The charter provision was an unlawful delegation of legislative authority, with no assurance that the result reached thereby would be reasonable or rational.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the city.

 

18 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hughes


No. 73-1037


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 208; 324 N.E.2d 731; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 447; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 395



March 19, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This case arose out of the arrest of the appellee, James Walter Hughes, in Green Township, Hamilton County, by an off-duty Delhi Township police officer. The officer, at the time he observed the appellee, was aware of the existence of two outstanding misdemeanor warrants for the arrest of the appellee, and also that the Cincinnati Police Division had issued a police broadcast to arrest the defendant for "investigation of grand larceny." Officer Murphy thereupon placed the appellee under arrest. Hughes refused to submit to the arrest, and, later, the charges involved in this appeal were brought, alleging violations of R. C. 2917.33, resisting an officer, and R. C. 2901.252, assault on a law enforcement officer.

On March 30, 1973, in the Hamilton County Municipal Court, appellee's motion to quash the warrants was granted and the charges were dismissed for the reasons that the police officer made the arrest outside his jurisdiction and did not have a warrant to arrest appellee for any crime.

The state of Ohio filed a notice of appeal to the Court of Appeals on April 12, 1973. That appeal was dismissed for failure of the appellant [***2] to comply with the requirements of R. C. 2945.68.

Appellant moved the Court of Appeals to certify the record to this court as manifesting a conflict between appellate districts on the issue of whether the state may proceed on notice of appeal alone. The Court of Appeals denied the motion.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A trial court granted defendant's motion to quash the arrest warrants issued against him and dismissed the charges because the arrest was made outside of the officer's jurisdiction and without a warrant to arrest defendant for any crime. The State challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) that dismissed its appeal of the trial court's order for failure to comply with the requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.68.


OVERVIEW: The State filed a notice of appeal pursuant to Ohio R. App. P. 4(B), which permitted the prosecution to appeal as of right in criminal cases. The State argued that the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.68, which required the permission of the court of appeals before a bill of exceptions could be filed, were procedural in nature and were superseded by the Ohio Rules of Appellate Procedure. The court held that the appeal was properly dismissed because Ohio R. App. P. 4(B) was in conflict with a substantive statutory provision and thus was required to yield to it pursuant to Ohio Const. art. IV, 5(B). Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2945.67 through 2945.70 created a substantive right in the prosecution to bring appeals in the instances permitted by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.70. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2945.67 through 2945.70 also limited the right of appeal by granting appellate courts discretion as to which cases will be allowed for review. Ohio R. App. P. 4(B), in providing an appeal as of right by the prosecution, enlarged the statutory right of appeal provided by the statutes and abridged the right of appellate courts to exercise their discretion in allowing such appeals.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision.

 

19 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Rogers


No. 74-223


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 161; 324 N.E.2d 563; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 441; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 308



March 5, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Defendant-appellant, John H. Rogers, herein referred to as appellant, was charged in the Franklin County Municipal Court with appearing in public in the dress and attire of the opposite sex in violation of Section 2343.04 of the Columbus City Codes.

At the trial, appellant, claiming the ordinance to be unconstitutional on grounds that it deprived him of the right of privacy guaranteed by the Fourth Amendment, the right of expression guaranteed by the First Amendment, and the due process guaranteed by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, moved, at the close of the evidence, for dismissal of the charge.

The trial court overruled the motion for dismissal and found appellant guilty. Appellant appealed the judgment of conviction to the Court of Appeals, assigning as error in that court the trial court's refusal to grant his motion to dismiss.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment, and the cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for appearing in public in the dress and attire of the opposite sex, in violation of Columbus, Ohio City Codes § 2343.04.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant assigned as error the trial court's refusal to grant his motion to dismiss. His motion to dismiss was predicated on the contention that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it deprived him of the right of privacy that was guaranteed by the Fourth Amendment, the right of expression that was guaranteed by the First Amendment, and the due process that was guaranteed by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. Because defendant raised the question of constitutionality in the trial court and preserved that issue both in the court of appeals and in the court, the court held that it was appropriate to consider defendant's contention and reversed his conviction. The court held that § 2343.04 was inadequate in providing guidelines for the law enforcement officials that were charged with its enforcement. The court held that the infirmity was of special significance in relation to the ordinance, which made criminal activities that by modern standards were normally innocent.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court, which affirmed defendant's conviction for appearing in public in the dress and attire of the opposite sex, and held the ordinance to be unconstitutional.

 

20 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Horner v. Anderson


No. 74-862


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 166; 324 N.E.2d 572; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 442; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 311



March 5, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an original action in mandamus in which the relator, Irene P. Horner, seeks a writ of mandamus directing the members of the Reclamation Board of Review to recognize her right to serve as a member of the board.

Relator was appointed a member of the board by the Governor on April 11, 1973. The Ohio Senate took no action on the appointment of relator during the first regular session of the 110th General Assembly. The second regular session of the 110th General Assembly began in January 1974. On June 6, 1974, the Senate, by a roll call of 22 to 6, refused to consent to the appointment of relator, and notified the Governor of that action.

Relator claims that the Senate vote of June 6 was a nullity and that she received consent to her appointment by action of the Ohio Constitution when the Senate failed to take any action on her appointment during the first regular session of the General Assembly.

This cause involves the interpretation of a constitutional provision.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an original mandamus proceeding, relator appointee sought an order directing respondents, members of the Ohio Reclamation Board of Review, to recognize her right to serve as a board member. The appointee contended that pursuant to Ohio Const. art. II, § 8 and Ohio Const. art. III, § 21, her appointment was consented to as a matter of law because the Ohio Senate had not refused consent prior to the first day of its second regular session.


OVERVIEW: The appointee was designated by the governor for a position on the Ohio Reclamation Board of Review on April 11, 1973, but the Ohio Senate took no action on the appointment during the first regular session of the 110th General Assembly. The Ohio Senate subsequently refused to consent to the appointment during the second regular session of that General Assembly. The appointee claimed that the Senate's failure to act on her appointment during the first session operated as consent as a matter of law. In denying the writ, the court held that the purpose of Ohio Const. art. II, § 8 was to establish a single continuous session divided into two "regular" sessions not, as the appointee claimed, to create two distinct "regular sessions." Further, the court found that the applicable portions of Ohio Rev. Code § 3.03, which permitted an appointment to be carried over from the first to the second regular session of the Senate, and Ohio Rev. Code § 101.01, which specifically provided for a second session and termed it a "continuum of the regular session, were not unconstitutional. Therefore, the court concluded that the Senate's action in refusing its consent was valid.


OUTCOME: The writ was denied.

 

21 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Fulton County Budget Com.


Nos. 74-192, 74-193, 74-197, 74-260, 74-261, 74-342, 74-343


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 147; 324 N.E.2d 566; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 439; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 300



March 5, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The facts of these cases are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant boards of education sought review of a judgment from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which upheld appellee budget commissions' actions of reducing the rates of voted school levies, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §5713.11(B), after the Board ordered an increase in the tax values of the property located within the counties.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to Board of Tax Appeals R. 5-01(B) and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.01, the budget commissions submitted statutory abstracts to the Board, but the abstracts were not in compliance with the relevant law. The Board subsequently ordered an increase in the taxable value of the property located within the counties. In response the budget commissions, proceeded to reduce the rates of voted school levies pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.11(B). On appeal, the court affirmed the budget commissions actions. The court determined that increases in valuation in the counties were the result of orders issued by the Board; therefore, the budget commissions were under a statutory duty to reduce the voted school levies. The language of § 5713.11(B) was clear and unambiguous; therefore, the court could not interpret the language in the manner proposed by the boards of education.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court judgment, which was in favor of the budget commissions.

 

22 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kinney v. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp.


No. 73-921


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 120; 322 N.E.2d 880; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 434; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 206



February 12, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Licking County.

In July of 1959, Daniel Bradley was employed by appellant, Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation. This company was an employer amenable to and in compliance with Ohio's Workmen's Compensation Act. On July 7, 1959, Bradley sustained an industrial injury; he subsequently filed a workmen's compensation claim and received compensation.

On November 20, 1968, Bradley died. His widow, appellee herein, filed a claim for death benefits with the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation, alleging that the death was directly and proximately caused by the industrial injury. The Administrator of the bureau dismissed the claim, ruling that none of the jurisdictional prerequisites of R. C. 4123.59 was satisfied. 1


1 R. C. 4123.59 provides, in part:
