"In case an injury to or an occupational disease contracted by an employee causes his death, and if (1) his death ensues, within a period of three years after the injury or the beginning of disability due to the occupational disease, or (2) compensation for total disability, or partial disability as provided in division (A) of Section 4123.57 of the Revised Code, on account of the injury or occupational disease which caused his death has been paid for any portion of the year next preceding the date of the death of such employee, or (3) the Administrator or Industrial Commission finds that a decedent, who applied for compensation as described in division (2) of this paragraph, and who was examined by a licensed physician, would have been entitled to an award of compensation had not death ensued * * * benefits shall be in the amount and to the persons following * * *."

The word "injury," as used in R. C. Chapter 4123, is defined in R. C. 4123.01(C):

"'Injury' includes any injury, whether caused by external accidental means or accidental in character and result, received in the course of, and arising out of, the injured employee's employment."

 [***2] Subsequent to an affirmation of this order by the regional board of review, appellee instituted an appeal in the Court of Common Pleas of Licking County. That court granted appellant's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the complaint. The Court of Appeals, in a split decision, reversed the trial court's judgment by holding the jurisdictional prerequisites of R. C. 4123.59 unconstitutional.

The cause is now before this court both as an appeal as a matter of right involving a constitutional question arising under the Constitutions of the United States and of this state, and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Licking County (Ohio) that reversed the dismissal of the claim filed by appellee former employee's widow. The widow sought death benefits under the Ohio Workmen's Compensation Act (Act), and the appeals court ruled that the jurisdictional requirements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59 were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The former employee sustained an injury while at work. He died several years later and his widow filed a claim for death benefits under the Act, asserting that his death was the direct result of the injury. The Administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Workmen's Compensation denied the claim, ruling that the jurisdictional prerequisites of § 4123.59 were not met; the former employee did not die within three years of injury, did not receive disability benefits, and was not entitled to receive them, the year before death. The county court affirmed the decision, but the appeals court reversed. On review, the court affirmed the judgment, finding that the prerequisites violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Ohio and United States Constitutions. The prerequisites classified heirs into two groups, those who met the prerequisites and those who did not. Because some members of the excluded group might have proven a causal connection between an injury and the death, the prerequisites obstructed the objectives of § 4123.59 and Ohio Const. art. II, § 35. Further, they were not rationally related to the accomplishment of a state objective as important as death benefits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment reversing the dismissal of the widow's claim and remanded the matter to the Bureau.

 

23 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lester


No. 74-50


Supreme Court of Ohio


41 Ohio St. 2d 51; 322 N.E.2d 656; 1975 Ohio LEXIS 421; 70 Ohio Op. 2d 150



February 5, 1975, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

On February 9, 1973, in the Court of Common Pleas of Allen County, William K. Lester, appellant herein, was found guilty of the sale of narcotics. He was subsequently sentenced to the Ohio Penitentiary for a term of 20 to 40 years. No appeal as of right was taken within the 30-day period after entry of judgment, although appellant did write letters to his court-appointed counsel and to the Court of Appeals concerning a possible appeal. On July 24, 1973, appellant filed a petition pro se in the Court of Common Pleas to set aside his sentence under Ohio statutory provisions for postconviction determination of constitutional rights. Appellant stated two grounds for relief: First, that there was insufficient evidence to warrant conviction; second, that he did not have effective assistance of counsel at his trial. The petition was dismissed without a hearing and without a filing of findings of fact and conclusions of law. The journal entry stated, as a basis for dismissal, that appellant "never appealed his judgment of conviction nor attempted to exercise further appellate remedies available to him." A motion for appointment [***2] of counsel was also denied.

On September 25, 1973, appellant filed a notice of appeal from the dismissal of his petition for postconviction relief in the Court of Appeals. This appeal was dismissed on December 14, 1973, for failure to timely file a record.

Appeal from that dismissal was thereupon taken to this court, and we dismissed an appeal as of right, but allowed a motion for leave to appeal and appointed counsel to represent the appellant before this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Allen County (Ohio), which dismissed his appeal of the summary dismissal of his petition for postconviction relief pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.21.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted in the trial court of the sale of narcotics. He filed a petition for postconviction relief pursuant to § 2953.21, claiming that his conviction was not supported by sufficient evidence and that he was denied his right to effective assistance of counsel. The trial court summarily dismissed the petition without filing findings of fact and conclusions of law. The intermediate appellate court dismissed defendant's appeal of the trial court's order. On further appeal, the court reversed the intermediate appellate court's judgment and remanded the case to the trial court. The court held that defendant was prohibited from raising the issue of ineffective assistance of counsel in a postconviction proceeding and that the issue was properly raised on direct appeal. The court determined that the trial court failed to make and file findings of fact and conclusions of law in connection with the summary dismissal of defendant's petition for postconviction relief as required by § 2953.21. The court ruled that the trial court failed to consider the question of whether defendant was entitled to the appointment of counsel pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.24.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the intermediate appellate court's judgment dismissing defendant's appeal of the trial court's summary dismissal of his petition for postconviction relief. The court remanded the case to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

24 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Moats v. Metropolitan Bank of Lima


No. 73-924


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 2d 47; 319 N.E.2d 603; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 369; 69 Ohio Op. 2d 323



November 27, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

This appeal arises out of an airplane crash which occurred in Pennsylvania on December 28, 1967. Plaintiff's decedent, John R. Moats, a passenger, and defendant's decedent, Raymond F. Pangle, the pilot, were killed. Both decedents were residents of Ohio, and the airplane was owned by an Ohio corporation and was regularly hangared in Ohio.

Appellant was appointed administratrix of the estate of John Moats, and brought an action for wrongful death against appellee, The Metropolitan Bank of Lima, executor of the estate of Raymond Pangle. Appellant did not contend that appellee's decedent was willful or wanton in his conduct, only that he was negligent in the operation of the airplane. Appellee answered by stating that appellant's decedent was a guest-passenger in the aircraft, and that the claim was therefore barred by virtue of R. C. 4561.151. *


* R. C. 4561.151 provides:

"The owner, operator, or person responsible for the operation of an aircraft shall not be liable for loss or damage arising from injuries to or death of a guest, resulting from the operation of said aircraft, while such guest is being transported without payment therefor in or upon said aircraft, unless such injuries or death are caused by the willful or wanton misconduct of such owner, operator, or person responsible for the operation of said aircraft."

 [***2] Appellee thereafter filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the trial court, and that judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals. In rendering its judgment, the Court of Appeals held that the substantive law of Ohio was controlling under the facts presented.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant administratrix of a passenger's estate sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Allen County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court's decision granting summary judgment in favor of appellee executor of a pilot's estate in her wrongful death action. The cause came before the court pursuant to the allowance of the motion to certify the record filed by the administratrix.


OVERVIEW: The passenger and the pilot were both killed in a plane wreck in Pennsylvania. The administratrix did not contend that the pilot was willful or wanton in his conduct, only that he was negligent in the operation of the airplane. The executor contended that the passenger was a guest in the aircraft, and that the claim was therefore barred by virtue of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4561.151. Affirming the appellate court's decision, the court ruled that the substantive law of Ohio was controlling under the facts presented. The court reasoned that Ohio courts no longer looked solely to the doctrine of lex loci delicti in ascertaining which state's law prevailed. Pennsylvania had little interest in having her law applied. Both decedents were residents of Ohio, the aircraft was owned by an Ohio corporation and was hangared there, and the administration of the estates of the deceased Ohio residents was a direct concern of that state. The only significant interest of Pennsylvania in the lawsuit was that it was the place where the accident occurred, a factor that was insufficient to outweigh the other considerations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision granting summary judgment in favor of the executor in the administratrix's wrongful death action.

 

25 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Roof v. Board of Comm'rs


No. 73-264


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 2d 130; 314 N.E.2d 172; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 409; 68 Ohio Op. 2d 85



July 17, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hardin County.

In September 1971, appellee Board of Commissioners of Hardin County entered into a lease-purchase contract for 46 voting machines. Voting machines were used in the November 1971 general election and the May 1972 primary election. In the latter election, the issue of the use of voting machines was placed on the ballot, and 68 percent of the voters approved their continued use.

On July 6, 1972, appellants instituted the present litigation by filing a taxpayers' suit in the Court of Common Pleas of Hardin County. In their complaint they (1) allege that the use of voting machines violated Section 2a, Article V of the Ohio Constitution, which requires the rotation of names of all candidates for an office voted upon at any general election; 1 and (2) seek an injunction against appellee board of commissioners, to restrain it from entering into new or complying with existing contracts for the purchase or use of voting machines.


1 Appellants also allege in their complaint that the use of voting machines conflicted with the equal protection clauses of the state and federal constitutions because "many elderly and less sophisticated voters are so confused by such machines that they either refuse to participate in elections, or cannot operate the machines in accordance with their wills and intentions within the five-minute period allowed by law to a voter to use the machine, and such electors are deprived of their elective franchise by requiring them to attempt to use such complicated and confusing machinery." However, this allegation was not presented to this court either by brief or in oral argument, and thus we express no opinion on its merits.

 [***2] In plain words, the principal thrust of this case is a claim by the appellants that the use of voting machines is absolutely unconstitutional and a request by the appellants that the use of voting machines be permanently enjoined.

On July 26, 1972, the Secretary of State's motion to intervene as a party defendant was granted by the trial court.

The pleadings and the evidence adduced at the hearing held on July 28, 1972, established the following facts: A single voting machine is totally unable to rotate names of candidates for an office; once an arrangement of names is locked into a machine, the position of each candidate in the group of candidates for an office will remain the same for every voter using that machine. However, in general elections conducted prior to this suit some rotation was achieved under the provisions of R. C. 3507.07 which required that in those localities utilizing voting machines the names of all candidates for each office must be rotated from precinct to precinct.

At the time this lawsuit commenced, Hardin County was divided into 33 precincts. The number of votes cast in each precinct varied significantly: in the November 1971 general election,  [***3] the least number of votes cast in a precinct was 122; the largest 564. Each precinct was allotted one, two or three voting machines, depending on the number of electors expected to vote in the precinct, based upon past experience. Pursuant to R. C. 3507.07, all machines in any multi-machine precinct displayed the names of candidates for each office in the same arrangement; there was no rotation by machine within a precinct.

The procedure followed by Hardin County to program its voting machines was described by the director of the Board of Elections of Hardin County. The board prepared two lists for the printer. The first was a list of candidates, positioned alphabetically under the titles of the various offices. The second was a list of all precincts in the county. The precinct list was divided into the several political subdivisions within the county, and under each political subdivision was a listing, in regular serial sequence, of all the precincts in that political subdivision.

Upon receipt of the two lists, the printer would determine the precinct in which he would begin the rotation. Having selected this starting point, the printer would compose a voting machine [***4] ballot arrangement for that precinct by listing the candidates in the same order as shown on the candidate list. Thereafter, the printer would compose voting machine ballot arrangements for the remaining precincts by proceeding through the precinct list, rotating the names of candidates for each office from precinct to precinct.

The Court of Common Pleas, stressing that rotation of candidates' names for each voter was impossible if voting machines were utilized, not only held the rotation provision of R. C. 3507.07 unconstitutional, but also enjoined appellees from contracting or continuing to honor existing contracts for the purchase or use of voting machines which could not comply with the constitutional requirement for rotating names, "as well as any other method of ballot formation anl alternation does." (Emphasis added.)

The judgment of the Court of Common Pleas was reversed by the Court of Appeals, which entered final judgment in favor of the appellees.

This cause, which involves a substantial constitutional question, is now before this court both as a matter of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals, Hardin County (Ohio), which reversed the lower court's judgment in favor of the taxpayers and entered judgment in favor of appellee board of commissioners. The court of appeals found that the rotational provision of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3507.07 was constitutional, and it refused to permanently enjoin the use of voting machines that could not achieve perfect rotation.


OVERVIEW: The court dismissed the taxpayers' appeal from the court of appeals' decision that the rotational provision of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3507.07 was constitutional because the General Assembly had repealed § 3507.07 without enacting a new rotational statute. Therefore, the court concluded that the constitutionality of § 3507.07 was moot. The court found precinct-by-precinct rotation of candidates' names was manifestly unconstitutional under the self-executing rotational requirement of Ohio Const. art. V, § 2a. The court found that machine-to-machine rotation with an even number of voting machines in each precinct assured a greater degree of rotation within reasonable limits of expense, mechanical effort, and practicality of operation. Precinct-by-precinct rotation was unconstitutional because the only permissible system was one that most closely approximated perfect rotation within reasonable limits of expense, mechanical effort, and practicality of operation. The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision, which reversed the lower court's judgment that voting machines could not comply with the self-executing rotational provision of Ohio Const. art. V, § 2a.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed as moot the taxpayers' appeal from the court of appeals' holding that a state statute's rotational provision was constitutional. The court held that the board of commissioners' precinct-by-precinct rotation procedure was unconstitutional. It affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals that voting machines could comply with the self-executing rotational provision of the state constitution.

 

26 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Karlan


No. 72-842


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 2d 107; 314 N.E.2d 162; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 405; 68 Ohio Op. 2d 62



July 10, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] ON REMAND from the United States Supreme Court.

The facts in this case are set out in our original opinion. Cincinnati v. Karlan (1973), 35 Ohio St. 2d 34, 298 N. E. 2d 573.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reaffirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The case was on remand from the United States Supreme Court, which vacated the court's judgment and remanded the cause to the court for further consideration in light of a Supreme Court decision that was decided subsequent to the publication of the court's first opinion. In the first opinion, the court had affirmed defendant's conviction for violating a city ordinance that prohibited disorderly conduct.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's conviction was based on speech that violated the city ordinance. The court determined that a criminal statute capable of punishing spoken words could not stand constitutional muster unless authoritatively construed by state courts to be inapplicable to speech that was protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The court found that the city ordinance was capable of punishing spoken words and, in that respect, had to be authoritatively narrowed or be held constitutionally overbroad. Thus, the court construed the city ordinance, such that persons could not be punished for speaking boisterous, rude, or insulting words, even with the intent to annoy another, unless the words by their very utterance inflicted injury or were likely to provoke the average person to an immediate retaliatory breach of the peace. The court concluded that it should adhere to its former judgment, because where epithets, used in a public place and wilfully directed at those who could hear them, were likely to provoke the average person to an immediate retaliatory breach of the peace, they were fighting words and the utterance thereof could be punished as a criminal act.


OUTCOME: The court reaffirmed defendant's conviction.

 

27 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Superior Uptown, Inc. v. Cleveland


No. 73-659


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 2d 36; 313 N.E.2d 820; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 392; 68 Ohio Op. 2d 21



July 3, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On March 23, 1970, the Cleveland city council enacted Ordinance No. 1842-69, which rezoned from a multi-family, general retail and semi-industry use district to a local retail business district the lands located at the northwest, northeast and southeast corners of the intersection of Superior Avenue and E. 105th Street. On the same day, council also approved Ordinance No. 2058-68, which effected a similar zoning change on the property at the southwest corner. The present declaratory judgment action, filed by the corporate owner of the property at the northwest corner of the intersection, challenges the validity of Ordinance No. 1842-69.

For many years prior to the zoning change, the property in question, which is located in the "Glenville" section of Cleveland, was zoned general retail. After enactment of the ordinance the lands abutting E. 105th Street north of the subject property retained their general retail zoning, as did the realty abutting Superior Avenue east of the Superior-105th intersection. The remainder of the land in the vicinity was, for the most part, zoned and developed residentially.

Although the neighborhood [***2] began to deteriorate in the late 1950's, the process was dramatically accelerated by the Glenville riot which occurred in July 1968. Several buildings in the area were burned during the disorder, and subsequently others were vandalized. The building situated on appellee's property was damaged, and eventually the city razed it. The property has since remained undeveloped.

Development of property as a gasoline service station was permissible under the general retail zoning that applied to appellee's land prior to the 1970 change. Such development was impermissible under local retail zoning. Appellee's complaint alleges that it has specific plans for a service station on its property, and that the rezoning ordinance was an "unconstitutional and arbitrary * * * deprivation of the plaintiff's [appellee's] property without due process of law * * *." The relief requested was not only a declaration that the ordinance was invalid, but also an award of damages to appellee for "loss of use of its property."

The Court of Common Pleas granted both aspects of appellee's prayer for relief. The ordinance was held unconstitutional and appellee was awarded damages of $ 15,600. The court labeled [***3] this amount as a "reasonable return" upon appellee's land during the period that the rezoning ordinance was in effect.

The Court of Appeals affirmed, and the cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a declaratory judgment action, appellant City of Cleveland sought review of a ruling from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the holding awarding appellee corporate property owner damages of $ 15,500 and held Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 1842-69 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The City enacted Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 1842-69, which rezoned some property from a multi-family, general retail, and semi-industry use district to a local retail business district. In addition, the City approved Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 2058-68, which effected a different portion of property. Subsequently, the corporate property owner filed the instant declaratory judgment action and challenged the validity of Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 1842-69. The trial court found that Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 1842-69 was unconstitutional and awarded the corporate property owner damages. On appeal, the court of appeals affirmed. The city thereafter sought further review, claiming that the trial court erred in finding Cleveland, Ohio, Ord. 1842-69 unconstitutional. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court found that the award of damages against the city could not stand. The court could not find any evidence to support a finding that the rezoning ordinance was a disguised attempt by the city to take the corporate property owner's land for a public purpose. Further, the court found that award of damages violated the doctrine of sovereign immunity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed that portion of the judgment of the court of appeals that held the challenged rezoning ordinance invalid, but reversed that portion of the judgment that held that the corporate property owner could recover monetary damages from the city.

 

28 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Petrocon, Inc. v. Kosydar


No. 73-946


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 2d 264; 313 N.E.2d 373; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 456; 67 Ohio Op. 2d 332; 48 Oil & Gas Rep. 436



June 19, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation was engaged in the production and management of oil and gas wells. A claim for a refund of the severance tax paid by the corporation on its production of oil and gas was denied by appellee the Tax Commissioner. The Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) affirmed.


OVERVIEW: The corporation contended that the severance tax imposed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5749.02 is in conflict with Ohio Const. art XII, § 10 because the tax is imposed on the amount rather than the reasonable value of the product severed. The corporation contended further that the tax was excessive in its application to oil and gas as compared to other, natural resources, and that it amounted to double taxation, which was prohibited by Ohio Const. art XII, § 2. The court held that the burden of showing that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5749.02 was in conflict with the constitutional provision rested upon the corporation to present clear and convincing evidence of a presently existing state of facts which made the statute unconstitutional and void. The record contained no evidence that the classifications and tax of natural resources, imposed by § 5749.02 were unreasonable. Therefore, the corporation failed to demonstrate that § 5749.02 was in conflict with the Ohio Const. art. XII, § 10.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

29 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


De Lozier v. Sommer


No. 73-843


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 2d 268; 313 N.E.2d 386; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 458; 67 Ohio Op. 2d 335



June 19, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellee is the widow of Paul K. DeLozier, who was employed by the International Development Corporation. On March 3, 1966, decedent suffered an injury in the course of his employment, for which compensation was allowed by the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation. Payments on the claim were continued without interruption until January 26, 1970, the date of decedent's death, and it is undisputed that in the year next preceding the date of death decedent received compensation for temporary-partial disability.

Following her husband's death, and within the statutory period of time, appellee filed an application with the Administrator of the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation for payment of death benefits and hospital and funeral expenses, alleging that death resulted from decedent's work-related injury. The claim was dismissed by the administrator, who asserted that he was without jurisdiction to consider the application. Appellee appealed to the regional board of review, which affirmed the decision of the administrator. Upon appeal to the Court of Common Pleas, the administrator's motion to dismiss the appeal was sustained,  [***2] the court holding that, under Emmons v. Keller (1970), 21 Ohio St. 2d 48, death benefits are not payable under R. C. 4123.59 where compensation for partial disability had been paid in the year next preceding death.

That judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals, 35 Ohio App. 2d 201. The Court of Appeals concluded that Emmons, 1 supra, did not unequivocally hold R. C. 4123.59 unconstitutional, nor did it strike the "partial-disability" language from the statute, and that that statutory provision remains a viable grant of jurisdiction to the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation to hear appellee's claim.


1 Paragraph two of the syllabus in Emmons stated that:

"If the portion of the first paragraph of Section 4123.59, Revised Code, reading 'or partial disability as provided in division (A) of Section 4123.57 of the Revised Code' is stricken therefrom, the remaining part of that statutory paragraph will not lead to arbitrary or capricious results or result in any denial of equal protection of the laws."

 [***3] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee claimant filed an action against appellant, the Administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Workmen's Compensation, seeking review of a regional board of review decision upholding the Administrator's denial of the claimant's workmen's compensation claim under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59. The Administrator sought review of a decision of the Cuyahoga County Court of Appeals (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's Administrator's decision.


OVERVIEW: The claimant was the widow of an employee who received temporary partial disability payments in the year preceding his death. Upon the employee's death, the claimant filed her claim for death benefits and hospital and funeral expenses. The administrator denied the claim on the grounds that death benefits were not payable under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59 where partial disability had been paid to the decedent in the year preceding his death. The trial court affirmed the denial of benefits. The court of appeals reversed and held that death benefits were payable under such circumstances. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that paragraph two of the syllabus in its decision in Emmons v. Keller, 21 Ohio St. 2d 48 (1970), in which the court stated that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59 was unconstitutional, was no longer valid. The court held that § 4123.59 was constitutional and allowed the payment of death benefits to the claimant even though the decedent had received temporary partial disability payments in the year preceding his death.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision.

 

30 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Oakwood v. Gummer


No. 73-679


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 2d 164; 311 N.E.2d 517; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 438; 67 Ohio Op. 2d 179



May 15, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

On July 14, 1972, defendant-appellant, Richard Gummer, and Jeffrey Gates were arrested by an Oakwood police officer and charged under Section 311.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Oakwood with participating in a parade on the public streets for which no permit had been issued.

Upon trial, the Oakwood Municipal Court found that the parade had consisted of from 30 to 70 persons, including the defendant, and had blocked vehicular traffic, to the extent of approximately two city blocks, before an Oakwood police officer forced the parade onto a side street. The patrolman, after futile attempts to stop the parade, with requests that the parties disperse, arrested the defendant and other participants. The court also found that application had not been made for a permit to conduct or participate in a parade or assemblage on July 14, 1972, as required by Section 311.02 of the Oakwood ordinances. 1 The parties also stipulated that there have been occasional other parades or processions, including high school band practices, in the city of Oakwood, where no permit was issued by the city and the participants had not been [***2] arrested or prosecuted for a violation of Section 311.02 of the Oakwood ordinances.


1 Section 311.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Oakwood, as stipulated by the parties, reads, as follows:

"Parades and Assemblages

"No person, group of persons or organization shall conduct or participate in any parade, procession or assemblage upon any street or highway, or block off any street or highway area, without first obtaining a permit from the city manager.

"Applications for such permits shall be made on such forms as may be prescribed and shall contain such information as is reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. Applications shall be filed not less than five days before the time intended for such parade, procession or assemblage.

"The permit may be refused or cancelled if the resultant conditions would unreasonably hinder the movement of traffic or would require the diversion of sufficient police officers or firemen so as to deprive the municipality of normal police and fire protection, or would be reasonably likely to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. [Emphasis added.]

"The permit or any order accompanying it may limit or prescribe reasonable conditions, including the hours, the places of assembly and of dispersal, the route of march or travel and the streets, highways or portions thereof which may be used or occupied. In addition, the city manager may provide, as a condition for the issuance of the permit, that the person, group of persons or organization conducting the parade, procession or assemblage assume, in writing, the obligation of paying the costs to the city of supervising and directing such parade, procession or assemblage, including the cost of providing personnel from the Departments of Safety and Service, or any other city personnel, and including the costs of the services of outside contractors."

 [***3] The trial court found the defendant guilty on the basis that the defendant did block traffic in the city of Oakwood and "that the portion of Section 311.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Oakwood, Ohio, which provides: 'No person, group of persons or organization shall * * * block off any street or highway area, without first obtaining a permit from the city manager' is not unconstitutionally vague or broad."

Appellant argued in the Court of Appeals that Section 311.02 of the Oakwood ordinances resulted in a prior restraint upon appellant's rights under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, and that the ordinance was unconstitutionally broad and vague. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Municipal Court, holding that the employment of the words "reasonable," "reasonably," and "unreasonably" did not render the ordinance vague or subject to arbitrary application.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of a municipal court, convicting him of participating in a parade on the public streets for which no permit had been issued under Oakwood, Ohio, Ordinance § 311.02.


OVERVIEW: The city ordinance stated that a parade permit could be refused or cancelled if the resultant conditions would be reasonably likely to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance.Defendant had not applied for a permit but objected to his arrest and conviction after conducting his own parade as a birthday celebration. The court reversed, finding that the ordinance was overbroad and an unconstitutional prior restraint on free speech and free assembly. The court found that defendant had standing to challenge the ordinance even though he had not applied for a permit. This was so because First Amendment issues were to be carefully scrutinized to avoid the improper application of penal statutes. The court ruled that the language of the ordinance granted overly broad discretion to the licensing authority. The city undoubtedly had the authority to police its own roads but could not rely upon such vague language as "the reasonable likelihood of the parade provoking disorderly conduct or creating a disturbance." What constituted such conduct was not defined in the ordinance and its vagueness rendered it unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment below, finding the ordinance under which defendant was convicted to be unconstitutional.

 

31 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Crebs v. Court of Common Pleas Probate Div.


No. 73-919


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 2d 51; 309 N.E.2d 926; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 420; 67 Ohio Op. 2d 61



April 17, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Wayne County.

A complaint was filed against appellant in the Common Pleas Court of Wayne County, Probate Division, charging him with misconduct in the office of village councilman, and asking that "the proper statutory steps be pursued pursuant to Sections 733.72, and 733.78, Revised Code."

Appellant's motion to dismiss the complaint, on the ground that "the statutes under which the action is prosecuted are unconstitutional," was denied by appellee judge.

A prohibition action was then instituted by appellant in the Court of Appeals to restrain the Court of Common Pleas, Probate Division, and the judge thereof, from proceeding with the misconduct action pending against him in that court. Appellees' motion to dismiss the complaint in prohibition was sustained, and the cause dismissed, the Court of Appeals holding that:

"Prohibition is not available to determine the constitutionality of a statute or ordinance, where the relator has, as he does here, an adequate remedy at law by way of appeal. Prohibition will not be granted, in advance of a trial, to test constitutionality, where the inferior court has jurisdiction independent [***2] of the statute in question, and may itself determine jurisdiction, and its decision is then subject to review on appeal."

An appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

32 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ewing v. "Without A Stitch"


No. 71-649


Supreme Court of Ohio


37 Ohio St. 2d 95; 307 N.E.2d 911; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 195; 66 Ohio Op. 2d 223



February 27, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Appellee brought this obscenity-nuisance abatement action under R. C. 3767.01 et seq. against a motion picture film entitled "Without a Stitch," the manager of the local theater where the film was playing, the corporate owner of the theater, and the corporate owner of the distribution rights in the film.

The Court of Common Pleas held that the film was obscene and permanently enjoined the owners, appellants herein, from exhibiting the film. However, the court stayed execution of the injunctive order pending appellate review. As a result of the stay, appellants were permitted to exhibit the film after the judicial determination that the film was obscene.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the finding of obscenity and held that the film's exhibition by the theater rendered the theater itself a nuisance. The court held further that R. C. 3767.01 et seq. mandated that the theater be closed for one year and that a tax of three hundred dollars be imposed upon appellants and against the real property on which the threater is located. The Court of Appeals also required appellants to account for and pay to the Lucas County treasurer [***2] the box office receipts arising from the exhibition of the film after the effective date of the trial court's injunctive order.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and affirmed as modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a theater manager, the theater owner, and a film rights owner, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of appellee complainant, on behalf of the State, that a certain film was obscene and that its exhibition by the theater rendered the theater itself a nuisance.


OVERVIEW: The complainant, on behalf of the State, brought an obscenity-nuisance abatement action under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3767.01 et seq. against appellants. The trial court held that the film was obscene and enjoined the exhibition of the film. The trial court stayed execution of the injunctive order pending appellate review. The appellate court affirmed the judgment and required appellants to pay the treasurer the box office receipts that arose from the exhibition of the film after the effective date of the trial court's injunctive order. On appeal, the court construed the accounting order issued by the appellate court to be limited to net receipts and affirmed the appellate court's judgment as modified. The court held that none of appellants' reasons for alleging that § 3767.01 et seq. prescribed an unconstitutional method for controlling obscenity were valid. The court ruled that § 3767.01 et seq. were applicable in cases involving the exhibition of a single motion picture film. The court held that appellants did not contend upon appeal that they did not have knowledge of the contents of the film. The court ruled that appellants should not be deprived of gross receipts.


OUTCOME: The court construed an accounting order issued by the appellate court to be limited to net receipts derived from the exhibition of the film after the filing date of the trial court's order declaring the movie obscene and affirmed the appellate court's judgment as modified.

 

33 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Sensenbrenner v. Crosby


No. 73-261


Supreme Court of Ohio


37 Ohio St. 2d 43; 306 N.E.2d 413; 1974 Ohio LEXIS 186; 66 Ohio Op. 2d 106



January 30, 1974, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On October 21, 1970, defendant-appellant Crosby was arrested in Columbus for allegedly violating R. C. 3719.44(B), which prohibits possession of hallucinogens for sale. At that time, his automobile was seized and impounded. On July 9, 1971, Crosby was found guilty.

Plaintiff-appellee, in his representative capacity as mayor of the city of Columbus, initiated the present action on August 6, 1971, in the Franklin County Municipal Court, alleging that Crosby had used his automobile while violating R. C. 3719.44(B), and therefore it was subject to forfeiture to the city pursuant to R. C. 3719.47. Crosby's parents were subsequently made parties defendant because they appeared to hold a valid lien on the car.

On August 10, 1972, the Municipal Court granted appellant's motion to dismiss the action, holding that the forfeiture provision of R. C. 3719.47 was unconstitutional because it failed to provide a proceeding for the adjudication of forfeiture.

The Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Municipal Court and remanded the cause to the Municipal Court for further proceedings. The cause is now before this court pursuant [***2] to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant claimant, the owner of an automobile that was seized after the claimant was convicted for possession of drugs for sale, sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), that reversed a municipal court judgment dismissing plaintiff mayor's action for forfeiture of the claimant's automobile to the city pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 3719.47.


OVERVIEW: The claimant was convicted of possession of hallucinogens for sale. The claimant's automobile was seized and impounded, and the mayor began a forfeiture proceeding under Ohio Rev. Code § 3719.47. The municipal court dismissed the action, finding that the forfeiture provision was unconstitutional because it failed to provide a proceeding for the adjudication of forfeiture. The court of appeals reversed the judgment. The court affirmed the judgment, holding that the rules of civil procedure provided a constitutionally adequate procedure for the enforcement of § 3719.47.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment reversing the dismissal of the mayor's action for forfeiture of the claimant's automobile.

 

34 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Brenneman


No. 72-832


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 2d 45; 303 N.E.2d 873; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 275; 65 Ohio Op. 2d 204



November 21, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

On December 31, 1970, appellant was arrested as the result of making a sale of marijuana to an undercover policeman. At his trial, he pleaded guilty to one count of possession of an hallucinogen for sale, and his case was referred to the court's probation department for a presentence investigation. Thereafter, probation was denied and appellant was sentenced to be imprisoned for 10 to 20 years, as provided by statute.

On September 27, 1971, appellant filed a petition under the Ohio postconviction relief statutes, R. C. 2953.21 et seq., alleging that his request for probation was never considered by the trial court. On September 28, 1971, appellee filed a motion to dismiss, which was overruled. A hearing before an assigned judge was had upon this question, and thereafter the trial court vacated the sentence and ordered appellant returned to Butler County for further proceedings. The prosecuting attorney appealed that decision to the Court of Appeals, which reversed the judgment of the trial court and ordered the appellant recommitted to the Lebanon Correctional Institution.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to [***2] the allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio), which reversed the judgment of the trial court vacating the sentence and ordering appellant returned for further proceedings on his allegation that his probation was never considered, and the court of appeals ordered appellant recommitted to the correctional institution.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was arrested as the result of making a sale of marijuana to an undercover policeman. At his trial, he pleaded guilty to one count of possession of an hallucinogen for sale, and probation was denied and appellant was sentenced to be imprisoned as provided by statute. Appellant alleged that his request for probation was never considered by the trial court, and the trial court vacated the sentence and ordered appellant returned for further proceedings. The state general assembly provided for the appeal of judgments of the trial court in postconviction relief proceedings. However, the court held that thee was an express limitation upon the state's right of appeal, and the court held that the state's argument that the trial court in a postconviction relief proceeding somehow became superior to itself, was unacceptable. In the absence of express authority to do so, the state was not entitled to appeal an adverse judgment of the trial court in a postconviction relief proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower court and remanded with instructions to vacate its judgment and to overrule the state's motion for leave to appeal.

 

35 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Taylor


No. 73-71


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 2d 73; 303 N.E.2d 886; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 280; 65 Ohio Op. 2d 219



November 21, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The defendants, appellants herein, were charged with violating Section 901-P10, Code of Ordinances, city of Cincinnati, the Cincinnati prowling ordinance. In the Municipal Court, upon pre-trial, defense counsel moved that the charges be dismissed on the ground that the ordinance was unconstitutional. Oral arguments upon the motion were presented by counsel. Thereafter, the court ruled the ordinance unconstitutional and discharged the defendants. The Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Municipal Court, concluding that "Section 901-P10, Cincinnati Municipal Code, is not unconstitutional on its face * * *."

The causes are now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed an order of the municipal court, that had granted defendants' motion to dismiss charges against them for prowling, in violation of Cincinnati, Ohio, Code of Ordinances § 901-P10. Defendants argued that the appeals court erred in ruling that the ordinance was not unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance purported to prohibit prowling, which was described as "lingering, lurking, or standing idly around." Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the charges, arguing that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The municipal court granted the motion. The appeals court reversed, ruling that the ordinance was valid. On appeal, the court held that the ordinance was unconstitutionally void for vagueness because it did not provide adequate standards by which activity could have been determined as legal or illegal. The court observed that the ordinance essentially prohibited prowling in circumstances warranting a reasonable man to believe that the safety of persons or property was threatened. The court noted that the description of prowling included the terms "lurking" and "lingering." The court ruled that based on such a description, the ordinance was void because a person merely waiting on a street corner would not have been given fair notice that such activity constituted prowling. The court also held that the ordinance did not provide adequate standards by which police officers could have judged whether persons were violating it, thus, it was void as contrary to due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appeals court's judgment, which had overturned the municipal court's decision granting defendant's motion to dismiss.

 

36 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Nelson


No. 73-69


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 2d 79; 303 N.E.2d 865; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 281; 65 Ohio Op. 2d 222



November 21, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

David Lee Nelson, appellant herein, was indicted by the grand jury of Hamilton County on a single count of armed robbery on December 7, 1971. He entered a plea of not guilty, and, on June 8, 1972, a jury was impaneled and the cause tried. The testimony of the prosecuting witness was properly submitted to the jury by way of deposition, since he was no longer a resident of the state. Appellant elected not to testify, and, during the course of the prosecutor's closing argument, the following statement was made:

"* * * Mr. Perry [defense counsel] says, 'We don't have a boot.' Certainly we don't have a boot. There is only one person in this courtroom today who knows where the boots are, and he is sitting there in the red shirt (indicating defendant seated at counsel table). Mr. Perry [defense counsel] says that we don't have a gun. Again, there is only one man in the courtroom who knows where the gun is, and he is sitting there in the red shirt (indicating defendant seated at counsel table)."

At the close of the court's charge, defense counsel conferred with the court, out of the hearing of the jury and off the record.  [***2] After the jury left the courtroom to begin their deliberations, the following colloquy took place:

"The Court: Mr. Perry asked the court to charge on the question of the fact that the defendant had not denied by taking the stand and refuting an argument which Mr. Shea made in his closing argument, namely that only the defendant could tell where the gun was or the shoes were." (Emphasis added.)

"I believe I am quoting you correctly, Mr. Perry.

"Mr. Perry: Yes, your Honor.

"The Court: You thought that I should instruct the jury in reference to the fact that the defendant had not taken the stand, and I specifically denied that request, saying that this court would be in error if it made any comment on the fact that defendant had not taken the stand.

"You may have an exception to my rulings, Mr. Perry.

"Mr. Perry: The charge that we asked the court to give is as follows: 'It is not necessary that the defendant take the witness stand in his own defense. In fact, he has a constitutional right not to testify. That being the case, the fact that he did not testify must not be considered for any purpose.'

"The Court: I feel that I would be in error to make any comment whatsoever [***3] with reference to the defendant not taking the stand.

"You may have an exception to my ruling, Mr. Perry * * *."

The jury returned a verdict of guilty. The judgment of conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals. The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction by the trial court of a single count of armed robbery in a jury trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant did not testify at trial. The prosecutor's closing argument called attention to the fact that he did not testify by commenting that defendant was the only person who knew where the gun and other items were and that he was seated at defense counsel's table. The trial court denied defense counsel's request for a jury instruction informing the jury that defendant had a constitutional right not to testify and that his failure to do so could not be considered for any purpose. In denying the request, the trial court stated that it believed that any comment by the court that referred to defendant's failure to take the stand would be erroneous. In reversing the court of appeals' judgment, the court ruled that the trial court committed prejudicial error and abused its discretion in refusing the requested instruction because it was sound in law and appropriate to the facts of the case.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeal's judgment, which had affirmed defendant's conviction by the trial court of armed robbery.

 

37 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Cincinnati Dist. Council 51


No. 72-697


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 2d 197; 299 N.E.2d 686; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 330; 84 L.R.R.M. 2241; 64 Ohio Op. 2d 129



July 18, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]  [*197]  [**689] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellants, Cincinnati District Council 51, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO (hereinafter Council 51), and the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO (hereinafter the International), were found in contempt of the Hamilton County Common Pleas Court for violation of a permanent injunction against striking and/or picketing against the city of Cincinnati, issued by that court on January 6, 1970. The strike was found by the Common Pleas Court to have lasted from January 4, 1970, through February 9, 1970. On September 14, 1971, the Common Pleas Court entered judgment finding appellants in contempt of court and fining them $ 37,000, $ 1,000 for each day of the strike. After crediting against this fine $ 7,800 (forfeiture of a security bond), $ 2,400 (fines previously paid by individuals), and $ 1,000 (court costs), the balance of the fine was determined to be $ 25,800. Of this $ 25,800 balance $ 13,000 was awarded to the city of Cincinnati as damages, and the remainder was awarded to Hamilton County as a "criminal penalty."

Further facts as necessary to the decision [***2] of this case are discussed in the opinion.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant unions sought review of a judgment entered by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the trial court that found the unions in contempt of a permanent injunction against striking or picketing against the city, a plaintiff in the underlying action but not a party to the appeal.


OVERVIEW: After the city expressed an intent to dismiss the contempt proceeding against the unions, appellee taxpayer intervened pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 733.581. The taxpayer asserted that the city's position failed to protect the interests of the people and that the city had suffered substantial damage as the result of the unions' strike. On appeal, the court held that it was not an abuse of discretion to permit the taxpayer to intervene because the underlying litigation was a matter of great public interest. The court further held that the contempt judgment was appropriate and supported by the evidence, except to the extent that it fined the unions for acts occurring prior to the date that the permanent injunction was issued. The court reasoned that the show cause order spoke only to the permanent injunction. Therefore it was improper to fine the unions for violations of an earlier restraining order. Otherwise, the court concluded that the award of damages was lawful and constitutional. The city's decision not to prosecute for contempt did not constitute a waiver of the taxpayer's right to proceed with the action under § 733.581.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower appellate court's judgment in part and reversed it in part. The court reversed that part of the judgment that fined the unions for acts occurring before the date of the permanent injunction.

 

38 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Brockman v. Proctor


No. 72-857


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 2d 79; 298 N.E.2d 532; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 314; 64 Ohio Op. 2d 50



July 3, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

Relator, Charles Brockman, was charged in the mayor's court of the city of Blue Ash with certain violations of the traffic ordinances of that city. He appeared in the mayor's court and, as he alleges in his complaint, objected to the proceedings "* * * on the basis that the mayor's court did not have jurisdiction of the person or subject matter and * * * that he would be denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial judicial officer as guaranteed by the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment should he be compelled to stand trial for traffic offenses before the mayor."

The mayor's court overruled relator's objections. Relator then filed this prohibition action in the Supreme Court, praying for the issuance of a writ ordering respondent, Charles Proctor, mayor of the city of Blue Ash, "to exercise no further jurisdiction in the matter" of the traffic offenses with which relator is charged.

The stipulation of facts filed in this cause states, in pertinent part:

"4. The budget and city revenues [of the city of Blue Ash] include monies derived from the fines and costs in the mayor's court which constitutes a contribution to the general operating fund [***2] of the city not in excess of ten (10%) per cent of that revenue. The council receives financial reports from the manager each month and alterations in the budget are subject to approval by council.

"5. The mayor of the city of Blue Ash, Ohio is elected by the council members from among their own number and the mayor serves a term of two (2) years. The mayor is paid the sum of $ 400 per year in addition to his salary as a council member. The mayor presides at all council meetings and votes on all issues before council. The mayor does not have an additional vote in case of tie but is limited to his one vote as council member. The mayor may call special meetings of council and may fill the vacancy on council if the council fails to act within sixty (60) days. The mayor also exercises powers, rights and duties as official head of the city for all ceremonial purposes and is recognized as the official head of the city by the Governor for military purposes and by the court for purposes of serving civil process. The mayor also performs all other duties imposed on him by any measure of council and the city charter.

"6. The mayor has jurisdiction to hear and determine any prosecution [***3] for the violation of ordinances of the municipal corporation and has jurisdiction in all criminal cases causes [sic] involving moving traffic violations occurring on state highways located within the boundaries of the municipal corporation, subject to the limitations of Sections 2937.08 and 2938.04 ORC. The mayor hears the evidence in such causes, rules upon objections, decides creditability of the witnesses and determines guilt or innocence. The mayor also exercises his discretion in the imposition of fines and sentences of incarceration and assessment of court costs. The mayor collects the fines levied upon the defendant and each month pays the balance of his account into the general operating fund of the city of Blue Ash, Ohio. The only other expenditures from the mayor's fund are the return of bonds which have been posted for appearances.

"7. The manager for the city of Blue Ash, Ohio is appointed by the council and he is the chief executive and administrative officer of the city. The manager is appointed for an indefinite term subject to removal as provided by the charter and is chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications. The manager is [***4] responsible to the council for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and the enforcement of all its laws and ordinances and he has exclusive authority to make all appointments, suspensions, and removal of all employees in the departments and offices under his control including the heads of all departments, and offices, but subject to such restrictions as may be imposed upon such authority of the manager pursuant to the provisions of the city charter and the civil service procedures. The manager prepares and submits to council an annual budget and an annual appropriation ordinance provided for in the charter and is responsible for the administration of them after their adoption. He prepares and submits to council at the end of each fiscal year a complete report on the finances and the administrative activities of the city for the prior year. The manager also prepares and submits to council each month a report showing the conditions of all appropriated funds.

"8. The manager manages and supervises all public works, garbage and other services, utilities and undertakings of the city."



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator sought a writ in prohibition to order respondent, the mayor of a city, to exercise no further jurisdiction as to traffic offenses with which relator was charged in the mayor's court on the ground that the mayor's court did not have jurisdiction of the person or subject matter and that relator would be denied a trial before a disinterested and impartial judicial officer as guaranteed by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.


OVERVIEW: Relator was charged with several traffic offenses in the mayor's court. He argued that being compelled to stand trial before the mayor, who had no executive power or duties, but who was a voting member of the city council that determined the appropriations and expenditures of revenue derived from fines, bond forfeitures, and court costs assessed by the mayor, denied him due process. The court denied him relief. Ohio Const. art. IV, § 1 empowered the General Assembly to establish mayors' courts and vests judicial power in such courts. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1905.01 established a mayor's court in all municipal corporations not having a police court and not being the site of a municipal court. An enactment of the General Assembly was presumed to be constitutional. Controlling judicial precedent held that the mayor's relation to the finances and financial policy of the city was too remote to warrant a presumption of bias toward conviction in prosecutions before him as judge.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ.

 

39 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Accountants Computer Services, Inc. v. Kosydar


Nos. 72-263, 72-660, 72-860


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 2d 120; 298 N.E.2d 519; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 320; 64 Ohio Op. 2d 72



July 3, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Each of these cases arises out of a sales and/or use tax assessment made by the Tax Commissioner of the state of Ohio. Each also involves a transaction, in the course of which there is transferred, printed or other productions or reproductions of written or graphic matter. The relevant facts pertaining to each individual case are as follows:

In case No. 72-263, Accountant's Computer Services, Inc. (ACS), a data processing company, receives raw data in the form of punch paper tapes or adding machine tapes upon which are recorded debits and credits which constitute records of current financial transactions of a particular business enterprise.

Thereafter, ACS, on its premises, transcribes the information from the tapes onto key punched cards, and, with the use of data processing machines, it sorts, systematically classifies and rearranges this data.

Print-outs of this rearranged data are furnished to the accountant-customer of ACS and in that form are used by the customer as drafts of financial statements, books of original entry, cash receipt journals, sales journals, cash disbursement journals and general ledgers. Historically, the function [***2] above described was a part of the accounting profession. Known as "write-up work," it was performed manually by the accountant or his staff. The print-out, now furnished by ACS, duplicates the accountant's writeup efforts.

The Tax Commissioner assessed the entire charge made by ACS as a sale. ACS appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals, arguing that the assessment was arbitrary, unreasonable, unconstitutional and not according to law in that its "activities constitute a service, and said services are specifically exempt under Sect. 5739.01(B), O. R. C." The board affirmed the assessment order of the Tax Commissioner.

Case No. 72-660, Central Data Systems, Inc. (CDS), also involves a data processing company. CDS obtains information from its customers for analysis of business problems and the data is furnished by the customer in a continuous ongoing manner.

The activity of CDS is described by the board in its decision, as follows:

"'The taxpayer is engaged in the business of providing both computing and software (brains and paper) sales and services which fall into four categories: (1) Data Processing is the operator's time, machine time, and the various reports and supplies billed [***3] generally on a monthly basis. (2) Key Punching is where the operator's time usually is billed at an hourly rate or 1000 card price. In this procedure the company takes the data, paper, or document, and has it transcribed into punched cards. (3) Systems Design and Programming primarily consists of program and system time by the hour; sometimes on a flat fee. The company's professional workers apply thinking to the customer's present system and then write instructions to automate the systems as in the case of upgrading machines from hand bookkeeping. (4) Contracts, which, are not involved herein, are the outside consulting division done almost always at the clients' place of business which is billed for the consultants time only by the hour where no forms are used. Both (3) and (4) are considered software but 3 does provide certain computer printouts in addition to consultation.

"'* * * The testimony was uncontradicted that the appellant provided its operation on a twenty four hour day, seven day each week basis and that during the audit period appellant had 35 to 40 employees.'"

Again, the Tax Commissioner assessed the entire charge made by CDS as a sale, and the board, finding [***4] that CDS's activities constituted a transfer of tangible personal property which was not eligible for exception under R. C. 5739.01(B) as an inconsequential transfer, affirmed the assessment in its entirety.

In case No. 72-860, Andrew Jergens Company (AJC) contracted with A. C. Neilsen Company, a market research organization whose function is to provide services which consist of compiling statistical data as to the movement of consumer products into and from drug stores, food stores and mass merchandiser stores; to interpret this data in order to determine marketing information as to these products on a national basis and in specific geographic areas; and to analyze, interpret and present to its customers the statistical information compiled and assist management in making marketing decisions based on this data.

During the audit period, AJC utilized the services of Neilsen with respect to both hand lotions and toilet soaps. As to each of these products, it prescribed specifications for the information it wanted from Neilsen -- as to the product class, the particular brands of products within each such class, and the sizes of each such brand. It also prescribed that the information [***5] was to be assembled on a nationwide basis and in accordance with specific sales territories. These specifications were changed from time to time during the audit period as to each of the products. The information requested by AJC included information not only as to its own products but also as to products of its competitors.

As an integral part of the service furnished, Neilsen assigned two account executives to AJC's account, whose duty it was to analyze, interpret and present to AJC's management the information developed by Neilsen in a meaningful and useful manner.

Once again, and for the same reasons, the Board of Tax Appeals affirmed the assessment order.

The causes are now before this court upon appeals from the Board of Tax Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Decision in case No. 72-263 affirmed. Decision in case No. 72-660 reversed. Decision in case No. 72-860 reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In three consolidated cases, appellant taxpayers challenged the judgment of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) which affirmed sales and/or use tax assessments made by appellee state tax commissioner.


OVERVIEW: Appellee state tax commissioner assessed taxes against appellant taxpayers. The Board of Tax Appeals affirmed the assessments, holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.01(B) required the imposition of a sales tax on professional, insurance, and personal service transactions that involved any transfer of "printed matter." On appeal, the court held that printed matter could be the subject of an excepted inconsequential transfer under the statute and that not all sales of printed matter were subject to taxation. The court affirmed the board's judgment as to the first appellant, who took raw material from its customers, transcribed it onto key punched cards, and sorted, classified, and rearranged it because the personal service appellant provided was inconsequential to the print out sold to the customers and was therefore taxable. The court reversed the judgment as to the other two appellants, who provided analysis of business problems and compiled, interpreted, and presented marketing data on customers' products, because appellants' services were the main items contracted for, rather than the print-outs of data processing machines.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed as to two appellant taxpayers because the printed matter generated by their work was inconsequential to the services they provided to their customers. The judgment was affirmed as to one appellant because its customer was paying for reorganization of raw material rather than for appellant's services.

 

40 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Zellner v. Board of Education


No. 72-484


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 2d 199; 297 N.E.2d 528; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 368; 63 Ohio Op. 2d 310



June 6, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This is a mandamus action, orginating in the Court of Appeals, to require the Cincinnati Board of Education to comply with an order of the Ohio Board of Education. The Cincinnati Board of Education was ordered to transfer certain territory in its district to an adjoining district, as provided by R. C. 3311.24.

In February 1970, appellee, and 26 other qualified electors of the Four-Mile area of Hamilton County, which is involved in the order, petitioned, under R. C. 3311.24, for the transfer of that territory from the Cincinnati School District to the Hamilton County School District and the Forest Hills Local School District. The petition was forwarded by the appellant to the State Board of Education, with strong opposition by the Cincinnati board on the ground that the transfer request was racially motivated.

A public hearing was held, and the state board approved the transfer on July 13, 1970. It then denied appellant's request for reconsideration on September 14, 1970.

On September 15, 1970, appellant filed an action for a declaratory judgment in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Western [***2] Division, against the State Board of Education to determine whether the order of the state board constituted illegal gerrymandering and discriminatory practices in violation of the federal Civil Rights Act (Section 1983, Title 42, U.S. Code) and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

On January 17, 1972, appellee filed an action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals. Appellant filed a motion to dismiss the action on the ground, inter alia, that the federal District Court had first acquired jurisdiction of the subject matter. That motion was overruled, and, on May 9, 1972, the court granted appellee's motion for summary judgment. On May 12, 1972, the court issued a writ of mandamus requiring appellant to comply with the transfer ordered pursuant to R. C. 3311.24.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a city board of education, sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which issued a writ of mandamus requiring the city board to comply with an order of the state board of education that the city board transfer certain territory in its district to an adjoining district as provided by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.24 and as requested by appellee, a county elector.


OVERVIEW: The elector petitioned the state board under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.24 for certain territory to be transferred out of the city school district. The state board approved the transfer, and the city board filed suit in federal court for a declaratory judgment that the state board's order was illegal gerrymandering in violation of 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 and the Equal Protection Clause. The elector then filed an action in mandamus; the court of appeals overruled the city board's motion to dismiss, on the ground that the federal court first acquired jurisdiction, and issued a writ of mandamus. The court reversed. The court held that considerations of comity, orderly procedure, and judicial economy required the state court to defer to the federal court action even though the elector was not a party to that action. Federal district courts were the proper forum for school desegregation controversies. A finding by the federal court that the transfer was without racial basis and constitutional, or conversely that it was unconstitutional, would determine the whole controversy. The elector failed to show clearly a right to the writ of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment requiring the city board to transfer the territory and remanded with instructions to dismiss the elector's petition.

 

41 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Stewart v. Trumbull County Board of Elections


No. 72-673


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 2d 129; 296 N.E.2d 676; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 359; 63 Ohio Op. 2d 227



May 23, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County.

On August 5, 1970, a group of citizens filed with appellee board of elections local option petitions for the purpose of having electors of Ward 5, Precincts H and J, and Ward 6, Precincts A and B, in the city of Warren, Ohio, vote in the November 1970 general election upon whether to permit the sale of beer and intoxicating liquors within the district comprised of those precincts.

On August 28, 1970, appellants, Laura J. Stewart and Robert L. Stewart, as qualified electors, filed a written protest to the local option petitions with the appellee board on their own behalf and on behalf of various tavern owners in the area. In a hearing on the protest, appellants presented evidence respecting the character of the district.

On October 14, 1970, the board denied the appellants' protest and validated the petitions. Appellants appealed to the Court of Common Pleas, which refused to enjoin the placing of the issue on the ballot, but did temporarily enjoin certification of the balloting results. The balloting resulted in a dry vote. Ultimately, the Court of Common Pleas affirmed the board's decision.

The Court of Appeals affirmed [***2] the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas. The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

Further facts necessary to the decision of this appeal are discussed in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A group of citizens filed with appellee board of elections local option petitions to vote in the general election upon whether to permit the sale of beer and intoxicating liquors within a district. Appellants, electors and tavern owners, unsuccessfully sought to enjoin the placing of the issue on the ballot. The Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio) upheld the validation of the petitions. A motion to certify the record was allowed.


OVERVIEW: The tavern owners argued that the terms "residence district" as used in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4301.32 and "residential district" as used in § 4305.14 limited the local option privilege to districts comprised of two or more contiguous precincts which were primarily residential in character. They also contended that the term "residence district" was unconstitutionally vague and ambiguous. The court upheld the decision of the court of appeals. The court rejected the tavern owners' constitutional argument because the statute itself fully defined and circumscribed the term "residence district."
