Further, applying the presumption that a just and reasonable result was intended by the legislature, the court held that the tavern owners' interpretation of § 4305.14 was not viable. To interpret that statute as requiring that more than 50 percent of the land area of each precinct be used for residential purposes would be manifestly unjust to those precincts which fell short of such an arbitrary standard. Both § 4305.14 and § 4301.32 intended that a portion of a municipal corporation consisting of two or more contiguous precincts should have the privilege of local option.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

42 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Pinzone v. Cleveland


No. 72-570


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 2d 26; 295 N.E.2d 408; 1973 Ohio LEXIS 342; 63 Ohio Op. 2d 46



April 18, 1973, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellee, the executive secretary of the Cleveland Building and Construction Trades Council, filed this action in mandamus in the Court of Appeals to compel the city of Cleveland to adopt an ordinance "providing for increases in the hourly rates of all craft workers in the employ of the city of Cleveland employed on an hourly rate, effective May 1, 1971, in all of the classifications, in accordance with schedules heretofore adopted by the city of Cleveland * * *." This action was brought "* * * on behalf of all skilled building and construction tradesmen employed by the defendant city of Cleveland."

The Court of Appeals allowed the writ, ordering appellants "* * * to implement the wage rate schedule provided in the agreement between the Cleveland Building and Construction Trades Employers Association and the Mechanical Contractors Association on the effective dates contemplated by and incorporated in the agreement."

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.

Further facts as are necessary to the decision of this case are set forth in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged a decision of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which granted mandamus relief to appellee trades council and ordered the city to implement the wage rate schedule provided in the agreement between two trade associations in order to raise the city's wage rates for skilled building trades laborers to the prevailing level in private industry.


OVERVIEW: In 1970, the city enacted an ordinance which established the prevailing wage rates for construction workers employed by the city, which were the same as wage rates for tradesmen similarly employed by private industry. The ordinance was based upon three-year agreements that established the prevailing wage rate for skilled building trades laborers in the area. The contracts provided for wage increases effective May 1, 1971, but the city failed to enact ordinances to raise the city's wage rates to the prevailing level in private industry. The court of appeals ordered the city to implement the wage rate schedule provided in the three-year agreement and the court affirmed. It found that the establishment of municipal wage rates based upon prevailing wages was not an unlawful delegation of legislative authority. Further, fringe benefits such as paid sick leave, greater job security, and more steady employment could not be used as an offset against the higher base wage in private industry.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the court of appeals, which granted mandamus relief to the trades council and ordered the city to enact ordinances to raise the city's wage rates to the prevailing level in private industry.

 

43 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Coleman v. Coleman


No. 72-201


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 2d 155; 291 N.E.2d 530; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 378; 61 Ohio Op. 2d 406; 57 A.L.R.3d 213



December 15, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This cause arose from the dismissal, by the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County, of a complaint filed by Louise C. Coleman, plaintiff-appellant, for a divorce from her husband, Joseph E. Coleman, defendant-appellee.

The complaint alleges that plaintiff and her husband were married on January 15, 1956, at Ozone Park, New York; that four children, presently in the custody of plaintiff, are issue of the marriage; that defendant has threatened plaintiff and the children; and that defendant has been guilty of gross neglect of duty and extreme cruelty. Plaintiff prayed for a divorce, custody of the minor children, alimony and support, and other equitable relief.

Plaintiff alleges further that she has been a bona fide resident of Ohio since December 1969. The complaint was filed August 21, 1970, less than one year after plaintiff had moved to Ohio from New York. Service of process was obtained upon defendant in New York by certified mail. No answer or appearance was interposed by defendant.

Temporary restraining and custody orders were issued on August 21, 1970, and this matter was heard as an uncontested case on December [***2] 30, 1970. Upon questioning by the court, plaintiff admitted not having a year's residence at the time of filing as required by R. C. 3105.03. No request for leave of court to amend the complaint having been filed, the court dismissed the case on the ground that plaintiff was not a resident of the state of Ohio for a year prior to the filing of her complaint.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas. The cause is now before this court pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review from an order of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the dismissal of her divorce complaint from appellee husband.


OVERVIEW: The wife filed a divorce complaint alleging that the husband had threatened her and their children and had been guilty of gross neglect of duty and extreme cruelty. The complaint requested a divorce, custody of the minor children, alimony, and support. The complaint was filed less than one year after the wife had moved to Ohio and the trial court dismissed the complaint. The dismissal was affirmed by the appellate court. On appeal, the wife contended that the residency requirement violated her right to travel freely throughout the United States. The court held that the privilege of obtaining a divorce was not a basic need as divorce was a creature of state statute. The court determined that the state had a compelling interest in overseeing divorce and marriage laws and that the one-year durational residency requirement did not prevent persons wanting a divorce from moving to Ohio, however it did provide a reasonable deferral of application for divorce, thus encouraging a new examination of the marriage to see if the move itself had resolved the differences.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order from the appellate court.

 

44 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Blair


No. 72-145


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 2d 237; 291 N.E.2d 451; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 390; 61 Ohio Op. 2d 463



December 15, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Richard A. Blair, appellant herein, was indicted on two counts of sale and four counts of possession for sale of obscene literature, in violation of R. C. 2905.34, as it existed prior to September 15, 1970. 1 He was brought to trial, and found guilty by a jury on June 11, 1971, on four of those counts. 2


1 R. C. 2905.34 was recodified, effective September 15, 1970.


2 The magazines involved in this case are "Gaia," "Male and Female Nudes, No. 2," "The Girl Friends, Vol. 2, No. 1," and "Ram."

A motion for new trial was overruled, and judgment was rendered upon the verdict. The Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction by a Franklin County (Ohio) trial court for the sale and possession for sale of obscene literature, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.34. The trial court overruled defendant's motion for a new trial. Defendant's conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted by the trial court of the sale and possession for sale of obscene literature, under Ohio Rev. Code § 2905.34. The trial court overruled defendant's motion for a new trial. The lower court affirmed defendant's conviction, and he sought further review. On review, the court rejected defendant's claim that the lower court erred in refusing to allow testimony by defense counsel that defendant sought his opinion as to whether or not the material was obscene prior to selling it. The court concluded that the risk taken by the seller of selling obscene material would not be minimized by a third party opinion. The court also rejected defendant's claim that the state failed to establish the degree of proof necessary to find the material obscene. The court found that the determination of obscenity by the finder of fact had to be based not on personal viewpoints but on contemporary community standards, and that the factfinder had to find the material without redeeming social value and appealing to a prurient interest in sex. The court noted that the evidence conflicted on those standards and concluded that the jury was properly left to weigh the evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court.

 

45 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Fuldauer v. Cleveland


No. 72-241


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 2d 114; 290 N.E.2d 546; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 369; 61 Ohio Op. 2d 374



December 13, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This case was commenced in June 1968 in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County as a taxpayer's action for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief. The gravamen of the complaint was to set aside the action of the electors of the city of Cleveland who amended their city charter * on May 7, 1968, and established a formula by which the basic rates of compensation of the members of the fire department and of the members of the police department are to be computed annually.


* Sections 198-1 and 198-2 of the Charter of the city of Cleveland provide:

"Section 198-1. Annual rate of pay to be paid members of the fire department.

"Whereas, the danger and skill required in fighting fires is greater in Cleveland than any other city in Ohio, because of its size and industrial development.

"Be it resolved that firemen 1st grade, members of the Department of Public Safety, Division of Fire, in the city of Cleveland be paid no less than firemen 1st grade, are paid in any city of Ohio, with a population of 50,000 or more.

"No later than the 15th day of February of each year, the Cleveland City Council shall survey and certify rates of compensation paid firemen 1st grade, employed in all cities of 50,000 population or over, in the state of Ohio, based upon the latest federal decennial census; and council shall, by ordinance, not later than the 1st day of June of each year, provide for paying a rate of compensation, consisting of the highest rate of any city of Ohio of over 50,000 population, plus 3% of such rate as an acknowledgment, not a measurement of the high responsibility involved. Such pay ordinances shall also include an additional 16% differential between ranks of the members of the Fire Department.

"The expression 'rate of compensation' or pay, as used in this section shall apply only to a basic amount of wages and does not include such benefits as might be set up by any city by way of holidays, vacations, other permitted absences, overtime, longevity, night or split shifts, pay for specialized service within a classification or rank, or other premium pay differentials of any type whatsoever. The foregoing enumeration is not exclusive; it is the intent of this section that nothing other than a basic amount of wages, with included range scales be included within the meaning of 'rate of compensation' or pay.

"Upon passage of this Charter Amendment, a special survey shall be made in accordance with the hereinbefore stated provisions, and the new rate shall be paid beginning June 1, 1968. (Effective June 3, 1968.)"

"Section 198-2. Annual rate of pay to be paid members of the police department.

"The annual rate of compensation of a patrolman, 1st grade, Division of Police, Department of Public Safety shall be no less than that paid to a patrolman, 1st grade, in any city of Ohio with a population of 50,000 or more.

"On or about the 15th day of February of each year the council shall cause a survey to be made as to the rate of compensation paid a patrolman, 1st grade, by all cities in Ohio with a population of 50,000 or more, based upon the latest federal decennial census. Not later than the 1st day of June of each year council shall enact legislation providing for the payment of a rate of compensation for a patrolman, 1st grade, which shall consist of the highest rate paid any patrolman, 1st grade, in any city of Ohio with a population of 50,000 or more, plus three percent (3%) of the sum so paid. Such pay ordinance shall also include an additional sixteen percent (16%) differential between ranks of the members of the Police Division.

"The expression 'rate of compensation' or pay, as used in this section shall apply only to a basic amount of wages and does not include such benefits as might be set up by any city by way of holidays, vacations, other permitted absences, overtime, longevity, night or split shifts, pay for specialized service within a classification or rank, or other premium pay differentials of any type whatsoever. The foregoing enumeration is not exclusive; it is the intent of this section that nothing other than a basic amount of wages, with included range scales be included within the meaning of 'rate of compensation' or pay.

"Upon passage of this charter amendment, a special survey shall be made in accordance with the hereinbefore stated provisions, and the new rate shall be paid beginning June 1, 1968. (Effective June 3, 1968.)"

 [***2] The Common Pleas Court denied any relief to plaintiff, and the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court.

The cause is before us pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.

Motions to intervene have been filed in this court and granted to the Citizens League of Greater Cleveland and to James P. Neelon and Jack Gannon of the Firefighters Union of Cleveland.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment in favor of appellee city. The taxpayer sought to set aside an action of the city's electors, who amended the city charter and established a formula by which the basic rates of compensation for fire fighters and police officers were to be computed annually.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer brought a declaratory judgment action against the city claiming that amendments to the city's charter violated the home-rule power of the city's electors. The provisions adopted a formula by which basic compensation rates for city safety personnel were to be computed annually. The trial court entered judgment upholding the validity of the amendments and the court of appeals affirmed. The taxpayer sought review and the court affirmed. The court held, first, that through the actions of the electors in enacting the amendments, the city's citizens established the substantive policy and standards governing safety personnel salaries and instructed the city council as to the manner and method of its exercise of legislative power in furtherance of that policy. Through the charter, the court said, the citizens had retained for themselves those matters specifically regulated in the charter. All other matters, the court said, were left to the city council. The court also found that the charter amendments did not delegate legislative powers to any entity outside the city's control. The court said that the amendments merely fixed a formula, which looked to wage rate surveys.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed a judgment that rebuffed the taxpayer's attempt to set aside a city's action amending its charter to provide basic compensation rates for safety personnel.

 

46 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Gregory v. Flowers


No. 71-782


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 2d 48; 290 N.E.2d 181; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 358; 61 Ohio Op. 2d 295



November 29, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Scioto County.

Appellee, Lewis T. Gregory, while employed by appellant General Telephone Company of Ohio, fell from one of appellant's telephone poles, sustaining both neck and lower back injuries. The accident occurred in January 1959. Shortly thereafter, appellee filed an application for compensation with the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation for the neck injuries. The claim was allowed and compensation thereon was duly paid. At that time, the lower back injury was ignored by his doctor because "* * * we were so fearful of the neck area."

By December 1967, however, the back injury necessitated appellee's further hospitalization. An extruded disc in the spinal canal was discovered and a laminectomy was performed.

In that regard, on June 5, 1968, appellee filed an application to reactivate and modify his original claim, to include the expenses arising out of the lower back injury.

The application was denied at the administrative level upon the ground that the back injury was unrelated to the neck injury. Upon appeal, the Court of Common Pleas, although finding that the back injury arose out of the 1959 accident, simultaneously with the [***2] neck injury, sustained appellants' motion for summary judgment for the reason that appellee's application was not filed within two years of the injury as required by R. C. 4123.84, as amended, effective December 11, 1967.

The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that amended R. C. 4123.84 could not be applied retroactively so as to preclude appellee's recovery. The cause is now before this court pursuant to our allowance of appellants' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation and an employer, sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Scioto County (Ohio), which held that amended Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.84 could not be applied retroactively so as to preclude appellee claimant's recovery for a back injury, which arose out of an accident eight years earlier for which he had been allowed compensation for neck injuries.


OVERVIEW: The claimant was injured when he fell from one of his employer's telephone poles. He sustained both neck and back injuries; however, he filed an application for compensation the neck injuries alone. Eight years later, the back injury necessitated further hospitalization, and the employee filed an application to reactivate and modify his original claim to include these expenses. The trial court found that although the back injury arose out of the accident simultaneously with the neck injury, the application was not filed within two years of the injury as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.84. Section 4123.84 provided that any pending claim, in which the remedy was affected by § 4123.84, was to be governed by the terms of § 4123.84 requiring an application to be filed within two years of the injury. The court found that such application of § 4123.84 operated to destroy an accrued substantive right, which arose by virtue of the workmen's compensation laws, and conflicted with Ohio Const. art. II, § 28 rendering it unconstitutional and void.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

47 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. McIntyre v. Mininni


No. 72-722


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 2d 17; 288 N.E.2d 816; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 352; 61 Ohio Op. 2d 158



October 25, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Relators, appellees herein, filed a complaint in mandamus in the Court of Appeals to compel the respondents, members of the Board of Elections of Franklin County, to issue relator Craig A. McIntyre a certificate of nomination as the Republican candidate for the office of State Representative for the 30th Ohio House District for the November 1972 general election and to place his name on the ballot for that election.

An agreed statement of facts, filed in the Court of Appeals, relates that:

"1. Plaintiff-relator, Craig A. McIntyre, is, and was at all times pertinent hereto, a qualified elector of Franklin County, Ohio, a resident of the 30th Ohio House District and a registered Republican. Plaintiff McIntyre was a duly authorized write-in candidate for the Republican nomination for the office of State Representative for the 30th Ohio House District in the May 2, 1972 primary election, having filed his declaration of candidacy as required by law and having paid the prescribed filing fee.

"* * *

"4. The name of no candidate appeared on the printed Republican primary ballot for the 30th Ohio House District for the May 2, 1972 [***2] primary election. In said election there were two duly qualified write-in candidates for said nomination, to-wit: Plaintiff McIntyre and Roy Shinaberry. At said election, a total of six hundred and forty-five (645) votes were cast for the Republican nomination for the said office. Plaintiff McIntyre received four hundred and sixty-six (466) votes and candidate, Roy Shinaberry received one hundred and seventy-nine (179) votes. At said election four thousand three hundred twenty (4,394) [sic] persons registered and voted as Republicans in the 30th Ohio House District.

"5. After the May 2, 1972 primary election, plaintiff McIntyre duly filed his statement of receipts and expenditures with the Franklin County Board of Elections. At a regular meeting of the said board on June 19, 1972, plaintiff McIntyre requested that he be issued a Certificate of Nomination as the Republican candidate for the 30th Ohio House District and that his name be placed on the ballot as the Republican candidate for said office. The defendants, however, voted to deny said requests solely upon the basis that plaintiff McIntyre did not receive the minimum percentage of votes specified in Ohio Revised [***3] Code Section 3513.23. Plaintiff McIntyre is in all other respects qualified to be a candidate at the next general election for the office of State Representative for the 30th House District and to assume and perform the duties of said office if elected thereto."

The Court of Appeals granted the writ as prayed for and the cause is now before this court upon appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, the members of the Board of Elections of Franklin County, sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) granting a writ of mandamus requested by relators seeking to have the name of their candidate added to an election ballot for state representative.


OVERVIEW: Relators sought to have the name of their candidate added to an election ballot for state representative. Respondents refused, and relators filed an application for a writ of mandamus seeking to compel the addition. The court of appeals granted the writ, and respondents appealed the decision. The court noted that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3513.23 required a certain percentage of votes for a candidate's name to appear on the ballot. However, this percentage created an invidious distinction between write-in candidates, who only had to reach a lower percentage, and candidates whose names appeared on the printed ballot. Therefore, the court concluded that § 3513.23 violated the equal protection clause, and was unconstitutional. The decision of the court of appeals was proper.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was affirmed.

 

48 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Leigh


No. 71-578


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 97; 285 N.E.2d 333; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 404; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 80



July 19, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On September 24, 1969, a robbery of the Cabinet-Supreme Savings & Loan Association, located in Delhi Township, Hamilton County, occurred. During the robbery, the lone woman teller and three female customers were shot and killed.

On September 28, 1969, John Leigh, defendant herein, and Watterson Johnson, a codefendant, were arrested in Arizona. At that time, the defendant provided a statement to an FBI special agent, in which he confessed that he had fired all the shots. He also provided a description of how the shooting occurred and what guns were used. The following day, the defendant repeated his confession to a Cincinnati police officer. Both statements were introduced in evidence at the trial.

Raymond Kassow, another codefendant who was arrested in Cincinnati on the day of the robbery, had led the police to three guns which met the specific descriptions provided by the defendant in his statement.

The prosecutor tried the case on the theory that the defendant was "the trigger man," and had shot and killed all four women by firing a .25-caliber automatic until it jammed, then firing a .22-caliber revolver until all four [***2] women quit moving. This theory corresponds to the statements provided to the police by the defendant.

At trial, upon one of four counts of first degree murder, the defendant testified that he had been at the Cabinet-Supreme Bank on September 24th; that he met the two other persons involved in the robbery that morning; that he had gone to Delhi with them and waited for the manager of the bank to leave; and that when the manager left, they drove to the bank. Thus, the defendant's participation in the crime is not disputed. However, the defendant refuted his prior statements insofar as they related to his active participation in the shooting. He stated that he remained in the car, and that Kassow did all the shooting.

After the case had been submitted to the jury, defense counsel learned that expert testimony had been available to the prosecutor's office prior to this trial. This evidence indicated that Kassow had fired more than one shot from some gun or guns on the day of the robbery. Such evidence had not been disclosed to this defendant.

The jury returned a verdict of guilty, without a recommendation of mercy, and judgment was entered upon the verdict. No motion for a new [***3] trial was filed by the defendant, nor was a request made to have the jury advised of this additional evidence.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction.

The cause is now before this court upon appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.

 

49 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 71-780


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 106; 285 N.E.2d 751; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 406; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 85



July 19, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This is an appeal as of right arising out of the conviction without a recommendation of mercy of defendant, Watterson Johnson, for one count of violation of R. C. 2901.01, the killing of Lillian Dewald while perpetrating or attempting to perpetrate robbery.

The Grand Jury of Hamilton County, Ohio, returned a joint indictment against this defendant and codefendants Raymond Kassow and John Levi Leigh for violation of the above section. To the indictment, the defendant entered pleas of not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity. Subsequently, an order was made directing the trial court to hold a separate trial for each defendant, each trial to run simultaneously in order to insure that the jurors in each trial were not influenced by the events occuring in the other.

The court also made an order for the clerk of courts to draw 75 names to serve as special jurors for the trial of the defendant. The names of these prospective jurors were drawn from the roles of electors, pursuant to R. C. 2945.18, 2945.19, 2313.06 and 2313.08.

At commencement of the trial, defendant moved for a change of venue and for a sanity hearing, both [***2] of which motions were overruled.

At defendant's trial, evidence was presented which showed that on September 24, 1969, at approximately 11:00 a. m., the Cabinet Supreme Savings and Loan Association, located in Delhi Township, Hamilton County, Ohio, was robbed. During the course of the robbery a female employee, Lillian Dewald, and three female customers were shot and killed. Mrs. Dewald was shot in the back four times with two different guns. The three women customers were each shot in the forehead. The husband of one of the victims who was waiting for his wife in an adjoining parking lot during the time of the robbery, saw three men walk from the building, enter an automobile, and speed away. He then entered the building and called for his wife. When she did not respond, he investigated, and saw piled inside a vault the bodies of his wife and three other women. The police, after responding, put out a call for the arrest of defendant Johnson and codefendant Kassow.

Prior to the date of the crime, two men had entered the Cabinet Supreme Savings and Loan Association and opened a savings account with the teller, Mrs. Dewald. An account signature card was filled out at that time [***3] under the name of "Watterson Johnson." Mrs. Dewald became suspicious and notified her husband who was a Cincinnati police officer. The next day, the two men returned to complete the account card. At this time, Mr. Dewald was in a back room with his gun drawn and he heard one of the men identify himself as Watterson Johnson. Dewald did not personally observe the defendant. The two men left without incident.

Shortly after the murder-robbery on September 24, 1969, codefendant Kassow was arrested. Subsequently, he gave a statement to the Cincinnati police, and as a result of this statement the police went to Fairview Park, Cincinnati, Ohio, where a paper bag containing three guns was recovered. Ballistics examination of the guns revealed that two of them had been used in the killing of the four women.

On the morning of September 28, 1969, Johnson and Leigh were apprehended in New Mexico by a police officer. After their arrest, they were turned over to FBI agents at Gallup, New Mexico. Subsequently, an FBI agent, after duly advising Johnson of his constitutional rights, obtained a statement from him in which Johnson admitted that some time prior to the robbery he and Kassow had [***4] planned the robbery.

Johnson also admitted to Cincinnati police officers, who had gone to New Mexico to return him to Cincinnati, that on the date prior to the robbery he and Kassow had gone to the Savings and Loan Association, where Kassow had filled out an account card using Watterson Johnson's name; that a few days before the robbery-murder they procured the services of the third defendant, John Levi Leigh; and that on the morning of the robbery the three men drove to the Cabinet Supreme Savings and Loan. Johnson stated that Kassow remained in the car, while he and Leigh entered the building. After entering, they announced to the teller, Mrs. Dewald, that it was a holdup. Three other women then entered the savings and loan, and all four women were ordered into the vault, whereupon Johnson stated that Leigh then started shooting the women and, when his gun jammed, Leigh grabbed Johnson's gun and continued firing.

A police specialist in the identification section testified that he picked up a signature card, found in the Cabinet Supreme Savings and Loan Association on the date of the robbery, and on the signature card there was found a fingerprint of defendant, Johnson.



DISPOSITION:  [***5] Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for murder in the first degree and his death sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of murder and was sentenced to death. He appealed, and the appellate court affirmed the decision. He appealed again and argued that the penalty of death was cruel and unusual punishment. The court agreed that the infliction of the death penalty under the existing law of Ohio was unconstitutional. Defendant also argued that he was denied due process because all non-registered electors were systematically excluded for jury services. The court found that the underlying requirements to become a qualified elector eligible for jury selection in Ohio were not unreasonable and that all groups of society were adequately represented within the ranks of registered electors. The court held that the trial court did not err, as alleged by defendant, when it refused to inquire into his present sanity because a last minute motion was filed on the first day of trial. The court found nothing in the record to suggest that defendant was not sane. There was no evidence presented which would have shown that the trial judge abused his discretion by failing to notice that defendant was not then sane nor entitled to an examination into the question of sanity.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate court's judgment and reduced defendant's sentence to life imprisonment. The court affirmed defendant's conviction for first degree murder.

 

50 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Hoffman


No. 71-424


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 163; 285 N.E.2d 714; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 410; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 117



July 19, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On March 7, 1970, these appellants were arrested by police officers of the city of Cincinnati. Thereafter, Brown was convicted of violating Section 901-d4 of the Code of Ordinances of that city (disorderly conduct), and Hoffman and Berliner were convicted of violating Section 901-r2 (resisting an officer). Further facts appear as warranted in the opinion.

The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County affirmed the convictions and the causes were consolidated for appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged judgments of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) affirming their convictions for disorderly conduct in violation of Cincinnati, OH Code of Ordinances § 901-d4 and resisting an officer in violation of § 901-r2.


OVERVIEW: Demonstrators confronted police officers and defendants were arrested. One defendant was convicted of disorderly conduct and the other defendants were convicted of resisting an officer. The intermediate appellate court affirmed, and defendants sought review. The court affirmed, holding that defendant was properly convicted of disorderly conduct because his conduct was performed in a noisy, boisterous, rude, insulting or other disorderly manner. Also, defendants were properly convicted of resisting an officer because the City had the authority to adopt and enforce within its limits such local police, sanitary and other similar regulations, as were not in conflict with the general laws. Ohio Const. Art. XVIII, § 3. Finally, the jury was properly charged regarding the insertion of the Ohio Revised Code scienter standards into the ordinances; therefore, the ordinance was fully extended to contain all of the elements of the offense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for disorderly conduct and resisting an officer.

 

51 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Krause v. State


No. 71-779


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 132; 285 N.E.2d 736; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 408; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 100



July 19, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellee, as administrator of the estate of Allison Krause, brought a wrongful death and survivorship action against appellant, the state of Ohio.

Appellant filed a motion to quash service of summons upon it and to dismiss it as a party defendant for the reason that it had not consented to be sued and, therefore, was immune from such suit.

The Common Pleas Court judge sustained the motion, quashed the service of summons and dismissed the state as a party defendant.

The Court of Appeals of the Eighth Appellate District, one judge dissenting, reversed and remanded. 28 Ohio App. 2d 1, 274 N. E. 2d 321 (1971).

The cause is before this court by certification as being in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Tenth Appellate District in Clark v. Dept. of Mental Hygiene (1955), 72 Ohio Law Abs. 340, 135 N. E. 2d 72, and with the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Seventh Appellate District in Carolyne v. Youngstown State University (1970, unreported).



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In appellee estate administrator's wrongful death and survivorship action against appellant state, the trial court quashed service of summons upon the state and dismissed the state as a party defendant because the state did not consent to be sued. The Court of Appeals of the Eighth Appellate District (Ohio) reversed the decision and remanded. The state appealed. The case was certified as conflicting with cases decided by other appellate courts.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court found the governmental immunity doctrine violated the Equal Protection Clause. The court re-examined the doctrine and expressly approved precedent that held the state was not subject to suit in its own courts without its express consent because Ohio Const. art. I, § 16 (amended September 3, 1912) was not self-executing and statutory authority was required as a prerequisite to bringing suits against the state. Although the defense of governmental immunity was not available, the defense of lack of consent by the general assembly to a suit was available. The court could not constitutionally grant consent to sue the state in drafting the Rules of Civil Procedure because that would modify a substantive right. The general assembly did not manifest its consent to suits against the state by approving Ohio R. Civ. P. 1(a), 4.2(10). The governmental immunity doctrine did not violate the Equal Protection Clause because Ohio Const. art. I, § 16 (amended September 3, 1912) created no classification and assuming there was a classification, the general assembly was empowered to make one based on its judgment that there were substantive differences between two types of conduct.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment reversing the trial court's decision quashing service of summons upon the state and dismissing the state as a party defendant because the state did not consent to be sued.

 

52 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Kitchen v. Christman


No. 71-474


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 64; 285 N.E.2d 362; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 415; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 42



July 12, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The facts are not in dispute. The North Olmsted City Council (herein City Council) determined that a need existed for the construction of a swimming pool; however, because of the constitutional tax rate limitations and the existing city indebtedness, the city could not issue bonds in an amount sufficient to provide funds for its construction. 1


1 It is conceded by relator that if this court "determines that the lease agreement is in effect a 'bonded indebtedness' within the contemplation of Section 11 of Article XII, relator * * * would have been required to provide in the ordinance authorizing the lease for the levy of a tax in an amount sufficient to pay the annual rental under the lease and to follow the procedures of the Uniform Bond Law."

Section 11 of Article XII of the Ohio Constitution reads:

"No bonded indebtedness of the state, or any political subdivisions thereof, shall be incurred or renewed unless, in the legislation under which such indebtedness is incurred or renewed, provision is made for levying and collecting annually by taxation an amount sufficient to pay the interest on said bonds, and to provide a sinking fund for their final redemption at maturity."

 [***2] As a result, the Community Recreation Company (herein Company) "presented to the city a proposal for the construction * * * [by it] on property to be conveyed [to it] by the city * * * of a municipal swimming pool * * * and the leasing of such facility including the real estate on which it is to be constructed * * * to the city for a period of ten years * * * and with provision for the city to acquire complete ownership and title to the facility and real estate upon the expiration of such lease * * *." The city accepted this offer. This method of financing was deemed necessary in order to obtain the recreational facility "without the necessity of the city incurring debt."

City Council then directed the mayor to execute, on behalf of the city, a deed conveying the property to the Company, and, at the same time, to execute a lease for the same property from the Company. The deed recites that the grantor "does hereby grant, bargain, sell and convey unto the grantee, its successors and assigns, but only for so long as the premises are subject to the lease * * *. * * * To have and to hold the same to the grantee * * * but only until the termination of the lease * * *."

The lease [***3] provides that the Company will "construct and develop * * * [the swimming pool] * * * in consideration of the aforesaid conveyance * * * and the city's agreement to lease the premises and the project." The facility would be constructed at the "sole expense" of the Company, while the city would pay rent in the amount of $ 8,375 quarterly, beginning the second month following the delivery of possession to the city. During the term of the lease the Company waived all right of reentry or right to retake possession of the premises for default in the payment of rent, but expressly retained "any available remedy in law or in equity to sue for and collect such rentals as the same become due."

Upon termination of the lease, or "at any other time that * * * [the Company's] interest in the premises terminates pursuant to the terms of the deed * * * [the Company agrees to] deliver to the city the premises * * * and any other improvements that * * * [it] has made on the premises at no cost and * * * [they] shall become the absolute property of the city."

The lease and the deed, incorporated and made a part of the ordinance, were presented to the mayor for his signature. He refused [***4] to execute the instruments. Relator pursuant to R. C. 733.58 2 applied for a writ of mandamus to compel the execution of the two instruments. The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County granted the writ. From that judgment, respondent appeals to this court.


2 "In case an officer or board of a municipal corporation fails to perform any duty expressly enjoined by law or ordinance, the solicitor shall apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for a writ of mandamus to compel the performance of such duty."



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant mayor appealed from the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which granted the petition for writ of mandamus to compel the execution of two instruments filed by plaintiff city.


OVERVIEW: The city's council determined that the city needed a new swimming pool. The city could not issue sufficient bonds. A recreation company presented the city with a construction proposal on land conveyed to it by the city, on which the city would have paid rent for a period of years, acquiring title to the real estate and property upon the lease's expiration. The city accepted the offer and directed the mayor to execute the deed, the lease, and an accompanying ordinance. The mayor refused and the city petitioned for a writ of mandamus to compel the execution of the documents. The lower court granted the writ. The mayor appealed and the court reversed. The court held that the instrument was not a bona fide lease, but an installment purchase contract and that the entire contract price was a present indebtedness of the city. The court held that the ordinance containing the proposed transaction fell within the purview of activity proscribed by Ohio Const. art. XII, § 11. The court found that the ordinance that authorized and directed the mayor to execute the instruments was unconstitutional and invalid and that mandamus was not available as a remedy to compel an unconstitutional act.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower court, which granted the city's petition for writ of mandamus to compel the mayor's execution of two instruments.

 

53 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Albini


Nos. 71-736, 71-737


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 2d 27; 285 N.E.2d 327; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 422; 60 Ohio Op. 2d 15



July 5, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In case No. 71-736, appellant, James John Albini, was convicted in the Franklin County Municipal Court on the charge that he "did unlawfully and knowingly exhibit * * * an obscene motion picture film * * *," in violation of R. C. 2905.34 (now R. C. 2905.35). Appellant Albini was the manager of a theater where the film was being shown when several members of the Columbus Police Department entered the theater, viewed segments of the film, arrested him and seized one copy of the film.

In case No. 71-737, appellants, Dominic Suriano and Frederick Young, were also convicted in the Franklin County Municipal Court of violating the same section. In this case, Suriano and Young were also arrested and one copy of the film being exhibited was seized as in case No. 71-736.

All the film in question was found to be obscene by the Municipal Court. No appeal was taken from that finding. The convictions were appealed, however, upon the contention that an adversary hearing must be held upon the question of the obscenity of a motion picture film before it may be seized and its exhibitors arrested.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgments [***2] of conviction and the causes are before this court pursuant to our allowance of motions for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed the affirmance of their convictions by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) on the charges that they unlawfully and knowingly exhibited obscene motion pictures in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.34 , following the seizures of the films complained of by members of the police department.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendants contested the warrantless seizures of the films and the failure of the State to afford them a prior hearing on the obscenity prior to seizing the films. Noting that no United States Supreme Court decision prohibited police officers from making a unilateral determination, after viewing a film, that it was obscene and arresting the exhibitor and seizing the film, the court affirmed the convictions and held that the seizures were not violative of U.S. Const. amend. I and XIV. Further, the seizures were not made for the purpose of preventing the film's dissemination, but to preserve the film to allow for their use as evidence in proceedings to determine defendants' culpability for criminal acts. Nor was a pre-seizure adversary hearing constitutionally required because, in each defendants' case, a single copy was seized for the sole purpose of preserving the film as evidence in defendants' criminal trials and only that one particular copy could no longer be disseminated. Moreover, the seizures were also allowable as an incident to a lawful arrest in order to prevent the concealment or destruction of evidence of the crime for which the arrest was made.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decisions of the court of appeals and remanded the causes to the trial court for execution of sentences.

 

54 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Dayton v. Cloud


No. 71-739


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 295; 285 N.E.2d 42; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 425; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 370



June 28, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

On February 12, 1958, by Resolution No. 1858, the city of Dayton formulated a plan for the renewal of the East Dayton area of the city, an area determined to be a blighted area appropriate for urban renewal. Pursuant to that plan, designated the East Dayton Urban Renewal Plan, the city proposes to finance a portion of the cost of the project by the method provided for in R. C. Chapter 725.

 R. C. 725.05 empowers a municipal corporation to issue unvoted urban renewal bonds, payable solely from revenues provided for in other sections of R. C. Chapter 725. R. C. 725.03 requires a municipal corporation, at the time it issues the bonds, to establish an urban renewal debt retirement fund, from which the principal and interest on the bonds are paid. R. C. 725.02 provides that all improvements to real property in an urban renewal area are a public purpose and exempt from real property taxation by all political subdivisions and taxing districts, commencing with the date of issuance of the bonds or acquisition of the property by the municipality. The exemption continues for as long as the urban renewal bonds are outstanding. This [***2] section imposes a condition to the exemption, wherein the municipality must certify that an exemption period be specified and that the agreement for service payments, provided for by R. C. 725.04, has been entered into and is in effect.

"Improvements," so exempted, are defined by R. C. 725.01(G) as "the increase in assessed valuation after the date of the adoption of an urban renewal plan of each parcel of real property or part thereof included within the boundaries of such urban renewal plan and owned in fee by the municipality on such date or acquired by the municipality after such date."

 R. C. 725.04 and 725.05 authorize the municipality to require each purchaser from it of real property in the urban renewal area to enter into an agreement, as a condition of purchase, to make semiannual urban renewal service payments, in lieu of taxes, upon the improvements made during the period of exemption. Such payments are to be equal to the amount of real property taxes which the purchaser would have paid on the improvements had there been no exemption, and are to be paid into the urban renewal debt retirement fund.

To finance the project by the method provided by R. C. Chapter 725, the [***3] city enacted Ordinance No. 23065 on August 7, 1968, to become effective on September 7, 1968. This ordinance provided for the issuance of $ 2,500,000 in principal amount of East Dayton Urban Renewal Bonds, payable solely from urban renewal debt retirement funds.

Section 4(c) of the ordinance, in accordance with R. C. 725.09, provides that the urban renewal bonds are not an obligation of the city.

This action under R. C. 133.71 et seq., the Validation of Securities Act, was instituted by the city of Dayton in order to determine the legality of the East Dayton Urban Renewal Bonds. Among the parties defendant named therein was The Miami Conservancy District which is the appellant in this court. The essential issue is the constitutionality of R. C. Chapter 725.

The Court of Common Pleas held R. C. Chapter 725 constitutional, in all respects but one. The court held R. C. 725.02 to be unconstitutional for the reason that the provision therein for partial exemption of real property, "when there exists no physically exempt use" was violative of Section 2, Article XII of the Ohio Constitution. The court also held that it could not determine, on the evidence before it, that there [***4] would be a contractually-binding obligation on the purchaser of affected property to make the payments to the city required to support the bonds, and therefore declined to issue an order validating the bonds.

The Court of Appeals, on authority of this court's decision in Denison University v. Board of Tax Appeals (1965), 2 Ohio St. 2d 17, reversed on the constitutional issue. However, it affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, insofar as that court declined to issue an order validating the bonds.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion filed by The Miami Conservancy District to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant conservancy district challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which held Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 725 constitutional, in all respects but one. The court held § 725.02 to be unconstitutional for the reason that the provision therein for partial exemption of real property, when there existed no physically exempt use, was violative of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2.


OVERVIEW: Appellee city sought to finance a plan to improve a blighted area. The issue was the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 725. The district contended that § 725.02, calling for a partial exemption of property from taxation where there was no physically severable exempt use, violated the uniform taxation requirements of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2. The district argued that § 2 operated as a limitation upon the power of the general assembly to authorize exemption of property from taxation, in that no exemptions could be granted to property not used for the specific purposes mentioned therein. The court held that the general assembly had plenary power to determine exemptions from taxation, limited only by the provisions of Ohio Const. art. I. Therefore, that art. XII, § 2, was not a constitutional prohibition against the issuance of urban renewal bonds in accordance with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 725. The district argued that the partial exemption violated Ohio Const. art. I, § 2, known as the "equal protection clause." The court found no constitutional prohibition against such partial exemption based upon value, so long as it did not otherwise violate the equal protection clause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, insofar as it upheld the constitutionality of the statute, and rendered final judgment in favor of the city.

 

55 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Howard v. Allen


No. 71-683


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 130; 283 N.E.2d 167; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 455; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 148



May 17, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This case involves a personal injury action for a money judgment.

Plaintiff, Carolyn G. Howard, suffered personal injuries on or about February 24, 1967, at an airport located in Greenville, South Carolina, when she was allegedly negligently struck by the propeller of an airplane being operated by defendant, Donald L. Allen.

On November 18, 1968, less than two years after receiving her injuries, plaintiff instituted an action against defendant for said injuries in the Court of Common Pleas, County of Spartanburg, state of South Carolina. In that action, plaintiff attempted to obtain jurisdiction over the defendant by causing the "attachment" of the limits of liability and duty to defend incident to defendant's policy of liability insurance. Defendant entered a special appearance in that action by a motion to quash service of summons and to vacate the warrant of attachment, which motion was sustained and plaintiff's complaint dismissed.

The plaintiff took an appeal from such dismissal to the appropriate Court of Appeals, and finally to the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The sole question decided on those appeals was whether [***2] the duty to defend and the limit of liability contained in a policy of liability insurance constituted a "debt" subject to attachment under South Carolina law. The Supreme Court of South Carolina decided that issue in the negative and affirmed the action of the trial court. The Supreme Court of South Carolina also stated that its determination was "otherwise than upon the merits" of the complaint. Howard v. Allen (1970), 254 S. C. 455, 176 S. E. 2d 127.

The initial decision of the Supreme Court of South Carolina was rendered on July 9, 1970, and its decision denying plaintiff's petition for rehearing was rendered on July 28, 1970.

On September 18, 1970, within a year after the final decision by the Supreme Court of South Carolina, plaintiff filed her complaint against defendant in the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County, Ohio. That complaint was superseded by plaintiff's amended complaint, filed on October 27, 1970. The amended complaint alleges a claim against defendant for personal injuries suffered by plaintiff on February 24, 1967; alleges that a prior action was brought in South Carolina; and alleges that such prior action failed "other than on the merits" in [***3] July of 1970.

Defendant filed his answer to the amended complaint on November 12, 1970, asserting, among other defenses not relevant to this appeal, that plaintiff's action is barred by Ohio's two-year statute of limitation and that the Ohio savings statute, R. C. 2305.19, is not available to plaintiff.

On November 20, 1970, defendant filed a motion for summary judgment, supported by affidavit which, in pertinent part, simply states that the South Carolina courts did not have jurisdiction over his person. On December 16, 1970, plaintiff filed her memorandum contra said motion, with copies of the decisions of the Supreme Court of South Carolina attached.

The Common Pleas Court sustained defendant's motion for summary judgment on the grounds that plaintiff's action was not commenced in Ohio within the two-year statute of limitation and that the Ohio savings statute is not applicable in this case.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, the judgment of the trial court was affirmed.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record and as an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff's complaint in South Carolina was dismissed. Within a year of the final decision in that case, plaintiff filed a personal injury suit in Ohio. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) granted defendant's motion for summary judgment because the suit was not commenced within the two-year limitation period and the savings statute did not apply. Plaintiff appealed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff alleged that she was struck by an airplane at an airport located in Greenville, South Carolina. Defendant was operating the airplane. Less than two years after plaintiff's injuries, she filed the South Carolina lawsuit. She unsuccessfully attempted to obtain jurisdiction over defendant by attaching the duty to defendant and liability under his insurance policy. The Supreme Court of South Carolina affirmed the dismissal of plaintiff's action and stated that its determination was otherwise than upon the merits. Plaintiff's Ohio complaint was filed within one year of the Supreme Court of South Carolina's decision and alleged that the prior action failed other than on the merits. On appeal, the court held that the Ohio saving clause, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.19, did not apply to actions commenced or attempted to be commenced in foreign states. The court stated that the two-year Ohio statute of limitation, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.10, controlled plaintiff's action. The court concluded that plaintiff's action was not commenced within the Ohio period of limitation even though her prior action was filed in the foreign jurisdiction within two years after it accrued.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the grant of defendant's motion for summary judgment.

 

56 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


InterCity Foods, Inc. v. Kosydar


No. 71-312


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 159; 283 N.E.2d 161; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 458; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 164



May 17, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

Plaintiff-appellee, Inter-City Foods, Inc., doing business as Bill's Diner, operates two restaurants, one located in Massillon, Ohio, and the other located in North Canton, Ohio. On November 27, 1968, the Tax Commissioner, after conducting a test check, assessed sales taxes against the plaintiff-appellee in the amount of $ 2,659.44 for the tax period beginning July 1, 1964, and ending August 31, 1967.

From that determination, appellee, on January 8, 1969, filed a notice of appeal with the Board of Tax Appeals. A hearing was held on June 20, 1969, and on November 19, 1969, the Board of Tax Appeals affirmed the order of the Tax Commissioner.

Pursuant to R. C. 5717.04, appellee, on December 17, 1969, filed a notice of appeal in the Court of Appeals for Stark County, alleging:

"1. The final order of the Board of Tax Appeals is unreasonable, unlawful, and against the manifest weight of the evidence.

"2. The evidence adduced on behalf of the Tax Commissioner is so manifestly in error, and the evidence adduced by the appellant is so manifestly credible and creditable, that the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals amounts to an unconstitutional [***2] taking of the appellant's property."

On December 24, 1969, the Tax Commissioner filed a motion to dismiss appellee's appeal, asserting that the notice of appeal did not set forth errors complained of as required by R. C. 5717.04, and thereby failed to invoke the jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals. The Court of Appeals overruled the motion, heard the case on its merits, and, on April 2, 1970, entered judgment for the appellee. The judgment voided all deficiency assessments, penalties and interests for the tax period from July 1, 1964, to August 31, 1967, holding appellee is not to be further civilly liable for that tax period.

The Tax Commissioner appealed that judgment to this court. The motion to certify the record was allowed and we limited oral argument to the question of the validity of the notice of appeal filed in the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio), which entered judgment for appellee taxpayer in the taxpayer's appeal of an assessment of sales taxes by the commissioner.


OVERVIEW: The tax commissioner assessed sales taxes against the taxpayer. The taxpayer filed a notice of appeal with the board of tax appeals, which affirmed the tax commissioner. The taxpayer then filed a notice of appeal in the court of appeals, which alleged that the board's final order was unreasonable, unlawful, and against the manifest weight of the evidence. The court of appeals entered judgment for the taxpayer. On appeal, the tax commissioner argued that where a taxpayer in his notice of appeal from a decision of the board of tax appeals to a court of appeals employed language so broad and general that the same language might apply in almost any case, the appellate court was not vested with jurisdiction to hear the appeal. The court affirmed the decision, holding that the notice of appeal to the court of appeals, which complained that the final order of the board was against the manifest weight of the evidence, enumerated with specificity an error that was adequate to vest jurisdiction in the court of appeals to hear the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

57 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Edgell


No. 71-106


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 103; 283 N.E.2d 145; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 454; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 134



May 17, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL as of right from the affirmance of the death penalty by the Court of Appeals for Noble County.

Appellant was tried by a jury on two counts of first degree murder and found guilty without a recommendation of mercy. The Court of Appeals affirmed without opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Noble County (Ohio) that upheld the judgment of the trial court convicting him of first-degree murder and sentencing him to death.


OVERVIEW: When he was arrested, defendant was in possession of a car belonging to a man who was missing. Defendant had other property belonging to the missing man and his clothing had blood on it. During questioning, defendant orally admitted that he had stabbed the missing man and hidden his body. Defendant did not seek to suppress these oral statements, but he did move to suppress on voluntariness grounds a tape-recorded statement that he made later to the prosecutor. The motion was denied and defendant was convicted. The conviction and death sentence were upheld by the appellate court and defendant appealed. In affirming, the supreme court ruled that the tape-recorded statements should not have been admitted because there was a gap in the tape at the point where defendant was being warned of his Miranda rights. The error was harmless, however, because the statements were consistent with the prior unobjected to statements and the other unchallenged evidence was so overwhelming that conviction was inevitable beyond a reasonable doubt, as was the jury's failure to recommend mercy. Also, it was not an abuse of discretion to deny defense counsel's motion to withdraw four days before trial.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate court on defendant's murder conviction and death sentence was affirmed.

 

58 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sidell


No. 71-511


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 45; 282 N.E.2d 367; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 463; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 74



May 3, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

Defendant, a student at Miami University residing in the Reservation Apartments in Oxford, Ohio, was arrested by Butler County deputy sheriffs on May 21, 1970, upon the charge of using obscene language directed toward police officers. An affidavit was filed charging that he "did disturb the peace and good order of the community by conducting himself in a disorderly manner by using obscene language to passing officers in the vicinity of the Reservation Apts., contrary to Section 3773.22 ORC of the state of Ohio."

The affidavit contained no allegation charging that defendant was intoxicated at such time, nor was any claim made by the prosecution that he was intoxicated. The trial court overruled defendant's motion to dismiss, concluding that an allegation and proof of intoxication was not required for conviction under the statute, and that conviction could be had merely upon proof that the defendant conducted himself in a disorderly manner.

The trial court found defendant guilty of a violation of R. C. 3773.22 and imposed a fine of $ 50 and costs. Defendant's motion for new trial was overruled. The Court of Appeals affirmed,  [***2] and the cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3773.22 for conducting himself in a disorderly manner by using obscene language to police officers. The charge contained no allegation that defendant was intoxicated at the time. The trial court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge and entered a judgment of conviction. The Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio) affirmed. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the conviction had to be reversed because there was no allegation or proof that defendant was intoxicated at the time of the incident and that, as a matter of legislative intent, the mere use of obscene language was not included within the prohibitions of § 3773.22. The court held that the trial court erred in its determination that the provision "shall conduct himself in a disorderly manner," found in the statute was a separate clause, under which defendant could have been convicted without proof of intoxication. The court, by reference to the legislative history of the statute and by application of the principle that ambiguity must be resolved against the state, concluded that the provision in question was not a separate and distinct clause of the statute. The court held that the statute specifically prohibited drunk and disorderly conduct, not merely disorderly conduct.


OUTCOME: The appellate court reversed defendant's conviction.

 

59 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Schreckengost


No. 71-489


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 2d 30; 282 N.E.2d 50; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 475; 59 Ohio Op. 2d 60



April 26, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

The record herein discloses that on August 21, 1970, an affidavit was filed in the Barberton Municipal Court charging that defendant did swim in a non-designated area, in violation of NRP 5-07 of the rules and regulations of the Ohio Division of Parks and Recreation.

To this affidavit defendant filed a motion to quash, asserting "that the law * * * [R. C. 1541.09], is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority of Article 2, Section 1 of the Constitution of the state of Ohio, and for other reasons equitable in the premises."

The trial court sustained the motion to quash on the basis, as stated in its entry, that " Section 1541.09 of the Ohio Revised Code is unconstitutional and void and constitutes an unlawful delegation of legislative power to the Division of Parks and Recreation and as a result Rule NRP 5-07, made in pursuance thereof, is void and of no effect."

The judgment of the trial court was premised on the holding, in its opinion, that R. C. 1541.09 "establishes no standards to guide the Division of Parks in enacting rules and regulations * * *."

The Court of Appeals reversed, 1 and the cause is here pursuant [***2] to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.


1 The majority opinion of the Court of Appeals, in effect, concluded that R. C. 1541.09 (and thus Rule NRP 5-07) was "not unconstitutional because of an unlawful delegation of legislative authority." One judge, while concurring, "in all aspects of this opinion," dissented from "the holding that the rule itself is constitutional" and expressed the opinion that "the rule as written is unreasonable in that it prohibits all swimming in the Portage Lakes except at state beaches."



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which reversed the judgment of a trial court that sustained defendant's motion to quash. Defendant had been charged with swimming in a nondesignated area, in violation of Ohio Div. of Parks and Recreation NRP 5-07. Defendant's motion to certify the record was allowed.


OVERVIEW: After defendant was charged for swimming in a nondesignated area, he filed a motion to quash, asserting that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1541.09 was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority under Ohio Const. art. 2, § 1. The trial court sustained the motion on the basis that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1541.09 was unconstitutional and void, and constituted an unlawful delegation of legislative power to the Ohio Division of Parks and Recreation. Thus, the trial court found that Ohio Div. of Parks and Recreation NRP 5-07 was void and of no effect. On appeal, the court of appeals reversed. The court affirmed and remanded the matter for further proceedings, finding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 151.09 was not unconstitutional because of an unlawful delegation of legislative authority. The state had authority to regulate swimming as well as the areas where swimming would be permitted on waters under its jurisdiction and control. Further, the court found that the state's delegation to state administrative officials of the authority to adopt and enforce regulations to implement such a declared legislative policy was not, per se, unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals and remanded the matter to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

60 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Tulley v. Brown


No. 72-196


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 2d 235; 281 N.E.2d 187; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 478; 58 Ohio Op. 2d 489



March 24, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relators filed a complaint in this court on March 10, 1972, seeking a writ of mandamus ordering the Attorney General of Ohio to "proceed with certification of the petition to amend the Constitution of Ohio by the initiative method." 1 That proposed amendment would add language to Section 8, Article XII, and is designed to prohibit certain collections or impositions of state taxes levied upon, or measured by, income after January 1, 1973. In substance, the complaint alleges that on February 24, 1972, relators filed with respondent Attorney General William J. Brown a petition, in several parts, for a proposed amendment to the Ohio Constitution; that on February 28, 1972, Attorney General Brown advised the relators that he had reviewed the petition and summary of the proposed amendment, had found said summary to be "a fair and truthful statement of the proposed * * * constitutional amendment," and was in the process of preparing the necessary certification to file with the Secretary of State. 2


1 See R. C. 3519.01.


2 Ibid.

 [***2] The complaint also contends that on March 1, 1972, before the certification was effectuated, other respondents herein filed an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County against the present relators, and against Attorney General Brown and Secretary of State Ted W. Brown, seeking, among other things, to prohibit the Attorney General from proceeding with his intended certification of the proposed amendment.

Relators allege further that the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County has ordered the Attorney General "to retain the proposed constitutional amendment and summary thereof pending (1) further order of this court, (2) order of the Supreme Court of Ohio in case No. 72-196 as so numbered in that court, but (3) in no event for more than fourteen (14) days from March 13, 1972, the date this order was announced in open court."

No answer has been filed by the respondents, although briefs have been filed by all parties.

Relators argue that the Court of Common Pleas' order constituted an abuse of discretion; that their remedy at law from such abuse is inadequate; and that further delay of this matter will irreparably impair the constitutional right of the voting public [***3] to act upon the proposed amendment.

The matter was presented to this court upon oral argument on March 22, 1972.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators filed a complaint seeking a writ of mandamus ordering the Attorney General of Ohio to proceed with certification of the petition to amend the Constitution of Ohio by the initiative method.


OVERVIEW: Respondents contended that relators were not entitled to a writ of mandamus because a pending trial court action constituted a plain and adequate remedy in the ordinary course of the law. The court disagreed and allowed the writ. The court held that in the instant case, the Attorney General had unequivocally stated that he found the summary in question "fair and truthful" under Ohio Rev. Code § 3519.01 and stood ready to certify. Therefore, the court held that relators had met their burden in all respects concerning this writ.


OUTCOME: The court allowed the writ of mandamus ordering the Attorney General of Ohio to proceed with certification of the petition to amend the Constitution of Ohio by the initiative method.

 

61 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Soller v. West Muskingum Local Board of Education


No. 71-180


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 2d 148; 280 N.E.2d 382; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 490; 58 Ohio Op. 2d 347



March 8, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County.

The relator, Raymond Soller, appellant herein, commenced this action in the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County, praying that a writ of mandamus be issued compelling the respondent, the West Muskingum Local Board of Education, appellee herein, to return him to his position as a bus driver, with compensation from the commencement of the 1970-1971 school year, and to furnish him with a continuing contract of employment.

The initial nonteaching contract between Mr. Soller and the Board of Education was for one year, beginning on September 1, 1966.

On July 24, 1967, the same parties entered into another one-year contract, to begin on September 1, 1967. On June 20, 1968, Soller and the board entered into a two-year contract, to commence at the start of the 1968-1969 school year.

On May 13, 1970, Soller was notified by the board of its intention not to re-employ him at the expiration of the two-year contract.

The Court of Appeals denied the writ, and an appeal as of right brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator employee sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County (Ohio), which denied him a writ of mandamus to compel respondent board of education to return him to his position as a bus driver with past compensation and to furnish him with a continuing contract of employment.


OVERVIEW: The employee was hired by the board of education as a bus driver under two successive one-year contracts. The employee was then hired under a two year contract. The board of education then notified the employee that his contract would not be renewed. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3319.081 governed contracts with non-teaching school employees. The statute was amended prior to the execution of the two year contract and provided that employees with more than three years of service prior to the effective date of the amended statute would be entitled to a continuing contract of employment. The employee brought an action for mandamus to compel the board of education to return him to his position and to grant him a continuing contract of employment. The court of appeals denied the writ. The court affirmed the judgment, holding that the employee did not have three years of service as of the effective date of the amended statute and therefore that he was not entitled to a continuing contract.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

62 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Edgecomb v. Rosen


No. 71-139


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 2d 114; 279 N.E.2d 870; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 494; 58 Ohio Op. 2d 312



March 1, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On January 1, 1968, Catherine J. Edgecomb, appellee herein, assumed the office of Clerk of the Cuyahoga Falls Municipal Court pursuant to her election to that office the preceding November. At the time she assumed office, her salary was computed in accordance with R. C. 1901.31(C), which reads, in relevant part:

"* * * the clerk [of a Municipal Court] shall receive annual compensation in a sum equal to eighty-five per cent of the salary of a judge of such court. * * *"
