The computation of compensation paid to Municipal Court judges on January 1, 1968, was in accordance with R. C. 1901.11 and on that date fixed Municipal Court judges' salaries at "seven thousand five hundred dollars per annum, plus an amount equal to three cents per capita for the first fifty thousand of the population of the territory; two cents per capita for the population of said territory of more than fifty thousand and not more than one hundred thousand; one cent per capita for the population of such territory of more than one hundred thousand and not more than three hundred thousand; and one-half cent per capita for the population of such territory of [***2] more than three hundred thousand * * *."

However, on June 10, 1968, six months after appellee assumed office, R. C. 1901.11 was amended and now fixes Municipal Court judges' salaries at "ten thousand dollars per annum, plus an amount equal to twelve cents per capita for the first forty thousand of the population of the territory in which he resides when elected or appointed * * * [and] ten cents per capita for the population of said territory of more than forty thousand. * * *"

As a result of the increase in salary afforded Municipal Court judges, appellee alleges her entitlement to a similar increase in salary based upon the 85% formula of R. C. 1901.31(C), which has remained unchanged.

Appellee filed this suit in mandamus on June 23, 1970, requesting that the finance director of Cuyahoga Falls, and the county treasurer and county auditor of Summit County be ordered to pay her the appropriate increase in salary allegedly due her under R. C. Chapter 1901 and Article IV of the Ohio Constitution. The Court of Appeals allowed the writ of mandamus, thus commanding that the salary of the Clerk of the Cuyahoga Falls Municipal Court be increased during her term of office.

The cause [***3] is before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a town finance director, the county treasurer, and the county auditor, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which allowed a writ of mandamus, commanding that the salary of appellee, the clerk of a municipal court, be increased during her term of office under Ohio Const. art. IV and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 1901.


OVERVIEW: The clerk argued that, despite the provision of Ohio Const. art. II, § 20, she was entitled to a salary increase during term because: 1) her office was a "provided for" position under Ohio Const. art. IV, § 6 and the prohibitions of Ohio Const. art. II, § 20 thus did not apply; and 2) the application of the existing statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C), required a recalculation of her salary based upon the increase allowed to municipal court judges. The court disagreed because the salary terms in § 1901.31(C), although pre-set themselves, required a legislative act providing an increase in the salary of the municipal court judge to, in turn, provide an increase for the clerk. By granting an increase to municipal court judges, the legislature concomitantly made a "change" in the compensation of municipal court clerks to whom the provisions of § 1901.31(C) were applicable which would "affect" the salary of such clerks. Such a change was prohibited by Ohio Const. art. II, § 20 from affecting the salary of any officer during his existing term. Therefore, the clerk was not entitled to the increase allowed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

63 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Willoughby Hills v. Corrigan


No. 70-764


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 2d 39; 278 N.E.2d 658; 1972 Ohio LEXIS 507; 58 Ohio Op. 2d 100



February 2, 1972, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

Cuyahoga County owns and operates the Cuyahoga County Airport, a portion of which extends into the village (now city) of Willoughby Hills in Lake County.

In April 1963, the Boards of County Commissioners of Cuyahoga and Lake counties, acting as "the airport zoning board" pursuant to the provisions of R. C. 4563.03(B), 1 adopted certain airport zoning regulations for the "airport hazard area." 2


1 R. C. 4563.03(B) reads:

"When an airport is publicly owned and any airport hazard area appertaining to such airport is located in more than one political subdivision, the board of county commissioners of each county in which such airport or such airport hazard area may exist, shall constitute the airport zoning board, which shall have the same power to adopt, administer, and enforce airport zoning regulations as provided in division (A) of this section. The board shall elect its own chairman."


2 Defined by R. C. 4563.01(C) as follows:

"'Airport hazard area' means any area of land adjacent to an airport which has been declared to be an 'airport hazard area' by the Division of Aviation in connection with any airport approach plan recommended by such division."

 [***2] In accordance with the provisions of R. C. 4563.03(A), 3 the board divided the airport hazard area into zones, 4 and within such zones regulated and restricted certain land uses. The regulation provided, within each zone, graduated height restrictions with reference to structures and natural growth and certain use restrictions. 5


3 R. C. 4563.03(A) reads, in part:

"* * * Airport zoning regulations may divide an airport hazard area into zones, and, within such zones, regulate and restrict land uses which by their nature constitute airport hazards, and regulate and restrict the height to which structures may be erected or objects of natural growth may be allowed to grow. An obstruction of air space in an airport hazard area rising to a height not in excess of forty feet above the established elevation of the airport, or three feet for each one hundred feet or fraction thereof its location is distant from the nearest point in the perimeter of the airport, whichever is greater, shall be prima facie reasonable."


4 The zones were designated as (1) Runway Landing Areas, (2) Approach Zones, (3) Transitional Zones, (4) Horizontal Zone, and (5) Conical Zone.

 [***3] 

5 The use restrictions herein specifically prohibited such uses as would result in electrical interferences with radio communication and lighting which would impair visability or make it difficult to distinguish airport lights, and generally prohibited any use which would "otherwise endanger the landing, taking-off, or maneuvering of aircraft * * *."

In November 1968, the village of Willoughby Hills filed suit in the Common Pleas Court of Lake County, naming as defendants all of the members of the Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Board, and the members of the "airport zoning commission." 6 Alleging that "the constitutional right of plaintiff exclusively to enact and to enforce zoning regulations within its territorial limits has been infringed," that R. C. Chapter 4563 "violates Section 3, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution," and that plaintiff "has been damaged" by the zoning regulations adopted by the airport zoning board, the village of Willoughby Hills sought an order of the court that R. C. Chapter 4563 be declared unconstitutional and that the board be enjoined "from enforcing any zoning [***4] regulations within the territorial limits of the plaintiff."


6 See R. C. 4563.05.

The trial court sustained a motion to make the petition definite and certain by setting "forth facts in what respect the plaintiff Willoughby Hills has been damaged." Thereafter, an amended petition was filed, joining as additional parties plaintiff, James A. and Bessie Chongris and Anton J. and Mildred F. Oblak. The amended petition alleged, inter alia, that:

"13. Plaintiff Willoughby Hills Village has been damaged by the aforementioned activities of defendants in that said plaintiff cannot properly plan and zone for the development of that portion of its territory under the alleged jurisdiction of the Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Board, said power and duty being imposed upon said plaintiff by virtue of the provisions of Section 713.02 et seq. of the Revised Code of Ohio. Additionally the activities of defendants as aforesaid are causing the property values of real property within the area alleged to be subject to [***5] the jurisdiction of the defendants to be depressed, with a resulting loss of tax revenues to said plaintiff.

"14. Defendants wrongfully contend that the real property of the individual plaintiffs is subject to the jurisdiction and regulations of Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Board, and said plaintiffs have been caused by such contention of the defendants to suffer a diminution in the value of their said real property."

During trial, plaintiffs Oblak were voluntarily dismissed as parties. The trial court, considering the evidence adduced at trial, found "that there is no evidence to support the contention of the plaintiffs Chongris that their property has suffered an impairment of use or a diminution in value by reason of the enactment and enforcement of the Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Regulations."

As to the plaintiff Willoughby Hills, the trial court found "that there is no evidence of interference with the right of the village of Willoughby Hills under Article XVIII, 3, Ohio Constitution, to control development of the lands and to adopt zoning regulations within its jurisdiction."

The trial court found further that R. C. Chapter 4563 "is a constitutional exercise of state [***6] legislative authority and does not violate the Ohio, or the United States Constitution"; that R. C. Chapter 4563 "and the Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Regulations enacted pursuant thereto, provide for regulations for the operation of public airports and for the safety and welfare of persons, both above and on the ground, and are, therefore, legitimate matters for state legislation and regulations adopted pursuant thereto"; and that the regulations "complement without nullifying the Village of Willoughby Hills Municipal Zoning Regulations operating within the perimeter of the Airport Hazard Area, and are constitutionally enacted and in compliance with the statutes of Ohio."

The trial court entered judgment in favor of defendants.

The Court of Appeals reversed, finding "that the owners of property located in the 'Airport Hazard Area' in the airspace directly above their property through which airplanes approach and leave the Cuyahoga County Airport, own at least as much space above their property as they can occupy and use"; that R. C. 4563.03, "which creates the power of an Airport Zoning Board to regulate and restrict land uses and the height of structures and natural growth, constitutes [***7] a taking of property interest without due process of law and the Cuyahoga County Airport Zoning Regulations issued pursuant thereto, are unconstitutional, being a violation of the due process clauses of the constitutions of the United States and Ohio"; and that the regulations, "enacted under the authority of Section 4563.03 of the Revised Code of Ohio, are not zoning regulations under the exercise of police power, but constitute the taking of private property without compensation * * *."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record and as an appeal as of right involving a substantial constitutional question.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant village challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio) that reversed the trial court and found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4563.03 constituted a taking of property interest without due process of law, that the county airport zoning regulations enacted by appellees, airport zoning board and zoning commission, were unconstitutional, and that the regulations were the taking of private property without compensation.


OVERVIEW: The Board divided the airport hazard area into zones and within such zones restricted certain land areas. The village alleged that its constitutional right to exclusively enact zoning regulations within its territorial limits was infringed, that it violated the state constitution, and that the village was damaged by the zoning regulations. The trial court found that the law was a constitutional exercise of state legislative authority and did not violate the constitution and that the regulations were legitimate matters for state legislation. On appeal, the court reversed and agreed with the trial court. The evidence did not show an impairment of use or diminution in value of the village's property. The airport zoning regulation adopted were designed to reduce airport hazards and could constitutionally be adopted as an exercise of the state's police power when they were reasonably necessary to insure the safety of aircraft in landing and taking off and the safety of persons using the area. There was no claim of frequent low flights over the village's land. The invasion of the airspace was not shown to have affected the present use or any reasonably foreseeable use of the land.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

64 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


United Air Lines, Inc. v. Porterfield


No. 71-120


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 2d 97; 276 N.E.2d 629; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 408; 57 Ohio Op. 2d 288



November 26, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The instant case is a challenge by appellant, United Airlines, Inc. (United), against an assessment of the Ohio Airline Excise Tax levied against it under R. C. Chapter 5745. The contested assessment was made by the Tax Commissioner in the sum of $ 75,083.72 in taxes, to which he added a penalty of $ 11,262.56 for a total of $ 86,346.28. This is an appeal as of right from the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals dated February 5, 1971, affirming the determination of the Tax Commissioner.

We are called upon to determine whether the airlines excise tax (R. C. Chapter 5745), as applied to appellant, is violative of the Commerce Clause of the Constitution of the United States or the due process provisions of the Constitutions of Ohio and the United States. 1 Appellant also seeks determination of whether the Tax Commissioner has abused his discretion in refusing to remit the penalty assessment.


1 Article I, Section 8, Clause 3, United States Constitution; Article I, Section 16, Ohio Constitution; Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, United States Constitution.

 [***2] United Airlines, Inc., a Delaware corporation, is a common carrier by air which has been doing business in Ohio since 1935. On August 18, 1969, Amended House Bill No. 689 (R. C. Chapter 5745) became law. During the third quarter of 1969, the taxable period in question, United serviced six airports in the state of Ohio under authority of three certificates of public convenience and necessity issued to United by the Civil Aeronautics Board, an agency of the federal government.

Appellant holds no certificate of public convenience and necessity from the state of Ohio, nor requires one to render the above service. Ohio neither licenses nor regulates United in any manner.

Pursuant to its federal certificates of public convenience and necessity, United engages in four kinds of flights over the state of Ohio. There are flights crossing some portion of the state but not landing in Ohio; flights originating in Ohio and terminating out of state; flights originating out of state and terminating in Ohio; and flights stopping over at one or more points within the state, but incident to an out-of-state origin or destination. Clearly, the first type flight is not a subject of the airlines [***3] excise tax.

United is not authorized to have flights originating and ending within the state. Any flight that serves two points in Ohio must originate or terminate out of state. However, United does carry passengers and goods whose origin and destination are points in Ohio.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant airline sought review of the judgment of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) which affirmed a tax assessment made by appellee Tax Commissioner under the Ohio Airline Excise Tax, Ohio Rev. Code ch. 5745. The airline argued that the tax was violative of the Commerce Clause of the Constitution of the United States or the due process provisions of the Constitutions of Ohio and the United States.


OVERVIEW: The airline contested the Ohio Airline Excise Tax as a violation of interstate commerce and due process. Affirming the judgment of the Board, the court held that the local "in-state" activity could have been the proper subject for taxation even though it was an integral part of interstate commerce, so long as the tax did not place interstate commerce at a competitive disadvantage with local commerce. The court noted that the tax in the case at bar was equally applicable to both interstate and intrastate commerce and did not discriminate against either. Ohio Rev. Code § 5745.02 fairly apportioned the tax between in-state and out-of-state activities. The tax was not considered incompatible with the United States Constitution because the tax did not condition doing business on the state on the payment of the tax. Furthermore, state regulation of the airline industry did not provide immunity from state taxation under the Commerce Clause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision.

 

65 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Protestants & Other Americans United for Separation of Church & State v. Essex


No. 70-583


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 2d 79; 275 N.E.2d 603; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 412; 57 Ohio Op. 2d 263



November 24, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Appellants brought this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, seeking to have R. C. 3317.06(H), as effective December 1, 1967, declared unconstitutional. After consideration of the evidence and stipulations, that court held that the statute was constitutional. The Court of Appeals affirmed, holding that the statute was not violative of the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States or Section 2 of Article VI of the Constitution of Ohio.

The cause is before this court as an appeal involving a constitutional question and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals of Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's determination that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3317.06(H) was not violative of the First Amendment or Ohio Const. art. VI, § 2. Appellants had filed a declaratory judgment action against appellees, seeking to have § 3317.06(H) declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Appellants commenced an action against the appellees, seeking a declaration that § 3317.06(H) was unconstitutional. The trial court determined that § 3317.06(H) was not violative of the First Amendment or Ohio Const. art. VI, § 2. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's judgment. The court affirmed the appellate court's decision. The court held (1) that the materials and services provided by § 3317.06 (H) did not lend themselves to the religious aura of the recipient sectarian schools, but rather enhanced only the secular educational process and that process was properly the concern of the State; and (2) that the degree of contact between church and State permitted by § 3317.06(H) was no more than minimal and was no more involved than the contact which presently existed in the schemes of aid distribution that had been approved of previously.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's affirmance of the trial court's determination that the statute was constitutional.

 

66 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Gordon


No. 71-264


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 2d 45; 276 N.E.2d 243; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 415; 57 Ohio Op. 2d 180



November 10, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On April 8, 1968, Ralph Gordon was convicted and sentenced for a violation of R. C. 4549.04(B), operating a motor vehicle without the owner's consent. On October 15, 1969, he was indicted under the same section, and for "second offense" under R. C. 4549.99 which states that "for each subsequent offense such person shall be imprisoned not less than one nor more than twenty years." The subsequent offense penalty is considerably harsher than the first offense penalty.

The issue of "second offense" was submitted to the jury, along with the question of guilt or innocence on the current "operating" charge, without limiting instructions from the court on the use of prior convictions and without defense counsel's objection or request for such instructions.

The jury found the fact of prior conviction true and also found the defendant guilty of the second "operating" charge. A motion for a new trial was overruled.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals (26 Ohio App. 2d 270, 271 N. E. 2d 300) reversed the judgment of the trial court and ordered a new trial, holding that it was not necessary to submit the issue of the prior conviction to [***2] the jury where the fact of such conviction was relevant only for the purpose of enhanced punishment, and where such conviction was "not an element of the offense for which the accused was being tried." The court found also that the cumulative effect of the prosecutor's statement to the jury regarding the prior conviction, the sending and reading of the indictment (containing the "second offense" averments) to the jury, and the failure of the trial court to instruct the jury as to the limited purpose for which such prior conviction should be considered constituted error prejudicial to the defendant.

The cause is before this court pursuant to our allowance of the prosecutor's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for operating a motor vehicle without the owner's consent, a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.04(B), and for "second offense," a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.99. The matter came before the court pursuant to the allowance of the State's motion for leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: The trial court found defendant guilty of operating a motor vehicle without the owner's consent and of second offense. The appellate court reversed the trial court's judgment, finding that the cumulative effect of the prosecutor's statement to the jury regarding defendant's prior conviction, the sending and reading of the indictment containing the second offense averments, and the trial court 's failure to instruct the jury as to the limited purpose for which they should consider the prior conviction constituted error prejudicial to defendant. The court concluded that it was essential that the indictment or information aver that the offense charged was a second or subsequent offense before a greater punishment could be inflicted. Defendant faced a possible felony conviction for the second offense, while the first offense was only a misdemeanor. The State had to be put to its proof regarding the identity of the accused in the prior offense and had to demonstrate the fact of the prior offense beyond a reasonable doubt. The jury then had to find that fact to be established and also convict defendant of the second violation in order for the court to impose the greater punishment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, affirmed the trial court's judgment, and remanded the cause to the trial court for execution of sentence.

 

67 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Smith v. Ohio Valley Ins. Co.


No. 71-236


Supreme Court of Ohio


27 Ohio St. 2d 268; 272 N.E.2d 131; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 447; 56 Ohio Op. 2d 160



July 21, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

This case involves questions of interpretation and constitutionality of the Ohio Insurance Guaranty Association Act, R. C. Chapter 3955 (133 Ohio Laws 2939), effective September 4, 1970, in its application to the insolvency of the Ohio Valley Insurance Company.

The pertinent facts are included in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Superintendent of Insurance challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which determined that the Ohio Guaranty Association Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3955 was constitutional as applied retroactively, and that it applied to appellee insolvent insurance company despite the fact that the insurance company was insolvent prior to September 4, 1970.


OVERVIEW: The Act became effective September 4, 1970, and the insurance company had claims that existed prior to that date. The insurance company was continuously insolvent from December 31, 1969, but was not decreed insolvent and ordered to liquidate until November 27, 1970. The Superintendent argued that the Act was prospective in nature and was unconstitutional retroactively because it became operative only upon the happening of an event subsequent to the effectiveness of the lower court's decree. The lower court held that the Act was constitutional and that it applied to the liquidation proceedings of the insurance company despite the company's insolvency prior to the Act's effective date. The court agreed with the lower court and held that a claim already in existence against an insurance company prior to the effective date of the Act, on September 4, 1970, was not a "covered claim," as defined by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3955.01(B). The court held that the definition of "covered claim" was, as a matter of English grammar, in the present tense, not the past tense. The Act's definition spoke of an unpaid claim "which arises," not one "which arose."


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment against the Superintendent.

 

68 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Monroeville v. Ward


No. 70-135


Supreme Court of Ohio


27 Ohio St. 2d 179; 271 N.E.2d 757; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 780; 56 Ohio Op. 2d 110



July 14, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Huron County.

Defendant-appellant, Clarence Ward, was found guilty in the mayor's court of the village of Monroeville of failing to comply with a lawful order of a police officer, and for refusing to produce his driver's license upon request by a police officer. Defendant was fined $ 50 and costs on each offense.

Defendant's convictions were affirmed by the Court of Common Pleas, and appeals in both were consolidated for hearing in the Court of Appeals.

At oral argument in the Court of Appeals that court raised the question "whether the amendment of Section 4(B) of Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, adopted on May 7, 1968 * * * deprived the General Assembly of power to confer appellate jurisdiction on the Common Pleas Court to review the judgment of the mayor's court."

That question was briefed by counsel, and the Court of Appeals, holding that such an appeal is still maintainable, affirmed the judgments. (21 Ohio App. 2d 17.)

The causes are before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the Court of Appeals for Huron County (Ohio), which affirmed two convictions that were initially entered by the mayor's court, then affirmed by the common pleas court. Defendant challenged the power of the common pleas court to review the judgment of the mayor's court under Ohio Const. art. IV, § 4(B) and Ohio Rev. Code §§ 1905.22, 1921.01, 2953.02.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty in the mayor's court of failing to comply with a lawful order of a police officer, and for refusing to produce his driver's license upon request by a police officer. He was fined on each offense. Defendant's convictions were affirmed by the court of common pleas. On a consolidated appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the judgment. Defendant contended that the common pleas court lacked jurisdiction to review the mayor's court's judgment. On a motion to certify the record, the court held that Ohio Const. art. IV, §§ 1,4 did not clearly prohibit the establishment of provisions for the review of mayor's court's decisions by the courts of common pleas. The court found that the language of Ohio Const. art. IV, § 1 was broad enough to support jurisdiction under Ohio Rev. Code §§ 1905.22, 1921.01, 2953.02 despite the wording of Ohio Const. art IV, § 4(B). Likewise, the court opined that even though the revenue produced from the mayor's court provided a substantial portion of the municipality's funds, that fact did not mean that the mayor's impartiality was so diminished thereby that he could not act in a disinterested fashion in a judicial capacity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions.

 

69 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


House of Seagram, Inc. v. Porterfield


No. 70-732


Supreme Court of Ohio


27 Ohio St. 2d 97; 271 N.E.2d 827; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 453; 56 Ohio Op. 2d 55



July 7, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The state of Ohio, Department of Liquor Control, purchased liquor, hereinafter referred to as State Stock Items, from appellee, House of Seagram, at its place of business in New York. Seagram delivered the liquor, at its place of business, to a common carrier designated by the state of Ohio, and it was then brought into Ohio and delivered to a state warehouse.

On November 18, 1968, appellant, Tax Commissioner, issued an assessment of a franchise tax against Seagram pursuant to R. C. 5733.05. The franchise tax was computed by the use of a property fraction and a business done fraction as directed by R. C. 5733.05.

The property fraction was derived from a numerator composed of Seagram's Ohio property and a denominator composed of its total property. No question is raised herein as to the accuracy of the property fraction.

The Tax Commissioner determined the business done fraction by including within the numerator, as business done in Ohio, all sales of liquor by Seagram to the state of Ohio. The dispute herein involves only the numerator of the business done fraction. The denominator of this fraction includes all sales by Seagram wherever [***2] and to whomever made.

On November 25, 1968, appellee applied for a reduction in its assessment, contending that its sales originated outside of Ohio and thus that none of such sales could be included in the Ohio business-done ratio fraction set forth in R. C. 5733.05.

The Tax Commissioner affirmed the original assessment. Seagram then appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals.

The Board reversed the Tax Commissioner's ruling in part stating that "* * * State Stock Items were items delivered to the carrier for the state of Ohio, outside the state of Ohio and therefore not to be included in the business done fraction." The board affirmed the Tax Commissioner only to the extent that "bailment stock" sales (items owned by Seagram and held at an Ohio warehouse until needed by the Department of Liquor Control) were included in the numerator.

The Tax Commissioner appealed from that decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, and the cause is before this court as an appeal of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner challenged a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), to the extent that it reversed the commissioner's calculation of appellee taxpayer's property and business done fractions under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5733.05 for franchise tax assessment. The commissioner determined the business done fraction by including within the numerator, as business done in Ohio, the taxpayer's sales of liquor to the state of Ohio.


OVERVIEW: The state of Ohio bought liquor from the taxpayer, a foreign corporation, at its place of business in New York. The taxpayer delivered the liquor to a common carrier designated by Ohio, and it was then brought to Ohio and delivered to a state warehouse. The commissioner assessed taxes against the taxpayer, and the dispute involved only the numerator of the business done fraction. The commissioner included, as business done in Ohio, the taxpayer's sales to the state of Ohio. The taxpayer claimed that the sales originated outside of Ohio and were not included. The commissioner affirmed the assessment, and the Board reversed in part, stating that the liquor delivered to Ohio's carrier outside Ohio was not included. On appeal, the taxpayer claimed that where an Ohio buyer selected the carrier and took delivery outside Ohio, the sale was not done in Ohio, although the goods were ultimately received there. The court disagreed and reversed. Sales to an Ohio buyer, delivered by the seller to a carrier outside Ohio and ultimately received in Ohio was business done in Ohio and was included in the numerator of the business done fraction, regardless of which party designated the carrier.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Board's decision to the extent it reversed the commissioner's order.

 

70 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Capello v. Mayfield Heights


No. 70-493


Supreme Court of Ohio


27 Ohio St. 2d 1; 271 N.E.2d 831; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 463; 56 Ohio Op. 2d 1



June 30, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Plaintiff-appellants, desiring to erect an automatic car wash, along with gasoline pumps, on certain land in the city of Mayfield Heights, filed an application for a building permit for such construction with the building commissioner. The commissioner refused to issue a permit, and an appeal was taken by appellants to the Board of Zoning Appeals.

A hearing was conducted by the Board of Zoning Appeals, at which appellants' counsel presented letters from adjoining property owners who did not object to the proposed use. Counsel outlined the proposed use and presented, as a witness, one of the applicants, Vince Capello, Jr., who gave testimony on the approximate cost of the installation. He stated that car wash customers would be given a discount on gasoline.

The Board of Zoning Appeals upheld the decision of the building commissioner. Appellants requested city council to override the zoning board's decision. The matter was tabled by council, and appellants lodged an appeal in the Court of Common Pleas.

Pursuant to R. C. 2506.02, appellants requested that a transcript of the proceedings be prepared and submitted by the Board [***2] of Zoning Appeals to the Court of Common Pleas.

The deputy city clerk thereupon submitted a transcript which contained copies of appellants' application, exhibits relative to location and description of the property, letters and minutes of the hearing before the Board of Zoning Appeals.

As to appellants' statement at the hearing, the minutes read:

"Mr. Robiner stated that his clients proposed to install a 'Big Barney' auto wash which is completely automatic. No interior cleaning, -- the customer stays in the car. The only attendant is the person who takes the money; the charge will be $ 1.00. The gas pumps would be at the rear of the building, the nearest being 165 ft. back of the sidewalk. The operating hours are proposed to be from 8:00 a. m. until 8:00 or 9:00 in the evening. Mr. Robiner further stated that they will be able to store approximately 70 cars on the property because of its depth. There would be ingress and egress from Mayfield and S.O.M. Center roads. If this is not sufficient, they have provisions for two more lanes. The auto wash can handle about 120 cars per hour. Mr. Capello, Jr., stated that there would probably be a discount of some sort for the people [***3] who buy gasoline to have their cars washed. He stated that the approximate cost of the combined installation would be $ 125,000 not including the land. Mr. Robiner stated that to deny their request would be arbitrary, capricious, unreasonable, confiscatory and unconstitutional. He requested a decision from the board as soon as possible."

Before the hearing in the Court of Common Pleas, appellants filed an affidavit in accordance with R. C. 2506.03 stating that:

"(A) The transcript does not contain a report of all evidence admitted or proffered by the appellant.

"(B) The appellant was not permitted to appear and be heard in person or by his attorney in opposition to the order appealed from:

"(1) To present his position, arguments and contentions;

"(2) To offer and examine witnesses and present evidence in support thereof;

"(3) To cross-examine witnesses purporting to refute his position, arguments and contentions;

"(4) To offer evidence to refute evidence and testimony offered in opposition to his position, arguments and contentions;

"(5) To proffer any such evidence into the record, if the admission thereof is denied by the officer or body appealed from.

"(C) The testimony [***4] adduced was not given under oath.

"(D) The appellant was unable to present evidence by reason of a lack of the power of subpoena by the officer or body appealed from or the refusal, after request, of such officer or body to afford the appellant opportunity to use the power of subpoena when possessed by the officer or body.

"(E) The officer or body failed to file with the transcript, conclusions of fact supporting the order, adjudication or decision appealed from; in which case, the court shall hear the appeal upon the transcript and such additional evidence as may be introduced by any party. At the hearing, any party may call as if on cross-examination, any witness who previously gave testimony in opposition to such party."

At the hearing, the Court of Common Pleas permitted appellants to present additional evidence. Appellants then presented testimony by Vincent Capello, Jr., Robert W. Fairless, a real estate consultant, the mayor, the chairman of the planning and zoning commission and the building commissioner.

After the hearing the Court of Common Pleas made the following journal entry:

"Based upon the record of proceedings and transcript filed in this appeal, and excluding [***5] the additional evidence produced at the time of the hearing before this court, the court finds that the determination of the Board of Zoning Appeals, based upon what evidence it had before it, is reasonable and is supported by reliable and probative evidence, and is therefore affirmed."

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas. The cause is now before this court following allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant applicants challenged a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court in favor of appellees, the City of Mayfield Heights (Ohio) and its Board of Zoning Appeals, upholding the Board's administrative decision denying the applicants' application for a building permit.


OVERVIEW: At a hearing before the Board, the applicants presented letters from adjoining property owners who did not object to the proposed use, outlined the proposed use, and presented, as a witness, one of the applicants, whose testimony was not sworn. Upon denial of their application, the applicants appealed to the trial court. A transcript was submitted which contained copies of the application, exhibits related to the property, the letters, and minutes of the hearing. The applicants filed an affidavit under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506.03 stating that the transcript did not contain a report of all evidence admitted or proffered. The trial court received additional evidence but sustained the Board's decision solely on the transcript of the proceedings before the Board. The trial court's judgment was affirmed by the court of appeals. On further appeal, the court reversed, reasoning that the trial court erred in basing its decision solely on the transcript of the proceedings before the Board because the transcript did not contain reliable and probative evidence to support the Board's decision. There was no sworn testimony, and no evidence was offered in opposition to the application.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' decision, which affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of appellees upholding the administrative denial of their application for a building permit.

 

71 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kaufman v. Newburgh Heights


No. 70-221


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 2d 217; 271 N.E.2d 280; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 485; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 462



June 23, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

Elliott M. Kaufman purchased a vacant parcel of land located at the northwest corner of Harvard Avenue and East 49th Street in Newburgh Heights, a nonchartered municipal corporation. Kaufman's application for a permit to build a gasoline service station thereon was rejected by the village building commissioner for the reason that it would have violated the municipal zoning code.

Although the Harvard Avenue frontage is zoned for retail business which would permit the service station, this zone extends less than one-third of the property depth along the East 49th Street curb line and as little as 15 feet at the west boundary. Thus, the entire parcel is, for all practical purposes, restricted to residential uses.

Harvard Avenue, within the village of Newburgh Heights, is a heavily travelled four-lane highway and, excluding a municipally-owned park area, both sides of the right of way are zoned for retail or commercial uses to a depth of at least 100 feet except the corner parcel belonging to Kaufman. The other three corners of the Harvard Avenue and East 49th Street [***2] intersection are occupied by the village hall, including the police and fire departments with appropriate parking facilities, the city of Cleveland automotive repair yards, and a retail gasoline service station.

An intersection traffic count prepared by the Cuyahoga County Engineer's office shows that over 20,000 vehicles have used the Harvard Avenue-East 49th Street intersection during a given 12-hour period.

The adjacent property to the north of the intersection is residential and so zoned on the west side of East 49th Street. On the opposite side is a publicly owned park including the village hall. The street is a four-lane thoroughfare carrying southbound truck, bus and auto traffic from Willow Freeway to Harvard Avenue.

Before the building permit was requested, Kaufman's application to the village council for a change of the residential portion of the property to retail zoning had been unanimously rejected.

After the refusal of his building permit and without appealing to the Newburgh Heights Board of Zoning Appeals, Kaufman filed this declaratory judgment action in the Court of Common Pleas, alleging unconstitutionality of the zoning ordinance as applied to his corner location,  [***3] and sought a mandatory injunction against the building commissioner. The Common Pleas Court held for the village, finding the zoning ordinance reasonable, valid and constitutional.

The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that the zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as applied to the property in question, and that an exhaustion of administrative remedies was not a prerequisite to the declaratory judgment action in this case.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant village sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County that reversed a trial court's judgment, which found in favor of the village in appellee applicant's declaratory judgment action. The appellate court held that a zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as applied to the property in question, and that an exhaustion of administrative remedies was not a prerequisite to the declaratory judgment action.


OVERVIEW: The applicant's request for a building permit was denied. Instead of seeking review by the village board of zoning appeals, the applicant filed a declaratory judgment action, alleging that the zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as applied. The trial court entered judgment for the village and held that the ordinance was valid. The appellate court reversed, holding that the ordinance was unconstitutional as applied to the property and that an exhaustion of administrative remedies was not a prerequisite to the declaratory judgment action. On further review, the court held that the applicant did have the right to attack the constitutionality of the ordinance without first appealing to the board of zoning appeals because the village had only delegated to its board of zoning appeals the power to review and correct an interpretation of the zoning regulations by the administrative officers charged with their enforcement. There was no such interpretation involved in the denial of the applicant's request for a permit. Therefore, because no effectual or adequate administrative remedy was available to the applicant, he was entitled to seek a declaratory judgment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

72 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Park Inv. Co. v. Board of Tax Appeals


No. 68-277


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 2d 161; 270 N.E.2d 342; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 497; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 338



June 2, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

ON MOTION to show cause.

The facts of this case are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator investment company filed a motion with the court to require respondent board of tax appeals to show cause why it should not have been adjudged in contempt for failing to perform its statutory duty as required by a previous order to assess all real property within the state at a uniform percentage of its true value.


OVERVIEW: In a prior action, the board was ordered to perform its statutory duty under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.24, which imposed an obligation upon it to establish a uniform statewide rule for the determination of the taxable value and assessment of real property. After the board proposed an amendment to its rules for assessing real property, the legislature amended Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5715.01, providing in part that the board's power to issue rules concerning the determination of the taxable value of real property was not to be effective for another two years. The board then took no further steps to implement the court's prior order. The company then filed an action to show cause why the board should not have been adjudged to be in contempt. On review, the court held that the legislature's amendment purporting to delay the board's action was in conflict with Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2 mandating the taxation of land by uniform rule according to value. The court noted, however, that the board took steps to comply with the original order and ceased its efforts only because it thought it was powerless to proceed further. The court concluded, therefore, that the board was not in contempt.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to hold the board in contempt.

 

73 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Carter


No. 70-174


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 2d 79; 269 N.E.2d 115; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 518; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 130



April 21, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

On February 10, 1968, at 2:30 or 2:45 p. m., a man armed with a gun entered Pantorium Cleaners in Dayton and robbed Mrs. Rasberry, one of the employees on duty, of the money in the cash register. She and another employee, Miss Edna Bolan, were ordered into a back room by the robber, told to disrobe, throw their clothes out and stay in the room for ten minutes. They followed the robber's instructions, and when they came out of the back room, it was discovered that the telephone cord had been severed and that $ 10 was missing from Miss Bolan's purse.

Defendant, Lewis Carter, was later indicted on two counts of armed robbery based on the above-described incidents.

At the trial, both victims identified defendant as the robber. The state introduced evidence through testimony of Patrolman Armstrong that one hour before he was called to Pantorium Cleaners to investigate the robbery there he also investigated a robbery at the Golden Point Drive-Inn which was located approximately 15 blocks from Pantorium Cleaners.

Ann Collins, an employee of Golden Point, testified in the trial that on February 10, 1968, at a little after 3:00 [***2] p. m., while at work, she was robbed at the point of a gun and that she and Mrs. Holden, another employee, were forced into a back room, ordered to disrobe, and that the robber ripped the telephone from the wall before he fled.

Neither of the Golden Point robbery victims made a positive in-court identification of defendant as being the robber, but both testified that they had identified defendant as the robber in a police lineup. Both described the robber as having a scar on his face; they stated that he wore a dark trench coat and that he carried a black gun or automatic.

Another state's witness, Detective Beutle, testified that he took a black raincoat, or trench coat, from defendant's home after his arrest, as well as a blank-shooting automatic gun.

The jury returned verdicts of guilty as to the count of armed robbery of Mrs. Rasberry, and not guilty as to the count involving Miss Bolan.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment and the cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed the decision of the trial court that convicted him of armed robbery.


OVERVIEW: A series of robberies were committed. Defendant was arrested for two of them. At trial, the State introduced testimony of witnesses to different robberies. The witnesses were unable to positively identify defendant, but they described him and his car. Defendant's motion to suppress the testimony was overruled. Defendant's conviction was upheld on appeal. When defendant appealed further, the court affirmed. The standard of proof for the admission of similar acts into evidence under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.59 was not proof beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant had committed the similar acts. The testimony had been relevant to the issue of the robber's identity. The State had only been required to offer substantial proof that the similar robberies were committed by defendant. The State had accomplished this. Therefore, the evidence was properly admitted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

74 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 69-551


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 2d 43; 268 N.E.2d 807; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 522; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 40



April 7, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In 1956, petitioner was convicted as an habitual criminal ( R. C. 2961.12), and no direct appeal was taken from that judgment. In 1968, petitioner's petition to vacate the judgment was denied by the Court of Common Pleas. The Court of Appeals affirmed and the cause is now before this court pursuant to our allowance of petitioner's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) affirming the trial court's denial of his motion to vacate a judgment convicting him as an habitual criminal, a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2961.12.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner sought to vacate his 1956 conviction as an habitual criminal on the ground that his 1944 conviction for burglary and larceny, upon which his 1956 conviction was based, was void because he pleaded guilty without being advised of his right to an attorney and, thus, did not knowingly or intelligently waive his right to counsel. The court noted that in denying petitioner post-conviction relief with respect to his 1956 criminal conviction, the trial court made a factual determination that petitioner had not knowingly and intelligently waived his right to counsel with regard to his 1944 conviction but determined that the error was not reviewable in petitioner's postconviction proceeding. The court held that justice and logic required a determination of the constitutional viability of petitioner's habitual criminal conviction and that the constitutional infirmities relating to his 1944 conviction should be considered without requiring petitioner to file additional appeals or postconviction proceedings because the matter would ultimately arrive back at the court in essentially the same posture. Thus, the court reversed the court of appeals' judgment and remanded.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment and remanded for further proceedings.

 

75 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Jackson


No. 70-579


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 2d 51; 268 N.E.2d 812; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 523; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 45



April 7, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

Petitioner, Albert Jackson, on April 13, 1970, was convicted of two charges of driving while intoxicated by the Middletown Municipal Court, was sentenced to 20 days in the Butler County Jail and fined $ 683.

After the expiration of his jail sentence, Jackson was held in jail for nonpayment of the fine, credit being provided at $ 10 per day pursuant to a rule * adopted by the Butler County Common Pleas Court, purportedly applicable to all prisoners held in that jail.


* The trial herein took place after the holding of this court on December 17, 1969, in Strattman v. Studt, 20 Ohio St. 2d 95, that a credit of $ 3 per day on a fine, under R. C. 2947.20, was unconstitutional when applied to an indigent, and before the amendment of R. C. 2947.20, effective September 3, 1970, providing for a credit of $ 10.

Thereafter Jackson filed an original action in the Court of Appeals for Butler County, asserting that the imprisonment was without legal authority in [***2] that he was indigent and totally unable to pay the fine.

The Court of Appeals denied the petition for writ of habeas corpus. This cause is now before this court as an appeal as a matter of right, the case having originated in the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio) that denied his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was convicted of driving while intoxicated. He was sentenced to a term of imprisonment and fined. After the expiration of his jail sentence, petitioner was held in jail for nonpayment of the fine. He filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus with the appellate court asserting that the imprisonment was without legal authority in that he was indigent and totally unable to pay the fine. On review, the court reversed the appellate court's judgment that denied the writ. In so doing, the court followed precedent established by the United States Supreme Court, which held that as to indigent defendants converting a fine into a prison term was inconsistent with the equal protection clause. Therefore, the court concluded that petitioner's fine should not have been converted into a prison term while he remained indigent and without the means to pay the fine. However, the court noted that if petitioner's financial status changed, then a different result was possible. Because there was no constitutional infirmity in imprisonment of a defendant with the means to pay who refused or neglected to do so.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment.

 

76 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Meeker


No. 69-838


SUPREME COURT OF OHIO


26 Ohio St. 2d 9; 268 N.E.2d 589; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 525; 55 Ohio Op. 2d 5



March 31, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

By a four-count indictment returned by the Grand Jury of Lake County in April 1969, defendant, appellant herein, was charged with (1) armed robbery (R. C. 2901.13), (2) stealing a motor vehicle (R. C. 4549.04[A]), (3) cutting with intent to wound (R. C. 2901.23), and (4) assault with intent to commit robbery (R. C. 2901.24). All these crimes are alleged to have been committed on April 26, 1963, and it appears that all of such offenses are connected with the alleged robbery of a filling station owned and operated by one William Balch.

Defendant was apprehended in June 1963, and by affidavit was charged in the Painesville Municipal Court with armed robbery. Upon entering a plea of "guilty" in that court, he was bound over to the Grand Jury. A few days later, in the Common Pleas Court, he waived indictment and entered a plea of guilty to an information charging him with armed robbery.

For reasons not clearly shown in the record, in November 1963 defendant was permitted to withdraw his plea of guilty to armed robbery, as charged  [***2] in the information, and to plead guilty to the lesser included offense of robbery. He was then sentenced to the Ohio Reformatory at Mansfield. During all of such time defendant was not represented by counsel.

On March 3, 1969, in a postconviction proceeding, defendant's motion for vacation of sentence and for new trial was granted by the Court of Common Pleas on the ground that defendant had not been advised of his right to court-appointed counsel and that there had been no knowing and willing waiver of his right to counsel.

The order of the Common Pleas Court gave defendant the option of waiving indictment by the Grand Jury or requiring indictment. 1.


1 Appellee apparently concedes that at this point of time defendant would have been permitted to again plead guilty to unarmed robbery, its brief stating:

"The appellant, after his original sentence was set aside, could have plead by way of information to the charge of unarmed robbery, but as a usual tactic of the defense, perhaps he hoped to have his case dismissed by the Grand Jury in view of the fact that witnesses many times do not remember the person who committed the crime or that they may not be available to testify because they may have moved.".

 [***3] Defendant chose not to waive indictment. The Grand Jury, in April, 1969, returned the four-count indictment. Defendant, represented by counsel, then filed a motion in the Common Pleas Court seeking an order prohibiting the state from trying him on any charge other than unarmed robbery. The court treated the motion as a motion to quash all four counts of the indictment, overruled it as to count one (armed robbery), and sustained it as to the other three counts.

At the same time, defendant also filed a motion for an order "crediting him with time served in prison under the vacated sentence." While stating that "defendant's request for credit against any future sentence is premature, as the mere statement of it shows," the court's opinion and journal entry also stated that "credit must be ordered for prison time served upon the original sentence," and that "I will order it * * *.".

The state appealed to the Court of Appeals the action of the Common Pleas Court quashing the counts of the indictment charging theft of a motor vehicle, cutting with intent to wound, and assault with intent to commit robbery, and the action of the Common Pleas Court in stating that it "will order" a credit  [***4] against any future sentence.

The Court of Appeals reversed the judgment quashing the three counts of the indictment and remanded the cause "for proceedings under all four counts of the indictment." It further concluded that the question of credit on any future sentence did not appear to be "directed to a final appealable order.".

This cause is now before this court upon appeal pursuant to the allowance of defendant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a second prosecution, defendant appealed the reversal by the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio) of a judgment of the trial court that quashed counts in an indictment of stealing a motor vehicle, cutting with intent to wound, and assault with intent to commit robbery, leaving only a count for armed robbery. The court of appeals reinstated the quashed counts. In the first prosecution defendant was convicted but then granted a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in 1969 with the instant offenses in connection with the robbery of a gas station in 1963. He was originally charged in municipal court with armed robbery in 1963. He entered a guilty plea and was bound over to the grand jury. A few days later, in common pleas court, he waived indictment and entered a plea of guilty to a charge of armed robbery. He was then permitted to withdraw that plea and to plead guilty to the lesser included offense of robbery. During all of the proceedings, defendant was not represented by counsel. In a postconviction proceeding defendant was granted a new trial. Defendant decided not to waive indictment, and when the grand jury returned the indictment at issue here, he sought to prohibit the State from trying him on any charge other than unarmed robbery. The common pleas court quashed three of the counts, but the court of appeals reversed. The court reversed again, finding that defendant's speedy trial rights had been violated by the unjustifiable delay of six years in commencing the instant prosecution. The delay was unjustified because the State had all the necessary facts to charge defendant with the three quashed counts in 1963.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded.

 

77 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Berry


No. 70-404


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 255; 267 N.E.2d 775; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 541; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 374



March 17, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Defendant, Jefferson Thomas Berry, was indicted on two counts of first degree murder for the killing of Juanita Perkins and James Arthur Hartman. On August 6, 1968, the bodies of both victims were found in a badly decomposed state in the Beverly Apartments, located on Gilbert Avenue in Cincinnati, Ohio. The testimony of a medical expert indicated that the approximate time of their deaths was four days prior to August 6, 1968. Another expert witness testified that a .38 caliber weapon was used in the killings.

At the time of the voir dire examination, the defendant sought to have juror number 5, Marion C. Rogers, excused for cause. This challenge was denied. After the seating of twelve jurors, the defense and the prosecution began the alternate exercise of peremptory challenges to dismiss jurors, each using five.

The prosecutor then stated: "The state is satisfied with the jury as it is now constituted." Defendant then exercised his sixth, and final, peremptory challenge, on juror Rogers. After overruling a defense objection, the court allowed the prosecutor to exercise his final peremptory challenge on juror number [***2] 6, Martha Herche, who had been seated at the time of the prosecutor's above-quoted statement.

At trial, the state introduced evidence showing that, at about 10:00 p. m. on August 2, 1968, the defendant was seen by participants in a "crap" game being held in front of the K. T. Lounge on Gilbert Avenue, across the street from the apartment where the bodies were found. Defendant approached and entered the game. Two players in the game testified that they noticed a bulge under his (Berry's) shirt, and stated that it appeared to be the outline of a gun. After an argument, Berry left the game.

Ernest Zanders, Robert Smith and Maurice Smith, witnesses for the prosecution, testified as to the events following Berry's departure from the game. The former two testified that after leaving the game Berry walked "down the street," while Maurice Smith stated that after leaving Berry headed "in the direction" of the Beverly Apartments.

The testimony of those three witnesses next reveals that shots (or what sounded like a cap pistol to Maurice Smith), and the sound of a woman screaming "Oh, my God," were heard from the direction of the Beverly. There was no testimony as to how much time elapsed [***3] between Berry's departure from the game and those sounds; but the witnesses did state that about three to five minutes thereafter, Berry appeared in the middle of Gilbert Avenue, seemingly crossing the street towards the "crap" game. After asking for a ride, and being refused, Berry began walking up Gilbert Avenue towards Deerfield.

State's witness Arthur Wright, a former co-worker of the defendant's, testified that prior to August 2, 1968, he had twice seen Juanita Perkins at the defendant's residence; that he had seen Berry with a .38 special gun and had tried unsuccessfully to purchase it from him. Wright also stated that, in a conversation at work sometime in the summer before August, Berry had told him that Juanita Perkins had left him and gone with "Arthur * * * a cab driver"; that Berry had threatened to "catch them, them two together, he was going to kill them."

During their deliberations, the jury twice requested information from the court with respect to certain testimony. In response to the requests the trial judge related to the jury his recollection of one witness's testimony, and had read to the jury from the transcript certain portions of testimony of one witness,  [***4] and the complete testimony of four witnesses.

The jury returned a verdict of guilty on both counts of the indictment, without a recommendation for mercy. Defendant's motion for a new trial was overruled, and his appeal to the Court of Appeals resulted in an affirmance of the trial court's judgment. Defendant's appeal is now before this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which convicted him on two counts of first degree murder, without a recommendation for mercy.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with and convicted of first-degree murder. The convictions were based on mostly circumstantial evidence. On appeal, defendant contended that the trial court erred when it allowed the prosecution to exercise its sixth peremptory challenge on a juror after the prosecutor had expressed satisfaction with the jury, that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.21 was unconstitutional, that the verdicts were against the manifest weight of the evidence, that the refusal to dismiss a juror for cause deprived him of a fair trial, that the trial court permitted improper questioning, and that the trial court abused its discretion when it allowed testimony to be read to the jury. The court affirmed because § 2945.21 was not unconstitutional and the passing of a turn had operated as a waiver of the right to make peremptory challenges. The court was convinced that the convictions were not against the weight of the evidence and that there was no error in the refusal to excuse a properly interrogated juror for cause. There was no error in the trial court's evidentiary rulings. Finally, the trial court properly allowed part of the testimony to be read to the jury during deliberations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions on two counts of first degree murder.

 

78 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati Motor Transp. Asso. v. Lincoln Heights


No. 70-120


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 203; 267 N.E.2d 797; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 544; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 317



March 10, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Plaintiffs trucking companies brought an action in the Court of Common Pleas to enjoin the enforcement of Ordinance No. 69-2 of defendant, city of Lincoln Heights, which prohibits the operation upon Shepherd Lane, a residential street, of vehicles weighing more than 20,000 pounds. In their petition, plaintiffs pray that "said ordinance be declared invalid without legal effect, unconstitutional, null and void to the extent that it restricts the use of Shepherd Lane * * *."

Plaintiffs also allege in their petition that:

"A substantial portion of the outgoing and incoming over-the-road traffic from the aforesaid terminals of the plaintiff carriers proceeds from their terminals to Interstate Route 75 for both northerly and southerly destinations and/or originations. The shortest, safest and only reasonable way to travel between said terminals and Interstate Route 75 is over Shepherd Lane as it traverses the city of Lincoln Heights and all of said traffic involves motor vehicles capable of carrying loads which would increase their gross weight to in excess of the minimum prescribed by said Ordinance 69-2."

The trial court stated,  [***2] in its opinion, that:

"Since 1967, at the time of the development and location of plaintiffs' businesses in their present locations, truck traffic over Shepherd Lane has increased to a considerable degree and as a result thereof has increased the noise, vibration and safety hazards to some fifty families residing along Shepherd Lane between Wayne Avenue and I-75. There is evidence that the vibrations have caused damage to homes in the area and the wear on Shepherd Lane has increased as a result of the additional heavy traffic.

"The evidence also discloses that there are alternate routes through the city of Lockland and/or through the city of Lockland and Cincinnati to gain access either northbound or southbound on I-75; that the use of the alternate routes would involve extra mileage for plaintiffs' trucks, the making of 90 degree turns in the city of Lockland, and travelling through areas involving as many as 300 homes."

The trial court also said that, "by reason of its almost entirely residential make-up, the city of Lincoln Heights acted in a reasonable and lawful manner in enacting Ordinance 69-2 and that said ordinance is therefore constitutional."

The court denied the injunction [***3] and entered judgment for defendant city, holding "that Ordinance No. 69-2 of the city of Lincoln Heights, Ohio, is reasonable in operation and effect; that said ordinance is, in all respects, valid and constitutional."

That judgment was appealed to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact. That court found as follows:

"The effect of the ordinance before us is, substantially, to exclude trucks carrying or capable of carrying otherwise legal loads from the city of Lincoln Heights. The ordinance prohibits all east-west movement through the city of such traffic and does not provide any route as an alternative to the use of Shepherd Lane to gain access to Interstate Route 75, either northbound or southbound.

"The city attempts to refute this by urging that plaintiffs do have alternative routes over which to travel to I-75 through the city of Lockland. The evidence before us discloses that such routes are circuitous, through congested areas and considerably longer than the direct path afforded were the use of Shepherd Lane not prohibited."

The Court of Appeals concluded that:

"Ordinance No. 69-2 of the city of Lincoln Heights is invalid and unconstitutional in that it prohibits [***4] unreasonably the use by trucks of a street which is adequate to accommodate them without providing a reasonable alternate route through Lincoln Heights. Such prohibition is unnecessarily oppressive and bears no discernible relationship to the end sought to be achieved."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which in an action by plaintiff trucking companies determined that a city ordinance prohibiting vehicles of specified weights from using certain streets with the city was unconstitutional because it was unnecessarily oppressive and bore no discernible relationship to the end sought to be achieved.


OVERVIEW: A city ordinance dictated that vehicles over a specified weight could not use a particular city street. Alternate routes were available for the larger vehicles, although the alternate routes were often less direct. On appeal, the court held that the ordinance was constitutional. The court held that the city was allowed to reasonably control the weight of vehicles using its highways and streets and that the limitations in the disputed ordinance were reasonable. The means adopted by the ordinance bore a real and substantial relation to their purpose and were suitable to the end in view. Furthermore, the availability of alternate routes supported the reasonableness of the ordinance. The fact that the alternate routes were circuitous or that the prohibited route was the shortest route were not sufficient to establish that the ordinance was either unduly oppressive or that it interfered with private rights beyond the necessities of the situation. The evidence in the court of appeals demanded a finding that the ordinance was reasonable and lawful.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and rendered final judgment in favor of the city.

 

79 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Bedford Heights v. Tallarico


No. 70-7


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 211; 267 N.E.2d 802; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 545; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 321



March 10, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellant was arrested, tried and convicted on a charge of violating Sections 1.3 and 1.4 of Codified Ordinance 1701.01 of the city of Bedford Heights. The Court of Appeals upheld her conviction and the cause is now before us pursuant to our allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which upheld defendant's conviction pursuant to Bedford Heights, Ohio, Codified Ordinance 1701.01, §§ 1.3, 1.4.


OVERVIEW: The affidavit upon which defendant stood trial stated that defendant, as owner of certain premises, refused upon request to permit the fire chief to enter and inspect at a reasonable hour said premises for the purpose of determining the cause of a fire that occurred on October 23, 1967, in said premises. On appeal, defendant urged the court to declare Ordinance 1701.01 unconstitutional and, also, to determine that she was convicted upon insufficient evidence. The fire chief testified that he phoned the home of the person he thought owned the apartment in question. When he asked the woman who had answered the phone if he could search the apartment, she told the chief to get a warrant. Defendant's conviction was based solely on the chief's testimony concerning his telephone conversation with the woman, whom he alleged was defendant. The fire chief was unable to recognize defendant's voice over the telephone or in person. The court held that the evidence was insufficient to support defendant's conviction where the fire chief could not identify that defendant was indeed the person he spoke to on the phone.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction. The court entered final judgment for defendant.

 

80 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Fox v. Morrison Motor Freight, Inc.


No. 70-128


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 193; 267 N.E.2d 405; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 553; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 301



March 3, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Plaintiff's decedent, Harry E. Fox, an Ohio resident, was killed in a collision in Illinois between the tractor-trailer he was operating and a tractor-trailer operated by defendant's employee. Both drivers were engaged in trips which had begun, and would have ended, in Ohio.

The defendant corporation, which was authorized to, and was doing business in Ohio, maintained trucking terminals in Akron, Mansfield, Warren and Cleveland. Plaintiff, Helen G. Fox, was appointed administratrix of the estate of Harry E. Fox, and brought this action on behalf of her decedent's next of kin, herself and her minor children, praying for damages in the sum of $ 750,000. Defendant, Morrison Motor Freight, Inc., offered to confess judgment in the amount of $ 30,000, the maximum amount of damages recoverable under the then existing Illinois Wrongful Death Act (Section 2, Chapter 70, Illinois statutes) and moved that the trial court rule that damages could not exceed that amount. At the close of plaintiff's opening statement the Court of Common Pleas, holding applicable the Illinois statutory limitation on the amount plaintiff could recover, entered [***2] judgment against defendant in the amount of $ 30,000. The judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals. A motion to certify the record having been allowed, the cause is now before this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, decedent's survivors, appealed an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the decision of a court of common pleas limiting the survivors' recovery in their suit for wrongful death to $ 30,000, pursuant to the Illinois Wrongful Death Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 70, para. 2.


OVERVIEW: The decedent, an Ohio resident, was killed in a collision in Illinois when the tractor-trailer he was driving was struck by a tractor-trailer operated by defendant trucking company's employee, also an Ohio resident. Both drivers began their trips in Ohio and would have ended them there. Decedent's survivors filed suit in an Ohio court of common pleas for wrongful death against the trucking company. The trucking company argued that Illinois law applied and offered to confess judgment for the limits of the Illinois Wrongful Death Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 70, para. 2. The court of common pleas entered judgment for the survivors in that amount. On appeal, the court held that the rule of lex loci delicti was not applicable because Ohio had substantial governmental interests in the litigation due to its concerns that the next of kin of an Ohio resident be fairly compensated and that the decedent's estate be lawfully administered. Illinois, however, had no interest in the suit. The trucking company employee admitted liability for negligence, and therefore, Illinois did not even have the interest of compelling compliance with its traffic laws.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the court of common pleas.

 

81 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Fleischman v. Flowers


No. 69-615


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 131; 267 N.E.2d 318; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 556; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 265



February 24, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This is an action under the Ohio Workmen's Compensation Act in which plaintiff-appellee, a school teacher who fell on a flight of stairs at a school and received personal injuries, seeks an award based on the "percentage of his [her] permanent partial disability resulting from the injury" under the provisions of R. C. 4123.57.
