The facts are not in dispute, having been stipulated in the trial court.

Plaintiff was employed by the Cleveland Board of Education. When she fell, on September 30, 1964, she sustained a fracture of the third metacarpal of her left hand, and abrasions and contusions over other parts of her body. A cast was applied and was worn for seven and one-half weeks.

Her claim was allowed by the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation, and medical bills paid. She received no temporary total compensation, being absent from work for only three days, and has never received any compensation for partial disability. As the result of the injury, plaintiff, who is left-handed, has permanent residual disability diagnosed as fibrositis of the paracapsular structures of the left ring finger, resulting in limitation of motion.

 [***2] Plaintiff, on September 16, 1966, filed with the Industrial Commission an application for a determination of the percentage of her permanent partial disability resulting from the injury. Her application was dismissed on the basis that it did not comply with the requirements of paragraphs (A) and (B) of R. C. 4123.57, as amended October 1, 1963.

Upon appeal, the Common Pleas Court held that certain provisions of R. C. 4123.57, as amended in 1963, prescribing "eligibility" requirements for filing an application for an award of compensation under paragraph (B) thereof, were unconstitutional, and ordered the Industrial Commission to determine the extent of plaintiff's permanent disability, if any, without regard to said provisions.

The judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court as an appeal involving a substantial constitutional question and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Ohio Bureau of Workmen's Compensation sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which entered judgment affirming a lower court's ruling that held that certain provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.57 were unconstitutional and that ordered the Ohio Industrial Commission to determine the extent of appellee schoolteacher's permanent disability without regard to said provisions.


OVERVIEW: The teacher suffered a fracture of a bone in her dominant hand when she fell at work. The Bureau allowed her claim for medical bills and, having only missed three workdays, she received no temporary total compensation and never subsequently received any compensation for partial disability. As a result of the injury, however, she was left with permanent residual disability. The Commission dismissed her application for a determination of her permanent partial disability on the grounds that it did not comply with § 4123.57. The court affirmed the lower courts' judgments in favor of the teacher. Noting that § 4123.57 limited eligibility to file applications for such determinations to only those persons who have received compensation for temporary total disability, who would have been eligible for compensation for temporary total disability had the employer not paid such person wages during the period of disability, or who did receive compensation for partial disability based on impairment in earning capacity, the court held that the provisions led to arbitrary and capricious results and therefore violated the equal protection requirements of Ohio Const. art. II, § 26.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, which sustained the judgment of the lower court in favor of the teacher.

 

82 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. De Golyer


No. 69-253


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 101; 267 N.E.2d 282; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 564; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 232; 48 A.L.R.3d 1318



February 17, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The defendant was charged by affidavit in the Hamilton County Municipal Court, Criminal Division, for failure to pay the city of Cincinnati income tax for the year 1966. The appellant moved for an order quashing the affidavit on the ground that the tax ordinance, by its terms, makes the tax a debt and that the provision for criminal liability, including a fine and imprisonment, violates Section 15 of Article I of the Constitution of Ohio.

The trial court sustained the motion, quashed the affidavit and discharged the appellant.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County reversed the trial court.

The cause is before this court upon an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's decision that sustained defendant's motion to quash an affidavit that charged him with failure to pay city income taxes pursuant to Cincinnati, Ohio, Income Tax Ordinance § 12.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with failure to pay the city income tax. Defendant moved for an order quashing the affidavit on the ground that the tax ordinance made the tax a debt and that the provision for criminal liability, including a fine and imprisonment, was unconstitutional. The trial court sustained defendant's motion, quashed the affidavit, and discharged defendant. The appellate court reversed the trial court's judgment. On further appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the tax ordinance did not violate Ohio Const. art. I, § 15, which provided that no person could be imprisoned for debt in any civil action except in cases of fraud. The court found that a debt was an obligation to pay money and that a tax was a debt. One could not be imprisoned for mere failure to pay taxes. Because the tax ordinance contained the term "refuse," which implied willfulness or intent, the court held that only a wilful failure or refusal to pay the tax was punishable by imprisonment. Therefore, the tax ordinance did not violate the constitutional prohibition against imprisonment for debt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

83 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Gates Mills Inv. Co. v. Parks


No. 69-724


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 16; 266 N.E.2d 552; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 574; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 157



February 3, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On February 5, 1965, Gates Mills Investment Company, appellee herein, submitted to the planning commission of the village of Pepper Pike, Ohio, a plat for a subdivision of land. The commission refused to approve the plat. Appellee then filed a petition in the Court of Common Pleas, seeking a decree requiring the Recorder of Cuyahoga County to record the plat of the proposed subdivision. Named as defendants were members of the village council and the planning commission of the village of Pepper Pike and the Recorder of Cuyahoga County. The trial court found that the plat was entitled to be recorded. The Court of Appeals affirmed that judgment, and the cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a village council, its planning commission, and a county recorder, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment in favor of appellee developer on its suit seeking a decree requiring the county recorder to record the plat of the proposed subdivision. The cause was before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify.


OVERVIEW: The developer submitted to the planning commission a plat for a subdivision of land. The commission refused to approve the plat. The developer filed a petition seeking a decree requiring the county recorder to record the plat of the proposed subdivision. The trial court found that the plat was entitled to have been recorded and the court of appeals affirmed. Appellants sought review. Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 711.09, the legislative authority of a village which had a planning commission was not permitted to legislate a plan or rules and regulations governing plats and subdivisions of land. Under § 711.09 the village legislative authority could only have adopted a plan if there was not commission. The village had a commission, and therefore, it was not permitted to have adopted the ordinances constituting the village plan. Accordingly, the commission's refusal to approve the plat was based on village ordinances which were improper under § 711.09.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the developer.

 

84 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Thompson


No. 70-334


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 2d 26; 266 N.E.2d 571; 1971 Ohio LEXIS 575; 54 Ohio Op. 2d 162



February 3, 1971, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Defendant-appellant, Thomas A. Thompson, and another person were observed by a control tower operator at the Port Columbus Airport at about 4:00 a. m. on December 20, 1968, pushing automobile tires toward a car in the airport parking lot. The two men placed three tires alongside the car and then entered the car. Some minutes later, a police officer, who had been summoned by the control tower operator, approached the two men who were still seated in the parked car. The officer asked them what they were doing and was told that they had been looking for a set of keys which had been lost in the parking lot. They denied rolling the tires, which were then up against the passenger side of the vehicle in which they were seated, to this car, and an examination of other vehicles in the parking lot failed to reveal any with missing wheels and tires.

The police officer arrested appellant and seized the tires. Subsequently, appellant was charged with being a suspicious person. The affidavit filed by the officer recited that appellant "* * * did unlawfully loiter and wander about a public place, street, to wit: Port Columbus parking [***2] lot * * * to wit: Was prowling cars, trying to get into them, and was seen rolling tires from rental car area to side of his car * * *. Sect. 2387.02 G without being able to give a reasonable and satisfactory account of himself, contrary to the ordinance of said city * * *."

At appellant's trial in Municipal Court, the arresting officer testified that from the time of arrest to the date of trial no one had claimed the seized tires and there had been no report that they were stolen.

Appellant's motion to dismiss the affidavit on the ground that the Columbus suspicious person ordinance, Section 2387.02 (G), was unconstitutional was overruled by the trial court. Appellant was found guilty and sentenced to 60 days in the workhouse and fined $ 100 and costs.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, appellant renewed his contentions in relation to the constitutionality of the ordinance. That court held the ordinance to be constitutional and affirmed the judgment of the Municipal Court. However, the Court of Appeals found its judgment to be in conflict with a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in the case of Cleveland v. Forrest, case No. 28,446, and certified [***3] the cause to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction for being suspicious person, a violation of Columbus, Ohio, Ordinances § 2387.02(G). Defendant raised the constitutionality of the ordinance as grounds for his appeal. Although the Court of Appeals for Franklin County held that the ordinance was constitutional and affirmed the conviction, it certified the cause to the court for review and final determination.


OVERVIEW: After defendant was observed by a control tower operator at an airport pushing tires toward a car in the airport parking lot at 4:00 a.m., defendant was arrested and charged with being a suspicious person under § 2387.02(G). Defendant was convicted as charged, and he appealed claiming that the ordinance under which he was convicted was unconstitutional. The appellate court held that the ordinance was constitutional and affirmed defendant's conviction. The appellate court, however, certified the cause to the court for review and final determination. The court reversed the appellate court's judgment. Wandering about, as it applied under the ordinance to all citizens, was too indefinite, restrictive, and liberty depriving to have satisfied due-process requirements. The ordinance left the public uncertain as to the conduct it prohibited and left judges and jurors free to decide, without any legally fixed standards, what was prohibited and what was not in each particular case. Thus, the ordinance lacked ascertainable standards of guilt and violated the due-process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Consequently, it was invalid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, which held that the city ordinance penalizing a person for wandering the streets was constitutional and affirmed defendant's conviction under that statute.

 

85 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Moorehead


No. 70-80


Supreme Court of Ohio


24 Ohio St. 2d 166; 265 N.E.2d 551; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 360; 53 Ohio Op. 2d 379



December 30, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL as of right in a capital case from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

Clitus Moorehead was convicted by a three-judge panel of murder in the first-degree, without a recommendation of mercy. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas and the appellant is in our court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment, as of right, from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment from a trial court convicting and sentencing defendant for murder in the first-degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the introduction of evidence which tended to show the commission of a crime for which defendant had not been indicted was prejudicial and deprived defendant of an impartial and fair trial. On appeal, however, the court upheld the appellate court's judgment upholding defendant's conviction and sentence. Specifically, the court first held that the evidence of an episode at a motel was admissible because it tended to prove all the important elements of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.59, mainly defendant's intent, motive, lack of mistake, scheme, and final action. Secondly, the court rejected defendant's contention that § 2945.59 was unconstitutional. Rather, the court noted that the statute had been declared constitutional. Lastly, the court rejected defendant's argument that the evidence was insufficient to prove an intentional killing in the commission of a robbery, which was required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.01. Instead, the court concluded that the evidence constituted an inescapable web of circumstances which showed that all the elements of the crime of murder during the commission of a robbery were present.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment upholding defendant's conviction and sentence.

 

86 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Toledo v. Custer


No. 69-718


Supreme Court of Ohio


24 Ohio St. 2d 152; 265 N.E.2d 284; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 355; 53 Ohio Op. 2d 351



December 23, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant City of Toledo challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court's valuation order entered in a condemnation action. Appellee landowner had not filed his answer to the condemnation action within the period of time prescribed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.08, but the City did not immediately object and failed to appeal when the trial court denied its motion to strike the owner's answer.


OVERVIEW: The City initiated the action against the owner. The owner did not file his answer within the mandatory time period set out in § 163.08. The owner filed his answer after purporting to receive an extension of time from the trial court pursuant to Lucas County, Ohio, Ct. C.P. R. 7, which allowed the trial court's assignment commissioner to grant a 30 day extension of time in which to file pleadings. The City waited several months before filing a motion to strike the answer based upon its untimeliness under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.08; it also filed a motion to declare the value of the property under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.09(A). The trial court denied the motions, the City did not appeal their denial, and the matter went to trial. The City unsuccessfully asserted the trial court's error in granting an extension of time on appeal. In affirming that court held that the time limitation set out in § 163.08 was mandatory and the trial court did not have authority to extend the time to answer. The City waived its claim as to the untimely filed answer, however, by abandoning its right to appeal the trial court's order denying its motion to strike, which was an appealable order.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

87 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Collins


No. 69-680


Supreme Court of Ohio


24 Ohio St. 2d 107; 265 N.E.2d 261; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 346; 53 Ohio Op. 2d 302



December 9, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Fairfield County.

On December 8, 1968, appellee was arrested and charged with violating R. C. 4301.58 and R. C. 4399.09.

Complaining that evidence against him had been unlawfully obtained, appellee filed a pre-trial motion to suppress, which was sustained by the trial court.

Appellant's leave to file a bill of exceptions in the Court of Appeals was denied. The cause is now before us pursuant to our allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Fairfield County (Ohio), which denied the State leave to file a bill of exceptions from a decision sustaining defendant's pre-trial motion to suppress evidence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, arrested and charged with violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4301.58 and 4399.09, filed a motion to suppress evidence against him that he alleged was unlawfully obtained. The trial court sustained defendant's motion to suppress. The State filed a bill of exceptions, and the appellate court denied the State's bill. On appeal, the court held that the decision to sustain defendant's motion to suppress was a final order, as defined by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2505.02. The court found that the deprivation of the use of the evidence suppressed would render it virtually impossible for the State to obtain a conviction, and that without the evidence the prosecution would have been terminated. The court further held that an order granting a pre-trial motion to suppress evidence was not appealable because of the "clearly exclusive" nature of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.70.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's decision, which affirmed the trial court's motion to suppress evidence against defendant.

 

88 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Union Sav. Ass'n v. Home Owners Aid


No. 69-345


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 2d 60; 262 N.E.2d 558; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 372; 52 Ohio Op. 2d 329



September 16, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On September 29, 1965, Union Savings Association obtained a judgment against Home Owners Aid, Inc., and other codefendants, by virtue of confession as authorized by the warrant of attorney to confess judgment, on a promissory note upon which the corporate codefendant and other individual codefendants appeared as comakers. One of the individual codefendants, Howard Kirsch, also president of Home Owners, filed a petition to vacate the judgment as to himself personally. A petition to vacate the judgment and stay execution, filed by Home Owners, sets forth that it is appearing in propria persona and is indigent. The petition was signed, "Howard Kirsch, in propria persona for defendant, Home Owners Aid, Incorporated."

Union Savings then moved to strike both petitions for the reasons that they were not properly filed and were so deficient as to amount to a legal nullity. The Court of Common Pleas overruled the motion to strike the individual codefendant Kirsch's petition to vacate and sustained the motion as regards the corporate defendant.

The corporate defendant appealed from the order striking the petition. The Court [***2] of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

The causes 1 are before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.


1 In the Court of Appeals, 11 cases were appealed from the Court of Common Pleas. This court allowed defendant's motion to certify the records, and consolidated those 11 cases in one appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) overruled appellee association's motion to strike appellant president's petition to vacate the judgment as to himself personally and sustained the association's motion to strike appellant corporation's petition to vacate the judgment. The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County affirmed the lower court's judgment. The corporation appealed.


OVERVIEW: The corporation alleged that it was indigent. It contended that Ohio corporate statutes either provided or implied that the corporation was the same as a natural person in all respects, including the right to represent itself in propria persona. It asserted constitutional protection for the right to litigate in propria persona. The supreme court concluded that the corporation and a natural living person were not in all respects equal because the statutes and general assembly did not give a corporation all the rights and privileges of a natural person. Accordingly, the corporation's alleged indigence had no relevance. The procedure requiring a corporation to appear through an attorney in no way deprived the corporation of its constitutional rights because it had, by the laws of the state, a fair trial in a court of justice, according to the applicable modes of proceeding. Regarding the corporation's impairment of contract argument, the evidence failed to show that the corporation ever had the right to defend itself in propria persona. As the corporation did not show the possession of the right, impairment was impossible.


OUTCOME: The appellate court's judgment was affirmed.

 

89 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Clouston v. Remlinger Oldsmobile Cadillac, Inc.


No. 69-95


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 2d 65; 258 N.E.2d 230; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 397; 51 Ohio Op. 2d 96



April 22, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

There is no dispute concerning the facts. Plaintiff's husband was involved in an automobile accident on September 27, 1967, with an agent and employee of the defendant. Mrs. Clouston filed this suit on her own behalf for the loss of her husband's services and loss of his consortium.

The trial court sustained defendant's demurrer on the ground that there is no cause of action in Ohio for Mrs. Clouston's loss of her husband's services and the loss of her husband's consortium.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the trial court and certified the case to this court, upon a finding that its judgment was in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Ninth Appellate District in Seigenthaler v. Winslow. (Summit County, No. 5899), unreported.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant automobile dealership sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio), which reversed a decision that had sustained appellant's demurrer to appellee wife's action for loss of her husband's consortium after her husband was injured in an accident caused by the negligence of appellant's agent.


OVERVIEW: Appellee wife brought a lawsuit against appellant automobile dealership in which she alleged that her husband had been injured in an accident caused by the negligence of appellant's agent. On her own behalf, appellee sought damages for loss of her husband's consortium. The trial court sustained appellant's demurrer on that point, but the court of appeals reversed. Appellant sought review and the court affirmed. The court found that the trial court had sustained the demurrer on the basis of the common law rule, which was that only a husband could recover consortium damages. The court said that that rule was based on the ancient fiction that a husband and wife were one, with the one being the husband. The court said that the modern view, as espoused in numerous statutes that proclaimed that the wife could hold property in her own right, had not recognized that fiction. Also, the court stated that it had long been the rule that a wife could recover consortium damages from a tortfeasor who intentionally injured the husband. Therefore, the court held that appellee could have recovered loss of consortium damages for an injury to her husband caused by the negligence of appellant's agent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision that reversed the judgment sustaining appellant automobile dealership's demurrer to appellee wife's action for loss of her husband's consortium after he was injured in an accident resulting from the negligence of appellant's agent. The court held that the common law rule that only a husband could recover consortium damages after a negligent injury to his wife was no longer valid.

 

90 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Bible v. Board of Elections


No. 70-113


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 2d 57; 258 N.E.2d 227; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 394; 51 Ohio Op. 2d 92



April 17, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator potential candidate filed a mandamus action against respondent, the Board of Elections of Hamilton County (Ohio), seeking to compel the Board to place his name on the primary ballot as a Democratic candidate for state representative. The Board filed a demurrer arguing that the potential candidate was disqualified under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3513.191 because he had voted in the Republican primary four years prior.


OVERVIEW: The potential candidate argued that he had always been a member of the Democratic party. However, the Board argued that he had not voted as a Democrat at the primary four years prior. The court found that: (1) under the statute, an individual could not be a candidate in a party primary if he had voted in a different party's primary within the prior four calendar years; (2) the key issue was whether the statute had been properly enacted; (3) the statute had been enacted for the reasonable purpose of prohibiting candidates from altering their party affiliations for opportunistic reasons; and (4) under the statute, the demurrer had to be sustained.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the demurrer and denied the requested writ of mandamus.

 

91 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Switzer


No. 69-273


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 2d 47; 257 N.E.2d 908; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 393; 51 Ohio Op. 2d 69



April 15, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Warren County.

This case is concerned with fish, not as in the "pretty kettle of fish" of Gilbert and Sullivan's Iolanthe but in tanks of walleyed pike, the yellow pike of the gastronome's dream. And we do not have to be mindful of the time-honored maxim "piscatorial pursuits are conducive to mendacity" in our consideration of the facts, because the fish in the tanks were acquired by a rodless Walton of the lakes, a bloodless sportsman, one Cletus Switzer, appellant herein. In March 1968, he bought, for the purpose of resale in the United States, approximately 2,750 walleyed pike in Ontario, Canada, where the legal limit on length was 14 inches. Appellant then transported those fish through Canadian and United States Customs and thence through Michigan and Indiana to Ohio.

Appellant intended to stop at his home in Morrow, Ohio, change the water in the fish tanks and proceed to find a buyer for the fish. On the road to Morrow, he was stopped by agents of the Division of Wildlife of Ohio who inspected the fish. After some of the fish were measured and it was discovered that they were undersized according to Ohio law, appellant was charged,  [***2] pursuant to the provisions of R. C. 1533.63, with possession of undersized walleyed pike and under R. C. 1533.301, with transportation of fish without a transportation permit.

Appellant's fish were confiscated by the Division of Wildlife.

Appellant was tried in the Franklin Municipal Court and found guilty on both charges.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Warren County (Ohio), which convicted him of possession of undersized walleyed pike, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.63, and with transportation of fish without a transportation permit, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.301.


OVERVIEW: Defendant bought, for the purpose of resale in the United States, approximately 2,750 walleyed pike in Ontario, Canada. Defendant transported those fish through Canada and United States Customs and then through Michigan and Indiana to Ohio. Defendant intended to stop at his home in Morrow, Ohio, change the water in the fish tanks, and proceed to find a buyer for the fish. On the road to Morrow, he was stopped by agents of the Division of Wildlife of Ohio who inspected the fish. After some of the fish were measured, and it was discovered that they were undersized according to Ohio law, defendant was charged with possession of undersized walleyed pike and transportation of fish without a transportation permit. Defendant's fish were confiscated, and he was later convicted of both charges against him. The court reversed the judgment, by holding that defendant was not subject to prosecution under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.63 because the evidence did not unequivocally establish the fact that he was going to sell the fish in Ohio, where it was not shown, at the time of his arrest, that the fish he had in his possession were for use, consumption, sale, or storage within Ohio.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, which convicted defendant of possession of undersized walleyed pike and with transportation of fish without a transportation permit.

 

92 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Fortner v. Thomas


No. 69-86


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 2d 13; 257 N.E.2d 371; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 387; 51 Ohio Op. 2d 35



April 8, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On April 12, 1966, appellants, members of the Ohio Liquor Control Commission, amended one of the Conmission's regulations. Appellee is the holder of permits issued by the Department of Liquor Control. Pursuant to R. C. 119.11, and although he had never been directly subjected to the application of the amended regulation, appellee lodged an appeal from appellants' action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. That court reviewed the procedure used by appellants in adopting the regulation, and the lawfulness and reasonableness of the regulation, and held in favor of the appellant. Appellee then appealed to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, which court substantially modified the lower court's ruling.

Appellants' motion to certify the record to this court was allowed and the cause is now before us for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a liquor permit holder, appealed the actions of defendant, the Ohio Liquor Control Board (board) for amending one of the board's regulations. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) substantially modified a trial court decision in favor of the board members. The board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The liquor permit holder challenged the actions of the board for amending one of its regulations. The intermediate appellate court substantially modified a trial court decision in favor of the board. The court reversed the decision and dismissed the case because it determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1911.11 could not be employed to obtain judicial review of quasi-legislative proceedings of administrative officers and agencies. The court concluded that because the action was a challenge to the amendment rather than a review of application of the amended regulation the case required dismissal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision and dismissed the case because the court determined that that modified a the statute allowing judicial review of agency judicial actions could not be used to obtain judicial review of quasi-legislative actions of administrative officers.

 

93 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


General Data Corp. v. Porterfield


No. 69-524


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 223; 257 N.E.2d 359; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 458; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 468



March 25, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

General Data Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Holiday Inns of America, leases terminals, which function somewhat like teletypewriters, for use in the international reservation system for Holiday Inns. Each motel operated under the name "Holiday Inns of America" has a terminal which is connected by leased wires to central computers in Memphis, Tennessee. All communications must be routed through the Memphis computers, and it is impossible to use a terminal at one inn to communicate with another inn without going through the Memphis computers.

The terminals are used in conjunction with the central computers to make various types of reservations, to cancel reservations, to check on room availability, and to transmit administrative data. The terminals function as input devices to transmit information for storage in and use by the Memphis computers, and as output typewriters printing messages received from the computers.

General Data's witness, Long, testified before the Board of Tax Appeals that there are about 1,000 Holiday Inns using the system. Ninety-nine per cent of the use of the terminals is for transmitting messages regarding [***2] room reservations, while approximately one per cent of the use is devoted to other purposes.

A sample standard type lease agreement used by General Data and its lessees, appellee's exhibit B, recites that, at the 19th Annual Conference of the International Association of Holiday Inns, the association voted "that the installation in all Holiday Inns of the new computer-type central reservation control system be a requirement of the Rules of Operation of the International System, and by such act did authorize Holiday Inns of America, Inc., to arrange for such a 'system,' and Holiday Inns of America, Inc., did contract with the International Business Machine Corporation, hereinafter referred to as 'IBM,' for such a 'system' and did contract to lease the 'terminals' for use in this 'system' from C. C. Leasing Company, and which lease has been assigned to General Data Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Holiday Inns of America, Inc.; and a majority of the members present at the above described meeting did also vote to charge each member of the International Association of Holiday Inns (each member of the International Association being a 'licensee' of Holiday Inns of America, Inc.)  [***3] two and 50/100 dollars ($ 2.50) per rental guest room per month as a requirement of the Rules of Operation for the purpose of and as the method of payment for the computer-type central reservation control system * * *." (Emphasis added.)

Each of the inns enters a similar lease agreement with General Data and the monthly charge ($ 2.50) per rental guest room increases or decreases only if the number of rooms changes. The evidence shows that General Data pays a third-party leasing firm $ 82.99 for the rental of one type terminal and $ 154 for another heavy duty model used in inns of over two hundred rooms, although the time for which such charge is made is not disclosed.

The Tax Commissioner, under Section 5741.02, Revised Code, assessed General Data for use taxes based upon the rentals collected for the terminals. General Data appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals, which reversed the Tax Commissioner's order on the following grounds: (1) The tax was a tax levied on activity in interstate commerce, which is excepted under Section 5741.02(C)(3), Revised Code, and (2) the terminals were being rented and used directly in making retail sales, which use is excepted from taxation under [***4] Sections 5741.02(C)(2) and 5739.01(E)(2), Revised Code.

The Tax Commissioner has appealed to this court, contending that the board erred in its ruling reversing the commissioner's order of assessment.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner sought review of the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which reversed the tax commissioner's order of assessment against appellee taxpayer for use taxes on the taxpayer's equipment.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer leased terminals for use in the international reservation system for a hotel chain. The tax commissioner assessed the taxpayer with use taxes based upon the rentals collected for the terminals. The board reversed the tax commissioner's order because: (1) the tax was a tax levied on activity in interstate commerce, which was excepted; and (2) the terminals were being rented and used directly in making retail sales, a use which was also excepted from taxation. The court affirmed the board's decision. The use tax was not levied and assessed on the transaction wherein the property came to rest in Ohio, but was levied and assessed on a rental charge made by the tax commissioner both for the use of the terminals and their use in the computerized system by the various hotels across the country. As the assessment was based on charges per room, per month, after the terminals were used in interstate commerce as a part of an international computerized system of motel room reservations, the assessment was an unlawful tax burden on interstate commerce. Also, because the terminals were used in making sales for a motel's consumers, they fit within a second exception.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the board's decision.

 

94 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Burt Realty Corp. v. Columbus


No. 69-276


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 265; 257 N.E.2d 355; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 465; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 491



March 25, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

Burt Realty Corporation owns two parcels of real property on the east side of High Street between 15th and 16th Avenues in Columbus, Ohio. The area was, prior to 1963 and still is, zoned for commercial use. In that year, Columbus adopted uncodified Ordinance No. 313-63, which establishes the building setback line from High Street in this area at a minimum of 65 feet from the center of the street and prohibits any above-ground use of the property, including parking, within that limitation.

The existing buildings on each parcel front on High Street. They pre-date the adoption of the 1963 ordinance, are devoted to uses permitted in the applicable commercial district, but are situated only 32.5 feet from the center of the street. Thus, the 1963 setback line cuts through the buildings to the extent of 32.5 feet and affects approximately 35% of the combined parcels.

The buildings are now deteriorating and the owner desires to reconstruct and replace them on their present locus. After being refused a building permit for such purpose, the owner brought this action against [***2] Columbus in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County for a declaratory judgment, challenging the constitutionality of the 1963 ordinance as it applies to its property.

The case was tried upon a stipulation of facts which fail to disclose whether it is economically feasible and physically possible for Burt Realty to rebuild on the remainder of its real estate unaffected by the setback ordinance without suffering loss of value to the property taken as a whole.

The trial court granted a declaratory judgment as prayed for. The Court of Appeals reversed and dismissed the action, holding that plaintiff was not entitled to a declaratory judgment because it had not exhausted its administrative remedies.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner filed an action against appellee city challenging the constitutionality of a zoning ordinance as applied to the owner's property. The trial court granted the owner's request for declaratory judgment. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), reversed the trial court's judgment. The owner sought review of the appellate court's decision.


OVERVIEW: The owner's buildings were erected prior to the enactment of a new set-back ordinance and were in compliance with a prior set-back ordinance. The owner sought to reconstruct the buildings in the same location, but the city refused to issue a building permit. The trial court granted the owner's request for declaratory judgment finding that the ordinance was unconstitutional as applied to the owner's property. The court of appeals reversed the trial court's decision on the ground that the owner had not exhausted his administrative remedies. On review, the court reversed the appellate court's judgment, holding that the appellate court was in error because declaratory judgment was an alternative to the administrative remedy. The court did not address the constitutional issue. The court found that the location of the owner's buildings was a use of land which was protected from conforming to new ordinance upon replacement of the buildings. The court declared that the city could not refuse the owner a building permit for the improvement of its property for the reason that plans for such construction or improvement would not set back the building line in accordance with the new ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals, which reversed the trial court's declaratory judgment in favor of the owner.

 

95 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Coates


Nos. 69-116, 69-117, 69-118, 69-119, 69-120


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 66; 255 N.E.2d 247; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 436; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 161



January 28, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) affirming their convictions for violating Cincinnati, Ohio Code of Ordinances § 901-L6.Defendants sought to have the ordinance declared to be in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and Ohio Const. art. I, § 3, for the reasons that it was vague and imprecise as to what conduct was proscribed.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance provided that it was be unlawful for three or more persons to assemble, except at a public meeting of citizens, on any of the sidewalks, street corners, vacant lots, or mouths of alleys, and there conduct themselves in a manner that was annoying to persons passing by, or occupants of adjacent buildings. The ordinances further stated that whoever violated any of the provisions of the section would be fined not exceeding $ 50.00, or be imprisoned not less than 1 nor more than 30 days or both. The court noted that U.S. Const. amend. I provided that the United States Congress was not to make laws that abridged the right of the people to peaceably assemble. Further, Ohio Const. art. I, § 3 provided that the people had the right to assemble together, in a peaceable manner. The court noted that both the federal and state constitutions contemplated that the right to assemble would be asserted and enjoyed in a peaceable manner. On appeal, the court affirmed defendants' convictions because the affidavits charged assembly and a course of conduct that was annoying to persons passing by. The court found that the word "annoying" was widely used and well understood, not vague.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the Court of Appeals.

 

96 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Starnes


No. 69-189


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 38; 254 N.E.2d 675; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 432; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 84



January 14, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Appellant herein, Herbert G. Starnes, was charged by the city of Toledo with the offense of driving while under the influence of alcohol. The arresting officer asked appellant to give a chemical test specimen, but appellant refused. Subsequently, appellant pleaded guilty in Toledo Municipal Court to being in physical control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

Under the provisions of Section 4511.191(D), Revised Code, the Registrar of Motor Vehicles suspended appellant's driver's license because of his refusal to submit to a chemical test to determine if he was under the influence of alcohol at the time of his arrest. Appellant filed a petition in the Municipal Court, pursuant to Section 4511.191(F), Revised Code, contesting the validity of the suspension of his license.

A hearing was held in the Municipal Court, and the court affirmed the order of suspension. At the hearing, appellant contended that Section 4511.191, Revised Code, is unconstitutional. He contended also that, in a hearing under Section 4511.191(F), Revised Code, the fact that he was adjudged guilty of the offense of physical control of [***2] a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor precludes a finding of reasonable ground to believe he was driving while under the influence of alcohol.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Municipal Court.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the municipal court upholding the suspension of defendant's driver's license by plaintiff state Registrar of Motor Vehicles under the implied consent statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.191.


OVERVIEW: After two levels of judicial review upholding the suspension of defendant's driver's license under the implied consent statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.191, defendant sought further judicial review from the state supreme court, arguing that the statute was unconstitutional. Without extensive analysis, the court rejected defendant's arguments that the statute permitted unreasonable searches and seizures in contravention of the Fourth Amendment or compelled a person to be a witness against himself in a criminal prosecution in contravention of the Fifth Amendment. The court then held that the implied consent statute did not violate due process because proceedings under § 4511.191(F) were civil and administrative in nature, and a burden of proof less than proof beyond a reasonable doubt was sufficient for a valid suspension of a driver's license.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court upholding the suspension of defendant's driver's license.

 

97 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Emmons v. Keller


No. 69-67


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 48; 254 N.E.2d 687; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 433; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 90



January 14, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Plaintiff filed a petition in the Common Pleas Court against the administrator of the Bureau of Workmen's Compensation as an appeal from a decision of the Industrial Commission denying her claim for benefits on account of the death of her husband.

The petition alleges that plaintiff's husband was injured on January 9, 1962, and that the injury was received in the course of and arose out of his employment and directly and proximately caused his death on July 7, 1965.

The administrator's demurrer to the petition was overruled, and, since the administrator elected to stand on his demurrer and not plead further, judgment was rendered for plaintiff.

That judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court as an appeal involving a substantial constitutional question and pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court (Ohio) reversed a decision by the Industrial Commission (Ohio), which denied a claim for benefits filed by plaintiff widow against defendant, the Ohio Bureau of Workmen's Compensation, following the death of the widow's husband. The Court of Appeals (Ohio) affirmed the decision of the trial court. The bureau filed an appeal.


OVERVIEW: The widow's husband sustained a work-related injury. Subsequently, he died from his injury. The Bureau denied the widow's claim for benefits based upon its finding that the claim failed to state any right to recovery under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59, as amended in 1963. The widow appealed. The trial court overruled the demurrer filed on behalf of the Bureau and entered judgment in favor of the widow. The intermediate appellate court affirmed, holding that the portion of § 4123.59 at issue violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26, the equal protection clause, for that reason that it failed to afford equal treatment to all persons in the same class. On review, the court reversed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court. The court found that the 1963 amendment to the statute, which eliminated the widow's basis for recovery, was constitutionally valid. While the court found that the application of a portion of the section could lead to arbitrary and capricious results, the court found that the remainder of the statute was valid. The court held, however, that even under the valid remaining portions of the statute, the widow was not entitled to prevail on her claim.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court.

 

98 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Duling


No. 69-83


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 2d 13; 254 N.E.2d 670; 1970 Ohio LEXIS 428; 50 Ohio Op. 2d 40



January 7, 1970, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In 1965, Eugene W. Duling, appellant herein, was convicted by a jury of murder in the first degree, without a recommendation of mercy, and was sentenced to death for the killing of a police officer. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction and this court dismissed an appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals on the ground that no substantial constitutional question was involved. Upon appeal, the Supreme Court of the United States denied a petition for a writ of certiorari.

In June 1967, appellant filed a petition for postconviction relief in the Court of Common Pleas, raising the same arguments as in the original appeal. At the same time, he also filed a motion for new trial on the basis of newly discovered evidence. Relief was denied in both instances. Appeal was then taken to the Court of Appeals and subsequently was voluntarily dismissed.

In January 1968, appellant refiled in the Court of Common Pleas his original petition for postconviction relief and the motion for new trial. The trial court denied relief and appeal was again taken to the Court of Appeals. Prior to the hearing in the Court [***2] of Appeals, the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of Witherspoon v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 510, was handed down. That decision was brought to the attention of the Court of Appeals, but no transcript of the voir dire examination of jurors was filed. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment, but, of necessity, that court did not pass on the Witherspoon issue.

Upon appeal to this court, appellant has provided the transcript of the voir dire examination necessary to review the questions raised in relation to selection of the jury at his trial.

The cause is before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court decision that denied defendant postconviction relief and denied his motion for a new trial following his conviction for murder in the first degree. Defendant challenged the selection of the jury for his trial. A prior motion and appeal based on newly discovered evidence were unsuccessful.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to death for killing a police officer. Defendant unsuccessfully moved for postconviction relief and for a new trial, and on appeal challenged the selection of his jury. Prior to his appellate hearing, the Supreme Court of Ohio handed down a decision governing the process for selecting and rejecting jurors. Defendant did not attach the transcript of the voir dire examination in his action before the lower appellate court, but did in his action before the court. The court affirmed the lower appellate court, finding that some prospective jurors were excused even though they did not proclaim opposition to the death penalty regardless of the evidence, but the court also found that the trial judge adhered to U.S. Const. amend. VI and to Ohio Const. art. I, § 10. The court noted that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.25 conformed to the new decision, and that defendant could have raised the same questions as were raised in that case. Because he did not, he was precluded from doing so on appeal. The court also concluded that defendant's new evidence was cumulative of evidence already presented.


OUTCOME: The court found for the State and affirmed defendant's conviction for first degree murder.

 

99 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Madden v. Bower


No. 69-393


Supreme Court of Ohio


20 Ohio St. 2d 135; 254 N.E.2d 357; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 319; 49 Ohio Op. 2d 469



December 23, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County in an action originating in that court.

Under the authority of former Revised Code Section 305.171, 1 the relators, the Board of County Commissioners of Summit County, procured hospitalization, surgical and major medical insurance for all officers and employees of the county and, by resolution, ordered the premium therefor, in the amount of $ 80,000, to be paid "at county expense." The record fails to disclose that the Board made an appropriation of any funds to pay the premium.


1 Revised Code Section 305.171: "The board of county commissioners of any county may procure and pay all or any part of the cost of group hospitalization, surgical, major medical, or sickness and accident insurance or a combination of any of the foregoing types of insurance or coverage for county officers and employees and their immediate dependents, whether issued by an insurance company or a hospital service association duly authorized to do business in this state." (132 Ohio Laws 252, 2688, effective November 24, 1967.)

The section was amended (133 Ohio Laws S 112, effective September 23, 1969) by inserting after the word "dependents," the following: "from the funds or budgets from which said officers or employees are compensated for services." The amendment does not control the premium involved in this case.

 [***2] After the respondent county auditor charged the cost of the premiums entirely to the general fund of the county, relators commenced this action for a writ of mandamus to compel the respondent to pay or apportion from funds other than the general fund that portion of the premiums attributable to those county employees whose regular compensation is paid from those funds.

Thereafter, the respondent county auditor refused to pay that part of the premium attributable to the elected county officers whose terms of office had commenced prior to the board's action procuring the insurance. Relators then filed a supplemental petition in mandamus in the action which injected that issue into the case.

The Court of Appeals denied the relief sought by the original petition but held that the payment of premiums on behalf of elected county officers are not "compensation and salary" and granted a writ of mandamus against the respondent county auditor in accordance with the prayer of the supplemental petition. The relators alone have appealed to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of county commissioners sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which held that payment of premiums on behalf of elected county officers was not compensation or salary, and granted a writ of mandamus against respondent country auditor.


OVERVIEW: The issue on appeal was whether respondent county auditor had a duty to charge each special fund of the county from which certain employees were regularly compensated with a proportionate share of the insurance premium cost attributable to those employees. The court found that a charge to any fund, general or special, by respondent county auditor, on account of premiums attributable to employees of that office, on his own volition or at the mere request of appellant board amounted to an appropriation by respondent county auditor that he was unauthorized to undertake. Further, in the absence of an appropriation by appellant board, respondent county auditor had no duty to apportion the premium cost among the various funds of the county. Thus, as to the premium attributable to employees of the engineer's office, the court affirmed the judgment in denying the writ.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed in denying the writ because respondent country auditor had no duty to apportion the premium cost among the various funds of the county in the absence of an appropriation by appellant board.

 

100 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Baker


No. 69-239


Supreme Court of Ohio


20 Ohio St. 2d 142; 254 N.E.2d 363; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 320; 49 Ohio Op. 2d 473



December 23, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hocking County.

Appellant, Michael L. Baker, was charged in Juvenile Court with being a delinquent child. The complaint stated that:

"Michael Lee Baker, age 17 years, who appears to be a delinquent child in that he did knowingly sell or make available to minors under 16 years of age a drug or powder containing an ingredient deleterious to health, specifically a substance containing a preparation of the poisonous compounds belladonna and stramonium; said substances being capable of causing complete confusion with hallucinations, contrary to Sections 3719.31, 3719.32 and 3719.42 of the Revised Code of the state of Ohio."

Appellant entered a plea of not guilty. At the trial, there was evidence that appellant sold some "brown powder" to other juveniles and that the powder was taken orally by some of them by teaspoon.

At the conclusion of the trial, the Juvenile Court made the following findings:

"Based on the evidence and testimony that the court has heard today, the court is of the opinion that the evidence * * * does substantiate the allegation in the complaint that Michael Lee Baker was a delinquent child on December 29, 1967, and the court [***2] will so adjudicate that he was a delinquent child as of December 29, 1967.

"* * * The finding of the court * * * is that Michael Lee Baker * * * is a delinquent or was a delinquent on December 29, 1967, by virtue of a fact he committed the acts alleged in a complaint filed in this case and in that the acts fall within Revised Code Section 2151.02, sub-paragraph D."

Under the provisions of Section 2151.35 (E), Revised Code, the Juvenile Court then committed appellant to the Ohio State Reformatory at Mansfield. In committing appellant to the reformatory, the court found that appellant had "committed an act, which act if committed by an adult, would be a felony."

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment. However, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Appellate District in the case of State v. Fisher, 17 Ohio App. 2d 183, the Court of Appeals ordered the record certified to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a juvenile, appealed from a judgment that adjudicated him a delinquent for selling a drug containing ingredients capable of causing hallucinations in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 3719.31, 3719.32, 3719.42 and that committed him to the reformatory under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2151.35(E). The Court of Appeals for Hocking County (Ohio) affirmed but certified the record for review and final determination.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the statute under which he had been committed was unconstitutional. He also argued that certain evidence had been improperly admitted into evidence and that the determination that he was guilty of acts that would be a felony if he were an adult was improper. The court found that: (1) it was unnecessary to consider the constitutional issue in light of the disposition of other errors; (2) while the medicine given by defendant to other juveniles did contain prohibited substances justifying a finding of delinquency, the question remained whether the acts involved actually would have constituted a felony; (3) where the testimony was conflicting as to whether the drug was a hallucinatory drug, there had been a failure to show that the acts charged would have been a felony if committed by an adult; and (4) it was necessary to resentence defendant based upon the correct application of the law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the adjudication of delinquency but reversed the part of the judgment committing defendant to the reformatory and remanded for proper resentencing.

 

101 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Strattman v. Studt


No. 69-381


Supreme Court of Ohio


20 Ohio St. 2d 95; 253 N.E.2d 749; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 311; 49 Ohio Op. 2d 428



December 17, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On September 30, 1968, petitioner, Walter Strattman was found guilty in the Hamilton County Municipal Court of making a false report to the police in violation of Section 901-f3 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cincinnati, Ohio. 1 He was given the maximum authorized sentence of six months in the Cincinnati workhouse and assessed a fine of $ 500 and costs. After serving the six months (ending on March 31, 1969), petitioner, unable to pay the fine and costs, was further confined, apparently pursuant to Section 2947.20, Revised Code, 2 until the fine and costs were paid at the rate of three dollars per day credited against them.


1 Section 901-f3, False Report of Felony or Misdemeanor, provides:

"It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to report or cause to be reported any felony or misdemeanor, or to give any information relating to such felony or misdemeanor, to the division of police or to any member of said division, by telephone, in writing or by any other communication, knowing that no such felony or misdemeanor has in fact been committed. It shall further be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to give any information or report relating to any felony or misdemeanor, which information or report is false, and which such person, firm or corporation knows to be false. Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not to exceed five hundred dollars ($ 500) or by imprisonment for six (6) months or both." (Emphasis added.)

 [***2] 

2 Section 2947.20, Revised Code, provides:

"Where a fine may be imposed in whole or in part, in punishment of a misdemeanor, including the violation of an ordinance of a municipal corporation and the judge or magistrate has authority to order that the defendant stand committed to the jail of the county or municipal corporation until the fine and costs are paid, the court may order that such person stand committed to such jail or workhouse until such fine and costs are paid or secured to be paid, or he is otherwise legally discharged. Persons so imprisoned shall receive credit upon such fine and costs, at the rate of three dollars per day."

On April 18, 1969, petitioner filed a pauper's affidavit with the Municipal Court; and on April 22, 1969, he filed a petition for habeas corpus in the Court of Appeals. A memorandum supporting his petition alleged that his continued incarceration deprived him of his rights of due process and equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Petitioner contended further that the Municipal Court abused its discretion in sentencing [***3] him to both the maximum prison term and the maximum fine and costs, when the imposition of the fine and costs in reality meant further incarceration.

The Court of Appeals dismissed the petition, holding that the petitioner was not denied equal protection and that the trial court did not abuse its discretion. It should be noted that, although the pauper's affidavit was filed in the Court of Appeals prior to the hearing on the writ of habeas corpus, there is nothing in the record to indicate petitioner's indigency at the time of sentencing by the Municipal Court. Moreover, the record does not reveal when or how the sentencing court implemented the provisions of Section 2947.20, Revised Code. Inasmuch as the parties do not argue those points, we assume that the procedural requirements of the statute were met and that petitioner is indigent.

The Court of Appeals certified the record to this court, finding that its judgment was in conflict with the case of In re Petition of Cole, 17 Ohio App. 2d 207, decided by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, which held that a court abuses its discretion by imposing a sentence which results in imprisonment in default of payment of the [***4] fine which exceeds the maximum term of imprisonment which could be imposed as an original sentence.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner was convicted of making a false report to the police. He was sentenced to six months in a work house and assessed a fine and costs. After serving the sentence, he was unable to pay the fine and cost. Thus he was further confined pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2947.20. He filed a petition for habeas corpus, which the Court of Appeals (Ohio) dismissed. The court of appeals certified the record to the court.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner served his sentence at the workhouse but was unable to pay the fine and costs imposed for his conviction. Thus, he was further confined pursuant to § 2947.20. The court of appeals dismissed his petition for a writ of habeas corpus. The court of appeals certified the record to the court, finding that its judgment was in conflict with a case decided by another appellate court. The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment, holding that § 2947.20 as applied to an indigent defendant who had served the maximum incarceration authorized by the substantive statute, violated the equal protection guarantee of the Fourteenth Amendment. The court determined that a three dollars per day credit on an unpaid fine was so unreasonable that it unfairly discriminated against petitioner. Petitioner was able to decide whether three dollars was equal to a day in jail but he was unable to manifest his choice. The court noted that a judgment for costs in a criminal case was a civil, not a criminal, obligation, and that as such it was only collectable by the methods provided for the collection of civil judgments. Ohio Const. art. I, § 15 expressly prohibited imprisonment for civil debt.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and remanded to the court of appeals, with instructions to allow the petitioner's writ.

 

102 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Hofstetter v. Kronk


No. 69-145


Supreme Court of Ohio


20 Ohio St. 2d 117; 254 N.E.2d 15; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 313; 49 Ohio Op. 2d 440



December 17, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Geauga County.

Relator, Carl Hofstetter, was elected and served as a Geauga County Court Judge from 1959 through 1962. On November 6, 1962, he was re-elected for the term 1963 through 1966.

In 1963, the General Assembly enacted Section 1901.02, Revised Code, creating the Chardon Municipal Court and giving it jurisdiction within Geauga County, effective July 11, 1963. Section 1901.04, Revised Code, provides "that upon the institution of a municipal court, the jurisdiction of county courts * * * in all civil and criminal causes terminates in any township or municipal corporation which is entirely within the territory."

After relator served through the year 1963, the respondent auditor refused to issue payroll vouchers or to establish funds for paying relator as judge.

In January 1964, the Chardon Municipal Court began operation. Relator alleges that the prosecuting attorney filed a mandamus action in the Court of Common Pleas seeking an order compelling him to turn over his court records and other property as required by Section 1901.04, Revised Code. A writ of mandamus was issued ordering relator to surrender this property. Relator complied [***2] with the writ and did not prosecute an appeal.

In December 1967, relator filed a mandamus action in the Court of Appeals requesting the issuance of various writs of mandamus which would, in essence, require respondents to pay relator his salary as county court judge for the years 1964 through 1966, plus interest. Relator claims that Section 15, Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, prohibits any change, addition or diminution which will result in the vacation of the office of any judge during term, notwithstanding the fact that the office of county judge was created by statute, and that the legislation which established Chardon Municipal Court with county-wide jurisdiction unconstitutionally deprived him of his office. The Court of Appeals, holding that the General Assembly having created relator's office could abolish it, sustained a demurrer to the writ and overruled motions to strike the demurrer and for reconsideration.

The cause is before this court pursuant to an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State of Ohio on behalf of relator judge sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Geauga County (Ohio), which sustained appellee auditor's demurrer to the judge's writ of mandamus and overruled his motions to strike the demurrer and for reconsideration.


OVERVIEW: The judge filed a mandamus action requesting the issuance of various writ of mandamus which would require the auditor to pay him his salary as a county court judge for the balance of his term plus interest. The lower court, holding that the Ohio General Assembly, having created his office, could abolish it, sustained a demurrer to the writ and overruled motions to strike the demurrer and for reconsideration. Upon the judge's appeal, the court affirmed the judgment, holding that the principle of collateral estoppel barred the judge from litigating an issue which had already been decided by a court of competent jurisdiction. Inasmuch as the previous mandamus order, which directed relator to surrender all the records and other property of the county court to the municipal court, was not appealed, the judge was barred from prosecuting this action, and because the question in both cases was identical, and under the real party in interest analysis the same parties were involved, the judge was estopped from relitigating that question.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the lower court, which sustained the auditor's demurrer to the judge's writ of mandamus and overruled his motions to strike the demurrer and for reconsideration.

 

103 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Crampton


No. 68-533


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 2d 182; 248 N.E.2d 614; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 395; 47 Ohio Op. 2d 394



June 11, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Defendant was indicted for first degree murder in the killing of his wife on January 17, 1967. After pleading not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity, he was tried before a jury which rendered a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree and did not recommend mercy. After defendant's motion for a new trial was overruled, the court sentenced defendant to death in the electric chair.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction.

The cause is before this court upon appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction against defendant for first-degree murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of first-degree murder for killing his wife, and a jury recommended no mercy. After overruling a motion for a new trial, the trial court sentenced defendant to death in the electric chair. Defendant argued that he was denied his constitutional right to a fair trial when potential jurors were excused for cause because their opinions precluded them from finding the accused guilty of an offense punishable by death. The court affirmed defendant's conviction and concluded that defendant was not denied a fair trial since only four of the 29 jurors were excused because of their opinions regarding capital punishment. The court ruled that defendant was not prejudiced by the jury charge given on the issue of insanity and ruled that defendant was not prejudiced by the trial court's refusal to permit a medical expert from answering hypothetical questions regarding defendant's excessive use of drugs and their possible affects on his mental state. The court found that defendant, by asserting his right against self-incrimination, was not denied his right to present evidence of mitigation on the issue of punishment since witnesses could and did present such testimony.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision sustaining the trial court's judgment of conviction against defendant for first-degree murder.

 

104 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Glass v. Dryden


No. 68-246


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 2d 149; 248 N.E.2d 54; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 391; 47 Ohio Op. 2d 313



May 28, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Brown County upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

Appellee is the owner of two tracts of real estate situated in the unincorporated territory of Huntington Township, Brown County, Ohio. Her real estate borders on land owned by Virgil Cooper. Appellants are the members of the Board of Trustees of Huntington Township.

In April 1966, Virgil Cooper filed a complaint with the trustees pursuant to Section 971.01 et seq., Revised Code, which directs the trustees, upon complaint, to view the premises of adjoining landowners and assign to each owner his equal share of a partition line fence to be constructed and kept in repair. The trustees, following the statute, made an assignment requiring each of the parties hereto to build an equal portion of the fence on the line between their lands.

Thereupon, appellee commenced this action in the Court of Common Pleas to enjoin the trustees from taking any further proceedings relating to the fence construction order, her primary contention being that the fence would be of no benefit to her because her land was not being used for agricultural purposes but was in the process of being laid [***2] out into lots for residential and recreation purposes.

The trial court denied the injunction. Upon appeal on questions of law, the Court of Appeals reversed, and, in lieu of remanding the cause back to the trial court, granted the injunction.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Board of trustees of Huntington Township challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Brown County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court and granted appellee owner's petition to enjoin the Board from requiring the owner to pay a portion of the costs of building a fence between her property and her neighbor's property.


OVERVIEW: The neighbor filed a complaint with the Board pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 971.01 et seq., which directs the Board to view the premises of adjoining landowners and assign to each owner his equal share of a partition line fence to be constructed and kept in repair. The Board made an assignment requiring each of the parties to build an equal portion of the fence on the line between their lands. The owner brought an action enjoin the Board's action, claiming that the fence would not benefit her because her land was not being used for agricultural purposes but was in the process of being laid out into lots for residential and recreation purposes. The appellate court reversed the trial court's denial of the injunction and the court reversed, finding that (1) the owner failed to establish that the cost of building the fence would not have enhanced the value of her land by the amount of that cost; (2) the owner did not come within the exception of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 971.02 because the land was not laid out in lots; and (3) the trial court was entitled to consider the survey that was offered into evidence even though it was not produced pursuant to the trial court's order.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order granting injunctive relief.

 

105 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Lorr v. Court of Common Pleas


No. 69-44


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 2d 54; 247 N.E.2d 309; 1969 Ohio LEXIS 363; 47 Ohio Op. 2d 166



April 30, 1969, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] IN PROHIBITION.

By this action in prohibition originating in this court, relator, a chiropractor, seeks to prohibit the respondent Court of Common Pleas from trying her under indictments charging her with the illegal practice of medicine.

The relator filed in the Common Pleas Court a motion to quash the indictments against her on the ground that the statutes relating to the licensing of chiropractors, the unlawful practice of medicine and the disposition of fines are unconstitutional. The motion to quash was overruled, relator was tried and found guilty by a jury, but neither sentence nor judgment has been rendered.
