The instant cause is now before this court upon the petition, a demurrer thereto and an answer to the demurrer.

Relator bases her right to relief upon the alleged unconstitutionality of the hereinbefore-mentioned statutes.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.

 

106 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Buckley


No. 68-5


Supreme Court of Ohio


16 Ohio St. 2d 128; 243 N.E.2d 66; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 356; 45 Ohio Op. 2d 469



December 31, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Charles E. and Robert E. Buckley, appellants herein, operate a junk yard (Buckley's Auto Wrecking) in Summit County. On January 30, 1965, the county prosecuting attorney filed an application in the Court of Common Pleas to abate the operation of this yard as a nuisance under Sections 4737.05 to 4737.99, Revised Code, hereinafter referred to as the junk-yard statutes.

The Buckleys cross-petitioned for a declaratory judgment to test the constitutionality of those statutes, and impleaded as new parties the county auditor, the sheriff and the Attorney General of Ohio.

The trial court held that those parts of the junk-yard statutes which define fences, which create a legislative nuisance where there are no fences, and which provide for enforcement are vague, indefinite, and unconstitutional. The court held also that the exemption of scrap processing dealers was unreasonably discriminatory.

Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals found the statutes constitutional and reversed that portion of the judgment of the trial court which held the junk-yard statutes unconstitutional in part. The cause is now before this court as an appeal involving [***2] a constitutional question and pursuant to the allowance of Buckleys' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant junk yard operators sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which reversed that part of the trial court's judgment that held that the junk-yard statutes, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4737.05 - 4737.99, were unconstitutional in part. The operators' motion to certify the record was allowed.


OVERVIEW: The county attorney filed an application seeking to abate the operation of the operators' yard as a nuisance under the junk-yard statutes. The operators' cross-petition for a declaratory judgment sought to test the statutes' constitutionality. The trial court held that the parts of the statutes that defined fences, created a legislative nuisance where there were no fences, and provided for enforcement were vague, indefinite, and unconstitutional. The trial court held also that the exemption of scrap yards was unreasonably discriminatory. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, which reversed the trial court's judgment. The court held that the statutes were properly supported by aesthetic considerations because interference with the natural aesthetics of the surrounding countryside caused by an unfenced or inadequately fenced junk yard was generally patent and gross, and not merely a matter of taste. However, the court cautioned that its holding was not a blanket approval of all regulation based upon aesthetics. The court determined that the exemption of scrap yards was reasonable because they alleviated the eyesores of automobile graveyards by consuming vehicles.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, which held that the junk-yard statutes were constitutional.

 

107 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Bossert Machine Co.


No. 68-225


Supreme Court of Ohio


16 Ohio St. 2d 76; 243 N.E.2d 105; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 345; 45 Ohio Op. 2d 420



December 18, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The city of Cincinnati, appellant, filed a petition on May 19, 1967, against defendants to appropriate their land, in which petition the value thereof was stated to be $ 24,000. Service of process was made in due course and no issue is raised that defendants failed to receive timely notice of the pendency of the action. Final answer date was June 17, 1967, under Section 163.08, Revised Code, which provides that "any answer shall be filed on or before the third Saturday after the return day of the summons. . . . No extension of time for filing of an answer shall be granted." (Emphasis supplied.) No answer was filed until almost three months later, and then only by leave of court, which was given ex parte. Cincinnati immediately moved the court to strike the answer and to declare the value of the property to be as set forth in the petition, pursuant to Section 163.09, Revised Code, which states that: "If no answer is filed pursuant to Section 163.08 of the Revised Code . . . the court on motion of a public agency shall declare the value of the property taken and the damages, if any, to be as set forth in any document [***2] [in this case, the petition] properly filed with the clerk of courts by the public agency."

The Court of Common Pleas granted the motions and fixed the value of the property at the amount stated in the city's petition.

The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County reversed, holding Sections 163.08 and 163.09 of the Revised Code to be unconstitutional (14 Ohio App. 2d 35).



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the grant of the city's motions and fixed the value of the property of appellee landowners at the amount stated in the city's petition, holding Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.08 and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 163.09 to be unconstitutional against the landowners to appropriate their land.


OVERVIEW: Service of process was made in due course and no issue was raised that the landowners failed to receive timely notice of the pendency of the action. No answer was filed until almost three months later, and then only by leave of court, which was given ex parte. The court held that the purpose of the responsive pleading was to raise the issue of the proper valuation. The court held that the trial court had no power to extend the statutory time. The landowners claimed, and the Court of Appeals held, that their right under Ohio Const. art. I, § 19, to have a jury fix the compensation for the property taken was violated by the instant procedure. The court held that the landowners' failure, without justification, to conform to the procedures by which the jury was to be obtained constituted waiver of a trial by jury.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

108 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Blacker v. Wiethe


No. 68-165


Supreme Court of Ohio


16 Ohio St. 2d 65; 242 N.E.2d 655; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 342; 45 Ohio Op. 2d 367



December 11, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This action originated in the Common Pleas Court of Hamilton County with the filing of a petition on October 30, 1967, seeking an injunction against submission to the voters of that county at the November 7, 1967, election of the question of adopting the alternative form of county government, as described in Chapter 302, Revised Code, and known as "the appointive county executive plan." See Section 302.02, Revised Code.

On November 1, 1967, the Common Pleas Court rendered a judgment, permanently enjoining the submission of that question.

On November 3, 1967, the Court of Appeals suspended the injunction of the Common Pleas Court against submission of that question to the voters, but enjoined the counting of the ballots and ordered that they should be impounded until this cause was finally determined.

Thereafter, on February 27, 1968, the Court of Appeals rendered a judgment affirming the judgment of the Common Pleas Court and continuing its order against the counting and providing for the impounding of the ballots.

The cause is now before this court upon appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals, both as an appeal involving [***2] substantial constitutional questions and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.
Blacker v. Wiethe, 13 Ohio App. 2d 199, 235 N.E.2d 142, 1968 Ohio App. LEXIS 415 (Ohio Ct. App., Hamilton County, 1968)



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Board of Elections of Hamilton County, challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court, which entered an order against the counting and providing for the impounding of ballots in a certain election. Appellees were citizens of the County.


OVERVIEW: The citizens sought to enjoin the Board's submission, in an election, of a question of adopting an alternative form of County government. The trial court entered a permanent injunction and the appellate court affirmed the decision. On appeal, the court reversed the judgment of the appellate court. The court held that the Board was authorized to submit the question pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 302.13(M). The court held that while § 302.13(M) purported to grant legislative power to a board of county commissioners acting under the alternative form of government proposed in the submission, the statute did not purport to grant limitless legislative power. The court also held that nothing in Ohio Const. art. X supported a reasonable conclusion that Ohio Const. art. X, §§ 3, 4 constituted a limitation on the power of the general assembly under Ohio Const. art. X, § 1 by general laws to provide for the government of counties and for alternative forms of County government for submission to the electors of a county and approval by a majority of those voting on it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court and entered final judgment for the Board.

 

109 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Baston v. Sears


No. 41259


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 2d 166; 239 N.E.2d 62; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 389; 44 Ohio Op. 2d 144



July 10, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Josephine Baston bore a child, William Curtis Baston, out of wedlock in 1962. She subsequently married a man other than the father of the child. In 1964, after her marriage, she brought an action for a declaratory judgment on behalf of the child, as his next friend, in the Juvenile Division of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County. In this action, she seeks to have the court declare that one James Russell Sears is the father of the child, and that the child has the right to receive support money from Sears.

Sears filed a general demurrer to the petition. The Court of Common Pleas sustained the demurrer and dismissed the action. Upon appeal, the Court of Appeals, holding that a declaratory judgment action will lie to determine the parenthood of an illegitimate child, and to secure thereby an order for his support and maintenance, reversed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

The cause is here for determination pursuant to the allowance of Sears' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On behalf of her illegitimate child, plaintiff mother filed a declaratory judgment action against defendant, the child's alleged father, seeking to have the issues of paternity and child support determined. The trial court sustained the alleged father's demurrer and dismissed the action. The Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), reversed the trial court's judgment. The alleged father challenged that decision.


OVERVIEW: The mother filed a declaratory judgment action in order to have the trial court determine the issue of her illegitimate child's paternity and the issue of that child's right to receive support money from his alleged father. The trial court sustained the alleged father's demurrer and dismissed the action. The intermediate appellate court reversed that judgment and held that a declaratory judgment action could lie to determine the parenthood of an illegitimate child and to secure an order for his support. On further appeal, the court reversed the intermediate appellate court's decision and affirmed the trial court's judgment. According to the court, there was no common-law or statutory right for an illegitimate child to receive support from its father. The court held that, because Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2151.42 made no provision for a civil action and gave no substantive right of enforcement of support to the mother's illegitimate child, the decision of the intermediate court was legislative, and thus, invalid. In addition, the court rejected the mother's argument that the different legal treatment of legitimate children and illegitimate children violated the equal protection clause.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the intermediate appellate court's decision and affirmed the trial court's decision.

 

110 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cook-Johnson Realty Co. v. Bertolini


No. 41306


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 2d 195; 239 N.E.2d 80; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 395; 44 Ohio Op. 2d 160



July 10, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

Appellant herein is the owner of lot No. 225, Trophy Estates Plat No. 5, situated in Austintown Township, Mahoning County, Ohio. Appellees herein are the duly elected and acting trustees of Austintown Township and the duly appointed and acting zoning inspector of Austintown Township.

Appellant's property consists of slightly more than 15 acres, having a frontage of 741 feet on the west side of Racoon Road in Austintown Township, and a depth of approximately 843 feet. Originally, as part of a 1948 zoning ordinance, this land was zoned entirely Residence R-1 (single family residences only). However, wishing to construct apartment dwellings on the tract, appellant succeeded, in 1959, in obtaining a Residence R-2 (multiple family residences) classification for a portion 741 feet wide along Racoon Road, 325 feet deep along the northerly property line and 480 feet deep along the southerly property line. In early 1966, appellant applied to the zoning commission of Austintown Township to rezone the remainder of the tract to a Residence R-2 classification. The zoning commission of Austintown Township and the Mahoning County Planning [***2] Commission approved the application, but the trustees of Austintown Township modified the recommendation of the zoning commission and rezoned the land Residence R-2 to a depth of only 525 feet in all, leaving the remainder of the lot zoned as Residence R-1. Appellant then brought this action for a declaratory judgment in the Common Pleas Court of Mahoning County, seeking a determination that appellee-trustees acted arbitrarily, unreasonably and unlawfully, a determination that the zoning amendment is unconstitutional, and an order of the court requiring appellee zoning inspector to issue the necessary permits to allow appellant to construct apartment dwellings on the property in question.

During the pendency of the proceedings in the Common Pleas Court, a duly executed referendum petition was filed with the Austintown Township trustees, in accordance with the provisions of Section 519.12, Revised Code. This petition requested submission of the 1966 zoning amendment to the township electorate at the November 8, 1966, general election. The referendum petition was complied with, and resulted in the voters of Austintown Township rejecting the 1966 zoning change by a vote of 5,993 to [***3] 1,441.

On December 30, 1966, without giving any consideration to the result of the referendum, the Common Pleas Court decided the issues in this cause adversely to appellant, and accordingly gave judgment for appellees. An appeal on questions of law and fact was prosecuted from that decision.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals took judicial notice of the referendum and dismissed the appeal, finding that the referendum had restored appellant's property to its 1959 status, and that the Common Pleas Court judgment was void. The Court of Appeals found constitutionally valid those provisions of Section 519.12, Revised Code, giving the right of referendum to the electors of a township on zoning amendments passed by the township trustees, and decided that there was "no longer a debatable issue to be determined."

The cause is here pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner challenged the decision from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County (Ohio), which dismissed the owner's action against appellee Austintown Township Trustees for a declaratory judgment.


OVERVIEW: The owner sought to have its property rezoned to a multifamily classification. Upon the owner's rezoning application, the zoning commission and planning commission recommended rezoning, but the Trustees modified the recommendation and only approved the rezoning of a portion of the property. The owner brought an action for declaratory judgment and sought a determination that the Trustees acted arbitrarily and that the zoning amendment was unconstitutional. During the pendency of the action, a referendum petition was filed with the Trustees, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 519.12, which rejected the zoning change. Thus, the trial court found in favor of the Trustees. The appellate court voided the trial court's judgment and dismissed the appeal because there was no longer a debatable issue to be determined. The owner appealed. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that the court found no constitutional impediment to the power granted to the Trustees to make zoning resolutions and that § 519.12 was constitutional. The court also found that the owner did not exhaust its administrative remedy and could not make a showing that an adequate remedy at law was not available.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision, which dismissed the owner's appeal in the owner's action for declaratory judgment regarding zoning laws.

 

111 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Euclid v. Heaton


Nos. 41178, 41193, 41194, 41228


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 2d 65; 238 N.E.2d 790; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 374; 44 Ohio Op. 2d 50



June 19, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hancock County.

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

State v. Dodge represents the appeals of the state to this court in two cases wherein Dodge was indicted for the first degree murder of his mother-in-law (No. 41193) and of his wife (No. 41194).

After a jury had been selected, impanelled and sworn to try defendant for the murder of his mother-in-law, he withdrew his pleas of "not guilty" and "not guilty by reason of insanity," and entered a written plea of guilty as charged. At the same time, defendant entered a written plea of guilty to second degree murder in connection with the death of his wife, although he had not yet been brought to trial on that charge. Both pleas were made with the approval of the court and with the consent of the prosecutor and defendant's counsel.

Subsequently, in the mother-in-law case, a three-judge court was convened pursuant to Section 2945.06, Revised Code, and it fixed the degree of the crime as second degree murder. The state's exceptions to this determination were overruled and defendant was sentenced to life imprisonment.

 [***2] Thereafter, on October 17, 1966, the state filed a motion in the case of the wife, requesting the court not to allow the previously entered plea of guilty to second degree murder. The motion was overruled by the resident judge of the Common Pleas Court who then sentenced defendant to life imprisonment.

In both cases, the state filed notices of appeal as of right to the Court of Appeals and applications for leave to file bills of exceptions pursuant to Sections 2945.67 to 2945.70, 1 inclusive, Revised Code.


1 Section 2945.67, Revised Code, provides:

"The prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or the attorney general may except to a decision of the court and present a bill of exceptions thereto. The court shall sign said bill and it shall be made a part of the record."

 Section 2945.68, Revised Code, provides:

"The prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or the attorney general may present a bill of exceptions in a criminal action to the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court and apply for permission to file it with the clerk of the court for the decision of such court upon the points presented therein. Prior thereto, he shall give reasonable notice to the judge who presided at the trial in which such bill was taken, of his purpose to make such application. If the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court allows the bill to be filed, the prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or attorney general shall, within ten days of the filing of the bill, file his brief in support of such exceptions and forth-with serve a copy thereof upon the trial judge and any attorney appointed by the judge to argue the exceptions against the prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or the attorney general."

 Section 2945.69, Revised Code, provides:

"The trial judge may appoint some competent attorney to argue the bill of exceptions against the prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or the attorney general under Section 2945.68 of the Revised Code, and such appointee shall receive for his services a fee of not more than one hundred dollars, to be fixed by the judge and paid out of the treasury of the county in which the bill was taken. Such attorney shall file his brief against the prosecuting attorney, solicitor, or the attorney general within ten days after service upon him of the brief in support of said exceptions. The hearing of such cases shall have precedence of other business and such cases shall be continued upon the docket of the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court until argued and submitted."

 Section 2945.70, Revised Code, provides:

"If the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court is of the opinion that the questions presented by a bill of exceptions should be decided, it shall allow the bill of exceptions to be filed and render a decision thereon. This decision shall not affect the judgment of the trial court in said cause, nor shall said judgment of the trial court be reversed, unless the judgment of the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court reversed the judgment of the trial court on its ruling on a motion to quash, a plea in abatement, a demurrer, or a motion in arrest of judgment. In all other cases the decision of the Court of Appeals or the Supreme Court shall determine the law to govern in a similar case."

 [***3] The Court of Appeals held that those sections of the Revised Code are unconstitutional as being an attempt to enlarge the jurisdiction and judicial power of the Court of Appeals beyond that prescribed by Section 6, Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, by attempting to bestow upon that court the power to render an advisory opinion where jeopardy has attached ( State v. Dodge, 10 Ohio App. 2d 92), and that the state had no appeal as of right in either case.

No. 41228 (State v. Benjamin) came to the Court of Appeals on the prosecuting attorney's attempt to have that court review, pursuant to the same sections of the Revised Code, the trial court's granting of defendant's oral "motion to dismiss" the indictment for carrying a concealed weapon contrary to Section 2923.01, Revised Code. The basis of that "motion" was that the indictment was insufficient in that it did not specify the type and length of the weapon. The trial court did not appoint counsel under Section 2945.67, Revised Code. The Court of Appeals overruled the prosecutor's application for permission to file a bill of exceptions on the ground that it had "no jurisdiction to entertain" the same on the basis [***4] of Dodge (10 Ohio App. 2d 92). It then certified the case to this court as in conflict with the case of State v. Doyle, 11 Ohio App. 2d 97.

In case No. 41178 (City of Euclid v. Heaton), defendant was acquitted, after a trial, of the charge of engaging in common labor on Sunday in violation of Section 3773.24, Revised Code. The bill of exceptions of Euclid's solicitor was signed by the trial court and allowed by the Court of Appeals. The trial court did not appoint an attorney pursuant to Section 2945.69, Revised Code. Heaton claimed an interest in the "appeal" because in future cases affecting her, the trial court, on similar facts, would be bound to follow the decision of the Court of Appeals.

Although that court refused to permit Heaton to intervene as an appellee by counsel of her own selection, it did consider her counsel's motion to dismiss the "appeal," claiming that Sections 2945.67 to 2945.70, inclusive, Revised Code, were unconstitutional, and overruled the same. Thereafter, counsel was permitted to participate in the "appeal" as an amicus curiae. The Court of Appeals rendered an opinion finding error in the trial court's dismissal of the affidavit [***5] and discharge of the defendant. Its judgment was limited to the assessment of costs against Euclid and did not attempt otherwise to affect the judgment of the trial court.



DISPOSITION: In case No. 41178, decision reversed. In case Nos. 41193 and 41194, judgments affirmed. In case No. 41228, judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Several appellate court cases were reviewed. In the first appeal from a Court of Appeals (Ohio), a defendant charged with engaging in common labor on a Sunday challenged the finding of error in her dismissal and discharge. In the next three appeals, the State challenged the finding that it did not have the right to appeal a defendant's second-degree murder convictions and the dismissal of another defendant's carrying a concealed weapon charge.


OVERVIEW: In the first case the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2945.67 to 2945.70 was at issue. The State filed a bill of exceptions after defendant was acquitted. The bill was allowed and an attorney was not appointed for defendant under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.69. Defendant claimed an interest in the appeal because of future cases affecting her. The court reversed the judgment and held for naught. In the second and third appeals defendant pled guilty to murdering his mother-in-law and entered a plea of guilty to second-degree murder of his wife. Thereafter, in the mother-in-law case, a three-judge court convened pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann, § 2945.06 and fixed the crime as second degree murder. The State excepted to the determination, which was overruled. The court affirmed. Finally, in the fourth appeal, defendant's oral motion to dismiss an indictment for carrying a concealed weapon was granted and the State's attempt to have an appellate court review the case was overruled on the ground it had no jurisdiction. The court reversed. The court concluded the appellate court did not have jurisdiction and judicial power beyond that prescribed by Ohio Const. art. IV, § 6.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in the first appeal and held for naught. The court affirmed the second and third appeals and reversed the fourth appeal.

 

112 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Anderson v. Brown


No. 40547


Supreme Court of Ohio


13 Ohio St. 2d 53; 233 N.E.2d 584; 1968 Ohio LEXIS 463; 42 Ohio Op. 2d 100



January 24, 1968, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lawrence County.

The appellant is the owner of the Chesapeake Trailer Park in the village of Chesapeake, Ohio. He brought this action in the Lawrence County Court of Common Pleas to enjoin the enforcement of village ordinances Nos. 348 and 349.

The pertinent parts of ordinance No. 348 set forth certain health and sanitary regulations for house trailer parks operated within the village and provide for the licensing of such parks. Compliance with the regulations and payment of the license or permit fee of $ 25 per year for the first two trailer spaces and two dollars for each additional space are the primary requisites for obtaining a permit. Any person operating a trailer park in the village without a village permit may be fined up to $ 50 for each day of operation. The appellant operated his trailer park without obtaining a permit, and consequently the city prosecuted him for violating ordinance No. 348. Upon the commencement of that prosecution the appellant brought the present action for injunction.

Ordinance No. 349 purports to regulate the use of house trailers within the village. It requires any person locating a house trailer in [***2] any house trailer park within the village to obtain a yearly permit, which will be issued to him upon the approval of the town marshal and the payment of a $ 36 fee. A penalty of not more than $ 50 for each day of noncompliance is provided.

The appellant contends that these ordinances violate Section 3, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution, which limits local police, sanitary and other similar regulations to those not in conflict with general laws. The allegedly conflicting laws are Sections 3733.03 to 3733.07, Revised Code, concerning the licensing of trailer parks, and Section 4503.06, Revised Code, concerning taxes on house trailers.

The Court of Common Pleas issued a temporary restraining order, but later dissolved it, finding that the ordinances did not conflict with the state statutes. The Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal, holding that an injunction action was not proper because the pending criminal proceeding provides an adequate remedy at law.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant trailer park owner sought review of an order from the Ohio Court of Appeals dismissing his appeal of the dissolution of a temporary restraining order enjoining appellee mayor from enforcing village ordinances.


OVERVIEW: The village issued ordinances regulating trailer parks. The trailer park owner sought to enjoin the enforcement of the ordinances on the ground that they were unconstitutional. The temporary restraining order was issued, and then was dissolved. The court of appeals affirmed the dissolution on the ground that the ordinances did not conflict with state statutes. The trailer park owner sought review of the decision. The court noted that Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3 provided municipalities with the authority to exercise all powers of self-government and to adopt and enforce local police, sanitary, and other similar regulations, as were not in conflict with general laws. Since one of the ordinances forbade and prohibited that which was directly permitted and allowed by state statute, that ordinance was in conflict with state statutes, and was prohibited. Thus the injunctive relief sought by the trailer park owner should have been granted as to that ordinance. As to the remaining ordinance, the court concluded that it was not violative of state statute and thus was not subject to injunctive relief.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals with regard to one ordinance was affirmed, but their decision with regard to another ordinance was reversed and remanded.

 

113 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Peltz v. South Euclid


No. 40416


Supreme Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 2d 128; 228 N.E.2d 320; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 342; 40 Ohio Op. 2d 129



July 12, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL as of right from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County upon substantial constitutional questions and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.

Plaintiff brought this action against the city of South Euclid in the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief pursuant to Section 2721.03, Revised Code, 1 seeking to have the court declare unconstitutional defendant's ordinance No. 18-63 enacted "to eliminate political signs." 2 The ordinance prohibits all political signs upon penalty of up to $ 500 a day whether on public or private property, or whether they are reasonable in size, appearance and content. The parties have stipulated that the ordinance was enacted to abate a potential traffic hazard and the unsightliness resulting from the widespread use of these signs. 3 Prior thereto political signs were permitted for a period of not more than 30 days before and ten days after an election.


1 Section 2721.03, Revised Code: "Any person interested under a deed, will, written contract, or other writing constituting a contract, or whose rights, status, or other legal relations are affected by a constitutional provision, statute, rule as defined in Section 119.01 of the Revised Code, municipal ordinance, contract or franchise, may have determined any question of construction or validity arising under such instrument, constitutional provision, statute, rule, ordinance, contract, or franchise and obtain a declaration of rights, status, or other legal relations thereunder."

 [***2] 

2 Ordinance No. 18-63 of the city of South Euclid is a negative ordinance, proscribing all signs that are not specifically permitted by it. It is entitled, "an ordinance amending the zoning code of the codified ordinances of the city of South Euclid, particularly Section 733.05 of Chapter 33 and Section 755.08 of Chapter 55, so as to eliminate political signs."

It was stipulated that "political signs, as referred to in the foregoing ordinances, include any sign which would be visible to passing traffic announcing, advocating, promoting or otherwise commenting upon a political candidate or a political subject or issue, except those political signs on vehicles not exceeding a total of one square foot in area, permitted under Section 501.07 of the codified ordinances of the city of South Euclid," and that "political signs, as referred to in the foregoing ordinances, include, as a matter of legislative intention, political signs attached to real property."


3 It was further stipulated that "the ordinances * * * were enacted in response to the following * * *:

"(a) At election times political signs were widely employed.

"(b) Such signs were often unattractive even when freshly erected and unspoiled.

"(c) Such signs were often permitted by the owners of the signs or the premises on which they stood to remain for an unreasonable period of time after the election to which they pertained.

"(d) Such signs were often neglected and permitted to become torn and unsightly.

"(e) Such signs were frequently defaced by vandals.

"(f) Such signs were often affixed to public property and had to be removed at public expense.

"(g) Signs were erected on main thoroughfares and at street intersections, as well as on residential lawns, and created a potential traffic hazard.

"(h) In consequence of the foregoing conditions, elections were generally accompanied by widespread unsightly litter and mess."

 [***3] Plaintiff appears as a resident, citizen, property owner and duly nominated candidate for the office of Senator of the state of Ohio for Cuyahoga County in the general election of Novvember 3, 1964. He also intends to run for political office in the future. But for the prohibitions of the ordinance in question, which the municipal authorities have publicly announced their intention to enforce, plaintiff stipulates he would erect and maintain on the front lawn of his property in the defendant municipality a political sign one foot square, briefly stating his position on a political question.

On November 17, 1964, the case was heard by the trial court on an agreed stipulation of facts. That court held that the question of the constitutional validity of the ordinance was moot and that plaintiff lacked sufficient interest and standing to raise the question since the election had been conducted and concluded on November 3, 1964. The Court of Appeals affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizen challenged, as of right, a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment that the question of the constitutional validity of South Euclid, Ohio Ordinance No. 18-63 was moot and that the citizen lacked sufficient interest and standing to raise the question because the election had been conducted and concluded. Defendant city passed the ordinance to ban political signs.


OVERVIEW: A violation of the ordinance was punishable as a misdemeanor. The court noted that the validity, construction, and application of criminal statutes and ordinances were appropriate subjects for a declaratory judgment action. On appeal, the court reversed the appellate court's judgment finding that the citizen had sufficient standing for declaratory relief under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2721.03 and for a determination of the validity of the ordinance. The court noted that the controversy did not disappear after the election, which did not eliminate the question of the citizen's constitutional right as a citizen, resident, and property owner to erect signs for candidates in the future. The court held that, although the city could have enacted regulations in the interest of the public safety, health, welfare, or convenience, these could not abridge the individual liberties secured by the United States and Ohio Constitutions. The court held that the ordinance violated Ohio Const. art. I, § 11, as well as the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. The court permanently enjoined the city from enforcing the ordinance to the extent of its constitutional infirmity.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court and permanently enjoined the city from enforcing the ordinance to the extent of its constitutional infirmity.

 

114 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. King v. Rhodes


No. 40475


Supreme Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 2d 95; 228 N.E.2d 653; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 341; 40 Ohio Op. 2d 109



June 30, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeals in an action in prohibition originally filed in that court. Relator, appellee herein, in his petition alleges that respondents, the Governor, Secretary of State and Auditor of State, acting as the Apportionment Board, adopted an apportionment plan for the state in September 1965 and that their action in so doing was unconstitutional. It is alleged that the Secretary of State would be governed by the apportionment plan, and that the Governor would cause publication of the plan, thereby causing an illegal expenditure of public funds by the state Treasurer.

The prayer of the petition is for a writ of prohibition and temporary restraining order "preventing James A. Rhodes from continuing to advertise said purported apportionment, restraining John D. Herbert from expending public funds to pay for said advertisements, and further restraining Ted W. Brown from accepting any declarations of candidacy and nominating petitions based on said purported apportionment * * *."

Relator prays further that the Secretary of State be restrained from taking other procedural steps in connection [***2] with the conduct of the election, that the Apportionment Board be restrained from taking further steps in connection with the apportionment plan, and that the apportionment plan already made be declared null and void.

This action was filed on October 18, 1965, and an alternative writ of prohibition and injunction were granted by the Court of Appeals. On November 4, 1965, the alternative writ of prohibition and injunction were modified to conform to an order of the United States District Court, S. D. Ohio E. D., entered on October 27, 1965, which involved three related cases decided by that court. ( Nolan v. Rhodes, 251 F. Supp. 584, affirmed, 383 U.S. 104.) In those cases the federal District Court proceeded to act under authority specified in Reynolds, Judge, v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, which case instructed the United States District Court to formulate apportionment plans in the event states failed to do so. Pursuant to that decision the federal District Court entered an order requesting each party to actions Nos. 6082 and 6491 "to file on or before October 15, 1965, suggested plans for the reapportionment of the Ohio House of Representatives and a suggested plan for [***3] the reapportionment of the Ohio Senate, and the order further provided that any interested person or persons might within the same period of time file such suggested plans by leave. Pursuant thereto such plans have been filed by the parties as well as by many other interested persons and organizations. Among the plans filed by the parties is one which was filed by the Governor, Auditor of State and Secretary of State of Ohio. Those state officials constitute the Apportionment Board created by Article XI, Section 11 of the Ohio Constitution * * *."

The United States District Court noted that the reason for the submission of these suggested plans was that that court, pursuant to a mandate from the Supreme Court of the United States (378 U.S. 556), previously had declared the prior apportionment unconstitutional. The federal District Court found that the apportionment plan submitted by the Apportionment Board did not violate the Constitution of the United States.

In speaking of the Apportionment Board's plan the federal court said:

"It is the position of said state officials, as urged in the supporting brief accompanying the plan filed in this court by the Attorney General of Ohio,  [***4] that they acted in accordance with the authority of said Section 11, thereby performing the mandatory duty imposed upon the board to reapportion the Ohio General Assembly.

"It is axiomatic that any action taken by a properly constituted governmental agency is entitled to a presumption of validity, and accordingly the action of the Apportionment Board is here to be presumed to be legal, valid and constitutionally taken. (See, e. g., Goldberg v. Truck Drivers Local Union No. 299, 293 F. 2d 806 [6th Cir. 1961].) In this regard, mention is made of the fact that such constitutionality has been challenged in an action instituted in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, Ohio, October 20th, 1965, in action No. 8228 on the docket of that court. Until or unless the presumption of validity hereinabove referred to is dissipated by determination by the Ohio courts, the presumption is deemed binding upon this court, the question whether the board acted in accordance with authority conferred by the Constitution of Ohio being peculiarly one of Ohio law and appropriate for resolution in the courts of that state.

"We regard the apportionment of the General Assembly of Ohio as being [***5] a legislative rather than a judicial function. The federal court should intervene only to protect rights guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States. When a state apportionment has been declared unconstitutional the federal court should devise and put into effect a reapportionment plan only as a last resort when the Legislature fails or is unable to act. In devising a plan the court acts to prevent a breakdown or disruption of essential state government services.

"If the presumption of validity prevails and finds support in the Ohio courts, it must necessarily follow that by its action the board has established a plan for the reapportionment of the General Assembly and the only determination to be made by this court is whether or not such plan is in violation of the Constitution of the United States or any provisions thereof. A study of such plan convinces us that the apportionment made by the board conforms as nearly as practicable according to population and follows the rules enunciated by the Supreme Court in Reynolds. This court therefore finds that said plan is not violative of the Constitution of the United States."

Thus, it was left to the Ohio courts to decide [***6] whether the Apportionment Board acted legally under authority granted by the Ohio Constitution.

The Court of Appeals for Franklin County granted the writ, holding that the Apportionment Board had authority to meet only after each decennial period, and that, having met and acted in 1961, it had no authority to meet again until after the next decennial census.

The entry of the Franklin County Court of Appeals reads in part:

"Article XI of the Ohio Constitution, Sections one through eleven, prescribes the method and manner of apportionment for the Ohio House and the Ohio Senate. By a series of federal court cases filed in the Southern District of Ohio, the apportionment of both the Ohio House of Representatives and the Ohio Senate, effected in 1961 by the Apportionment Board acting pursuant to the provisions of Article XI, was held unconstitutional as being in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and said court invalidated in whole or in part numerous sections of Article XI of the Ohio Constitution. Said United States District Court ordered into effect an apportionment plan for Ohio for the 1966 general elections but reserved to the state courts [***7] the question of the validity, under the Ohio Constitution, of the action taken by the Ohio Apportionment Board in 1965 in adopting a plan for the remainder of the decennium.

"This court finds that the aforenamed respondents acted without authority either from the Ohio Constitution or the laws of this state in adopting and attempting to put into effect an apportionment for the remainder of the decennium, and that said apportionment is null and void. This finding does not affect the federal court order for the 1966 elections."

The cause is now before this court on direct appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state citizen sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's ruling that respondents, the Governor, the Secretary of State, and the Auditor of the State, together acting as the Ohio Apportionment Board, could not adopt an apportionment plan and that their actions violated the Ohio Constitution, after a federal court ruled that several state apportionment sections were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: A federal district court ruled as unconstitutional several of Ohio's apportionment provisions contained within Ohio's Constitution, including the Board's most recent apportionment. The apportionment provisions that remained in Ohio Const. art. XI mandated reapportionment every 10 years. The citizen alleged that the Board's action to adopt a new apportionment prior to expiration of the 10-year period violated Ohio Const. art. XI, § 11. The court reversed the appeal's court judgment affirming the prohibition on the reapportionment. The court held that the remaining provisions in Ohio Const. art. XI, §§ 1, 6, and 11 were severable, and thus operable, from the other sections that were found unconstitutional by the federal courts. The court then held that the Board not only had the implied power, but also a duty to act pursuant to § 11 to reapportion the districts within the state into a valid apportionment, where the prior apportionment was declared a nullity. The court held that to hold otherwise would leave the state without an apportionment for legislative representative in a process that had been approved by the citizens of the state.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appeals court's affirmance of the trial court's ruling that respondents were prohibited from adopting an apportionment plan under the provisions of the remaining Constitutional apportionment sections.

 

115 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Benda v. Fana


No. 40452


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 2d 259; 227 N.E.2d 197; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 405; 39 Ohio Op. 2d 410



June 7, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This case originated in the Lyndhurst Municipal Court, in Cuyahoga County, to recover damages allegedly sustained in a motor vehicle collision which occurred on December 27, 1963. Plaintiff seeks a recovery of $ 10,000. After the petition was filed, and the case was at issue, counsel for defendant made a written offer to allow judgment for the sum of $ 500, pursuant to Section 2311.17, Revised Code, on July 25, 1965. The offer to allow judgment pursuant to Section 2311.17, Revised Code, was rejected by plaintiff on August 11, 1965.

Subsequent to the rejection of the foregoing offer by plaintiff, a medical examination was obtained, at the request of defendant, by Dr. Byron K. Hoffman, as an incident to preparation for and trial of this action. In addition to the foregoing expenditure, certain of the court costs assessed against plaintiff were incurred during the interval between the rejection of the offer and the trial of this action.

When the case was called for trial, and out of the presence of the jury, defendant renewed his offer to allow judgment for $ 500, originally made pursuant to Section 2311.17, Revised Code, and [***2] also made an additional offer to confess judgment for $ 500 pursuant to Section 2311.18, Revised Code. Both offers were rejected and the case proceeded to trial with the jury returning a verdict for plaintiff for $ 500. Following the verdict of the jury, defendant filed a motion to tax certain of his expenditures and court costs. The motion of defendant was granted and the court taxed the items set forth in such motion as costs of this proceeding.

Plaintiff appealed from the judgment assessing the costs against him to the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, where the judgment was modified by elimination of those items of costs and expenses incurred subsequent to the first written offer to allow judgment and previous to the second such offer "for the reason that said items accrued after defendant's offer out of court to allow judgment was withdrawn by operation of law. R. C., Section 2311.17."

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff accident victim challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which modified a trial court's judgment assessing costs against the accident victim in an action to recover damages for injuries that he sustained in a collision. The appellate court modified the judgment in defendant's favor by deducting items that accrued after defendant's settlement offer was withdrawn and before the offer was renewed at trial.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff accident victim filed an action against defendant to recover damages for injuries that he allegedly sustained in a motor vehicle collision. The accident victim rejected defendant's subsequent offer to allow judgment. Defendant later renewed his offer to allow judgment and made an additional offer to confess judgment. The accident victim rejected defendant's offers and the case proceeded to trial. The jury returned a verdict in the accident victim's favor for the amount offered by defendant. Following the jury's verdict, defendant filed a motion to tax certain of his expenditures and court costs. The trial court granted defendant's motion. Upon review, the appellate court modified the trial court's judgment. Upon further review, the appellate court's judgment was reversed and remanded by the court. The court held that the accident victim was responsible for paying the costs incurred by defendant from the time he rejected defendant's offer. The court further held that the accident victim was only responsible for paying those costs that were specifically imposed by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2311.17, 2311.18.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment and remanded the action to the trial court for a reassessment of the accident victim's statutory costs.

 

116 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Mac Realty, Inc. v. Commercial Industrial Enterprises, Inc.


No. 40210


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 2d 227; 227 N.E.2d 210; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 397; 39 Ohio Op. 2d 365



May 31, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

This case arose as a result of certain proposed zoning changes in Boardman Township, Mahoning County, Ohio.

The appellants herein, and other property owners, requested the Boardman Township Zoning Commission to rezone certain properties to a business use. The zoning commission approved and recommended the changes. Under the provisions of Section 519.12, Revised Code, such recommendations are then submitted to the Board of Township Trustees for adoption or rejection. The pertinent part of Section 519.12, Revised Code, reads as follows:

"Within twenty days after such public hearing the board shall either adopt or deny the recommendations of the zoning commission or adopt some modification thereof. In the event the board denies or modifies the recommendation of the Township Zoning Commission the unanimous vote of the board shall be required."

The township trustees held the required public hearing and then put the matter to a vote. Two of the members voted to deny the recommendation and the third member voted to adopt it.

Appellee filed an action praying for an injunction to prevent the appellant owners and developers from [***2] erecting commercial buildings on the property involved and to prevent the defendant township trustees and the zoning inspector from issuing a permit for such construction. Defendant township trustees cross-petitioned for a declaratory judgment as to the legal effect of their actions. This prayer was then joined by all parties.

The Court of Common Pleas granted plaintiff the relief prayed for and issued the requested injunctions.

On an appeal on questions of law and fact, the same judgment was entered by the Court of Appeals.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed an order granting appellee corporation's action seeking an injunction blocking zoning changes that the property owners had sought.


OVERVIEW: The property owners applied for rezoning of an area for business use. The city's zoning commission recommended the rezoning; however, the board of trustees was split on the issue. In response to the corporation's claim for injunctive relief, the property owners argued that the failure to unanimously reject the recommendation of the zoning commission amounted to an adoption of the recommendation. On review, the court agreed and reversed the decision of the lower appellate court. In reaching its conclusion, the court analogized Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. 519.12, which detailed the provisions under which the trustees approved or rejected proposed rezoning recommendations, to state constitutional provisions detailing the court's vote on the validity of laws.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower appellate court's order affirming the entry of an injunction blocking zoning changes.

 

117 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Perry


Nos. 40299, 40300, 40301, 40302


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 2d 175; 226 N.E.2d 104; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 387; 39 Ohio Op. 2d 189



May 3, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant prisoners challenged the judgments of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the denial of their petitions for postconviction relief under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.21 et seq.


OVERVIEW: The trial court denied the prisoner's petitions under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.21 after finding that there was no denial or infringement of the prisoners' rights. The trial court admittedly did not cause notice of the petition to be served on the prosecuting attorney and did not grant a hearing in prisoners' cases, but rather concluded that the files and records showed that prisoners were entitled to no relief. On appeal, the court agreed. The court held that voidable judgments under § 2953.21 could be construed so as not to interfere with the doctrine of res judicata. None of prisoners' petitions included any allegations that would have justified an inference that the constitutional questions were not raised or could not have been raised, litigated, and adjudicated against the prisoners by the judgment of conviction or by appeals in the ordinary course. Those judgments, whether appealed from or not, barred the prisoners from raising the same questions in postconviction proceedings under § 2953.21.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the court of appeals denying the prisoners' petitions for postconviction relief.

 

118 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Foreman v. Brown


No. 40903


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 2d 139; 226 N.E.2d 116; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 596; 39 Ohio Op. 2d 149



April 19, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relators filed a petition in this court on April 5, 1967, seeking a writ of mandamus ordering the Secretary of State to advise, instruct and compel his representatives, the county Boards of Elections, not to proceed further with a special election on May 2, 1967, on a constitutional amendment, proposed by the 107th General Assembly in Amended Substitute House Joint Resolution No. 22. That proposed amendment would add Section 2i to Article VIII of the Ohio Constitution. It has been designated as Issue No. 1 and is generally referred to as the Ohio Bond Commission Amendment.

Several other individuals, who had instituted actions to enjoin such election in various counties of the state, have been permitted to intervene as parties.

On April 13, 1967, the case was submitted for decision on the petition and an agreed statement of facts.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators filed a petition for a writ of mandamus, seeking to compel respondent Secretary of State to desist from holding a special election on a constitutional amendment that pertained to the state bond commission.


OVERVIEW: The state general assembly proposed an amendment to the state constitution that pertained to the bond commission, and a date was set for the special election. Relators sought a writ of mandamus to stop the Secretary of State from proceeding with the special election. The court denied the petition. It found that the general assembly was authorized under Ohio Const. art. XVI, § 1 to authorize a special election for a proposed amendment to the state constitution without enacting a statute. The court further found that there was nothing in the state constitution that required an amendment proposed by the General Assembly pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XVI, § 1 to be confined to one subject, purpose, or object. The court also found that neither the length of the condensed text nor any omissions was likely to mislead voters.


OUTCOME: The court denied the relators' petition for a writ of mandamus.

 

119 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Platz v. Mucci


No. 40166


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 2d 60; 225 N.E.2d 238; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 369; 39 Ohio Op. 2d 48



April 5, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN QUO WARRANTO.

ON MOTION for Summary Judgment.

This is an action in quo warranto originating in this court. In his petition, relator alleges that he is a resident of the city of Wickliffe, a public-school teacher teaching in a school outside such city, and that on November 2, 1965, he was elected to the council of such city. He alleges further that the board of elections declared him duly elected and issued a certificate of election, and that on January 1, 1966, he took the oath of office.

His qualification was questioned on the basis of the provision of the charter which reads as follows:

"No person shall serve as a member of council unless during his term of office he shall continue to be a resident and a qualified elector of the city of Wickliffe, and if elected or appointed from a ward, shall be and continue to be a resident of such ward. He shall not hold any other public office or public employment, except as otherwise provided in this chapter * * *." (Emphasis added.)

On January 10, 1966, the council refused to seat him on the basis of his public employment as a school teacher, declared a vacancy to exist and on January 24, 1966, appointed respondent to fill the [***2] vacancy.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator teacher brought this original action in quo warranto to compel respondent city council to seat him as a member of the council. The board of elections had declared him duly elected and issued a certificate of election but the council refused to seat him on the basis of a city charter provision that forbade council members from holding public employment. The teacher filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The teacher was employed in a public school outside the city. The charter provision was subsequently amended to limit the prohibition to city employment. The court noted that there was no basic inherent or constitutional right to hold public office and that legislatures could impose certain basic qualifications upon those who sought public office so long as a classification was clear, rested on some reasonable ground, and affected all persons in the class equally. The court held that a classification, though discriminatory, was not arbitrary nor violative of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment if any state of facts reasonably could be conceived that would sustain it. The court held that a prohibition against receiving salaries from two positions supported by public tax dollars had a valid public purpose and that the charter provision was reasonable. The court also found that City of Wickliffe, Ohio, Charter art. III, § 3, which provided for the expulsion or removal of a member of council, did not apply to the teacher because he had never been seated as a member. The court further held that the amendment to the charter could not be applied retroactively.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the motion for summary judgment and denied the writ of quo warranto.

 

120 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Jackman v. Court of Common Pleas


No. 40444


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 2d 159; 224 N.E.2d 906; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 439; 38 Ohio Op. 2d 404



March 22, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

After David Terelli and Norman T. Kosky were indicted for murder in the first degree, they, through their attorneys, applied in writing to the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, in which their indictment was pending, for a commission to take depositions of certain witnesses. The trial judge set the matter for hearing, after which he announced his intention to grant such application for a commission and requested counsel to draw an order to that effect.

Thereupon five of the named witnesses filed an action in prohibition in the Court of Appeals, seeking a writ to prohibit the trial judge from entering the above order in the journal. The Court of Appeals issued the writ (6 Ohio App. 2d 182 [1966]), holding that amended Section 2945.50, Revised Code, which authorizes the trial judge's intended action, violated Section 10, Article I of the Ohio Constitution, and also constituted an unlawful delegation of legislative powers to the trial court.

The respondents appealed to this court as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two defendants were indicted for murder in the first degree. An Ohio trial court granted defendants their motion requesting a commission to take depositions of certain witnesses. The five named witnesses filed an action in prohibition. The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) issued the writ, holding that Ohio Rev. Code § 2945.50 violated Ohio Const. art. I, §10. Defendants appealed as a matter of right.


OVERVIEW: Defendants wanted to depose five witnesses so that they could better defend themselves in their murder trial. The court held that Ohio Rev. Stat. §§ 2945.50 and 2319.14 gave the trial court discretion to consider the merits of an application for a commission in accordance with certain rules that the law has already fashioned in the discovery area. The court found that Ohio Const. art. I, §10, which concerned the taking of depositions, was not drafted to preclude a defendant from taking a deposition in a criminal action. The court found that the constitutional provision, when drafted, sought to protect the right of confrontation if the State chose to conduct a deposition in a criminal matter. The court held that Ohio Const. art. II, § 1 did not establish a clear prohibition of a trial court's discretion in granting a commission to defendants in a criminal action. In reversing the appellate decision, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code § 2945.50 did not violate Ohio Const. art. I, § 10.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment. The court denied the five named witnesses a writ of prohibition.

 

121 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Mentor v. Giordano


No. 40038


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 2d 140; 224 N.E.2d 343; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 432; 38 Ohio Op. 2d 366



March 15, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County.

Defendant, appellant herein, a minor in his late teens, was charged by affidavit in the Painesville Municipal Court under Section 205.01 of the Ordinances of the City of Mentor with operating a motor vehicle on private property in the city of Mentor on January 31, 1965, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor -- a misdemeanor. Upon defendant's arraignment, the court entered a plea of not guilty for him. After several continuances, the case came on for trial without a jury on July 15, 1965. Certain preliminary motions by counsel for defendant to correct the record and to suppress evidence on constitutional grounds were overruled, as was the demurrer to the affidavit interposed on the date of trial. Also overruled was an oral motion by defendant on the trial date, July 15, for a jury trial. It was the unsuccessful contention of the defendant that his apprehension and the incidents which followed were in violation of Sections 10 and 14, Article I of the Constitution of Ohio, and of the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

The patrolman of the Mentor Police Department who apprehended [***2] defendant testified that, pursuant to a complaint by the pastor of a church on the Lake Shore Boulevard in the city of Mentor, he proceeded to the parking lot behind the church in the very early morning and found a parked automobile with the motor running and the lights off. Four persons were inside the vehicle -- defendant, a male companion and two young women. According to the patrolman, defendant was sitting in the driver's seat behind the steering wheel. Pursuant to the patrolman's request, defendant produced his driver's license. His breath had an alcoholic odor, and his appearance and behavior indicated to the patrolman that defendant was under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Defendant, without objection, accompanied the patrolman to the Mentor police station. Defendant stated to the patrolman that he had been drinking and had been driving the automobile. Upon defendant's motion, this evidence was excluded.

Over defendant's objection, the court admitted testimony as to the results of a Breathalyzer test given defendant at the police station and as to the manner in which he performed certain physical tests, including those of co-ordination and balance. A captain [***3] of the Mentor police force on duty at the police station when defendant entered testified concerning the odor of alcohol on defendant's breath and the faulty manner in which he performed some of the physical tests. He testified further that in his opinion defendant "was under the influence of alcohol." The Breathalyzer test given defendant showed ".18 per cent." Defendant was jailed and then released under a $ 500 bond.

Defendant's only witness was his male companion, who was with him when he was apprehended. He testified that he, not the defendant, had been driving the automobile prior to parking behind the church, and that while parked the motor and lights were off. Defendant did not testify.

The court found defendant guilty, sentenced him to 15 days in jail, suspending 12 days of the sentence, fined him $ 100, placed him on probation for one year and deprived him of the right to drive a motor vehicle during that period.

Defendant's appeal on questions of law to the Court of Appeals resulted in an affirmance of the judgment below without written opinion. One judge dissented with a short dissenting opinion.

The cause is now in this court for review and decision on an appeal [***4] as of right and the allowance of the motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review as of right from a decision of the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment convicting him of the crime of operating a motor vehicle on private property while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Defendant was given a partially-suspended sentence, fined, placed on probation, and deprived of the right to drive a motor vehicle during the period of probation.


OVERVIEW: On review, defendant first contended that he was unconstitutionally denied a jury trial. The court initially noted that the case involved a misdemeanor offense. The court then found that because defendant failed to proffer a written request for a jury trial, as mandated by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.24, the trial to the court without a jury was proper. Nonetheless, the court determined that defendant was entitled to a reversal of his conviction. There was nothing to show that defendant had consumed any beverage other than beer in a moderate amount prior to the parking on the church grounds where he was subsequently arrested. Although defendant was sitting behind the steering wheel of the stationary vehicle, there was testimony that others, in fact, had been driving prior to parking the vehicle. Moreover, the evidence relating to the Breathalyzer test was incompetent and should not have been considered because the prosecutor failed to establish that the device was in proper working order before the test was given. In essence, there was nothing to establish a relationship between the time there was evidence to show the influence of intoxicants and the time of operating a vehicle.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment affirming defendant's conviction for operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated.

 

122 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Kroger Co. v. Schneider


No. 40002


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 2d 80; 223 N.E.2d 606; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 419; 38 Ohio Op. 2d 204



February 8, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The cause presently before this court contains no factual issues. Rather, the only question presented is whether, as plaintiffs contend, in the amended petition for declaratory judgment, " Section 5711.22(B), Revised Code [as amended effective December 9, 1963], is unconstitutional and void in that it results in an unequal burden of taxation upon taxpayers and is a denial of equal protection of law * * * contrary to the provisions of Section 2, Article I of the Constitution of Ohio and the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States." Simply stated, that section provides that personal property held by a merchant for sale and not for resale shall be listed for taxation for the year 1964 and assessed at 70% of the value of such property exceeding $ 100,000 and at 66% of the value of such property for the first $ 100,000. Each successive year thereafter, the percentage of assessment on the first $ 100,000 is lowered at the rate of four per cent per year until 1968 when the rate of 50% is reached and maintained. Throughout this period all such merchant's property exceeding a valuation of $ 100,000 continues to [***2] be assessed at a rate of 70% of value.

The Tax Commissioner of Ohio entered an appearance denying that such statute is unconstitutional. Plaintiffs then moved for judgment on the pleadings.

The Court of Common Pleas found that "plaintiffs are entitled by law to judgment against defendant" and accordingly held Section 5711.22(B), Revised Code, unconstitutional as being in violation of the Constitution of Ohio and of the Constitution of the United States.

The Court of Appeals reversed, holding that Section 5711.22(B), Revised Code, is a reasonable exercise of the taxation and exemption power vested in the General Assembly.

The cause is before this court pursuant to a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers brought an action against defendant tax commissioner seeking a declaration that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5711.22(B) was unconstitutional. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) reversed the judgment of the common pleas court that held the statute unconstitutional and the taxpayers sought review.


OVERVIEW: The statute declared that personal property held by a merchant for sale should be listed for taxation for the year 1964 and assessed at 70 percent of the value of such property exceeding $ 100,000 and at 66 percent of the value of such property for the first $ 100,000. Each successive year thereafter, the percentage of assessment on the first $ 100,000 was lowered until 1968 when the rate of 50 percent was reached. The appellate court held that the statute was a reasonable exercise of the powers vested in the legislature. The court found that the basic power of taxation stemming from Ohio Const. art. II, §1 allowed personal property to be taxed at the discretion of the legislature, limited by the equal protection clause. The court also found that the Equal Protection Clause required all property within an enumerated classification that had not been lawfully exempted from taxation to be assessed and taxed at an equal rate. The court reversed and held that the statute violated equal protection because it directly imposed a different rate of assessment and, therefore, a different burden of taxation upon property within a particular class.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court judgment that ruled that the statute that provided for a graduated taxation upon merchants' inventory was constitutional. The court rendered judgment that the statute was unconstitutional as violative of equal protection.

 

123 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Olin Mathieson Chemical Corp. v. Ontario Store of Price Hill, Inc.


No. 40137


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 2d 67; 223 N.E.2d 592; 1967 Ohio LEXIS 415; 38 Ohio Op. 2d 163; 1967 Trade Cas. (CCH) P72,007



February 1, 1967, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant manufacturer sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which declared that the Ohio Fair Trade Act of 1959 (Act), Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.27 et seq., was unconstitutional in an action involving appellee distributor's sale of the manufacturer's goods for less than the manufacturer's stipulated minimum resale price.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer brought an unfair trade action under the Act against the distributor for selling the manufacturer's products at prices below the manufacturer's suggested resale price, and the court of appeals held that the Act was unconstitutional. The court reversed, found that the Act was a valid exercise of police power, and held that it was constitutional because it fell within the terms of § 3 of the McGuire Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 45(a)(3). Accordingly, the Act's provisions -- making it an act of unfair competition and unlawful for the distributor, with notice that the manufacturer had established a stipulated minimum resale price, to sell the manufacturer's goods for less than the established minimum resale price -- were constitutional and valid.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed.

 

124 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Cleveland v. Masheter


No. 39953


Supreme Court of Ohio


8 Ohio St. 2d 11; 221 N.E.2d 704; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 295; 37 Ohio Op. 2d 301



November 30, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

ON DEMURRER to answer.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court. Relator, city of Cleveland, seeks to compel respondents to honor certain bills for the providing of electric power for the lighting of interstate highways within the boundaries of the municipality.

The facts are as follows.

During the construction of interstate highways within the city of Cleveland, contracts were entered into between the director and the city, one provision of which reads as follows:

"The city agrees to make ample provisions each year for the maintenance of, and to maintain the project in a satisfactory manner, including any lighting system, traffic directional signs, and altered municipally owned utilities and sanitary sewers, and to furnish power for operation of all facilities requiring power."

In 1965, the General Assembly adopted in Section 2 of the highway appropriation bill, effective July 1, 1965, the following provision:

"Notwithstanding Sections 5501.14 and 5511.01 of the Revised Code, the Director of Highways shall remove snow and ice, maintain, repair, or improve, and provide adequate lighting upon interstate highways to meet the requirements of the Bureau [***2] of Public Roads which are located within the boundaries of a municipal corporation. Such expenses shall be chargeable, directly or indirectly, to the operation or maintenance of the state highway system."

The relator, on October 18, 1965, adopted the following resolution, a copy of which was sent to the Director of Highways:

"Acknowledging and acceding to the action of the General Assembly in waiving any rights under existing contracts and agreements, accepting the offer of the state of Ohio to remove snow and ice, maintain, repair, improve and light interstate highways now or hereafter located within the boundaries of the city of Cleveland."

In November 1965, the relator sent the Director of Highways a bill for lighting the interstate highway within the municipal limits. The director refused to pay such bill, whereupon, the present action was instituted.

The case is before the court on a demurrer to the answer.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, the City of Cleveland, filed an action in mandamus, seeking to compel respondents, the Director of Highways and others, to honor certain bills for the providing of electric power for the lighting of interstate highways within the boundaries of the City. Respondents filed an answer, and the City filed a demurrer.


OVERVIEW: The parties contracted for the City to maintain and provide electric power for the lighting of interstate highways within its boundaries.
