The general assembly later passed a bill requiring the Director to maintain and provide adequate lighting on interstate highways within the boundaries of municipal corporations. The City sent the Director a bill for lighting the interstate highway within its limits. The Director refused to pay it, and the City sought a writ of mandamus. The court granted the writ. The court held that the bill at issue did not impair the obligation of contracts as the state was entitled to release obligations due it. The court also held that although Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 723.01 required cities to maintain public highways within their municipal corporations, the bill did not violate Ohio Const. art. II, §16(2). The court found that the bill made joint the duty to maintain such highways and did not amend Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 723.01. The court held that as no exceptions were included in the bill, the state's duty applied to those cities which had previously contracted to maintain the highways, and that those cities were relieved from their contractual obligations.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the City's demurrer to respondents' answer and allowed the writ of mandamus.

 

125 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Brothers v. Zellar


No. 39721


Supreme Court of Ohio


7 Ohio St. 2d 109; 218 N.E.2d 729; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 325; 36 Ohio Op. 2d 107



July 13, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeals issuing a writ of mandamus compelling appellants, members of the Board of Tax Appeals, to place upon its journal an entry placing the appellee, Merrill D. Brothers, on its payroll as a member of the Board of Tax Appeals and for further relief in connection therewith.

There is no controversy as to the facts.

In 1959, appellee was appointed to the Board of Tax Appeals for a term ending on February 8, 1965. He received his commission, filed his bond and took the oath of office on February 28, 1959. On March 10, 1959, the Senate gave its advice and consent to the appointment.

On February 5, 1965, James R. Gould was appointed by the Governor for the term beginning on February 9, 1965, and ending on February 8, 1971. On February 11, 1965, Gould took the oath of office, furnished bond and entered upon the duties of the office. The appointment was submitted to the Senate, and on February 24 on a vote of 16 nays to 15 yeas the Senate refused to advise and consent to the appointment. On March 17, 1965, Gould resigned the office.

On April 7, 1965, the Governor appointed Francis [***2] B. Douglass as a member of the Board of Tax Appeals for the term ending on February 8, 1971. On April 20, 1965, Douglass received his commission, took the oath of office, filed his bond and entered upon the duties of a member of the Board of Tax Appeals. The appointment was submitted to the Senate on April 7, 1965, and referred to the Rules Committee. The Senate adjourned sine die on September 1, 1965, without acting on the appointment. Appellee instituted the present action in mandamus to compel his reinstatement to the board.

Appellee contends that under the provisions of Section 3.01, Revised Code, as the incumbent in office he continued therein until his successor was appointed and qualified, and that inasmuch as the Senate had not advised and consented to the appointment of either Gould or Douglass neither had qualified for the office. Appellee argued that, therefore, he was a member of the board and entitled to perform the duties and receive the compensation therefor.

The Court of Appeals found that, where advice and consent of the Senate is required in an appointment by the Governor, the appointment is not complete until submitted to and concurred in by the Senate and [***3] ordered a writ of mandamus issued restoring appellee to the payroll of the board.

The cause is before this court on an appeal as of right from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, members of the state Board of Tax Appeals, challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals, which issued a writ of mandamus directing the board to accept and place on its payroll as a member of the board appellee incumbent. The issue was whether under Ohio Const. art. III, § 21, the incumbent was still a member of the board due to the General Assembly's failure to affirmatively consent to the appointment of his nominated replacements.


OVERVIEW: The incumbent argued and the lower court agreed that the General Assembly's action in not affirmatively consenting by majority vote to the governor's nominated replacements on the Board of Tax Appeals meant that his appointment had not yet expired. The other board members disagreed and sought review. The court held that Ohio Const. art. III, § 21 was controlling; based on the wording of § 21 and its legislative history that lead to its passing and amendment of the state constitution, the court held that the new officials became members of the board upon their formal appointment by the governor; no other act was required. The General Assembly's sole power, the court held, was the ability to affirmatively disapprove of the existing appointment if they so wished. It was not required for the General Assembly to formally approve the appointment; all it could do was to formally and affirmatively disapprove an appointment by a majority vote. The court held that therefore the incumbent's term of office had expired and that his replacements were the new members of the board.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower appellate court and rendered a judgment on behalf of the board and against the incumbent.

 

126 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Sibarco Corp. v. Berea


No. 39846


Supreme Court of Ohio


7 Ohio St. 2d 85; 218 N.E.2d 428; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 320; 36 Ohio Op. 2d 75



July 6, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The Sibarco Corporation (hereinafter referred to as Sibarco) has title or contract rights to certain properties located at a point where Henry Street, Westbridge Drive, Prospect Street and West Bridge Street intersect in the city of Berea. The land is zoned for single-family dwellings (1-A-1) and apartments or hotels (2-A). Sibarco desires to construct a gasoline station on this land. In order to secure favorable zoning provisions for such construction, Sibarco petitioned the Planning Commission and the Council of the city of Berea for an amendment to the zoning ordinance, but was unsuccessful. Sibarco then formally applied for a building permit to erect a gasoline station on the above properties. Building Commissioner McDonald denied the application. An appeal was taken to the Board of Zoning Appeals which affirmed the commissioner's denial.

Sibarco, together with Walter E. Mischnick (who owned certain of the aforementioned properties to which Sibarco had a contract right of purchase), instituted an action in mandamus invoking the original jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County against the city of Berea [***2] and Building Commissioner McDonald, seeking an order commanding the appellants to issue the building permit to relators. The Court of Appeals heard the case on the merits and allowed the writ to issue. Appellants appeal, as a matter of right, to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which issued a writ of mandamus commanding the city to issue building permits to relators, a group of building owners.


OVERVIEW: The owners sought a building permit for the construction of a gasoline station on properties they already owned. The property in question was zoned for residential purposes and the city denied the permits. On review, the court reversed the appellate court's decision. The court held that a writ in mandamus must not issue, where there was a plain and adequate remedy in the ordinary course of the law. The court found that the appellate court exceeded the original jurisdiction conferred upon it by the Ohio Const. art. IV, § 6 when it allowed the extraordinary writ of mandamus to issue although the owners had available a plain and adequate remedy in the ordinary course of law by way of appeal pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506. The court found that after the owners' request was denied by the city, the owners went to the executive branch of the city government and were again rejected. The owners failed to seek an appeal of the denial; rather, they petitioned for a writ of mandamus. Because § 2506 provided a plain and adequate remedy for review by a trial court, the owners' mandamus petition was not a substitute for an appeal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's issuance of the writ of mandamus.

 

127 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Burton v. Greater Portsmouth Growth Corp.


No. 40139


Supreme Court of Ohio


7 Ohio St. 2d 34; 218 N.E.2d 446; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 569; 36 Ohio Op. 2d 19



June 22, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN QUO WARRANTO.

This is an action in quo warranto originating in this court. Relator attacks the validity of Section 13, Article VIII of the Ohio Constitution, which provides for public aid to private corporations for the purpose of creating new employment, and Section 1724.10, Revised Code, enacted pursuant to the provisions of Section 13, Article VIII.

Respondent, Greater Portsmouth Growth Corporation, is a corporation not for profit organized as a community improvement corporation for the purpose of advancing the economic development of Scioto County and the city of Portsmouth.

Under the provisions of Section 1724.10, Revised Code, respondent entered into agreements with Scioto County and the city of Portsmouth.

Pursuant to a plan for the county of Scioto and a plan for the city of Portsmouth of industrial, commercial, distribution and research development and as the agent of these two political subdivisions, respondent entered into an agreement with Dayton-Portsmouth Foundry Company, a private corporation, to construct and equip an addition to an existing plant of Dayton-Portsmouth on real estate purchased from Dayton-Portsmouth and to lease back to Dayton-Portsmouth the [***2] real estate with the plant addition thereon. The acquisition of the real estate and the construction and equipping of the plant addition are to be financed by the proceeds from a sale by respondent of its revenue bonds, in the principal amount of $ 400,000, to commercial banks in the city of Portsmouth. The bonds are secured by a first mortgage on the real estate and the plant addition and the equipment and are payable solely from the revenues and other amounts derived from the leasing of the real estate and the plant addition.

To further effectuate the plans of industrial, commercial, distribution and research development, respondent issued its guarantee insuring mortgage payments required by a first mortgage on a terminal and servicing operation of Yellow Cab Company, Inc., a private corporation for profit, securing a bank loan to Yellow Cab. By its terms the guarantee is limited to the sum of $ 2,000, and the interest earned thereon, received by respondent from contributions and pledged by the guarantee.

In this action, relator seeks to oust respondent from performing under the agreements and guarantees aforesaid and to determine that these agreements and the guarantee and [***3] the revenue bonds issued by respondent are void and of no effect for the purported reasons that the statute, Section 1724.10, Revised Code, under which respondent acted and seeks to act, is unconstitutional, and that the constitutional amendment, Section 13, Article VIII, under which the statute was enacted, is invalid.

The case is before this court on a motion for summary judgment in favor of respondent.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator filed an action against defendant not-for-profit corporation in quo warranto and alleged that the corporation was not entitled to public aid and that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1724.10 and was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Relator filed an action against respondent not for profit corporation (corporation) in quo warranto and alleged that the corporation was not entitled to public aid and that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1724.10 was unconstitutional. The statute had been put on a ballot and was voted on by the citizens. Relator also argued that the amendment to Ohio Const. §13 art. VIII was unconstitutional because it violated the single subject requirement. The corporation filed a motion for summary judgment. The court found that the amendment had a single purpose, which was to allow the government to give financial assistance to private industry in order to create new employment within the state. Relator also argued that the description on the ballot was improper. The court found that the amendment as set forth on the ballot was a clear and concise statement of the proposed amendment. Thus, it was sufficient to inform the voters of the contents of the amendment. The court also found that exclusion of electric and gas companies did not constitute a denial of equal protection because the classification was reasonable. Therefore, the court granted the corporation's motion for summary judgment.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted the not-for-profit corporation's motion for summary judgment.

 

128 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Hunter v. Erickson


No. 39586


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 2d 130; 216 N.E.2d 371; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 354; 35 Ohio Op. 2d 151



April 27, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

The facts are stated in the opinion by Herbert, J.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.

 

129 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Greenhills Home Owners Corp. v. Greenhills


Nos. 39229, 39230, 39231


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 2d 207; 215 N.E.2d 403; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 413; 34 Ohio Op. 2d 420



March 16, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff homeowners' association brought separate actions against defendants, a village and individuals, for declaratory and injunctive relief, and for a writ of mandamus, seeking to invalidate a village zoning ordinance. The trial court consolidated the three actions and entered judgments for defendants. On appeal, the Hamilton County Court of Appeals (Ohio) reversed and declared the ordinance unconstitutional. Defendants appealed the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The village was built by the federal government as a model community. After the community was built, the community was incorporated as a municipal corporation under Ohio law. The government then sold the village to the homeowners' association with the agreement that the original community plan would be maintained. Pursuant to such agreement, the homeowners' association petitioned the village to zone certain areas of the village that had been designated as green space in the original community plan as parkland and woodland. The village enacted the requested zoning ordinance. Years later, the homeowners' association wanted to develop the green space and brought its actions to invalidate the zoning ordinance. On appeal, the court reversed the court of appeals. The court held that the court of appeals erred in declaring the ordinance unconstitutional when it could have resolved the appeal on non-constitutional grounds. The court held that the homeowners' association was estopped from challenging the constitutionality of the ordinance when it originally petitioned for the ordinance and benefitted from its enactment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' judgment.

 

130 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Koblenz v. Board of Revision


Nos. 39414, 39415


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 2d 214; 215 N.E.2d 384; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 414; 34 Ohio Op. 2d 424



March 16, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

These two cases have been consolidated for the purposes of these appeals.

Norman H. Koblenz and Maxine L. Koblenz filed a complaint with the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision as to the 1963 tax assessment upon their two-and-one-half-story residence located at 3686 Normandy Road in the city of Shaker Heights, Ohio. It is agreed that the fair market value of their property was $ 23,000 as of January 1, 1963. The property was assessed for taxation for 1963 at the amount of $ 12,640. The total assessed value of $ 12,640 is approximately 55% (54.95%) of the agreed fair market value of $ 23,000.

The Koblenzes claim (1) that their home should not be assessed at a total value in excess of $ 9,000, and (2) that the assessment of their home by the county auditor was illegal because the ratio of the county auditor's valuation to the fair market value (54.95%) was greatly in excess of the prevailing average ratio of assessed value to the fair market value of residential property in Cuyahoga County, which ratio was 36%, and the ratio applicable to their home (54.95%) was also greatly in excess of the prevailing average ratio of assessed value to fair [***2] market value of all real property in Cuyahoga County, which ratio was approximately 40%.

Sarah R. Goldberg filed a complaint with the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision as to the 1963 tax assessment of her store and warehouse property located at 1277 W. Sixth Street, Cleveland, Ohio.

Her four-story store and warehouse building and the land upon which it was located were assessed at $ 34,640. The Board of Revision reduced the assessed valuation to $ 29,790. It is agreed by the parties that the fair market value of her property shall be considered to be $ 42,600, which was the highest appraised value submitted by witnesses for appellees.

Mrs. Goldberg claims (1) that her building and land should not be assessed at a total value in excess of $ 20,000, and (2) that the assessment of her land and building by the county auditor, as reduced by the Board of Revision, was illegal because the ratio of the county auditor's valuation, as reduced by the County Board of Revision, to the agreed fair market value of her property, was 78.39% (actually approximately 70%), which ratio was greatly in excess of the prevailing average ratio of assessed value to fair market value of commercial property [***3] in Cuyahoga County, which ratio was 52%, and the ratio applicable to her land and building was also greatly in excess of the prevailing average ratio of assessed value to fair market value of all real property in Cuyahoga County, which ratio was approximately 40%.

At a hearing before Edward J. Kirwin, attorney-examiner for the Board of Tax Appeals, the ratios set forth above were testified to by Edwin Ducey, Chief of the Division of County Affairs of the Board of Tax Appeals. These ratios were not disputed in the record.

The Board of Tax Appeals upheld the assessment of the county auditor in the Koblenz case and declined to make a further revision of the assessment in the Goldberg case.

The causes are before this court upon appeals from the Board of Tax Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Decisions reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers challenged decisions from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which upheld the property tax assessment of appellee county auditor in one of the cases, and which declined to make a further revision of the property tax assessment in the other case.


OVERVIEW: The real property parcels owned by the taxpayers were assessed for tax purposes at a higher percent of their value than other taxpayers were required to pay on their property. The taxpayers challenged the assessment, and the Board of Tax Appeals refused to further adjust one assessment and affirmed the other. The taxpayers appealed, contending that the assessments were illegal because the ratio of the county auditor's valuation to the fair market value was in excess of the prevailing average ratio of assessed value to the fair market value of other residential property, which was unconstitutional. The court agreed, holding that: (1) Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2 required land and improvements to be taxed by uniform rule according to value; (2) U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1 provided that no state could deny the equal protection of the laws; (3) under Ohio law, all real property, regardless of its nature or use, had to be assessed and taxed by a uniform rule on the basis of value; (4) the Board was required to correct any discriminatory valuation; and (5) the Ohio and federal constitutional requirements of uniformity and equal protection required adjustments be made to the tax assessments.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the Board of Tax Appeals decisions, which upheld one property tax assessment and declined to make a further revision of the other. The cases were remanded to the Board for a determination of assessments that would meet the constitutional requirements of uniformity.

 

131 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Philada Home Fund v. Board of Tax Appeals


No. 39548


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 2d 135; 214 N.E.2d 431; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 401; 34 Ohio Op. 2d 262



February 16, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Ohio real estate was acquired in December 1963 by the appellant, The Philada Home Fund, a nonprofit Ohio corporation, hereinafter referred to as the Fund, for the stated purpose of erecting thereon apartments solely for the occupancy by "aged and needy self-respecting persons of good character," couples and individuals at rentals at or below cost. The articles of incorporation stated this purpose and provided further that it be carried out under "liberal rules and regulations to be adopted by the trustees, one such regulation, however, to be that the principal and income of the Fund and all amounts received * * * in trust shall always be used exclusively for the purposes of the Fund as a purely public charity."

Land acquisition cost was $ 84,000. The site was promptly cleared, an architect was employed, bids were taken, a contract was let containing a provision guaranteeing that maximum price would not exceed $ 393,733, and construction was commenced diligently and proceeded uninterruptedly.

At or shortly after August 11, 1964, when application for exemption from real property tax was filed with the Hamilton County auditor, a home with a [***2] capacity of 34 residents, consisting of 13 double apartments, each containing a living room, dressing room, bath, bedroom and combination kitchen and dining room, and eight single apartments, each containing a combination bedroom and living room, bath, dressing room and combination kitchen and dining room, had been substantially completed. The average cost per unit will be approximately $ 22,750.

No formal rules for admission requirements or rental charges had been adopted, but the board tentatively fixed the monthly rentals at $ 60 per month for single apartments and $ 75 per month for doubles and contemplated that loss from rentals to some residents who are unable to pay the fixed rentals will be covered by subventions from the Fund.

The Board of Tax Appeals held that real property owned by a charitable institution but rented for residential purposes is not used exclusively for charitable purposes so as to be exempt under Section 5709.12, Revised Code. The board's opinion cited Benjamin Rose Institute v. Myers, Treas., 92 Ohio St. 252; Beerman Foundation, Inc., v. Board of Tax Appeals, 152 Ohio St. 179; Cleveland Branch of Guild of St. Barnabas for Nurses  [***3] v. Board of Tax Appeals, 150 Ohio St. 484; and Doctors Hospital v. Board of Tax Appeals, 173 Ohio St. 283.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of the decision of appellee Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which entered a decision that the taxpayer's leasing of real property for residential purposes was not included in the taxpayer's charitable purpose.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was a charitable institution that was exempt from taxation. The taxpayer owned a parcel of real property that the taxpayer erected residential structures upon and leased for residential purposes to tenants. The board entered a decision that the real property was not used exclusively for the taxpayer's charitable purpose under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.12. On appeal, the court affirmed the board's decision. The court held that property that was partly or incidentally used for private purposes was not exempt because the property was not used exclusively for exempt purposes. The court found that charitable exemptions were narrowly construed, and the taxpayer's rental of property for private purposes was a violation of its exempt purpose.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the board, which found that the taxpayer was not using real property for its charitable purpose when the property was being leased to tenants for residential purposes.

 

132 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Receivership of Wisser & Gabler


No. 39458


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 2d 89; 214 N.E.2d 92; 1966 Ohio LEXIS 392; 34 Ohio Op. 2d 217



February 9, 1966, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Ross County.

This is an appeal from the Court of Appeals for Ross County after that court had affirmed the approval of a final and distributive account by the Probate Court of Ross County.

Wisser & Gabler, a plumbing and heating company, was a partnership with its principal office in Chillicothe, Ohio. In late 1953, John A. Wisser, one of the partners therein, was declared an incompetent and Paul F. Ralston, one of the appellants herein, was appointed his guardian. Shortly thereafter, Ralston filed an application in the Probate Court for dissolution of the partnership and the appointment of a receiver for the purpose of winding up, liquidation, and sale of the business. On February 2, 1954, Merle V. Holcomb was appointed receiver. Buckeye Union Casualty Company was Holcomb's bonding company and is an appellee in this appeal. Holcomb was a local plumber and was granted authority to continue the operation of the business for the purpose of winding up and in so doing was required to complete existing work in progress.

When Holcomb was appointed receiver of Wisser & Gabler, there were numerous contracts which were only partially performed.  [***2] In those unfinished contracts lay the true worth of the business. Holcomb, as per instructions, immediately went to work in an attempt to finish them. John Burns, a public accountant, was hired. In 1955, Burns prepared an account for the receivership, showing the receipts, disbursements, petty cash disbursements and joint check disbursements. In January 1955, Holcomb filed an inventory and appraisement of the assets and liabilities of Wisser & Gabler. Exceptions were filed by Ralston. On March 8, 1955, Holcomb filed an interim report of operations styled, "Amended and Supplemental Inventory and Appraisement," which showed the assets and liabilities of Wisser & Gabler as of February 1, 1954, and as of January 19, 1955. Exceptions were again filed by Ralston and resulted in a hearing before a master commissioner. As a result of this hearing, the court on December 29, 1959, determined the assets and liabilities of Wisser & Gabler as of the time Holcomb was appointed the receiver.

In the judgment of December 29, 1959, the court sustained part of the exceptions of Ralston, overruled part of the exceptions, overruled Ralston's motion to remove Holcomb as receiver and asked Holcomb [***3] to file an accounting. Holcomb did not file an accounting and was removed on November 25, 1961. The hearings which preceded the judgment disclosed that on May 3, 1954, Holcomb, his wife and James Cutright, the attorney for both Ralston and the receiver, organized a corporation known as Scioto Plumbing & Heating Company, Inc. This company purchased the physical assets of Wisser & Gabler at a price of $ 19,021.40. The assets which were purchased actually were trucks and equipment and were appraised at approximately the value which was paid.

In 1962, Robert L. Reeb, a certified public accountant, examined for Holcomb all the original records of Wisser & Gabler and of the receivership. Reeb made inquiry with various banks, creditors and debtors of Wisser & Gabler. As a result of Reeb's work, a final and distributive account was filed by Holcomb showing every receipt by Holcomb of assets of the receivership and every disbursement made by him.

Exceptions were again filed by Ralston, E. A. Moats, the successor receiver, and W. E. Caldwell Company, a creditor. After a four-day hearing on these exceptions, the Probate Court determined that Holcomb's account was accurate. Based on [***4] this determination, the court approved the account and discharged Holcomb and his bonding company.

An appeal was taken from the above ruling to the Court of Appeals for Ross County. The appeal was one on questions of law and fact. Such appeal was dismissed on questions of law and fact and retained on questions of law. The unconstitutionality of appeals on questions of law and fact was the reason given by the Court of Appeals for its decision to dismiss the appeal on questions of law and fact.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a successive receiver and a creditor, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Ross County (Ohio), which affirmed the approval of a final and distributive account by appellee receiver and discharged the receiver.


OVERVIEW: One of the partners from a plumbing and heating partnership was declared an incompetent. The successive receiver was appointed his guardian. Shortly thereafter, the successive receiver filed an application for dissolution of the partnership and the appointment of a receiver. The receiver was appointed. The successive receiver filed exceptions to the account of the receiver and filed a motion to remove the receiver. After the account was filed, the probate court determined that the receiver's account was accurate. An appeal was dismissed on questions of law and fact but retained on questions of law. The court affirmed and held that a holding in favor of the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2501.02, 2505.21 was consistent with the established rules for statutory and constitutional interpretation. It was clear that the appointment of the receiver was not in issue. Thus, an appeal on questions of law and fact under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2501.02(4) was not proper. The court found that the court of appeals properly only considered the issue of whether the final and distributive account of the receiver was complete and accurate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the court of appeals.

 

133 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Celina Mut. Ins. Co. v. Bowers


Nos. 39142, 39143


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 2d 12; 213 N.E.2d 175; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 402; 34 Ohio Op. 2d 7



December 29, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Mercer County.

The Tax Commissioner of Ohio confirmed, as modified, certain deficiency sales and use tax assessments theretofore made against the two appellees herein, The Celina Mutual Insurance Company and The National Mutual Insurance Company, domestic insurance companies, over the audit period from January 1, 1958, to June 30, 1961, and covering manuals and replacement sheets.

Appellees were and are engaged in the business of writing and selling fire, casualty and other related lines of insurance. Under the laws of Ohio, they are required to file with the Department of Insurance for approval copies of the rules and rates appertaining to their business, represented by manuals and often in loose-leaf form.

It would appear from the records that none of the manuals or manual sheets are delivered to an insured, nor are they usually attached to an insurance policy. Rather they are for reference and guidance for the insurance companies and their agents in writing policies and fixing premium rates. Although referred to therein, they are separate from the policies themselves and are not sold or resold to anyone.

The manuals and replacement sheets [***2] in issue were purchased by appellees without the payment of sales or use taxes on such purchases, and the Tax Commissioner found that such purchases were subject to such taxes, and he made assessments accordingly.

Appellees, being dissatisfied with the Tax Commissioner's final orders, perfected appeals to the Board of Tax Appeals, where the orders of the Tax Commissioner were affirmed.

Further appeals to the Court of Appeals for Mercer County, as authorized by statute, resulted in each case in a reversal of the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals as unreasonable and unlawful, largely on the commutation provisions of Section 5725.25, Revised Code, and final judgments for the insurance companies were rendered.

Appeals as of right by the Tax Commissioner, with cross-appeals by the insurance companies, and the allowance of motions to require the Court of Appeals to certify the records place the causes here for decision.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Mercer County (Ohio), which reversed the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals as unreasonable and unlawful on the commutation provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5725.25, and entered final judgments for appellee insurers on the deficiencies imposed for sales and use tax assessments.


OVERVIEW: The insurers were required to file with the Department of Insurance for approval copies of the rules and rates appertaining to their business. The manuals and replacement sheets in issue were purchased by the insurers without the payment of sales or use taxes on such purchases, and the commissioner found that such purchases were subject to such taxes, and made assessments accordingly. The commissioner contended that the interpretation given Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5725.25 by the appellate court, whereby the insurers, domestic insurance companies, were relieved generally from the payment of sales and use taxes, rendered such statute unconstitutional as offensive to Ohio Const. art. I, § 2. The court held that the enactment of the statutes showed a legislative intent to subject the purchase and use of tangible personal property by the insurers to the sales and use taxes except in those instances where the purpose of the insurer was to resell, hold, use, or consume the thing transferred as evidence of a contract of insurance. In reversing, the court concluded that the manual and manual sheets in issue did not come within the exception.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court and affirmed the Board's decision to impose a deficiency for the unpaid sales and use tax assessments.

 

134 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Schneider v. Laffoon


No. 39337


Supreme Court of Ohio


4 Ohio St. 2d 89; 212 N.E.2d 801; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 429; 33 Ohio Op. 2d 468



December 22, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This proceeding originated in the Probate Court of Hamilton County on exceptions of the Tax Commissioner to an order of that court determining inheritance or succession tax in the estate of Emily Woodall Laffoon who was a resident of Ohio at her death. In 1927, decedent's husband, Polk Laffoon, who predeceased her and who was never a resident of or domiciled in Ohio, irrevocably conveyed in Kentucky certain assets to a Kentucky bank as trustee. In the instrument declaring the trust the settlor provided that the income from the trust was to be paid to his wife until their two children reached certain ages. When their daughter reached 25 (she did in 1941), the income from one-half of the trust was to be paid to the daughter. When their son reached 25 (he did in 1944), the income from the other half was to be paid to the son. When the son reached 35, he was to be entitled to his one-half of the principal. On the death of the daughter, her one-half of the principal was to be distributed to her issue. There were other provisions for distribution in the event of death of the son before 35 or death of the daughter without issue.

 [***2] The trust instrument provided further in part:

"Donor grants to his wife, Emily Woodall Laffoon, the power to modify this trust at any time so as to provide for any child or children of donor hereafter born, or to change the proportions, amounts and times of payment to the beneficiaries named above or their issue, but no such modification shall provide for the payment of any income or principal to donor. Such modification shall be in writing signed by donor's said wife, and delivered to the trustee."

In 1941, when the daughter became 25, the decedent, as donee of the foregoing power, exercised that power by specifying in writing that the income from the trust be paid to her, the decedent, for life. In 1956, she again exercised that power by specifying in writing that, on her death, her son was to receive four-fifths, if then living, and the children of her then deceased daughter were to receive one-fifth of the trust estate with other provisions for disposition of those shares in the event of deaths prior to death of the donee.

All the trust assets are intangibles having no claimed relationship to Ohio and it does not appear that any of the evidences thereof are located in Ohio.

 [***3] The Tax Commissioner contends that because the donee was a resident of Ohio both at her death and at the time she exercised the power of appointment the successions to the trust assets are taxable under those portions of Section 5731.02, Revised Code, which reads:

"A tax is hereby levied upon the succession to any property passing * * * to or for the use of a person * * * in the following cases:

"* * *

"(D) Whenever any person or corporation exercises a power of appointment derived from any disposition of property, such appointment when made shall be deemed a succession taxable under this section in the same manner as if the property to which such appointment relates belonged absolutely to the donee of such power and had been bequeathed or devised by said donee by will; and whenever any such person or corporation possessing such power of appointment fails to exercise the same within the time provided therefor, in whole or in part, a succession taxable under this section takes place as to the property passing by such failure, in the same manner as if the persons, institutions, or corporations thereby becoming entitled to the possession or enjoyment of the property to which such [***4] power related had succeeded thereto by a will of the donee of the power who failed to exercise the power, taking effect at the time of such failure * * *."

The Probate Court determined that no part of the foregoing trust created by decedent's husband should be treated as a taxable succession from decedent.

That determination was affirmed by the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court on an appeal from that judgment, pursuant to allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a determination of the probate court in favor of appellee executors that no part of a trust created by the decedent's husband should be treated as a taxable succession from decedent.


OVERVIEW: The decedent was a resident of Ohio at the time of her death. The decedent's husband, who predeceased her and was never a resident of Ohio, created a power of appointment over intangible property by a trust set up outside Ohio. The decedent, as the donee of the power, had no authority to appoint any part of the property to herself or to her estate and the power was to be exercised only inter vivos by a modification of the trust. The tax commissioner argued that, because the decedent was a resident of Ohio both at her death and at the time she exercised the power of appointment, the successions to the trust assets were taxable under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5731.02. The lower court affirmed the probate court's determination that no part of the trust should be treated as a taxable succession. The court affirmed, finding that the state had no power to tax the succession to property located outside the state where no incident whatever of the transfer of title to such property was in any way dependent for its effect upon the law of the taxing state and finding that to permit such a tax would be to give extraterritorial effect to the state's taxing statutes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the executors.

 

135 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Dowd v. Maxwell


No. 39354


Supreme Court of Ohio


3 Ohio St. 2d 117; 209 N.E.2d 421; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 459; 32 Ohio Op. 2d 95



July 14, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

This is an action in habeas corpus originating in this court. On December 16, 1954, the Grand Jury of Cuyahoga County returned an indictment charging petitioner, Eugene Dowd, with burglary of an inhabited dwelling house. On December 18, 1954, petitioner pleaded guilty to the charge and was sentenced to the Ohio State Reformatory, the court granting mercy. Thus, petitioner's sentence was for five to 30 years rather than for life.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed an original action in habeas corpus asserting that he was held for days prior to his confession and unconstitutionally denied his right to counsel.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner originally pled guilty to burglary of an inhabited dwelling house. Petitioner filed an original petition for writ of habeas corpus challenging his conviction and asserting that he had unlawfully been denied the right to counsel and had not waived that right. The court denied his petition. The court noted that the calendar of the court belied the assertions of petitioner. The calendar noted that his rights had been explained prior to his plea. The court noted that in weighing testimony, a court necessarily had to take into consideration the credibility of witnesses. In determining credibility, the court could take into consideration the criminal record of a witness pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.42. The court could also take into consideration the time that had elapsed since the happening of the event to which the testimony was related inasmuch as time may well have affected the accuracy of memory. In petitioner's case, the court felt that the trial judge had adequately explained to petitioner his rights prior to accepting his guilty plea.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ of habeas corpus and remanded petitioner to custody.

 

136 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 38692


Supreme Court of Ohio


3 Ohio St. 2d 82; 209 N.E.2d 424; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 450; 32 Ohio Op. 2d 58



July 7, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

On April 27, 1961, appellee The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company applied to the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio for authority to raise its rates for steam and hot-water service supplied to users in the city of Cleveland.

After hearing, the commission, on January 8, 1963, found that the existing rates being charged are insufficient to provide the company with an adequate return; that the statutory rate base is $ 19,261,306; that an annual return of 3.53% is not unreasonable or unjust; that the annual dollar return to which the company is entitled is $ 680,311.11; that the allowable annual expenses aggregate $ 3,343,657.08; that the allowable annual revenue to which applicant is entitled is $ 4,023,968.19; and that the amendment to the fuel adjustment clause of the application was reasonable.

After a rate increase was granted, a motion for rehearing was filed by the city of Cleveland and was denied by the commission.

The case is before this court upon appeal from the order of the Public Utilities Commission granting the requested increase in rates.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of an order of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which granted an application by appellee electric company for authority to raise its rates for steam and hot-water service supplied to users in the city.


OVERVIEW: The Commission found that the existing rates were insufficient to provide the company with an adequate return. On appeal, the court held that (1) in prior cases the court repeatedly rejected the city's argument that the net return to the company should have been based on total capitalization or net investment because it conflicted with the rate base formula provided by statute; (2) the Commission's order would not be disturbed unless it appeared that it was manifestly against the weight of the evidence, and there was evidence in the record to support a much higher rate of return; (3) the contention that a valuation based on published trend factors did not conform to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.05(D) was previously rejected by the court; (4) no evidence of past abuses of customers' rights under the company's coal escalation clause existed to indicate that the Commission's acceptance of the clause was unreasonable or unlawful; and (5) any dispute regarding retroactive application of the new rates was a matter between the customer and the company that would not be considered in the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the Commission.

 

137 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


O'Neil v. Board of County Comm'rs


Nos. 38835, 38836


Supreme Court of Ohio


3 Ohio St. 2d 53; 209 N.E.2d 393; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 600; 32 Ohio Op. 2d 42



July 7, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

An understanding of the matters involved herein will be assisted by reference to the following schematic diagram of the pertinent portion of the subdivision plat of Bellaire Allotment No. 2 in Lot 53, Bath Township, Summit County, Ohio, which plat was recorded in 1952.

[SEE ILLUSTRATION IN ORIGINAL]

Appellees O'Neil and Gaffney purchased lots 21 and 22 in 1958 and 1960 respectively and each constructed residences thereon. Lot 21A is unimproved and is described on the recorded plat as not a building lot but "may be used for future streets or may be used as additions to adjacent building lots." There is no evidence that it has ever been accepted for public use by any proper authority.

On the other hand, there is evidence to show that in the ordinary course of events lot 21A would have been a part of the street system of the subdivision but for a fortuitous circumstance. The plat was approved for recording over the signatures of two officers of the Summit County Planning Commission, contrary to a prior resolution of that body approving a tentative plat on the specific condition that the parcel now shown as lot 21A be offered [***2] unequivocally for dedication as a street to provide access to the adjoining undeveloped property.

That the error is now recognized by the planning commission but remains unexplained is revealed by the following excerpt from its minutes of April 26, 1963:

"Surveyor Swigart presented Bellaire No. 2 Allotment which was recorded in 1957. The preliminary plat presented in 1955 was accepted, subject to street reservations to the neighboring properties. There were road reservations at the time of the recording, but on the plat, the restrictions indicated that the road reservation could be purchased as part of adjoining lots. The lots are now purchased and there is no way to get to the adjoining property.

"It was moved by Alexander; seconded by Oser.

"That the Summit County Planning Commission wants to express the fact that the planning commission's intent was that those lots were reserved for future road at the time this plat was submitted and request the county commissioners appropriate this road, if necessary, at the cost of the developers of the adjacent land. Mr. Alexander said the trustees or planning commission didn't know a thing about this at that time, and now referred to [***3] county commissioners.

"Motion carried unanimously."


In March 1963, appellees jointly purchased lot 21A from the original subdivider. Thereafter, appellant Hamlin acquired the 60 acres of undeveloped land to the south for future development as a subdivision. Hamlin's tract extends to an existing public road on its southern boundary but the terrain on that portion is such that any access street would necessarily be on a grade in excess of the maximum permitted by the regulations governing construction and acceptance of streets by Summit County. In addition, lot 21A is the only access which would not place unreasonable burdens on public authorities in furnishing utility services, street maintenance and fire and police protection to future users of the tract.

Unable to obtain lot 21A by purchase from O'Neil and Gaffney, Hamlin petitioned the Board of County Commissioners of Summit County (Board) under Sections 5553.41 to 5553.43, inclusive, Revised Code, to establish a public road over lot 21A. In his petition, he agreed to improve that parcel in accordance with the construction standards of Summit County and at his cost.

After extensive hearings, the board found "that the [***4] road petitioned for will serve the public convenience and welfare and that said road * * * is established on and over lot 21A" and awarded the total amount of $ 2,500 to the appellees for the taking and damages.

Case No. 38836 began as two appeals to the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County under the provisions of Section 2506.01 et seq., Revised Code, from the separate decisions of the board granting the petition for the road (by O'Neil and Gaffney) and awarding compensation (by Hamlin). The appeals were consolidated in that court and proceeded as one case, whereupon the court affirmed both decisions of the board.

From this judgment, O'Neil and Gaffney appealed on questions of law to the Court of Appeals which reversed "the de novo findings, judgment and order of the Common Pleas Court" and denied the petition of Hamlin to obtain a road right-of-way over the real estate of O'Neil and Gaffney.

An appeal by the board of county commissioners and a cross-appeal by Hamlin were perfected to this court, which granted the motions to certify the record.

Case No. 38835 originated in the Common Pleas Court of Summit County on June 10, 1963, by appellees O'Neil and Gaffney, who [***5] filed their petition seeking an injunction against the board to restrain it from proceeding in the matters involved in Case No. 38836. That court refused the injunction, and plaintiffs appealed on questions of law to the Court of Appeals, which "permanently enjoined [the board] from proceeding to open a public road over said lot 21A and from pursuing further actions or proceedings to effect the same based upon the petition of Richard M. Hamlin as filed with it [sic] on June 3, 1963." We allowed a motion to certify the record upon the further appeal of the board to this court.



DISPOSITION: Judgment in case No. 38835 reversed. Judgment in case No. 38836 affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, Board of County Commissioners of Summit County and property owner, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which denied the property owner's petition to obtain a road right-of-way over the real estate owned by appellee lot owners and denied the lot owners' petition for a permanent injunction to enjoin the Board from proceeding to open a public road over the real property.


OVERVIEW: The property owner wanted a road right-of-way because he allegedly planned to develop a subdivision on his property and without the road right-of-way, his property was landlocked. On appeal, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate court to deny the petition for the road right-of-way and reversed the decision regarding the permanent injunction. The court reasoned that the use for which the eminent domain power was exercised must be public and not private and the immediate result of the granting of the road right-of-way would have been to furnish an individual access from an undeveloped tract of property to a public street. The court reasoned that if the property owner's commitment to develop his land was more definite, the decision would have been different. The court found that reversal of the injunction decision was proper because no bill of exceptions was filed in this matter, which was joined with the property owner's petition. Therefore, the court found that the appellate court had no authority other than to dismiss the appeal and to remand the cause to the lower court for a trial of the issue.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court to deny the property owner's request for a road right-of-way and reversed the decision of the appellate court to deny the lot owners' petition for a permanent injunction.

 

138 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Thompson v. Cincinnati


No. 38919


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 2d 292; 208 N.E.2d 747; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 546; 31 Ohio Op. 2d 563



June 23, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Jack Thompson, plaintiff, appellee herein, brought this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, wherein he seeks a declaratory judgment as to his rights and duties in respect to the payment of municipal income taxes to the city of Cincinnati, defendant-appellee herein, and defendant city of Loveland, appellant herein, by virtue of income tax ordinances enacted and enforced by both cities against plaintiff.

Plaintiff, Thompson, is a resident of the city of Loveland. He is employed by the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company in the city of Cincinnati and, as a result of work and labor performed within the boundaries of Cincinnati, Ohio, receives income from the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company. During the period of January 1, 1963, to December 1, 1963, plaintiff has been taxed at the rate of one per cent upon his wages under both the city of Cincinnati income tax ordinance (No. 4271961) and the city of Loveland income tax ordinance (No. 196233), for a total of two per cent.

The Common Pleas Court of Hamilton County held that the defendant city of Cincinnati had the right to collect an income tax of one per cent [***2] upon the wages of plaintiff, and that defendant city of Loveland had no authority to levy or collect from plaintiff any income tax upon his salary earned by him while working in the city of Cincinnati.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, the judgment of the trial court was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion of appellant to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which in appellee taxpayer's declaratory judgment action regarding his rights and duties with respect to the payment of income taxes, held that the city was not authorized to collect or levy income taxes upon wages received by the taxpayer while working in another city, a defendant below.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer lived in one city and worked in another. Pursuant to local regulations, his wages were taxed by both. The taxpayer contended that the taxation by the city in which he resided was unlawful. The court disagreed, holding that there was no constitutional provision or statute depriving his residential city of the power to tax incomes of its residents where such residents were also subject to an income tax by another municipality. Indeed, the General Assembly refused to enact a provision that would have obligated all municipalities to allow a tax deduction for income tax paid by a resident of a municipality on wages earned outside a municipality. Furthermore, because the taxpayer received benefits from both cities, he was not discriminated against by the taxation.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

139 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Lynch v. Rhodes


No. 38726


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 2d 259; 208 N.E.2d 906; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 543; 31 Ohio Op. 2d 545



June 16, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The conclusion of the majority of this court must necessarily rest upon their determination either (1) that Section 129.41, Revised Code, is unconstitutional because it purports to authorize a debt prohibited by Article VIII of the Constitution or (2) that amended House Bill No. 291 of the 105th General Assembly is unconstitutional to the extent that it purports to irrevocably appropriate money for payments to be paid two years after its effective date of April 26, 1963.

Article IV, Section 2, of the Constitution reads:

"No law shall be held unconstitutional and void by the Supreme Court without the concurrence of at least all but one of the judges, except in the affirmance of a judgment of the Court of Appeals declaring a law unconstitutional and void."

Since less than six of the judges of this court concur in the foregoing determinations with respect to Section 129.41, Revised Code, and amended House Bill No. 291 of the 105th General Assembly, the writ prayed for must be denied.



DISPOSITION: Writ Denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator citizen and taxpayer of Ohio sought a writ of mandamus to determine whether "certificates of obligation" represented debts of the State within the meaning of Ohio Const. art. VIII, § 3.


OVERVIEW: Respondent, the Board of Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, pursuant to an agreement with the Director of Highways sold certificates of obligation. The citizen argued that the "certificates of obligation" sold represented debts of the State within the meaning of Ohio Const. art. VIII, § 3 and were not allowed. A majority of the court determined that the certificates were lawful and denied the citizen's writ. Some of the court argued that the certificates were unlawful because they were due and payable at a date later than two years. However, the writ was denied because the issues raised by the relator appeared to be moot. The legislature enacted legislation, which extended the use of appropriations at the request of the Director of Highways. Ohio Rev. Code § 129.42 appropriated such funds to the Board. Furthermore, the court noted that the money had already been extended. It was not the function of the writ of mandamus to correct errors made by public officers.


OUTCOME: The majority of the court denied the citizen's writ.

 

140 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Price v. McCoy Sales & Service, Inc.


No. 38494


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 2d 131; 207 N.E.2d 236; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 505; 31 Ohio Op. 2d 229



May 5, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Huron County.

James L. Price, plaintiff, appellant herein, brought this action against the McCoy Sales & Service, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as McCoy), and Charles W. Chase, defendants, appellees herein, in the Court of Common Pleas of Huron County to recover damages for personal injuries alleged to have been suffered by Price in a motor vehicle collision on the Ohio Turnpike at about 1:30 a.m. on May 2, 1959.

Price, with a passenger, was driving westerly on the turnpike when the motor of his automobile ceased to function. The car was pushed over on the north berm of the highway, headed west.

In about ten or fifteen minutes, an employee of McCoy, one Sanders, arrived driving a "wrecker." He was unable to give any meaningful assistance at the time as he was on his way to another call. However, he did call McCoy's office and reported the position of Price's car and his misfortune. Another McCoy "tow-truck" arrived at the scene in response to Sanders' call. The driver, David Bundschuh, was inexperienced in this type of work and was in substance undergoing a training course. He determined to hook his truck onto the east end, or rear, of [***2] Price's car, execute a U-turn and then proceed westerly with the tow. Bundschuh had never performed this type of operation before. He was required to wait six or seven minutes before the flow of traffic permitted him to begin his proposed U-turn. He knew that this maneuver would block the westbound traffic lanes of the turnpike for more than one minute.

Price, with his passenger, got into his car. Sanders returned from his other call and assisted Bundschuh with the hookup. Prior to moving Price's automobile, the two employees of McCoy tied the steering wheel and the left front door of the automobile.

As McCoy's tow truck had almost crossed the westbound highway going from the north side to the south side, Bundschuh, driver of the tow truck, found that there was not space to clear the south guardrail of the turnpike to complete the U-turn, and that it would be necessary to back up both vehicles in order to execute the turn. At that time, the two vehicles completely blocked the westbound lanes of the turnpike. The tow truck did not have any equipment which would direct light towards approaching traffic when the tow truck was perpendicular to the westbound lane of travel.

A [***3] few seconds later, and while the vehicles were still stationary and blocking the entire highway, Bundschuh saw Chase's car approaching from the east. The truck was equipped with warning devices such as fusees and reflectors, but neither of the employees of McCoy displayed such devices on or about the vehicles.

Chase, traveling at a speed of 60 to 65 miles an hour, did not see the standing vehicles until they were illuminated by his headlights. He applied the brakes and slowed the speed of his car, but nevertheless it struck Price's automobile. The collision occurred on the west side or face of a downhill incline.

At the conclusion of the taking of testimony, the court instructed the jury that Chase was guilty of negligence as a matter of law but left the determination of the question of proximate cause to the jury. The jury returned a unanimous verdict in the amount of $ 10,000 against McCoy alone, there being no finding against Chase. Judgment was entered on the verdict. McCoy's motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict was overruled.

On June 3, 1963, the trial court sustained McCoy's motion for a new trial, stating, as follows, the reason in its entry, pursuant to [***4] the provisions of Section 2321.17 of the Revised Code.

"(1) The final judgment is contrary to law, and the jury, in determining the issues failed to properly apply the law to the facts and came to an unwarranted conclusion in rendering its verdict;

"(2) Error of law occurring at the trial in that the court should have declared defendant Chase's negligence a proximate cause of the injury;

"(3) Reasonable minds could only have concluded that defendant Chase's negligence was a proximate cause of plaintiff's damages;

"(4) Such unreasonable conclusions prejudiced the defendant McCoy Sales & Service, Inc."

Price perfected his appeal to the Court of Appeals for Huron County, which found that there was no abuse discretion by the trial court in granting the motion of McCoy for a new trial, held that the granting of the new trial was not a final appealable order and dismissed the appeal.

Allowance of Price's motion for an order to certify the record brings the cause before this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court entered a judgment against defendant towing company, in accordance with the jury's verdict, in plaintiff motorist's negligence action against the company and defendant driver. The Court of Appeals for Huron County (Ohio) found that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in granting the motion, held that the granting of a new trial was not a final appealable order, and dismissed the appeal. The motorist sought review.


OVERVIEW: The driver's vehicle collided with the motorist's car, which was being towed by the company. In later suit, the jury was instructed that the driver was negligent as a matter of a law, but was allowed to determine the issue of proximate cause. The jury returned a verdict against the company alone. After entering a judgment on the verdict and denying the company's motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, the trial court granted the company's new trial motion, stating that the jury erred in not finding that the driver's negligence was the proximate cause of injury. The court of appeals, although finding no abuse of discretion in the granting of the motion, held that the granting of a new trial motion was not a final appealable order. On review, the court reversed and remanded for reinstatement of the judgment for the motorist, holding, inter alia, that the trial court's order granting the new trial motion was a final appealable order. Further, the court noted that the injuries resulted from the acts both defendants and that either could have been held responsible. Thus, no error resulted from the jury's finding that the company's negligence was the proximate cause of injury.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was reversed and the cause was remanded to the trial court with instructions to set aside its order granting a new trial and to re-enter judgment for the motorist on the verdict of the jury.

 

141 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Denison University v. Board of Tax Appeals


No. 38994


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 2d 17; 205 N.E.2d 896; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 477; 31 Ohio Op. 2d 10



March 31, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Denison University filed three applications for exemption from taxation. The first relates to three parcels of land comprising a farm of 127 plus acres upon which are located certain buildings. This land is separated from the college campus only by a state highway.

The buildings on this land are a carpenter shop used for maintenance and repair of university equipment and buildings, a lumber storage shed for storing lumber for use in the carpenter shop, a quonset hut used by university painting crews for painting college equipment and by the university for storage of maintenance equipment, and a frame dwelling lived in by a caretaker of the facilities and his family. A riding ring and trail on this farm are used in a women's physical education course in horseback riding. A pole shelter is used to store hay for the horses.

The second application relates to the president's home located upon the college campus where the president and his family live.

The third application relates to Middleton House and the eight-acre tract upon which it is located about one and a half miles from the campus. Middleton House is used to provide lodging for official [***2] guests of the university, such as speakers, lecturers and examiners, and for college conferences and seminars. A caretaker and his family live in part of the house. No income is derived from the premises.

By its decision, the Board of Tax Appeals denied all three applications. The cause is now before this court on appeal from that decision.



DISPOSITION: Decision reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant university challenged a decision of appellee Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which denied its applications seeking exemption from taxation under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.07 for parcels of land upon which buildings were located, the president's home, and a house used to provide lodging for official guests.


OVERVIEW: The university was a private institution of learning. It was argued that § 5709.07 was inapplicable because the university was not a public college. The court held that under § 5709.07 all lands connected with public institutions of learning not used with a view to profit were exempt. The buildings connected with the university were specifically exempted from taxation by § 5709.07. They were with reasonable certainty used in furthering or carrying out its necessary objects and purposes. The land not occupied by buildings and connected with the university was also exempted from taxation if not used with a view to profit. The record as to the use of the building and land required their exemption from taxation. There was evidence that the land had been rented and that a farmer had harvested crops therefrom. There was no evidence to indicate what, if any, payment the university received or whether it merely allowed the use of the land to keep it in reasonably good condition.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision denying the university's applications to exempt certain property from taxation and remanded the cause with directions to allow the tax exemptions sought.

 

142 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


West Jefferson v. Robinson


No. 38784


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 2d 113; 205 N.E.2d 382; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 577; 30 Ohio Op. 2d 474



March 10, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Madison County.

Defendant, an employee of the publisher of a 24-volume encyclopedia, was convicted in the Mayor's Court of the village of West Jefferson of violating an ordinance by unlawfully soliciting orders for the sale of that encyclopedia at several private residences in West Jefferson, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owners or occupants of those residences.

The ordinance involved reads so far as pertinent:

"Section 1. The practice of going in and upon private residence [sic] in the village of Jefferson by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of said private residences for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, magazines, periodicals or other articles or publications and/or disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such nuisance as a misdemeanor.

"Section 2. Whoever violates Section 1 * * * upon conviction * * * * shall be fined not more than twenty-five dollars * * *."

On appeal [***2] to the Common Pleas Court, the conviction was affirmed.

Thereafter, the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court, declared the ordinance unconstitutional and remanded the cause to the Mayor's Court with instructions to discharge the defendant.

The cause is now before this court on appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The prosecution sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Madison County (Ohio), which declared an ordinance unconstitutional and reversed a judgment that affirmed defendant's conviction for violating the ordinance by unlawfully soliciting orders for the sale of an encyclopedia at several private residences.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of violating a city ordinance by unlawfully soliciting orders for the sale of an encyclopedia at several private residences. The common pleas court affirmed the conviction, but the appellate court declared the ordinance unconstitutional and reversed the judgment of the common pleas court. The prosecution appealed. The court reversed the appellate court's judgment and affirmed the judgment of the common pleas court. The court found that the ordinance was a local police regulation pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3 and that the city could adopt and enforce the ordinance unless it was in conflict with general laws or with some constitutional provision. The court determined that any conflict with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 715.63, 715.64 did not make the ordinance invalid because those statutes were not general laws under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3. The court also determined that interference with the enjoyment and use of property and the making of contracts did not make the ordinance invalid. The ordinance bore a real and substantial relation to the public safety and the general welfare of the public, and it was neither unreasonable nor arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment against the prosecution that declared the ordinance unconstitutional and reversed the judgment of the common pleas court. The court affirmed the judgment that affirmed defendant's conviction for unlawfully soliciting orders in violation of the ordinance.

 

143 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Porter v. Oberlin


No. 38734


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 2d 143; 205 N.E.2d 363; 1965 Ohio LEXIS 585; 30 Ohio Op. 2d 491



March 10, 1965, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

This action was instituted for the purpose of securing a declaration that the fair housing ordinance of the city of Oberlin is unconstitutional and for an injunction restraining its enforcement.

Under that ordinance, a "dwelling unit" is defined as meaning "(1) a single room, suite of rooms, or an apartment or a dwelling, occupied or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters, by an individual, by a family or a group of individuals living together or (2) a parcel of real property or a lot available for the construction of [such] a dwelling unit."

The ordinance makes it a crime, punishable by a fine of not more than $ 100, for an owner of five or more dwelling units in Oberlin "to discriminate against any person purely because of race, creed or color, in" the sale, rental or other disposition of one of those dwelling units or "in the terms, conditions or privileges" of such sale, rental or other disposition.

Also, the ordinance not only makes it a crime for any real estate broker, salesman or lending institution to participate in such discrimination with such an owner, but (because of the definitions for such broker,  [***2] salesman and institution) the ordinance in effect prohibits such discrimination by such broker, salesman or institution with respect to any real estate transaction in Oberlin.

The Common Pleas Court rendered a judgment determining the ordinance to be unconstitutional and enjoining its enforcement.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact, that court found the ordinance to be constitutional and determined that plaintiff's amended petition should be dismissed. However, because it also found its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment in Terry v. City of Toledo (Lucas County 1963), 194 N.E.2d 877, the Court of Appeals, as required by Section 6, Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed a judgment that held the fair housing ordinance that prohibited discrimination by owners of five or more dwellings and their real estate brokers was unconstitutional and enjoined its enforcement. The Court of Appeals (Ohio) reversed finding that the ordinance was constitutional, and so dismissed plaintiff taxpayer's complaint. The court certified the issues to the Ohio Supreme Court.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer had standing to challenge the validity of the city's fair housing ordinance because under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 733.59 and 733.56, the expenditure of public funds was necessary to enforce the ordinance. The ordinance did not constitute an unreasonable deprivation of individual property rights and contract rights in violation of Ohio Const. art. I, §§ 1 and 19, because it supported the right to acquire and possess property. Further any limitation imposed on an owner was constitutional as it enforced § 1 which declared all men free and independent with the inalienable right to acquire and possess property. Therefore, the ordinance as an exercise of police power was substantially related to the benefit of the general welfare of the public. The equal protection clauses of the U.S. Const. amend. XIV and Ohio Const. art. I, § 2, were not violated by the ordinance's application to owners of five or more dwellings because such owners posed potentially more of a discrimination threat than those with less than five dwellings, and other provisions discouraged owners with fewer dwellings from discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the portion of the judgment that found the ordinance constitutional as to its enforcement provision, but otherwise affirmed the constitutionality of the remainder of the ordinance as a valid exercise of the city's police power to stop discrimination in housing.

 

144 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Waldbillig


No. 38833


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 2d 50; 203 N.E.2d 361; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 733; 30 Ohio Op. 2d 28



December 29, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

About 11 p.m. on June 28, 1963, the Norwood Police were called about a break-in at a laundromat. On arrival at the laundromat, they found that several money containers had been broken and some had apparently been taken. The police were then advised that several individuals had been seen breaking into these coin boxes and they were given the descriptions of those individuals and of their get-away car and the license number of that automobile. Shortly thereafter, that automobile was located nearby while it was being backed out of defendant's driveway by defendant. Defendant and the four other occupants of the car were searched and arrested. At that time, a machete knife, which was on the floor of the back seat and was clearly visible from outside the vehicle, was seen by a police officer. Thereafter, defendant and his four companions were taken to the police station. After they had been taken to the police station, their automobile was taken to the police station where it was searched. While driving the automobile to the police station, the foot of the officer who was driving hit a steel object which he then determined was [***2] a revolver. It turned out to be a .38 caliber revolver. After reaching the police station, the automobile was searched. As a result of this search, which was made without a warrant, a chain was discovered under the front seat cushion, hacksaw blades and tin snips were discovered on the floorboards behind the front seat and "home-made knuckles" were found in the glove compartment.

The grand jury returned an indictment charging that defendant "unlawfully did carry concealed on or about his person a dangerous weapon, to wit: a .38 calibre [sic] revolver and one home-made knuckles."

Defendant pleaded not guilty and filed a pretrial motion to suppress as evidence all the items found in defendant's automobile. This motion was overruled. All the items found in the automobile were, over defendant's objection, introduced into evidence against him and defendant was found guilty.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction. The cause is now before this court on appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:
