PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a decision of the trial court (Ohio) overruling defendant's pretrial motion to suppress evidence and convicting defendant for unlawfully carrying concealed on or about his person a dangerous weapon in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.01. Defendant challenged the warrantless seizure of items from his car following a theft-related arrest.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested on suspicion of breaking into money boxes at a coin-operated laundry. A machete was in plain view inside defendant's car. Defendant was transported to the police station. A police officer said that his foot hit a gun on the floor of defendant's car while he was driving it to the station. Upon later search, various tools and objects were found, including home-made "knuckles," all of which was admitted into evidence against defendant. Defendant was convicted of carrying a concealed weapon and appealed, challenging the search. The appellate court affirmed the trial court, and the court affirmed the appellate court. The court acknowledged that the items other than the machete and the gun should have been suppressed in accordance with U.S. Supreme Court case law. The court said, however, that the machete and gun were not discovered through an unreasonable search. The machete was visible at the time of arrest and the gun was found while the officer lawfully transported the car. The court concluded that the other items did not prejudice defendant as he could have been convicted of violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.01 on the basis of the properly admitted gun.


OUTCOME: The court found for the State and affirmed the appellate court.

 

145 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. McLeod


No. 37465


Supreme Court of Ohio


1 Ohio St. 2d 60; 203 N.E.2d 349; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 735; 30 Ohio Op. 2d 34



December 29, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This cause is before this court upon the mandate of the Supreme Court of the United States issued on June 22, 1964, after defendant petitioned it for a writ of certiorari ordering this court to consider its judgment dismissing defendant's appeal as a matter of right for the reason that there was no debatable constitutional question.

Defendant, Joseph T. McLeod, along with two others, was indicted on October 3, 1960, for murder in the first degree. On October 11, 1960, before he procured or was assigned counsel, defendant voluntarily made an oral confession in the presence of a deputy sheriff and an assistant prosecuting attorney while riding around in the sheriff's automobile searching for the gun used in the holdup.

A jury trial was had in the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County. Over defendant's objection, testimony by the deputy sheriff as to the oral confession was admitted into evidence. Defendant was found guilty and was sentenced to life imprisonment in the Ohio Penitentiary.

At the time of the confession, the defendant was not represented by counsel nor had he even requested counsel. Admittedly, every procedural [***2] requirement of the state of Ohio was complied with from the time of arrest to the time of sentence.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, and an appeal to this court was dismissed for the reason that there was no debatable constitutional question involved. State v. McLeod, 173 Ohio St., 520.

Appeal was then taken to the Supreme Court of the United States, which vacated the judgment and remanded the cause to this court ( McLeod v. Ohio, 84 S. Ct., 1922) "for consideration in light of Massiah v. United States [decided May 18, 1964]), 84 S. Ct., 1199."

Thereafter, appellant's motion for leave to appeal was allowed and the cause was heard by this court on its merits.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed his murder conviction. At issue was the admissibility of defendant's voluntary oral confession to law enforcement officials, which was made before counsel was requested by or appointed to defendant. Defendant's appeal was before the court, after its initial dismissal, for consideration in light of a recent United States Supreme Court ruling.


OVERVIEW: Statements made in the recent U.S. Supreme Court case were made voluntarily by that defendant but were elicited by an accomplice who had agreed to co-operate with the government. At the time that defendant made the statements, he had no knowledge that the conversation was being overheard by a government agent and would be used against him at his trial. In this defendant's case, however, the court found that defendant's statements, though made at a time when he had no counsel, were made willingly in the known presence of public officers. His incriminating statements were made while he was voluntarily endeavoring to aid the police in securing evidence of the crime. In the instant case, defendant had not yet been arraigned and the court held that the circumstances under which his incriminating statements were given were wholly different from those in the U.S. Supreme Court case. The court therefore found no reason not to affirm the appellate court's judgment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment upholding defendant's conviction.

 

146 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Kessler


No. 38206


Supreme Court of Ohio


177 Ohio St. 136; 203 N.E.2d 221; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 826; 29 Ohio Op. 2d 348



December 23, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant tax commissioner sought review of a judgment entered by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed a probate court's judgment overruling his exceptions to the determination of the succession tax with regard to an estate.


OVERVIEW: While living in California with his wife, the decedent acquired certain shares of stock. At the time of his passing, the decedent and his wife resided in Ohio. Appellee executor determined that one-half of the stock was the outright property of his wife under California's community property law and that no tax was due on that interest. The probate and appellate courts upheld that contention. The tax commissioner sought review of the appellate court's judgment. With regard to their community property, Cal. Civ. Code § 161a provided that a husband and wife possessed equal interests that were under his management. Under § 161a, a wife did not have genuine control over her interest in the property. Moreover, the transaction from a partial and qualified ownership to total ownership was universally considered a taxable succession. Therefore, the wife's acquisition of the complete enjoyment of her interest in the decedent's stock was taxable under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5731.02(E), which provided that a taxable succession to the extent of one-half of the property's value occurred whenever a spouse obtained the right to the full and complete enjoyment of the property as a whole.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment. The matter was remanded to the probate court for further proceedings in accordance with the court's opinion.

 

147 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lisbon Sales Book Co.


Nos. 38370, 38371, 38372, 38373, 38374


Supreme Court of Ohio


176 Ohio St. 482; 200 N.E.2d 590; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 1006; 27 Ohio Op. 2d 443



July 8, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County.

At the September 1961 term of the Court of Common Pleas, the Grand Jury of Columbiana County returned indictments in these causes under the provisions of Section 2915.11, Revised Code. The appellants filed timely motions to quash the indictments on the ground that there was a "defect apparent upon the face of the record." The Court of Common Pleas overruled these motions to quash.

Thereupon appellants demurred to the indictments, contending that:

(1) Each of the indictments violates the due process clause of Section 1, Article XIV, Amendments, Constitution of the United States, and the due-course-of-law clause of Section 16, Article I of the Constitution of the state of Ohio; and

(2) the facts stated in the indictments do not show an offense punishable by the laws of the state of Ohio.

The Court of Common Pleas sustained appellants' demurrers to the indictments upon the ground that " Section 2915.11 of the Revised Code as amended, effective September 1, 1961, as it applies to manufacturers and printers, is unconstitutional for the reason that said section does not require that the manufacturing and printing be done with  [***2] a knowledge or intent that the article manufactured or printed is to be used in the numbers game." (Emphasis added.)

Plaintiff, the state of Ohio, appellee herein, perfected an appeal in each case from the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas to the Court of Appeals of the Seventh Appellate District. The Court of Appeals reversed the judgments of the Court of Common Pleas and remanded the causes for further proceedings in accordance with the law.

Each cause is now before this court upon the allowance of appellant's motion for leave to appeal on questions of law from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from the decision of the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County (Ohio), which reversed the lower court's decision to sustain defendants' demurrers to three indictments on the ground that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.11 was unconstitutional. The indictments alleged that defendants had printed lottery tickets. The State successfully appealed the granting of the demurrers to the court of appeals.


OVERVIEW: Indictments were brought against three defendants for printing tickets used for a lottery. Defendants complained that their constitutional rights were being violated. They also argued that the indictment was fatally defective because it was not alleged that defendants "knowingly" committed any offense or that they had a guilty purpose in printing certain tickets. The court noted that for over 150 years the people of Ohio had declared, through Ohio Const. art. XV, § 6, that lotteries, and the sale of lottery tickets, for any purpose whatever, was to forever be prohibited in the State. The court found that the language of the indictment in its terms descriptive of the offense, in substance, alleged knowledge. The court held that the Ohio General Assembly was well within constitutional boundaries in the enactment of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.11.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, which reversed the lower court's sustaining of defendants' demurrers, which claimed that the statute prohibiting gambling was unconstitutional.

 

148 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ghaster Properties, Inc. v. Preston


No. 38523


Supreme Court of Ohio


176 Ohio St. 425; 200 N.E.2d 328; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 1083; 27 Ohio Op. 2d 388



July 1, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

This action was instituted on October 21, 1959, in the Common Pleas Court of Allen County by Ghaster Properties, Inc., and Ghaster Outdoor Advertising, Inc., against the Director of Highways. The purpose of the action is (1) to enjoin the highway director from interfering with certain advertising signs owned and used by Ghaster and located within 660 feet of the edge of the right-of-way of Interstate Route No. 75 and access roads leading thereto and (2) for a declaratory judgment as to the validity of the Ohio statutes prohibiting the maintenance of signs adjacent to interstate highways.

These statutes were first enacted, effective in 1958, as Sections 5515.21 to 5515.24 and 5515.99, Revised Code (127 Ohio Laws, Pt. II, 14).

Effective June 28, 1961 (129 Ohio Laws, 1701), those statutes were repealed and replaced by Sections 5516.01 to 5516.05 and 5516.99, which, so far as pertinent to a consideration of this case, read:

Section 5516.01.

"(A) 'Advertising device' includes any outdoor sign, display, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, billboard, or any other contrivance designed, intended, or used to advertise [***2] or to give information in the nature of advertising, or any part thereof, and having the capacity of being visible from the travelway of any highway on the interstate system in this state.

"(B) 'Visible' means capable of being seen, whether or not legible, without visual aid by a person of normal acuity.

"(C) 'Interstate system' means the system of highways as defined in subsection (d), 23 U. S. C., 103, 72 Stat., 888 (1958) or amendments thereof.

"(D) 'Erect' means to construct or allow to be constructed.

"(E) 'Maintain' means to preserve, keep in repair, continue, replace, or allow to exist."

Section 5516.02.

"No advertising device shall be erected or maintained within 660 feet of the edge of the right of way of a highway on the interstate system except the following:

"(A) Directional or other official signs or notices that are required or authorized by law;

"(B) Signs advertising the sale or lease of the property upon which they are located;

"(C) Advertising devices indicating the name of the business or profession conducted on such property or which identify the goods produced, sold, or services rendered on such property;

"(D) Advertising devices which are located in [***3] commercial or industrial zones traversed by segments of the interstate system within the boundaries of incorporated municipalities as such boundaries existed on September 21, 1959, wherein the property adjacent to the interstate system is subject to municipal regulation or control."

Section 5516.04.

"Any advertising device which violates Sections 5516.02 and 5516.03 of the Revised Code, is a public and private nuisance, and the Director of Highways shall give 30 days notice, by registered or certified mail, to the owner or lessee of the land on which such advertising device is located, to remove such advertising device.

"If any such advertising device has not been removed on or before the expiration of 30 days following the receipt of the said notice by the owner or lessee of the land upon which the advertising device is located, the Director of Highways, or any of his duly authorized agents, may, at his discretion, either:

"(A) Remove, obliterate, or abate the advertising device. * * *

"(B) File a complaint by petition in the Court of Common Pleas of the county in which such advertising device is located, and, upon a finding by the court that a violation of Sections 5516.02 [***4] to 5516.04, inclusive, of the Revised Code, exists as alleged in the petition, the court shall enter an order of abatement against the person or persons erecting or maintaining such advertising device, or against the owner or owners of the land upon which such advertising device is situated, as the case may be."

Section 5516.99.

"Whoever erects or maintains an advertising device in violation of Section 5516.02 of the Revised Code shall be fined not less than $ 100 nor more than $ 1,000."

Ghaster has three parcels of real estate, which are outside of any municipality and are located on the north side of Route No. 30S near the interchange with Interstate Highway No. 75. On these parcels there are seven sign panels which come within the prohibitions of the foregoing statutes. All were in existence prior to June 28, 1961, the effective date of the foregoing-quoted statutory provisions.

On June 21, 1962, the Common Pleas Court held the foregoing statutes unconstitutional and issued a permanent injunction against their enforcement. (184 N. E. [2d], 552.) The cause was appealed to the Court of Appeals on questions of law and fact, and that court on September 18, 1963, found the existing [***5] statutes unconstitutional in their application to the foregoing Ghaster signs but otherwise refused to render a declaratory judgment on the constitutionality of those statutes. (194 N. E. [2d], 158.)

The cause is now before this court on appeals from the judgment of the Court of Appeals both by Ghaster and by the highway director as a case involving constitutional questions, and also pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporations and appellee highways' director sought review of the decision from the Court of Appeals for Allen County (Ohio) that, in an action to enjoin appellee from interfering with advertising signs owned by appellants and for a declaratory judgment as to the validity of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5516.01 to 5516.05 and 5516.99, found the statutes unconstitutional but refused to render a declaratory judgment.


OVERVIEW: Appellant corporations sued appellee, highways' director, to enjoin appellee from interfering with certain advertising signs owned and used by appellants and located at the edge of the right-of-way of an interstate route and access roads and for a declaratory judgment as to the validity of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5516.01 to 5516.05 and 5516.99. The lower court declared the statutes unconstitutional and issued a permanent injunction against their enforcement and the appellate court found the statutes unconstitutional as to their application against appellants but refused to render a declaratory judgment. Both parties appealed. Appellants claimed the statutes took private property without compensation in violation of Ohio Const. art. I, §§ 1, 16 and 19 and U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court reversed judgment. It concluded the statutes bore a real and substantial relationship to the public safety and general welfare. A statute was neither unreasonable nor arbitrary because it prohibited signs which advertised a product not sold on the property but permitted signs advertising products sold on the property. The statutes were valid and constitutional in their general application.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed, and appellants' petition was dismissed.

 

149 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Trust Estate of Ely


No. 38433


Supreme Court of Ohio


176 Ohio St. 311; 199 N.E.2d 746; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 940; 27 Ohio Op. 2d 236



June 3, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

This action in prohibition was originally instituted in the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

Helen C. Ely, appellee, is cotrustee and beneficiary under the testamentary trust of William A. Ely, deceased, filed in the Probate Court of Lorain County. She filed a motion in such court to remove as cotrustee the First National Bank of Elyria.

The probate judge of Lorain County disqualified himself from hearing the motion and requested the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court to assign another judge to hear and dispose of the issues raised by such motion.

The Chief Justice assigned a judge of the Court of Common Pleas of another county to hear the matter, but, after a pretrial conference, he, too, disqualified himself and asked the Chief Justice to assign another judge to hear and determine the matter.

About this time, the cotrustee bank filed a motion to remove the appellee as cotrustee, and appellee amended her original motion to remove the bank as cotrustee.

The Chief Justice then assigned the appellant, Myron T. Brenneman, the duly elected, qualified and acting probate judge of Wayne County, to sit as probate judge in Lorain [***2] County to pass upon the above-mentioned motions.

The Chief Justice in making this assignment acted under the provisions of Section 2101.39, Revised Code.

The appellant, sitting in Lorain County, proceeded to hear the motions, recessed the hearing and later resumed the hearing. After several days of trial, the hearing was again recessed in order to permit the parties to enter into settlement negotiations. A settlement was reached, the appellant was advised of this development by telephone, and he indicated that he would return to Lorain County the following Monday to make appropriate orders to perfect the settlement.

However, upon convening court the following Monday, appellant announced that he would not consider a settlement and that he proposed to cause an examination to be made of the assets of the trust, and he entered certain orders on matters not arising from the hearing.

Appellee then filed a motion to remove appellant as presiding judge, contending that appellant did not have jurisdiction to sit as a probate judge in Lorain County, as the statute under which he had been assigned offends the Constitution of Ohio.

Appellant overruled this motion, whereupon appellee filed [***3] a petition for a writ of prohibition in the Court of Appeals on July 8, 1963.

The Court of Appeals held that the statute, Section 2101.39, Revised Code, was contrary to the provisions of the Constitution of Ohio and allowed a writ of prohibition to issue.

The cause is now before this court upon appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant judge sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lorain County (Ohio), which granted appellee trustee's petition for a writ of prohibition, holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2101.39, which permitted the Chief Justice to appoint a probate judge of another county to replace a disqualified probate court judge, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The trustee and a bank sought in the probate court to remove each other as cotrustees of a trust. The judge was the probate judge of another county. He was the second judge appointed by the Chief Justice to hear the case after the county probate judge disqualified himself from hearing the case. The trustee filed an original action in prohibition in the Court of Appeals, alleging that the judge did not have jurisdiction to hear the case. The court held that § 2101.39 was presumed constitutional. Ohio Const. art. IV, § 8, conferred such jurisdiction on probate court judges in other counties as might be provided by law. The court termed this migratory jurisdiction. The legislature had conferred jurisdiction on probate judges to hear and decide matters in a number of areas outside of traditional probate court jurisdiction. Section 2101.39 was not violative of the Constitution beyond a reasonable doubt. There was no clear incompatibility between the Constitution and the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remanded for further proceedings according to law.

 

150 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ilersich v. Schneider


No. 38506


Supreme Court of Ohio


176 Ohio St. 255; 199 N.E.2d 388; 1964 Ohio LEXIS 921; 27 Ohio Op. 2d 157



May 20, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed an order of appellee Tax Commissioner imposing a sales tax assessment against the taxpayer in connection with the operation of the taxpayer's retail business. The tax was assessed pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.01(L) on food purchased for human consumption where the food was consumed at the place of purchase.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer operated a drive-in retail soft ice-cream and soft-drink business. Customers purchased items from a building, which was surrounded by a parking area, and a number of the taxpayer's customers would consume their purchases on the taxpayer's property, but away from the actual building. The Commissioner determined that 37 percent of the products sold by the taxpayer were consumed by the purchasers in the taxpayer's parking lot and assessed a sales tax on those purchases under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.01(L). The assessment was affirmed by the Board. The taxpayer contended that § 5739.01(L) was an unconstitutional violation of Ohio Const. art. XII, § 12, which exempted from sales tax food purchases that were taken away from the place of purchase for consumption to homes and other establishments. The court held that § 5739.01(L) represented a permissible legislative interpretation and application of the indefinite constitutional phrase "off the premises where sold" to meet modern merchandising practices. The court held that § 5739.01 was not unconstitutional and that the decision of the Board affirming the Commissioner's assessment was not unreasonable or unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision.

 

151 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ruggiero v. Common Pleas Court


No. 38409


Supreme Court of Ohio


175 Ohio St. 361; 194 N.E.2d 850; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 673; 25 Ohio Op. 2d 258



December 18, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROCEDENDO.

The Brooklyn Planning Commission refused to approve relator's application for a certificate of occupancy and other permits necessary to enable relator to make a certain storeroom ready for occupancy and to use it as a restaurant in which to serve food and intoxicating liquor, upon finding that relator did not provide adequate parking space for the operation of his contemplated business.

The Brooklyn Board of Zoning Appeals, on appeal, affirmed the decision of the commission.

The order of the board was appealed from to the respondent Court of Common Pleas pursuant to Chapter 2506, Revised Code. The court found that the decision of the commission was based on Section 4 (E) of the zoning ordinance, relating to parking facilities, and that the section was invalid. The court found also that relator had a D-5 liquor permit, that there was a valid city ordinance (No. 1956.74) relating to off-street parking for places selling intoxicating liquor for consumption on the premises, and that the cause should be remanded to the Board of Zoning Appeals with instruction to enter an order referring the matter to the planning commission for specific finding of facts and a final [***2] order granting or denying the permits after considering all applicable valid ordinances and statutes.

The relator then requested the respondent court to either affirm, reverse, vacate or modify the order of the board and to then make an order of remand accordingly. Upon respondent court's refusal to so do, relator instituted this action in procedendo in this court, praying for a writ requiring respondent court "to either affirm, reverse, vacate or modify the order of the said Brooklyn Board of Zoning Appeals, and to then make an order of remand accordingly, as provided by Section 2506.04, Revised Code."

A demurrer has been filed to the petition on the ground that it does not state facts which show a cause of action.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.

 

152 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Davis Inv. Co. v. Columbus


No. 36687


Supreme Court of Ohio


175 Ohio St. 337; 194 N.E.2d 859; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 807; 25 Ohio Op. 2d 244



December 18, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

In this action in mandamus, brought originally in this court, the Davis Investment Company, an Ohio corporation, is the relator, and the city of Columbus and Raymond D. Goller, Superintendent of Building Regulations of that city, are the respondents.

Before the court are the petition, the answer (a demurrer to which was overruled without written opinion), the reply and an agreed statement of facts which was submitted at the time the court had before it for disposition the demurrer to the answer.

The controversy revolves around the westerly 7.3 acres of a 17-acre tract of land owned by the relator, designated as the Berwick Manor Shoppers Mart Tract and situated in the easterly section of the city of Columbus, along the south side of East Livingston Avenue.

Relator acquired the entire 17 acres for the purpose of constructing a shopping center with accessory facilities. By city zoning ordinances passed in 1956 and 1957, the easterly 10 acres of relator's land was classified as C-4 (a commercial district), and the westerly 7 acres plus was classified as SR (a suburban residential district).

In November of 1959, relator applied for and was granted a building permit [***2] for the construction of units of the proposed shopping center on its easterly 10 acres. In March of 1960, application was made for a building permit to construct units of the shopping center on the westerly 7.3 acres, which was refused by the Superintendent of Building Regulations on the ground that the SR classification of that acreage precluded the granting of the permit. An appeal from such refusal was taken to the Board of Zoning Adjustment, and at the same time and pursuant to Section 3309.06 (b) of the Columbus City Codes, then in effect, relator asked for a variance in the SR classification of the 7.3 acres to permit construction of units of the shopping center. The appeal and the application for the variance came on for hearing before the board upon evidence pro and con and upon exhibits. No decision was made, and the matter was continued until May 20, 1960, for further consideration upon additional information and evidence.

On May 16, 1960, the Columbus City Council adopted as an emergency measure without notice Ordinance No. 618-60, designed to amend Section 3309.06 of the Columbus City Codes.

On May 20, 1960, relator's appeal and application for variance were considered [***3] further by the board upon the additional information and evidence requested. Against opposition and despite emergency Ordinance No. 618-60, the board on May 20, 1960, granted the appeal and allowed the requested variance in the zoning classification for relator's westerly 7.3 acres.

Thereupon, relator applied to respondent Goller for the issuance of a building permit to construct shopping-center units and appurtenances on the 7.3-acre tract, which was refused in writing "because of the City Attorney's opinion that Ordinance No. 618-60 precludes the Board of Zoning Adjustment from making the order issued by them on May 20, 1960."

Thereafter, two persons filed appeals from the May 20, 1960, order of the Board of Zoning Adjustment to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County. Those appeals were dismissed. On appeal, the Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the court below, and this court overruled the motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered the motion of relator developer that sought a writ of mandamus against respondents, a city and the city's superintendent of building regulations (city), to order the city to grant the developer a zoning variance.


OVERVIEW: The developer filed an application that sought a zoning variance for a parcel of land that adjoined another parcel that the developer had plans to develop as well. The city denied the developer's application for the zoning variance, so the developer filed a motion that sought a writ of mandamus to order the city to grant the variance. The court denied the developer's motion for a writ of mandamus to order the city to grant the application of the developer for a zoning variance. The court found that the zoning restriction on the parcel of property had been in place long before the developer acquired the property. The court concluded that the developer had not shown a clear legal right to the issuance of a writ of mandamus against the city.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of the developer that sought a writ of mandamus ordering the city to grant the developer's application for a zoning variance.

 

153 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Beck


No. 37808


Supreme Court of Ohio


175 Ohio St. 73; 191 N.E.2d 825; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 565; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 377



June 26, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Defendant, William Beck, appellant herein, was charged in the Cleveland Municipal Court under Section 2915.111, Revised Code, with the offense of having in his possession and under his control on the 10th day of November 1961 certain clearinghouse slips.

Before trial, defendant filed a written motion to suppress the evidence on the ground that his arrest and the search of his person, resulting in the discovery and seizure of incriminating evidence, were unauthorized, unwarranted, unreasonable and a violation of his rights under the Fourth and Fifth Amendments to the federal Constitution. The motion was heard and overruled. A plea of not guilty was entered, and the defendant was found guilty and fined.

An appeal on questions of law to the Court of Appeals resulted in the affirmance of the judgment below, and the cause is now here for decision pursuant to an appeal as of right and the allowance of a motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which upheld a conviction entered by the municipal court against him for the offense of illegal possession of clearinghouse slips pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.111.


OVERVIEW: The police acted on a tip from the informant that defendant, who had a prior history of carrying on a scheme of chance involving clearinghouse slips, would be in a certain locality in an automobile pursuing such an unlawful activity. The police stopped defendant's car and searched it without finding anything related to the scheme, but placed defendant under arrest. A subsequent examination of defendant's clothing revealed the illegal clearinghouse slips. Defendant was charged with possession of illegal clearinghouse slips pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.111, and filed a motion to suppress on the ground that the arrest and the search were unlawful and unconstitutional. The trial court overruled defendant's motion, a conviction was entered, and the appellate court upheld the conviction. According to the court, there was probable cause for an arrest and the police were searching for defendant in order to arrest him for possession of illegal clearinghouse slips, not merely for an exploratory search. The court also determined that there was no error in not disclosing the informant's name because it would not have altered the fact of defendant's guilt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for possession of illegal clearinghouse slips.

 

154 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Paramount Film Distributing Corp. v. Tracy


No. 37727


Supreme Court of Ohio


175 Ohio St. 55; 191 N.E.2d 839; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 560; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 352



June 19, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Plaintiff, Paramount Film Distributing Corporation, appellant herein and herein referred to as plaintiff, paid censorship fees to the state of Ohio under the provisions of the Ohio motion picture censorship statutes during the years 1952 through 1954.

In 1952, the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of Joseph Burstyn, Inc., v. Wilson, Commr., 343 U.S., 495, declared invalid in part a New York statute dealing with film censorship. After the judgment in the Burstyn case, this court in Superior Films, Inc., v. Department of Education (1953), 159 Ohio St., 315, upheld the constitutionality of the Ohio censorship statutes. On appeal that judgment was reversed by the Supreme Court of the United States in 346 U.S., 587 (1954), on the authority of the Burstyn case. Then in the case of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, Inc., v. Department of Education (1954), 162 Ohio St., 263, this court concluded that further censorship orders of the Department of Education must necessarily be invalid. The total effect of those decisions was a finding that the Ohio statutes on film censorship were unconstitutional. 

 [***2] During the period between 1952 and 1954, plaintiff, while paying the required fees under the censorship statutes, informed the state officials charged with the enforcement of such statutes and the collection of fees thereunder that payment was being made under protest, and that plaintiff intended to sue to recover the amount of the payments.

Thereafter in December 1958 plaintiff instituted the present action to recover the payments from the following persons; Roger W. Tracy and Joseph T. Ferguson, both of whom had held the office of Treasurer of State; James A. Rhodes, who held the office of Auditor of State; and Clyde Hissong, R. Merle Eyman and Edward E. Holt, who had held the office of Superintendent of Public Instruction. These named persons are the defendants, appellees herein, and herein will be referred to as defendants.

Recovery is sought from the defendants individually in their personal capacities and not from the state itself.

In the Court of Common Pleas the defendants filed a demurrer which was sustained on the ground that the petition does not state facts sufficient to show a cause of action against the defendants.

The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the [***3] trial court, but on different grounds, holding that plaintiff's remedy was to bring an action under Chapter 2723, Revised Code, for recovery of taxes, and that the one-year statute of limitations in Section 2723.01, Revised Code, was a bar to this action.

The cause is before this court on an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff film distributor sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's decision to sustain defendants' demurrer on the ground that the distributor's petition to recover censorship fees did not state facts sufficient to show a cause of action against defendants.


OVERVIEW: The film distributor paid censorship fees during certain years under Ohio motion picture censorship statutes, which were ultimately held to be unconstitutional. Thereafter, the distributor instituted the action to recover the payments. The trial court sustained defendants' demurrer and the appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court affirmed on the ground that the distributor's remedy was to file an action under Ohio Rev. Code § 2723 for recovery of taxes, and that the one-year statute of limitations in § 2723.01 was a bar to the action. The court held that it was difficult to believe that the General Assembly, in Ohio Rev. Code § 2723.01, would have intended to provide an injunctive remedy only with respect to illegally levied taxes and assessments other than license fees. In the court's opinion, the license fees were "taxes and assessments" within the meaning of those words as used in the statute. Because the action for recovery was not filed within one year after the taxes and assessments were collected, the court held that any cause of action for their recovery was barred.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court, which sustained defendants' demurrer to the film distributor's action to recover payments for license fees.

 

155 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


General Tel. Co. v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 37280


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 575; 191 N.E.2d 341; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 804; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 268



May 31, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission.

This case is before this court upon an appeal from an order of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio establishing rates for telephone service.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant telephone company sought review of a decision of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which established rates for telephone service.


OVERVIEW: The Commission established rates for telephone service. On appeal, the telephone company contended that the Commission erred in allowing a given sum as an expense for federal taxes. The court held that: (1) the income tax that the telephone company was required to pay to the federal government under the income tax law on its annual dollar return could be calculated mathematically according to the federal income tax law to an exact accurate amount; (2) instead of allowing the known and accurate expense for taxes to the telephone company, the Commission created a hypothetical public utility company, which was done by capitalizing the statutory rate base and thus converting the statutory rate base into a capitalization rate base composed of fictitious amounts of debt and fictitious amounts of equity; (3) what the Commission did was error; and (4) for purposes of rate making, the statutory rate base of a public utility company was the dollar value of its property, used and useful, in rendering the public utility service, and that value was to be found by a determination of the reconstruction cost new less existing depreciation on the property of the public utility.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of establishing rates for the telephone company and remanded the case to the Commission for further proceedings.

 

156 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Griffith


No. 37805


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 553; 190 N.E.2d 907; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 797; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 235



May 29, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The defendant, appellant herein, was charged by affidavit with having violated Section 2905.40, Revised Code. The affidavit charges that defendant "did unlawfully own, operate, or permit another to operate on his premises, a picture machine or other device exhibiting lascivious, indecent, immoral or impure picture or a picture tending to corrupt morals * * * contrary to state statute 2905.40, Revised Code."

Section 2905.40, Revised Code, provides in part:

"No person shall give a public or private exhibition of a lascivious, indecent, immoral, or impure nature or an exhibition tending to corrupt morals, or own, operate, or permit another to operate on his premises * * * a picture machine or other device exhibiting a lascivious, indecent, immoral, or impure picture or figure or a picture of crime or lust, or a picture tending to corrupt morals."

At the trial, the defendant moved to dismiss on the ground that the statute is unconstitutional. The Columbus Municipal Court found defendant guilty as charged in the affidavit.

An appeal was taken to the Court of Common Pleas where the judgment of conviction was affirmed. Subsequently [***2] an appeal to the Court of Appeals resulted in an affirmance of the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas. In each appeal defendant renewed his attack on the constitutionality of the statute.

An appeal as of right and the allowance of a motion to certify the record bring the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.

 

157 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


E. A. Schlairet Transfer Co. v. Public Utilities Com.


Nos. 37684, 37685


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 554; 190 N.E.2d 910; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 798; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 236



May 29, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Public Utilities Commission.

These cases, consolidated in this court for consideration and decision, are appeals by certain motor freight carriers from an order of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio rejecting and cancelling proposed joint rates between regular-route motor freight carriers and irregular-route motor freight carriers in the state of Ohio.

Case No. 37684 involves a joint rate filed with the Public Utilities Commission by Braddock Motor Freight, Inc., as an irregular-route carrier, and Mosholder Motor Freight, Inc., as a regular-route carrier. Case No. 37685 involves the filing of a joint rate with the commission by Duff Truck Line, Inc., as an irregular-route carrier, and E. A. Schlairet Transfer Company, as a regular-route carrier.

Both proceedings were heard separately by the commission, but, because the issues presented were the same, they were consolidated for opinion and order.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant motor freight carriers sought review of a order from the Public Utilities Commission (Ohio), which rejected and cancelled proposed joint rates between regular-route motor freight carriers and irregular-route motor freight carriers.


OVERVIEW: The motor freight carriers filed a proposal for joint rates between regular-route motor freight carriers and irregular-route motor freight carriers. The Commission rejected and cancelled the proposal. On appeal, the motor freight carriers alleged that the Commission did not have the power and authority to entertain and reject the proposed joint rates and that the order from the Commission was unreasonable and unlawful. The Commission asserted that a motor freight carrier could not arbitrarily enlarge its certificate of public convenience and necessity by the device of a joint rate arrangement. The court affirmed the Commission's order. The court held that the Commission had the authority to reject proposed joint rates between regular-route motor freight carriers and irregular-route motor freight carriers. The Commission had the function of supervising and regulating motor transportation companies under the authority conferred upon it by the general assembly as outlined in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4921.04. Further, the court held that the order from the Commission was based upon tenable and persuasive considerations, and that it could not be denoted as unreasonable or unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's order rejecting the motor freight carriers' proposed joint rates.

 

158 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Hudson Distributors, Inc. v. Upjohn Co.


Nos. 37320, 37321


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 487; 190 N.E.2d 460; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 774; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 133



May 8, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

These two causes originated in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, in each of which is sought a declaratory judgment that the Ohio Fair Trade Act, Sections 1333.27 through 1333.34, Revised Code, is invalid and unconstitutional. The facts in both cases are similar and the law applicable is the same. The appeals will be treated together, since the assignments of errors in both cases are exactly the same.

Hudson Distributors, Inc., a Michigan corporation, operates a number of retail stores in Cleveland. It brought these actions for the purpose of testing the constitutionality of the 1959 Ohio Fair Trade Act. In one case, Hudson named as defendant the Eli Lilly Company, and, in the other, The Upjohn Company. Both companies had complied with the Fair Trade Act, and Hudson had entered into no written contract with either. Hudson procured the merchandise of Lilly from a distributor in Detroit. Upjohn sold direct to the retailer or at times to the wholesaler. Hudson sold the merchandise for less than the fair-trade price.

In both causes, the Court of Common Pleas found that the Fair Trade Act is unconstitutional as [***2] an unlawful delegation of legislative power.

Those judgments were reversed by the Court of Appeals, and the causes are before this court pursuant to the allowance of motions to certify the records.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporation appealed judgments of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed a trial court's judgments holding the Ohio Fair Trade Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 1333.27 through 1333.34, unconstitutional and an unlawful delegation of power in plaintiff's declaratory judgment action against defendant corporations after plaintiff sold one of the defendant's products for less than the fair-trade price.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff brought declaratory judgment actions against defendants testing the constitutionality of the Ohio Fair Trade Act after plaintiff bought merchandise from one defendant and sold it for less than the fair-trade price of the other defendant. The appellate court reversed the trial court's finding that the Ohio Fair Trade Act was unconstitutional and an unlawful delegation of legislative power. The court found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.31 extended the original concept of the trademark to include, as a part of the ownership, a continuing proprietary interest in the trademark or trade name on the merchandise to the extent that the proprietor controlled the resale price of the merchandise even after it had left his possession and ownership. The court concluded that the general assembly properly determined that such extension of proprietary rights was necessary to protect the property rights and goodwill incorporated in the ownership of a trademark or trade name and also to protect the small-business man and the public in general. The court concluded that the legislative delegation of power was not price fixing but price maintenance contracts.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgments reversing the trial court's judgments holding that the Ohio Fair Trade Act was unconstitutional and an unlawful delegation of legislative power.

 

159 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Karrick v. Board of Education


No. 37358


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 467; 190 N.E.2d 256; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 769; 23 Ohio Op. 2d 114



May 1, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hancock County.

ON REHEARING.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, board of education and civil service commission, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals of Hancock County (Ohio), which determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 143.30, as applied to civil service jurisdiction for nonteachers of the municipal school districts, was unconstitutional, pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10 in the action by appellee designated individuals. The supreme court affirmed, but agreed to reconsider.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 143.30 was constitutional as applied to extend civil service jurisdiction to nonteaching employees of city school districts, pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10. On appeal by the board of education and the civil service commission, the court initially affirmed the decision of the appellate court, but, on reconsideration, the court reversed the decision of the appellate court. The court found the statute constitutional and, considering other issues, rejected the challenges to the rules of the civil service commission because they were not adopted in accordance with the APA, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 119 or because the age and residence requirements were unreasonable and an abuse of discretion. The court determined that, for the adoption of rules, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 119.01(A) applied only to state agencies, that § 143.30 granted the municipal commissions the powers conferred upon the state director of personnel, that § 143.16 permitted the director to consider residence, age, and other factors, and that the action of the commission was not inconsistent with requirements, were not unreasonable, or an abuse of discretion.


OUTCOME: The court, reconsidering its own affirmation of the appellate court's decision, reversed the decision of the appellate court, finding the statute extending civil service jurisdiction to nonteaching employees to be constitutional, and the civil service commission rules dictating age and residence requirements for examinations of nonteaching employees to be consistent with statute and not an abuse of discretion.

 

160 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Packard


No. 37529


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 349; 189 N.E.2d 434; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 747; 22 Ohio Op. 2d 409



March 27, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County.

Elizabeth Gillmer Packard, a resident of New York, died testate on January 19, 1960, in that state. Her will was probated in the Surrogate Court of Chautauqua County, New York, and The Central Hanover Bank & Trust Company of New York was named executor.

In addition to the decedent's New York property, she owned a business block, called the "Packard Block", in the city of Warren, Ohio. Accordingly, ancillary proceedings were filed in the Probate Court of Trumbull County, Ohio.

The gross estate of decedent in the amount of $ 1,277,869 was constituted as follows:

Realty in Ohio

$  87,500

Realty outside Ohio

$ 167,559

Tangible personalty in Ohio

None   

Tangible personalty outside Ohio

$  74,911

Intangible personalty in Ohio

None   

Intangible personalty outside Ohio

$ 947,899

Stated another way, decedent's estate consisted of $ 1,022,810 in personal property outside Ohio; $ 167,559 in real estate outside Ohio; and $ 87,500 in real estate in Ohio.

The decedent's will, after providing for the payment of debts and specific legacies, directs that the residue of the estate be turned over to The [***2] Central Hanover Bank & Trust Company as trustee for the benefit of Katherine G. Summers, niece, and Richard E. Gillmer, nephew. The Ohio real estate is part of the trust property.

The will provides further in pertinent part:

"TENTH: I direct that all estate, inheritance, transfer, legacy, succession and other death taxes, State and Federal, which may be assessed or imposed upon or with respect to any property passing under this will, or with respect to any other property, rights or interests included in my gross estate for the purposes of any such tax, shall be paid, as an expense of administration, entirely from and out of the assets available for and which constitute my residuary estate, disposed of by the Ninth Clause of this will, and I direct that no part of any such taxes shall be apportioned or pro-rated.

"* * *

"TWELFTH: I hereby give and grant to my Executors and Trustees hereinafter named and to his and its successor or successors in either such office, the following powers and authority, all of which, unless otherwise specified below, may be exercised by my Executors and by my Trustees in either or both such fiduciary capacities at any time and from time to time as [***3] such Executors and such Trustees may in his and its absolute discretion deem advisable: --

"(1) They may sell, at public or private sale, for cash or upon credit, with or without security, upon such terms as they consider advisable, or may lease, mortgage or otherwise dispose of, any properties, real or personal, other than property specifically devised or bequeathed by the foregoing provisions of this will, of which I may die seized or possessed, or in which my estate may from time to time be invested or reinvested, and may make, execute and deliver all conveyances, leases, mortgages and other instruments necessary or appropriate in exercising such powers, and they may extend or renew any loans made by me or other evidences of indebtedness held by me, coming into their possession.

"(2) I direct that my Executors shall sell as promptly as is feasible after my death, in such manner as they deem most practical and advantageous, my residence property at Lakewood and all the furniture and furnishings therein, and the articles and items of my jewelry, my automobiles and other personal property and effects, not disposed of by the foregoing provisions of this will, and [***4] also all other real property owned by me. But I authorize my Executors or my Trustees, hereinafter named, in their discretion, to retain my property in the Town of North Harmony known as 'Pine Top', including the cabin and furnishings therein, and the fifty acres of land on which such cabin is located, and the adjacent land approximately 500 feet in width next northerly of such fifty acres, for a period of three years after my death, as a portion of the residuary trusts hereinbefore created, or either of such trusts, or otherwise, for the use of my aforesaid niece, nephew and grandnephew, if that is requested in writing by them, or one of them, and I authorize my Executors or Trustees, while holding such property, to pay the taxes thereon and the essential costs of maintaining the cabin in good repair, and I further authorize them to sell such property, at its inventory value, during such period, to my aforesaid niece and grandnephew or to my aforesaid nephew, if either should desire to take the title.

"I realize that it may be difficult for my Executors to dispose of my Lakewood residence and garden properties and nearby Village lots owned by me promptly, at a fair price, and I [***5] hereby expressly authorize my Executors and Trustees to pay taxes upon such properties and to make such other expenditures, from the principal of my estate, as they deem necessary or advisable for the protection and proper care and maintenance of such properties pending the sale thereof, including the employment of such caretakers, gardeners and household help as are needed for those purposes, and I authorize them, in determining the price at which my residence shall be sold, to give consideration to the unusual character of and limited market demand for such residence property.

"* * *

"(6) The Trustees of the trusts created by the Ninth Clause of this will may, in their discretion, accept and retain in such trusts any stocks, bonds, securities, evidence of indebtedness or other property held by me at the time of my death, or sell or otherwise dispose of any part of such assets, or any other property which may at any time be held in the trusts, at such times and in such manner as they deem advisable. They may invest and from time to time re-invest the funds and assets of the trust estates in such stocks, bonds or other securities or property as may seem, in their judgment [***6] and discretion, to be advisable, without regard to and unrestricted by any statutory provisions or limitations, now or hereafter adopted, relating to the investment of trust funds, and I impose no requirements upon my trustees as to diversification of investments." (Emphasis supplied.)

In determining the Ohio tax on the successions of decedent's niece and nephew to the Ohio realty, the Probate Court allowed proportional exemption to the niece and nephew, but allowed no deductions for debts, taxes, including federal estate taxes, or expenses of administration against the appraised value of the Ohio realty on the ground that decedent's personalty outside Ohio was more than ample to pay all debts, taxes and expenses, amounting to approximately $ 475,000. The Court of Appeals affirmed the overruling of the exceptions filed by the ancillary administrator to the determination of the Ohio succession tax. This court allowed a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant ancillary administrator challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio), which overruled the administrator's exceptions to the probate court's judgment in favor of appellee state tax commissioner in the determination of the Ohio tax on the successions of the decedent's niece and nephew to Ohio realty.


OVERVIEW: The decedent had real property in Ohio. By her will, she directed that the residue of her estate be turned over to a trustee for the benefit of her niece and nephew and that state and federal death taxes were to be paid from the estate assets. The probate court allowed the niece and nephew no deductions for debts, taxes, including federal estate taxes, or expenses of administration against the value of the Ohio realty. The appellate court affirmed the overruling of the administrator's exceptions. On appeal, the administrator claimed that, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5731.10, a portion of the debts, including the federal estate tax and costs of administration, should have been deducted from the realty's value. The court disagreed and affirmed. No statute required apportionment of debts or federal estate tax. The court rejected the administrator's claim that because the will required the executor to sell the realty and pay debts, including death taxes, under the doctrine of equitable conversion, the realty was to be treated as personalty. The will did not clearly direct the executor to dispose of the realty, and failure to sell it did not interfere with estate settlement.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's affirmance of the probate court's overruling of the administrator's exceptions.

 

161 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Wacksman v. Harrell


No. 37603


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 338; 189 N.E.2d 146; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 742; 22 Ohio Op. 2d 389



March 20, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

One Wacksman, individually and as president of the Cincinnati Pawnbrokers Association, brought action for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County against Harrell, City Manager of the City of Cincinnati, and Schrotel, chief of police of that city, challenging the legality of their new rules (1) that require Cincinnati pawnbrokers to deliver articles pawned with them and claimed to have been stolen or taken illegally to the Cincinnati police department for placement and sequestration in the police property room, and (2) that, upon the hearing of the criminal case against the alleged thief of such property in the Police Court, the judge presiding at such trial shall determine the ownership of the alleged stolen or illegally taken property and deliver the same to that person whom the judge finds to be the true and lawful owner thereof, providing such property may be lawfully possessed and owned.

Both plaintiff and defendants moved in writing for summary judgments in their favor upon the pleadings. The trial court found that plaintiff's motion was not well taken and overruled the [***2] same, and it found further that defendants' motion was well taken, sustained the same and rendered judgment for the defendants.

The Court of Appeals, on an appeal on questions of law, affirmed the judgment below, and the cause is presently in this court for determination on an appeal as of right and upon allowance of the motion to require the Court of Appeals to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant pawnbroker, individually and as president of the pawnbrokers association, sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed the summary judgment for appellees, city manager and police chief, in an action challenging the legality of new city rules relating to pawnbrokers.


OVERVIEW: The pawnbroker, individually and as president of the pawnbrokers association, filed an action for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against the city manager and the chief of police. He challenged the legality of new city rules requiring pawnbrokers to turnover alleged stolen goods and have the right to possession of the goods determined by the criminal court. All of the parties filed motions for summary judgment. The trial court granted defendants' motion for summary judgment. The court of appeals affirmed the judgment. The pawnbroker appealed. The court reversed the judgment and entered a final judgment for the pawnbroker because the city rules denied a pawnbroker's rights in property without due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the summary judgment and entered a final judgment for the pawnbroker.

 

162 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Certified Credit Corp. v. Bowers


No. 37500


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 239; 188 N.E.2d 594; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 710; 22 Ohio Op. 2d 282



March 6, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Certified Credit Corporation, appellant here, was incorporated in 1951 in Ohio for the purpose of engaging in the small-loan and consumer financing business. In 1955, appellant decided to enter the life insurance and real estate investment business. As of December 31, 1958, appellant had $ 1,663,760.97 invested in ten out-of-state subsidiaries; as of December 31, 1959, after acquisition of substantial assets located in Mississippi and Texas by merger with two non-Ohio corporations, it had $ 4,334,907.42 invested in 18 out-of-state subsidiaries; and as of December 31, 1960, having also entered the motel business, it had $ 7,986,019.35 invested in 24 out-of-state subsidiaries. The record does not disclose the precise value of the various kinds of property held and business engaged in by appellant or the amounts of each allocable to Ohio.

On its dealer-in-intangibles tax return for 1959 and previous years, appellant arrived at the percentage of its capital employed in Ohio by determining the relationship between receipts from its small-loan and consumer finance business within Ohio and its total gross receipts from such business and expressing [***2] the relationship as a percentage. In preparing its 1960 and 1961 dealer-in-intangibles tax returns, appellant arrived at a percentage of capital employed in Ohio by determining the ratio between capital assets located in Ohio and its total capital assets and expressing the result as a percentage. Appellant's 1959 return reported the proportion of capital employed in Ohio as 94.3 per cent of the total, whereas appellant's 1960 and 1961 returns reported the proportion of capital employed in Ohio as 36.29 per cent and 45.94 per cent, respectively. The 1960 and 1961 returns also reported that receipts from appellant's Ohio small-loan and consumer finance business constituted 95.4 per cent and 98.45 per cent, respectively, of its total small-loan and consumer finance receipts in each year.

The Tax Commissioner issued an increased assessment certificate against appellant for the year 1960, reflecting a total net worth of $ 5,508,661.49, with 95.41 per cent thereof being attributable to appellant's shares of stock allocable to and taxable in Ohio. For the year 1961, he issued an increased assessment certificate reflecting a total net worth of $ 5,760,671.75, with 98.45 per cent thereof [***3] being attributable to appellant's shares of stock allocable to and taxable in Ohio. The appellant appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals, which affirmed the Tax Commissioner's assessments.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant small loan business challenged a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed appellee Ohio Tax Commissioner's increased assessments for two years based on the percentage of net worth being attributable to the business's shares of stock allocable to and taxable in Ohio.


OVERVIEW: The business, an Ohio corporation, also had properties in other states. As of December 31, 1959, it had $ 4,334,907.42 invested in 18 out-of-state subsidiaries; and as of December 31, 1960, it had $ 7,986,019.35 invested in 24 out-of-state subsidiaries. In preparing its 1960 and 1961 dealer-in-intangibles tax returns, the business changed its method of determining the percentage of capital employed in Ohio to finding the ratio between capital assets in Ohio and its total capital assets. Its 1959 return reported the proportion of capital employed in Ohio as 94.3 percent, whereas its 1960 and 1961 returns reported the proportion of capital employed in Ohio as 36.29 percent and 45.94 percent. The Commissioner issued an increased assessment for 1960 and 1961 based on 95.41 and 98.45 percent of net worth being attributable to the business's shares of stock allocable to and taxable in Ohio. The tax appeals board affirmed. On appeal, the court affirmed, finding that for the intangibles dealer, the method of ascertaining the fair value of capital was set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5725.13, .14., .15, and that the tax did not violate due process or directly burden interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the tax appeals board's affirmance of the Commissioner's increased dealer-in-intangibles tax assessment.

 

163 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Akron Trading Co. v. Bowers


No. 37567


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 245; 188 N.E.2d 583; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 712; 22 Ohio Op. 2d 285



March 6, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On December 31, 1957, the appellant here, an Ohio corporation, was engaged principally in the business of financing refrigeration equipment manufactured by Uniflow Manufacturing Company of Erie, Pennsylvania. The financing was predominately of sales of such refrigeration equipment to tavern owners by franchised dealers of Uniflow. This type of financing accounted for approximately 75 per cent of appellant's business. The remaining 25 per cent of its business consisted of financing the inventories of such refrigeration equipment for the same franchised Uniflow dealers.

The eight franchised Uniflow dealers were located in Columbus, Ohio; Chicago, Illinois; St. Louis, Missouri; Harrisburg, Pennsylvania; Indianapolis, Indiana; and Covington, Kentucky.

Appellant was a party to an agreement with each of the Uniflow franchised dealers, which in pertinent part provided:

(1) The dealer would submit to appellant for acceptance at Akron, Ohio, all conditional sales contracts, leases and notes, representing the balance due upon sales and leases made in the state of the dealer's domicile and covering Uniflow products, together with a current credit [***2] report on each purchaser or lessee of such equipment who would be designated as buyer upon "said paper which is being submitted to Akron for discount". The dealer also would submit to appellant its regular quarterly profit and loss statement and its balance sheet.

(2) Appellant would make "floor-plan finanacing" loans upon refrigeration equipment up to specified amounts ($ 5,000 to $ 10,000 approximately). The equipment so floor planned was to be listed in a chattel mortgage to appellant from the dealer. Upon receipt in Akron of the mortgage and note appellant would make the loan.

(3) The dealer agreed to collect payments on account from purchasers of Uniflow equipment and to deposit same to the appellant's account. Should the dealer find it necessary to repossess the equipment, it was to notify appellant of the fact and at that time pay off the balance remaining due upon the account or contract.

The refrigeration equipment was shipped direct to the dealer. All invoices for equipment financed under the "floorplan financing" were paid in Akron. Appellant maintained no sales force to sell equipment nor did it ever receive any of the refrigeration equipment. Although the evidence [***3] is not clear whether the dealer contracts were entered into at Akron or in the various cities where the dealers were located, the commercial paper involved was discounted at Akron. All commercial paper discounted was with recourse to the franchised dealer.

In its dealer-in-intangibles return for 1958, appellant listed the book value of its total shares or invested capital at $ 270,236.64 but allocated only 6.8 per cent of this amount, or $ 18,376.09, for taxation by Ohio. The Tax Commissioner, upon audit of the return, determined that all of appellant's capital, or $ 270,236.64, was taxable by Ohio because "all of applicant's [appellant's] business originated and took place at its main and only office located in Akron, Ohio."

The appellant appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals, which found that the proof as to the business dealings that appellant carried on with the out-of-state franchised dealers at out-of-state locations and the relationship between the appellant and such dealers was no proof that appellant maintained "separate business offices" at the business locations of the out-of-state dealers, and therefore affirmed the Tax Commissioner's assessment.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed [***4] .


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a judgment from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which ruled in favor of appellee state tax commissioner, who determined that all of the taxpayer's capital was taxable by the state because all of its business originated and took place at its main and only office located in the state. The Board held that the taxpayer's dealings with out-of-state franchises was not the maintenance of "separate business offices."


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was in the business of financing refrigeration equipment manufactured by an out-of-state company. The financing was predominately of sales of the equipment by franchised dealers. This type of financing accounted for approximately 75 percent of the taxpayer's business and the remaining 25 percent consisted of financing the inventories of such equipment for the same franchised dealers. The court held that the taxpayer did not establish separate business offices by discounting commercial paper or by the sales and purchases of refrigeration equipment by the franchised dealers. The court noted that the taxpayer's business was the making of loans, which was done in the state, and the fact that such loans were secured by property located in a foreign state did not constitute the employment of capital in the foreign state. The court held that although some basis other than the maintenance of separate business offices might have been used for determining whether the capital of a dealer in intangibles is employed in this state, the standard had a fair and substantial relation to the object of the legislation and treated all persons similarly situated alike.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision in favor of the commissioner.

 

164 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Toledo v. Crews


No. 37546


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 253; 188 N.E.2d 592; 1963 Ohio LEXIS 715; 22 Ohio Op. 2d 290



March 6, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

This action was instituted by the filing in the Toledo Municipal Court of an affidavit charging defendant with driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Defendant demurred to the affidavit on the ground that the ordinance, pursuant to which he was charged, is unconstitutional because it conflicts with a state statute. The Municipal Court by its judgment sustained the demurrer and discharged defendant.

The city endeavored to appeal to the Court of Appeals from that judgment. The Court of Appeals by its judgment held that no such appeal was authorized but found that its judgment is in conflict with the judgment pronounced upon the same question by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County in State v. Dean (1958), 107 Ohio App., 219, 158 N. E. (2d), 217, and, pursuant to Section 6 of Article IV of the Constitution, certified the record to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On certification, plaintiff City of Toledo sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which held that no appeal was authorized from the municipal court's judgment sustaining defendant's demurrer to an affidavit charging him with driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor.


OVERVIEW: The City filed an affidavit-charging defendant with driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Defendant demurred to the affidavit on the ground that the ordinance, pursuant to which he was charged, was unconstitutional. The municipal court sustained the demurrer and discharged defendant. On appeal by the State, the intermediate appellate court held that no such appeal was authorized but found that its judgment was in conflict with the judgment pronounced upon the same question in a different case. On certification, the State alleged that it had a right to appeal from an adverse judgment. The court affirmed trial court's judgment. The court held that there was no right of appeal in a criminal case involving a charge of violation of a municipal ordinance except from a judgment of conviction. Thus, the State had no right to appeal from the municipal court's judgment sustaining defendant's demurrer to the affidavit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed trial court's judgment sustaining defendant's demurrer to the affidavit charging him with driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor.

 

165 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Maloney v. Maxwell


No. 37537


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 84; 186 N.E.2d 728; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 514; 21 Ohio Op. 2d 341



December 12, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

This is an action in habeas corpus originating in this court. The Grand Jury of Allen County returned an indictment charging petitioner, Rolland Maloney, with a violation of Section 2961.12, Revised Code, the Habitual Criminal Act. Petitioner was arraigned on June 22, 1960. He was advised of his right to counsel, and, being without funds, counsel was appointed for him. Later on the same day, he was again arraigned and for a plea stood mute, and the court entered a plea of not guilty. He was granted a bill of particulars and in July 1960 was tried to a jury, found guilty and sentenced to life imprisonment.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought a writ of habeas corpus after he was convicted and sentenced under the Ohio Habitual Criminal Act, Ohio Rev. Code § 2961.12. He claimed that the Act was unconstitutional and resulted in double jeopardy.


OVERVIEW: The inmate claimed that § 2961.12 was impermissibly retroactive and that it denied him the equal protection of the laws. The court found no merit in the arguments, and it denied the request for habeas relief. There was no violation of equal protection by virtue of the fact that many persons who were subject to the Habitual Criminal Act were not prosecuted thereunder. Nor was § 2961.12 unconstitutional on the basis that it was indefinite and failed to state the crime completely. It cross-referenced crimes enumerated in Ohio Rev. Code § 2961.11. There was no double jeopardy with respect to a burglary offense as a result of the fact that two habitual criminal indictments had been returned against the inmate. Prior to trial, the first indictment at the request of the prosecutor was nol-prossed, and subsequently a new indictment was returned. The inmate showed no lack of jurisdiction in the trial court, nor any deprivation of his constitutional rights. The court held that an attack on the validity of a sentence under the Act was required to be made by appeal of the original action and that review could not be had by habeas corpus.


OUTCOME: The court denied a writ of habeas corpus and remanded the inmate to custody.

 

166 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Karrick v. Board of Education


No. 37358


Supreme Court of Ohio


174 Ohio St. 73; 186 N.E.2d 855; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 698; 21 Ohio Op. 2d 334



December 12, 1962, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing allowed, January 30, 1963. Judgment reversed, 174 Ohio St., 467.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hancock County.

This is an appeal as of right, a constitutional question being involved, from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hancock County affirming a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas of such county. Plaintiffs, appellees herein, Mary E.
