Karrick and other nonteaching employees of the Board of Education of Findlay School District, hereinafter called the board, brought a declaratory judgment action to determine their status as employees of the board and of the school district.

The defendant Findlay Civil Service Commission, appellant herein and hereinafter called the commission, is one of two defendants, the other defendant being the board. The members of the original commission were appointed soon after the adoption in 1912 of Section 10 of Article XV of the Constitution of Ohio, hereinafter called the civil service amendment. The commission was created by Section 486-19, General Code ( Section 143.30, Revised Code), and in 1914 adopted rules and regulations which were amended in 1948 and on February 2, 1960.

The civil service act creating the commission,  [***2] in addition to giving it jurisdiction over city employees, also gave it jurisdiction over the employees of the board except those engaged in teaching, library work, research and administrative duties.

From the time of the creation of the commission until early in 1942, it conducted civil service examinations for an undisclosed number of employees of the board. The facts are not in dispute, and it was stipulated that in the 18- or 19-year period from 1942 to April 20, 1960, the commission held no examinations whatever with respect to any employees of the board.

The board, however, continued to employ persons subject to civil service. The janitors' payroll of Findlay city schools for September 1947 (exhibit A) contained the names of 15 persons with compensation for that month totalling $ 2,435.52. The nonteaching employees' payroll of the Findlay city schools for September 1960 (exhibit B) contained the names of 93 persons with compensation for that month totalling $ 25,004.19. Both exhibits have this endorsement at the bottom: "Approved by the civil service commission as to those on civil service, Municipal Civil Service Comm., Findlay, Ohio, Edythe W. Morgan." It was stipulated [***3] that there were similar payrolls for each month of each school year between 1947 and 1960, and that each such payroll contained a similar endorsement by the commission. The name of each of the plaintiffs appears on exhibit B.

The commission's rules, as amended in 1948, required applicants for positions in the classified service to have been legal residents of Findlay for one year prior to filing their applications. The rules established age limits of not less than 21 years and not more than 60 years, except that for school janitors the age limits were 22 and 60 years and for truant officers, 25 and 50 years.

On February 2, 1960, without advance notice, publication or the holding of a public hearing, the commission met and amended its rules as to nonteaching employees of the board to require that they be residents of the Findlay School District; that the maximum age for bus drivers and maintenance men be 60 years; and that the age limits for secretaries, clerk-typists and bookkeepers be 21 and 50 years.

The commission, after 18 years of inactivity so far as nonteaching school employees of the board were concerned, determined to hold competitive examinations on April 20, 1960, for [***4] the positions of secretary, clerk and bookkeeper, causing legal notice thereof to be published in Findlay.

Of the eight plaintiffs in this case, four resided outside the limits of the Findlay School District. One is one year under the minimum age, two exceed the 50-year age limit and two others exceed the 60-year age limit. On the day of the examinations, two of the plaintiffs, one who did not meet the residence requirement and one who did not meet the age requirement, appeared to take the examination but were not allowed by the commission to participate.

In the amended petition, it is claimed that Sections 143.01 and 143.08, Revised Code, are unconstitutional and in conflict with the civil service amendment; that the age and residence requirements are unreasonable, discriminatory and an abuse of discretion by the commission; that the board may employ nonteaching employees without certification by the commission; that the rules of the commission are void because they were not adopted in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act (Chapter 119, Revised Code); and that plaintiffs, some of whom have been employed by the board as long as 18 years, have thereby acquired civil service [***5] status. The answer filed by the commission contains a general denial, and the answer filed by the board neither admits nor denies the allegations of the petition.

In both the Common Pleas Court and the Court of Appeals, the judgments are that the rules of the commission had no effect on the status of the plaintiffs, but for different reasons.

The Common Pleas Court held that the commission's regulations adopted on February 2, 1960, are unreasonable and constitute an abuse of discretion; that the commission, although required to comply with the Administrative Procedure Act, failed to do so; and that its regulations are, therefore, void.

The Court of Appeals, in affirming the judgment of the Common Pleas Court, disagreed with the two reasons above set forth and held that the commission's regulations need not be adopted in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Procedure Act, and that, if the commission had the power to act, it did so in a reasonable and lawful manner, but that the case could not be decided without passing upon the constitutional question. It then decided that the civil service amendment authorized the General Assembly to pass laws establishing civil [***6] service regulations for employees in the service of the state, the several counties and the cities, and that there was no authority to extend civil service jurisdiction to other political subdivisions, and, hence, Section 143.30, Revised Code, so far as it applies to city school districts, is unconstitutional.

The board did not appeal from the judgment of the Common Pleas Court. The commission has appealed as of right from the judgment of the Court of Appeals and has assigned as error the judgment of such court holding Section 143.30, Revised Code, unconstitutional in its attempt to bring nonteaching school employees under the jurisdiction of the commission.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a board of education and a municipal civil service commission, appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hancock County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment of a county court of common pleas, on constitutional grounds, that the commission's amended regulations had no effect on plaintiff non-teaching school employees' status.


OVERVIEW: Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10, the civil service amendment, was enacted in 1912. The commission was created by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 143.30, which gave it jurisdiction over employees of the board except those engaged in teaching, library work, research, and administration. On February 2, 1960, without notice or hearing, the commission amended its rules to require non-teaching employees to be residents of the school district, and imposed age limits and civil service testing for certain positions. The non-teaching employees brought a declaratory judgment action to determine their employee status. The trial court found that the regulations did not effect the employees, were an abuse of discretion, and void. The appellate court affirmed because the legislature was authorized to pass laws establishing civil service regulations of the state, counties, and cities, but not to other political subdivisions, so § 143.30, so far as it applied to city school districts, violated Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10. The court affirmed, concluding that unless a different intention was apparent, the enumeration of specified matters in the constitution was to be construed to exclude all things not enumerated.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's affirmance of the trial court's judgment that the commission's regulation had no effect on the non-teaching employees' status.

 

167 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Hayes v. Jennings


No. 37341


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 370; 182 N.E.2d 546; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 638; 19 Ohio Op. 2d 314



May 9, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN QUO WARRANTO.

This is an action in quo warranto originating in this court.

The relator's petition alleges that on November 5, 1961, Elmer F. Hunsicker, clerk of courts of Hamilton County, Ohio, died. On November 6, 1961, a joint session of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County entered an order appointing William Luke Leonard clerk of courts of Hamilton County, pro tempore, "for a period not to exceed 30 days from date hereof, or until the appointment of a statutory successor * * * whichever is earlier in point of time." Pursuant to this order, Leonard assumed the office of clerk of courts of Hamilton County and took custody of the books, papers, records and funds belonging thereto.

On November 13, 1961, the Board of County Commissioners of Hamilton County, pursuant to the provisions of Section 2303.04, Revised Code (this section was repealed and was reenacted as Section 305.02, Revised Code, on October 12, 1961), adopted a resolution appointing the relator, Ben Hayes, clerk of courts of Hamilton County, pro tempore, to serve for the term ending January 1, 1963. The relator took the oath of office and executed a bond properly signed by an insurance company authorized [***2] to do business in Ohio. Relator tendered his oath of office and bond with the approval of the county commissioners endorsed thereon to the Treasurer of Hamilton County.

On November 16, 1961, relator demanded of William Luke Leonard that he surrender to relator the office of clerk of courts, which Leonard refused to do.

On November 30, 1961, the central committee of the Republican Party of Hamilton County, pursuant to the provisions of Section 305.02, Revised Code, effective October 12, 1961, passed a resolution which declared that the respondent, Robert D. Jennings, was appointed clerk of courts of Hamilton County. Leonard voluntarily relinquished the office to the respondent, who is now serving as clerk of courts.

On December 5, 1961, the relator demanded that the respondent surrender the office to him and respondent refused.

Relator avers that Section 305.02, Revised Code, is unreasonable, unconstitutional and void, and that the portion of the section which repealed Section 2303.04 is void, and that, therefore, Section 2303.04 is in full force and effect.

Relator prays that the respondent be ousted from office, and that the relator be installed as clerk of courts of Hamilton [***3] County.

The respondent filed a demurrer on two grounds, (1) the relator lacks capacity to maintain the action and (2) the petition fails to state facts constituting a cause of action.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer sustained and writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, a court clerk who was appointed by the Board of County Commissioners of Hamilton County (Ohio) pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2303.04, brought a quo warranto action against respondent, a court clerk who was appointed by the Republican Party of Hamilton County (Ohio) pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 305.02, to oust respondent from office. Respondent filed a demurrer to the action.


OVERVIEW: When the original court clerk died, a temporary clerk was appointed. The Board then adopted a resolution and appointed relator; the Party then appointed respondent. The temporary clerk voluntarily relinquished the office to respondent, and respondent refused to surrender the office to relator. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2303.04 was repealed and reenacted as Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 305.02. Relator averred that § 305.02 was unconstitutional and void such that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2303.04 was still in effect. In his demurrer, respondent contended that relator lacked the capacity to maintain his action and that the petition failed to state a cause of action. In sustaining the demurrer, the court held that pursuant to Ohio Const. art. II, § 27 and Ohio Const. art. X, § 1, the Illinois General Assembly had the power to enact Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 305.02 to authorize the Party to appoint a clerk to fill the vacancy in the elective county office of clerk. The General Assembly had not violated these provisions by exercising appointing power because the General Assembly did not appoint anyone to the Party; the Party's members were elected pursuant to statute.


OUTCOME: The court sustained respondent's demurrer and denied the writ.

 

168 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Lehman v. Di Salle


No. 37432


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 361; 182 N.E.2d 564; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 636; 19 Ohio Op. 2d 309



May 4, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This is an action in mandamus originating in this court. The relator, Harry J. Lehman, is a resident, taxpayer and elector of Cuyahoga County, which comprises the 25th senatorial district. The respondents, Michael V. DiSalle, Governor, James A. Rhodes, Auditor of State, and Ted W. Brown, Secretary of State, are the three officers designated by Section 11, Article XI of the Ohio Constitution, to make a new apportionment of the General Assembly for the decennial period beginning January 1963, in accordance with the 1960 decennial census.

This apportionment was made by Rhodes and Brown and published as provided in Section 107.09, Revised Code.

The apportionment annexes the 9th-14th senatorial district, composed of Athens, Fairfield, Hocking, Morgan, Washington and parts of Monroe and Noble Counties, to the 15th-16th senatorial district, composed of Muskingum, Perry, Delaware and Licking Counties, to form a combined senatorial district to be known as the 9th-14th-15th-16th senatorial district.

The apportionment provides that the combined senatorial district shall be entitled to elect one Senator in each session, and two additional Senators, one in the third session [***2] and one in the fourth session of the decennial period.

The apportionment provides further that the incumbent Senator, elected from the 9th-14th district for a four-year term commencing in January 1961 and expiring January 1965, shall, in accordance with the provisions of Section 1 of Article XI of the Ohio Constitution, continue as a member of the Senate during the first session of the decennial period (1963-1964).

The relator questions that portion of the apportionment which provides for a Senator to be elected from the combined senatorial district in the first session of the decennial period.

Respondent DiSalle has filed an answer agreeing with relator's position.

Respondents Rhodes and Brown have filed a general demurrer to the petition.



DISPOSITION: Demurrer sustained and writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator petitioner filed a petition for a writ of mandamus to compel respondents, the Governor, Auditor, and Secretary of State of Ohio, to make a new apportionment of the General Assembly. The Auditor and the Secretary filed a demurrer to the petition.


OVERVIEW: Respondents made an apportionment for the General Assembly pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XI, § 11. The apportionment combined senatorial districts into one district and provided for the elections of senators in the combined district for future sessions. The petitioner filed a petition for a writ of mandamus to compel respondents to make a new apportionment. The Auditor and the Secretary filed a demurrer. Upon review, the court sustained the demurrer and denied the petitioner's application for a writ of mandamus. The court ruled that the mathematical inequalities in population between the districts that formed the combined district were insignificant. The court held that the petitioner's primary objection was to the manner in which respondents provided for the elections of senators in the combined district for future sessions. The court determined that there was no clear constitutional or statutory duty to fix the apportionment in a manner different than the apportionment adopted by respondents. Therefore, the court ruled that the petitioner was not entitled to a writ of mandamus.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the demurrer of the Auditor and the Secretary. The court denied the petitioner's application for a writ of mandamus.

 

169 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Blue Ash v. Cincinnati


No. 36887


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 345; 182 N.E.2d 557; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 702; 19 Ohio Op. 2d 274



May 2, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

The village of Blue Ash, a municipal corporation in Hamilton County, Ohio, brought this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County to enjoin the city of Cincinnati, likewise a municipal corporation in Hamilton County, from appropriating for airport purposes a presently used public street located within the corporate limits of the village of Blue Ash.

Previous to this suit the city of Cincinnati became the owner of land in an unincorporated portion of Sycamore Township, commonly known as Blue Ash; legal procedures followed, directed to the establishment of a municipal airport; plans for airport construction on its Blue Ash property were approved by the Civil Aeronautics Authority and the Ohio Aviation Board; and, under such plans, the principal runway bisects the public street herein involved in the now incorporated village of Blue Ash, and it is necessary to acquire the street easement for airport runway purposes.

The city of Cincinnati, in an effort to acquire the street, instituted an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County to assess compensation for the property. The instant action for injunction [***2] followed.

The second amended answer to the amended petition in this injunction action pleads, in part:

"* * * that under the Constitution and laws of the state of Ohio it [the city of Cincinnati] has the right to appropriate for airport purposes the existing easement for street purposes over the property described in the amended petition; that the zoning ordinance of the plaintiff village of Blue Ash to the extent, if any, it purports to prohibit the construction by the defendant city of Cincinnati of an airport in the village of Blue Ash having runways in excess of 3,000 feet is invalid and unconstitutional; and that the equities in this case are all in favor of the defendant city of Cincinnati and that the petition should be dismissed."

The Court of Common Pleas, treating as a demurrer a motion to strike Cincinnati's second amended answer, sustained the demurrer, and, the city of Cincinnati electing not to plead further, judgment was rendered for the village of Blue Ash on its prayer for injunction.

The Court of Appeals of the First Appellate District, with one judge dissenting, reversed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas.

The cause is before this court on an appeal [***3] of right and upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a village bordering a large city, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for the First Appellate District (Ohio), which reversed an order of the common pleas court that granted an injunction in favor of the village, and held that the large city had a legal right to appropriate a public street in the adjacent village over its objection, for the construction of an airport.


OVERVIEW: The village sought an injunction to prevent the city from appropriating its street for purposes of building an airport runway. The common pleas court granted the injunction, and the court of appeals reversed. The court reversed the court of appeals, holding that although the city was empowered by the constitution and by statute to build and operate an airport, and to appropriate property to do so, the village had a concomitant right to keep its street, already dedicated to public use, free from appropriation by a neighbor municipal corporation, on the basis of a right under the Ohio Constitution. The court found that property already appropriated in the proper exercise of the power of eminent domain, could not be taken for another use which would wholly defeat or supersede the former use unless power to make such second appropriation was expressly granted.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and affirmed the judgment of the court of common pleas granting the injunction in favor of the village.

 

170 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


General Industries Co. v. Leach


Nos. 37233, 37315


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 227; 181 N.E.2d 39; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 603; 19 Ohio Op. 2d 46



March 21, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

Each of the two causes here involved arose in the same manner.

In each instance an employee became unemployed by reason of lack of work -- the one on September 30, 1958, and the other on March 13, 1959. Each filed with the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation his application for a determination of his benefit rights. Without protest each was allowed a basic weekly benefit of $ 33 with a total of $ 858 for the maximum of 26 weeks for the benefit year. However, one employee was allowed an additional weekly sum of $ 6 for his dependents.

Subsequently after amended Section 4141.30, Revised Code, became effective on October 16, 1959, each employee filed an application for a redetermination and recomputation of his weekly benefit amount.

The Administrator of the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation allowed each employee an additional weekly benefit of $ 9, making a total of $ 42 per week.

These additional allowances were affirmed by the Board of Review.

On appeals to the Courts of Common Pleas, the decisions of the Board of Review were affirmed.

On appeals to the Courts of [***2] Appeals by the employers the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County affirmed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, but the Court of Appeals for Lorain County reversed the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas and entered a final judgment for the appellant employer.

The two causes are in this court for a review on questions of law.



DISPOSITION: Judgment in cause No. 37233 reversed. Judgment in cause No. 37315 affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated action, plaintiffs, employees and the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation, and defendant employers sought review of judgments of the Court of Appeals for Lorain County and the Court of Appeal for Mahoning County (Ohio).


OVERVIEW: The employees became unemployed by reason of lack of work and filed claims with the Bureau for a determination of their benefit rights. Each employee was awarded a weekly benefit. However, the Bureau awarded an additional weekly amount after the unemployment statute, Ohio Rev. Code § 4141.30, was amended. The employers contended that the statute was unconstitutional. One appellate court reversed the awards in favor of the employers, but the other appellate court affirmed the awards in favor of the employees. The court determined that the Bureau's determination was final upon establishment of the benefit year. The court found that it was each weekly claim that established whether an employee was paid benefits for such week. The court also held that the legislature had the right to amend or repeal the statute at any time. The court found that the amendment was not retrospective in nature but was a prospective statute and that it applied to the employees after their applications for benefits were filed. The court reversed the appellate court judgment in favor of the employers and affirmed the judgment in favor of the employees.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate court in favor of the employers was reversed. The judgment of the appellate court in favor of the employees and the Bureau was affirmed.

 

171 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. McElroy v. Akron


No. 37159


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 189; 181 N.E.2d 26; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 594; 19 Ohio Op. 2d 3



March 14, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This is an action brought on behalf of the state of Ohio to enjoin the city of Akron from issuing and requiring separate city boat licenses for the operation of watercraft on waters owned by the city, contrary to the provision of Section 1501.23, Revised Code, prohibiting licensing by political subdivisions. That provision now appears in Section 1547.61, Revised Code, without change, and reference will hereinafter be made to the latter statute. The city admits the requirement of a separate city license and contends that the statute prohibiting separate licensing by political subdivisions is unconstitutional.

The Court of Common Pleas found Section 1547.61, Revised Code, to be unconstitutional and dismissed the petition for an injunction.

That judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals, which court also found the statute to be unconstitutional.

The cause is before this court on an appeal as a matter of right, a constitutional question being involved.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff state government sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) that affirmed a decision of the Court of Common Pleas for Summit County (Ohio) that determined that Ohio Rev. Code. Ann. § 1547.61 was unconstitutional. The challenged statute prohibited defendant political subdivision from imposing a license fee for the operation of watercraft on waters owned by the political subdivision.


OVERVIEW: The political subdivision argued that the statute was unconstitutional because it violated its rights under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 4 that pertained to land operated by public utilities. The political subdivision further argued that it had a right to impose a license tax under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, also known as the home rule amendment. Finally, the political subdivision argued that the state statute deprived it of its property without due process of law. The court rejected the political subdivision's arguments. The court found that state government's requirement of a state license was valid exercise of the state government's police power. The court also pointed out that the political subdivision's reliance on Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 4 was misplaced because the use of the land in question was clearly a non-utility use or purpose. Also, the court noted that the state government had preempted the field, thus, Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, did not provide relief. Finally, the court noted that the statute in question did not affect the title or the control over such waters and thus, the political subdivision was not deprived of its property without due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgments of the lower court and the trial court and determined that the statute was constitutional and entered final judgment in favor of the state government.

 

172 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Board of Education


No. 37248


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 130; 180 N.E.2d 576; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 581; 18 Ohio Op. 2d 391



February 21, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This action was instituted by the Board of Education of the Jefferson Local School District (which board is herein referred to as the Jefferson board and which district is herein referred to as the Jefferson district) in the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County against the Board of Education of the Columbus City School District (which board is herein referred to as the Columbus board and which district is herein referred to as the Columbus district) and against the auditor and the treasurer of Franklin County.

In its amended petition, the Jefferson board alleges that on June 3, 1957, about 480 acres in the Jefferson district was annexed to the city of Columbus; that those 480 acres comprised part but not all of the Jefferson district; that the State Board of Education has not approved transfer of any portion of those 480 acres from the Jefferson to the Columbus district; that the Franklin County auditor for the years 1958 and 1959 wrongfully and unlawfully listed those 480 acres as being located in the Columbus district, determined from resolutions adopted by the Columbus board the sums to be levied for school purposes upon [***2] those 480 acres, apportioned and certified the amounts of such sums collected as due the Columbus district and drew warrants on the county treasurer for the payment of such amounts to the Columbus district; and that, unless prevented by court order, the county auditor will pursue a like course of action for the year 1960 and subsequent years. The Jefferson district asks for an accounting, injunction and equitable relief for the purpose of recovering from the Columbus district amounts collected from 1958 and 1959 school taxes levied on those 480 acres and for the purpose of requiring the county auditor to list those 480 acres in the Jefferson district for 1960 and subsequent years.

The demurrer of the Columbus district to that amended petition was sustained and, the plaintiff having elected not to plead further, judgment was rendered for defendants.

The opinion of the Common Pleas Court discloses that that court sustained the demurrer on the ground that the cause was moot.

The Court of Appeals found that the "cause is neither moot nor res judicata as to" the Jefferson district but that "the provision of Section 3311.06, Revised Code, which reads as follows:

"'* * * provided,  [***3] that when the territory so annexed to a city or village comprises part but not all of the territory of a school district, the said territory shall become a part of the said city school district or the school district of which the village is a part only upon approval by the State Board of Education'

"is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power without guides or standards to the state board * * * and therefore void and therefore the judgment * * * should be affirmed."

The cause is now before this court on appeal from that judgment.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school district sought review a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment that found for defendant school district in plaintiff's action to recover school taxes levied on property annexed without approval from plaintiff to defendant. The appeals court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06, which required the State Board of Education to approve the transfer, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff's property was annexed to defendant without obtaining the Board's approval as required by § 3311.06. Thereafter, plaintiff filed an action to recover school taxes levied on the annexed property. Following a judgment for defendant, the appeals court affirmed, holding that § 3311.06 was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power without guides or standards to the Board. Thereafter, plaintiff sought review. In reversing, the court cited Ohio Const. art. II, § 26, which stated that "All laws, of a general nature, shall have a uniform operation throughout the state; nor, shall any act, except such as relates to public schools, be passed, to take effect upon the approval of any other authority than the General Assembly." The court held that § 26 expressly sanctioned statutes relating to public schools to take effect upon approval of authority other than the General Assembly. Consequently, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06 was valid although its provisions for the transfer of territory were not to take effect without the Board's approval and although the General Assembly gave the Board no guides or standards for such approval.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and remanded for further proceedings.

 

173 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati Air Taxi, Inc. v. Bowers


Nos. 37103, 37121


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 99; 180 N.E.2d 17; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 570; 18 Ohio Op. 2d 330



February 7, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of order of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed an order of cross-appellant tax commission refusing to cancel a property tax for two years. The tax commissioner challenged a decision reversing his order refusing to cancel a tax for one year.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the same situation prevailed in all three years. On the day for listing property owned in 1958, the corporation held personal property, in the form of the aircraft, not licensed under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4561.18 and the court held that the tax commissioner was correct in his contention that it was taxable as personal property for that year, the same as for two other years. The corporation's claim of an unconstitutional interpretation and application of the statutes was not well founded. It should have complied with the law relating to the licensing of aircraft to escape the general personal property tax. The failure to do so made the aircraft amenable to taxation the same as other personal property. By its own inaction, it placed itself under the law relating to taxation of personal property generally. In the absence of the aircraft licensing law, aircraft was taxed as ordinary personal property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part regarding a refusal to cancel property tax and reversed in part regarding the cancellation of the tax.

 

174 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wetzel


No. 36945


Supreme Court of Ohio


173 Ohio St. 16; 179 N.E.2d 773; 1962 Ohio LEXIS 555; 18 Ohio Op. 2d 203



January 17, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Wyandot County.

Edward J. Wetzel, the appellee herein, was indicted by the Grand Jury of Wyandot County in the following language:

"The jurors of the Grand Jury * * * do find and present that Edward J. Wetzel * * * on the 8th day of February * * * 1960, at the county of Wyandot aforesaid, did unlawfully and knowingly have in his possession and under his control, obscene, lewd and lascivious picture photographs, pamphlets and other articles all of an indecent and immoral nature and all of which are too obscene for further description within the limits of decency and contrary to Section 2905.34 of the Revised Code of Ohio, and against the peace and dignity of the state of Ohio."

He pleaded not guilty and was tried before the Court of Common Pleas. A verdict of guilty was returned by the jury, and the defendant was sentenced to imprisonment in the Ohio Penitentiary.

An appeal on questions of law to the Court of Appeals reresulted in a reversal of the judgment below and an order directing the discharge of the defendant. Such reversal was based on the determination that the part of Section 2905.34, Revised Code, under which the defendant was [***2] indicted and tried, is unconstitutional and void, being in violation of "Article I, Section 11 of the Constitution of Ohio and the provisions of the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States."

The judges of the Court of Appeals, finding the judgment rendered to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in the case of State v. Mapp (March 31, 1959), certified the record to this court for review and determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Wyandot County (Ohio), which reversed a judgment convicting defendant of possessing obscene, lewd, and lascivious material in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.34. In reversing, the appeals court held that § 2905.34 was unconstitutional because it violated Ohio Const. art. I, § 11 and U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: After obscene, lewd, and lascivious material was discovered in defendant's possession, defendant was convicted of violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.34, which stated that "no person shall knowingly have in his possession or under his control an obscene, lewd, or lascivious book." Thereafter, the appeals court reversed, holding that § 2905.34 violated Ohio Const. art. I, § 11 and U.S. Const. amend. I because it applied to any person. Following the reversal, the State sought review. Upon review, the court held that if the operation of a statute was constitutional under one state of facts, the statute could not be declared invalid because its operation was unconstitutional under another state of facts not involved. In reversing, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2905.34 was constitutional and valid as applied to defendant because the evidence demonstrated that defendant possessed the pornographic material with knowledge of its nature and that the material was held for sale and distribution. In so holding, the court distinguished the situation from one where an individual merely possessed pornographic material for his own private purposes.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

175 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Board of Education v. Board of Education


No. 36534


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 533; 179 N.E.2d 347; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 627; 18 Ohio Op. 2d 81



December 27, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The relator, the Board of Education of the Whitehall City School District, has invoked the original jurisdiction of this court for the purpose of obtaining a writ of mandamus to require the respondent, the Board of Education of the Columbus City School District, to assume $ 450,103.71 of the relator's bonded indebtedness and also to pay the relator the sum of $ 49,103.21, less a credit of $ 3,215.21, by reason of municipal annexation proceedings whereby the respondent acquired certain land, buildings and appurtenances from the relator.

The matter is presented to the court on the pleadings, a stipulation of facts, evidence and briefs.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator Board of Education of the Whitehall City School District petitioned for a writ of mandamus to compel respondent Board of Education of the Columbus City School District to assume $ 450,100 of the relator's bonded indebtedness and to pay the relator $ 49,100 less a credit by reason of municipal annexation proceedings in which respondent acquired land and buildings from relator.


OVERVIEW: After municipal annexation proceedings took place, the affected cities transferred certain territory from relator to respondent. The transfer was submitted to the State Superintendent of Public Instruction and the State Board of Education. The Board, acting pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06, determined that an equitable division of the funds and indebtedness between the districts would require respondent to assume certain obligations of relator. Respondent refused to pay and relator filed an action for mandamus to compel respondent to meet its obligations. The court granted the writ. Respondent argued that the Board was without authority to make a complete determination of the matter because § 3311.06 provided that the division of funds and debts was to be made under the "supervision" of the Board. The court rejected that argument, noting that the word "supervise" was synonymous with superintend, which meant to oversee with power of direction. The court noted further that § 3311.06 stated that the Board's decision was to be final, thereby indicating that the board had authority to make a complete determination.


OUTCOME: The court granted the writ of mandamus sought by relator to compel respondent to assume certain financial obligations determined by the State Board of Education.

 

176 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Geo. Byers Sons, Inc. v. Metzger


Nos. 36873, 36874


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 354; 176 N.E.2d 417; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 563; 16 Ohio Op. 2d 211



July 5, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

In case No. 36873, it is alleged in the petition filed in the Common Pleas Court by plaintiff, an automobile dealer, that the dealer sold an automobile to a certain buyer on July 17, 1959, and attached to the application for a certificate of title for that buyer prepaid sales tax stamps in the proper amount of the tax imposed with respect to that sale but that defendant clerk of courts refused to issue a certificate of title because the tax was not paid to defendant by cash, certified check, draft or money order in accordance with the requirements of Section 4505.06, Revised Code, as amended effective July 1, 1959.

In case No. 36874, similar allegations are made in the petition filed in the Common Pleas Court by the buyer of that automobile.

Plaintiff in each case contends that certain amendments to Sections 5739.03 and 4505.06, Revised Code, which became effective July 1, 1959, are unconstitutional.

By Section 5739.02, Revised Code, "an excise tax is * * * levied on each retail sale made in" Ohio with certain specified exceptions. The amount of the tax is dependent upon the price; and, generally speaking, it amounts to three [***2] per cent of the price involved in a taxable sale.

Section 5739.03, Revised Code, reads in part:

"* * * the tax imposed by Section 5739.02 * * * shall be paid by the consumer to the vendor, and each vendor shall collect from the consumer the full and exact amount of the tax payable on each taxable sale, and, unless a receipt therefor is required to be issued by a Clerk of a Court of Common Pleas under the provisions of Section 4505.06 * * * shall evidence the payment of the tax by cancelling prepaid tax receipts, equal in face value to the amount of the tax * * *." (Emphasis added to indicate portion added by amendment effective July 1, 1959.)

Subsequent provisions of that section provide for delivery of "one part of each such cancelled prepaid tax receipt to the consumer." These prepaid tax receipts are commonly referred to as sales tax stamps and are frequently saved for charitable and other organizations for redemption by them at two per cent of their face value pursuant to the provisions of Sections 5741.08 and 5741.09, Revised Code.

Prior to July 1, 1959, Section 4505.06, Revised Code, provided in part:

"In the case of the sale of a motor vehicle by a dealer to a general [***3] purchaser or user, the certificate of title shall be obtained in the name of the purchaser by the dealer upon application signed by the purchaser. In all other cases such certificate shall be obtained by the purchaser. * * *

"The clerk, except as * * * [to nontaxable sales], shall refuse to accept for filing any application for a certificate of title and shall refuse to issue a certificate of title unless prepaid tax receipts required by Section 5739.03 * * * are presented with the application in the manner and form to be prescribed by the Tax Commissioner or unless the applicant submits with the application, payment of such tax by cash, certified check, draft, or money order payable to the clerk who shall issue a receipt in the form prescribed by the commissioner, or a receipt issued by the commissioner showing the payment of the tax. Such receipts are consumer's portions of prepaid tax receipts for the purposes of Sections 5741.08 and 5741.09 * * * and are subject to redemption in the same manner and at the same rate as the redemption of consumer's portions of prepaid tax receipts." (Emphasis added to indicate portions deleted by amendment effective July 1, 1959.)

 [***4] The Common Pleas Court sustained demurrers to each of the foregoing petitions and, the plaintiffs not desiring to plead further, rendered a judgment of dismissal in each action.

On appeals to the Court of Appeals on questions of law, those judgments were reversed.

The causes are now before this court on appeals from those judgments of reversal by the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Clerk of Courts sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed a lower court judgment dismissing the petitions of appellees, car dealer and car buyer, in appellees' action challenging the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5739.03, 4505.06. Under the cited provisions, the sales tax on a car had to be paid in cash or by check and could not be paid by prepaid tax receipts.


OVERVIEW: The legislature amended Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4505.06, 5739.03 to require car dealers and buyers, respectively, to pay the sales tax on a car by cash or check only. Appellees submitted to the Clerk an application for transfer of car title, attaching prepaid tax receipts, known as tax stamps, thereto. The Clerk refused to issue the title and appellees filed actions challenging the validity of amendments. The trial court sustained respondent's demurrer and dismissed appellees' petitions. The appellate court reversed and the Clerk appealed. Appellees' position was that the amendments were unconstitutional in that they singled out car sales as the only transaction for which the tax had to be paid by cash or check. The court stated that the legislature had the right to designate car sellers as a class to be deprived of certain opportunities if there were a substantial reason for doing so. The court noted that the tax stamps were a means of enlisting the aid of vendors in collecting the tax and stated that the aid of the car dealer was not needed because the title to the car had to be transferred by a government official who would ensure that the tax was paid. The court reversed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that dismissed appellees' petitions challenging the validity of certain tax provisions.

 

177 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Burns v. Di Salle


No. 37006


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 363; 176 N.E.2d 428; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 566; 16 Ohio Op. 2d 216



July 5, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

From the facts alleged in relator's petition and admitted in the amended answer of the respondent, Governor of Ohio, it appears that, effective November 2, 1959, the General Assembly created the State Racing Commission consisting of five members to be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate. Section 3769.02, Revised Code. Subsequent to the adjournment of the Senate at the closing of the regular session of the 103rd General Assembly and prior to the next session of the Senate which convened on November 28, 1960, the respondent appointed Harry M. Hoffheimer, of Cincinnati, to the State Racing Commission for a term beginning November 2, 1959, and ending April 1, 1963.

The respondent reported said appointment, along with several others, to the next session of the Senate on November 28, 1960. The Senate adjourned sine die on November 29, 1960, without giving its advice and consent as to the appointment of Hoffheimer and without acting in any manner, either affirmatively or negatively, on said appointment, although it affirmatively acted on several other appointments. Hoffheimer has continued to serve as a member of the State Racing Commission.

 [***2] The relator alleges in his petition that the respondent is under a clear legal duty to make a new appointment to the vacancy created by the Senate's failure to advise and consent as to Hoffheimer's appointment, that the respondent is under a clear legal duty to submit such new appointment to the Senate of the 104th General Assembly, and that Hoffheimer may not be reappointed to the same term.

The prayer of the petition is to the effect that the respondent be required to make a new appointment to the State Racing Commission for the term beginning November 2, 1959, and ending April 1, 1963, and that such appointment be of someone other than Hoffheimer.

The amended answer of the respondent raises two defenses:

The first is that, since the appointment of Hoffheimer, sent to the Senate on November 28, 1959, was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Rules but was never presented to that committee or any committee of the Senate and was never presented to the Senate for a vote of confirmation or rejection, and since the appointment was again sent to the Senate of the 104th General Assembly, which has as yet taken no action with respect to said appointment, there is no official duty [***3] enjoined upon the respondent by law remaining unfulfilled.

The second defense of the respondent is that any provision of Section 3769.02, Revised Code, which makes or purports to make such appointment contingent upon the advise and consent of the Senate, is unconstitutional and void as making the Genreal Assembly a participant in the appointing power in contravention of Section 27, Article II of the Ohio Constitution.

The issues are raised by a demurrer to the amended answer.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator brought an action in mandamus against respondent governor to compel the governor to make a new appointment to the State Racing Commission pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3769.02. The governor raised two defenses by way of answer, and the relator demurred to the answers.


OVERVIEW: The governor appointed five members to the Commission, but although the senate gave its advice and consent to the appointment of the other members, the senate adjourned without giving its advice and consent or acting in any manner on the appointment of one member. Relator claimed that the governor had a duty to make a new appointment and that the appointment had to be of a new member. The governor claimed that he had fulfilled his duty in appointing the member and referring it to the senate and that the provision of § 3769.02 that made the appointment contingent on the senate was unconstitutional. The court denied the writ and found that the provision concerning the advice and consent by the senate did provide for a participation pro tanto by the general assembly, which participation was expressly disallowed under Ohio Const. art. II, § 27. The court held that because the advice and consent of the senate was a necessary part of the appointment, as evidenced by the petition, and because the act of the senate alone could be considered an act of the general assembly, that portion of the statute was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court overruled relator's demurrer and denied the writ.

 

178 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Cincinnati v. Marshall


No. 36754


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 280; 175 N.E.2d 178; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 534; 16 Ohio Op. 2d 1



May 24, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

On December 3, 1958, in the Cincinnati Municipal Court, defendant, Joseph L. Marshall, appellant herein, was convicted for violation of Section 901-i3 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cincinnati which makes it a misdemeanor to possess or sell obscene writings or pictures.

The affidavit upon which the successful prosecution was based alleges that defendant "did unlawfully have under his control obscene, lewd and indecent publications."

Section 901-i3 provides in part as follows:

"Whoever shall print * * * sell * * * exhibit as for sale or other purpose, or have in his possession or under his control, any obscene, lewd, lascivious, indecent * * * book, pamphlet, paper, picture * * * or shall exhibit upon the public street or highway, any of the articles or papers * * * as aforesaid, within view of passersby upon said street or highway, shall be fined not more than $ 500 or imprisoned not more than six months or both * * *."

Prior to the trial, defendant filed a demurrer to the affidavit, which demurrer attacks the constitutionality of the ordinance in question on the ground that, because the ordinance fails to include [***2] scienter or knowledge as an essential element of the offense, it contravens the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. Other grounds for the unconstitutionality of the ordinance are urged.

The defendant is the president of a corporation engaged in the wholesale distribution of magazines and newspapers in the city of Cincinnati. The record herein reveals that the company distributes to retail newsstands approximately 1,000 different magazines, newspapers and books per month. The company employs approximately 70 employees and operates 17 trucks.

At the trial of this cause, defendant testified that most of his suppliers are located in the east; that his company does not select the magazines that it sells; that it has no right of selection; that magazines come in every day; that some magazines go out the same day they are received; and that others may remain in the warehouse for as long as a week.

On October 2, 1958, the police confiscated a large number of magazines from defendant's company's warehouse. These magazines, 14 of which were admitted in evidence at the trial, form the basis of the charge against the defendant. It appears that on that [***3] October date defendant was in Chicago and had been in that city for ten days preceding October 2. Upon his return to Cincinnati, defendant voluntarily appeared at police headquarters in Cincinnati and was arrested for violation of the ordinance in question.

Defendant's counsel examined defendant, as follows, concerning the 14 magazines which comprised the prosecution's exhibits:

"Q. With particular reference to these magazines here, did you or did you not see those magazines when they came in? A. No I don't see any of the magazines --

"Mr. Castle: Objection.

"A. -- that came into our place.

"* * *

"Q. Did you see those magazines when they came in? A. No."

Later, defendant testified as follows:

"Q. Let me ask you this. Would you knowingly have in your possession, or did you knowingly have in your possession or -- well, put it this way. On October 2, 1958 -- obscene or lewd magazines? * * * A. No, sir, and I never will."

In his charge to the jury, the trial judge stated, in part, as follows:

"The intent of the defendant, if you find in fact he did have the materials under his control, is of no matter in this case. Whether the defendant had a good or an evil or an unlawful [***4] intent is of no concern for you.

"The indecent publications ordinance makes the mere possession of having under his control obscene, lewd or indecent materials unlawful, and the intent with which they are possessed or held is of no consequence. The ordinance provides no exception by reason of the existence of any good, bad, indifferent or special intent in the possession of the materials."

After the conviction of defendant in the Municipal Court, appeal was taken to the Court of Common Pleas and subsequently to the Court of Appeals. In each appeal defendant renewed his attack on the ordinance as being unconstitutional. The judgment of conviction was affirmed in both the Court of Common Pleas and the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court by virtue of an appeal as of right and our allowance of defendant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment convicting defendant of possessing obscene, lewd, and indecent publications. In seeking review, defendant claimed that the criminal ordinance was unconstitutional because it did not require scienter or knowledge.


OVERVIEW: Defendant engaged in the wholesale distribution of magazines and, without his knowledge, possessed obscene material. When the obscene material was discovered, defendant was convicted of possessing obscene, lewd, and indecent publications in violation of Cincinnati, Ohio, Ordinance § 901-i3. Following the conviction's affirmance, defendant sought review, claiming that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it made criminal liability absolute on mere proof of possession without regard to scienter or knowledge. In reversing, the court ruled that because the ordinance imposed an absolute criminal liability without reference to any knowledge on the part of the accused, the ordinance was invalid and in conflict with the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution. In so ruling, the court held that scienter or knowledge was constitutionally essential in an offense which related to speech or press and that the mental element could not be eliminated from the crime of possession or dissemination of obscene matter. The court held that eliminating the mental element tended to impose a severe limitation on the public's access to constitutionally protected matter.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

179 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Board of Education v. Board of Education


No. 36488


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 237; 175 N.E.2d 91; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 520; 15 Ohio Op. 2d 403



May 10, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The relator, the Board of Education of the Worthington, Ohio, Exempted Village School District, has invoked the original jurisdiction of this court to obtain a writ of mandamus to require the respondent, the Board of Education of the Columbus, Ohio, City School District, to pay to the relator the sum of $ 271,817.26 as compensation for the loss of land, a school building and equipment transferred from the relator's district to the respondent's district as a result of annexation proceedings effective December 31, 1956.

The respondent filed an answer and a cross-petition asking that the new party respondent, the State Board of Education, be required to make or supervise the making of an equitable division of funds and indebtedness between the two districts.

The issues are joined by various answers, replies, stipulation of facts, and answers to interrogatories.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator village school board petitioned for a writ of mandamus requiring respondent city school board to pay compensation for the loss of land, a school building, and equipment transferred to the city school board as a result of annexation proceedings. The city school board filed a cross-petition asking that respondent state school board be required to make an equitable division of funds and indebtedness between the two boards.


OVERVIEW: The first, unamended form of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06 was in effect when the annexation proceedings began but, by the time the annexations became effective, an amendment had become effective with a new requirement that a transfer from the village school board to the city school board be approved by the state school board. By the date the state school board declared its "intention" to approve the transfer, a second amendment, still retaining the requirement that such a transfer be approved by the state school board, had become effective. The village school board contended that the amendments were applicable while the city school board insisted that they were not. The court adopted the reasoning of an appellate court that had considered the issue and concluded that, although it was unsure which amendment applied, the unamended statute did not control and approval of the state school board was required to complete a transfer of territory. Denying the petitions of both parties, however, the court found that the state school board's "intention" to approve the transfer was not a definitive statement of approval and that the transfer was not, therefore, completed.


OUTCOME: The requested writ of mandamus was denied, and both the village school board's petition and the city school board's cross-petition were dismissed.

 

180 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Bennett v. Diefenbach


No. 36656


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 185; 174 N.E.2d 259; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 504; 15 Ohio Op. 2d 331



April 26, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

An annexation petition was filed February 27, 1959, with the Lucas County Board of County Commissioners by one resident freeholder (the only one residing in the territory to be annexed), seeking to annex a portion of Washington Township, Lucas County, to the city of Toledo. After hearing, the petition was granted.

Within the 60-day statutory time limit after the certification of the transcript, maps and petition to the council of the city of Toledo, the plaintiffs, appellants herein, brought an action to enjoin the defendants, the clerk of the city of Toledo and the auditor of the city of Toledo, appellees herein, from taking any further action upon the certified transcript, petition, map or plat of the territory sought to be annexed.

The Common Pleas Court of Lucas County granted the injunction prayed for.

Upon appeal on questions of law and fact, the Court of Appeals rendered judgment for the defendants, denying the injunction and remanding the cause.

This cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants challenged a judgment by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio) in favor of appellees, a city clerk and auditor, and denied appellants' action for an injunction preventing the annexation of certain territory.


OVERVIEW: The county granted one resident freeholder's petition for annexation. Shortly after, appellants filed an action to enjoin the annexation. Appellants argued that the annexation was unconstitutional because school districts would overlap, and unvoted tax levies would be imposed. The trial court granted an injunction, but the court of appeals denied the injunction. The court affirmed on appeal. The court held that constitutional questions were not before it. Rather, the issue was whether the petition by the resident freeholder for the annexation of territory, which contained the language, "for municipal purposes, according to the statutes of Ohio," was valid under the provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 709.02 and 3311.06. The court held that the words accurately described the purpose of the annexation under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.02 and did not conflict with the procedure established in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.06 for the transfer of territory from one school district to another after the territory had been annexed by a municipality.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment.

 

181 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Lindsay v. Cincinnati


No. 36683


Supreme Court of Ohio


172 Ohio St. 137; 174 N.E.2d 96; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 492; 15 Ohio Op. 2d 278



April 19, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This action originated in the Cincinnati Municipal Court. The plaintiff, Lindsay, appellee herein, seeks a writ of replevin requiring the defendant, city of Cincinnati, appellant herein, to return to him an automobile which had been seized by the Cincinnati Police Department, pursuant to Section 407-134 of the Code of Ordinances of the city, which provides that any police officer, who finds a vehicle being operated as a public vehicle (taxicab) without a city license, shall take possession of the vehicle and arrest the person in charge thereof, and upon conviction of the person arrested, the court shall order the vehicle sold at public sale and the proceeds of the sale, after deduction of expenses and payment of liens, paid to the general fund of the city.

The plaintiff lent his automobile to one Harper for the purpose of having it driven to a repair shop and without any knowledge that Harper intended to use the vehicle as a "bootleg cab" or for any other illegal purpose.

Harper used the automobile as a taxicab contrary to the city ordinance and was arrested by the city police. The police impounded the car pending the hearing [***2] in the Cincinnati Municipal Court of the charge against Harper of having operated said car as a "bootleg cab" contrary to the ordinances of the city. Harper was convicted of the charge, and the court ordered the car sold pursuant to the provisions of Section 407-134 of the Code of Ordinances. This action in replevin to recover possession of the car was brought by the plaintiff prior to the sale.

The Municipal Court sustained the demurrer of the city to the petition, on the ground that Section 407-134 of the Code of Ordinances is constitutional.

On appeal, the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County reversed the judgment of the Municipal Court, on the ground that Section 407-134 of the Code of Ordinances is unconstitutional as applied to those cases where the person arrested for operating a vehicle as a public vehicle without a license is not the owner of the vehicle, because the ordinance does not afford the owner, but only the operator of the vehicle, an opportunity to be heard.

The cause is now before this court on the city's appeal as a matter of right and also pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff automobile owner sought a writ of replevin requiring defendant city to return to him an automobile that had been seized pursuant to Cincinnati, Ohio, Codified Ordinance § 407-134. The municipal court sustained the city's demurrer to the petition. The city appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the municipal court on the ground that § 407-134 was unconstitutional as applied.


OVERVIEW: The owner lent his automobile to a driver to have it taken to a repair shop without any knowledge that the driver intended to use it as a "bootleg cab." The driver was arrested, the car was impounded, and it was ordered to be sold after the driver's conviction. The owner made a plea that the penalty was too severe on an innocent owner. The court reversed the owner's award. The purpose of the city ordinance was to prohibit insolvent, inadequately insured, and unqualified drivers from using unsafe vehicles as taxicabs. The automobile was used for an illegal purpose in violation of the ordinance, and the driver was convicted of violating the ordinance. The owner's argument raised a question of public policy that had to be decided by the appropriate legislative authority and was not within the province of the court. The municipality's authority to seize and forfeit the otherwise lawfully used property that the owner lent to the driver and was illegally used by the driver was within the police power of the municipality. The ordinance was constitutional even though the owner had no knowledge of the illegal use and did not lend the property to be used for any illegal purpose.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and affirmed the judgment of the municipal court.

 

182 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


King Drug Co. v. Bowers


No. 36550


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 461; 172 N.E.2d 3; 1961 Ohio LEXIS 651; 14 Ohio Op. 2d 318



February 1, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The appellants, King Drug Company of Dayton and King Drug Company, owned and operated 11 retail drugstores during the audit period in question here, July 1, 1954, to February 28, 1958. Effective March 1, 1958, the appellants sold their stores to the Gray Drug Company, and shortly thereafter the latter company sold one of such stores to a Mr. Norman. Appellants filed final sales tax returns with the Department of Taxation.

After the stores were sold, the Tax Commissioner began a separate audit of each of the stores for such audit period, when they were owned and operated by appellants. Gray Drug Stores, Inc., made a composite test check of retail sales made in its stores, which included six of the stores acquired from appellants but not the three stores involved in this case. The Tax Commissioner made test checks of the five other stores, included in which were the three stores here involved. On the basis of these checks, appellants were given credit for nontaxable sales and deficiency assessments were issued against these three stores. It is these assessments which are the subject of this appeal.

The final order of the Tax Commissioner [***2] was affirmed by the Board of Tax Appeals.

An appeal from the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers challenged a decision by the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed appellee Tax Commissioner's deficiency assessments issued to the taxpayers for sales tax under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.10.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers had owned and operated 11 retail drugstores, but they sold the stores and filed a final sales tax return. The Commissioner began an audit of each store. Test checks of the stores were made and on the basis of these checks, the Commissioner issued deficiency assessments on three stores. The Board affirmed the Tax Commissioner's order. On appeal, the issue was whether Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.10, so far as it permitted the use of test checks outside the actual audit period to determine the tax liability for sales made during the audit period, was constitutional. The court held that the statute was constitutional and affirmed the Board's decision. The court held that whether a test check covered "a representative period" was a factual question to be determined by the Board. The court found that the record did not disclose any reason other than change of ownership to lead it or the Board to the conclusion that the test-check periods were not representative. The court also noted that continued ownership was not required under the statute. The court concluded that the statute was constitutional and the test checks were not unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decision.

 

183 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ex parte Womack


No. 36493


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 392; 171 N.E.2d 514; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 572; 14 Ohio Op. 2d 150



December 28, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

While serving a sentence in the Ohio State Reformatory for the crime of grand larceny, petitioner was transferred as a patient to Lima State Hospital. While at the hospital he and two other inmates made an attempt to escape, in the course of which a guard was killed. Petitioner was indicted for first degree murder under Section 2901.03, Revised Code.

On January 2, 1956, petitioner appeared in court with counsel, withdrew a plea of not guilty and voluntarily entered a plea of guilty to murder in the second degree. The court accepted this plea, sentenced him to life in the Ohio Penitentiary and entered judgment accordingly.

In September 1958, petitioner filed in the Court of Appeals a notice of appeal and a motion for leave to appeal. The court dismissed the appeal as of right because it was not "timely perfected" and overruled the motion for leave to appeal because "not well taken." This court overruled a motion for leave to appeal and dismissed an appeal as of right for the reason that no debatable constitutional question was involved.

Petitioner has now invoked the original jurisdiction of this court by this proceeding in habeas corpus to obtain his release [**2] from incarceration, contending that Section 2901.03, Revised Code, under which he was indicted, is unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.

 

184 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ex parte Stephens


No. 36553


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 323; 170 N.E.2d 735; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 548; 14 Ohio Op. 2d 1



November 30, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN HABEAS CORPUS.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner remanded to custody.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prisoner filed a habeas corpus proceeding for his release from incarceration on the ground that the Court of Common Pleas of Wood County (Ohio) was wholly without jurisdiction and authority to sentence and commit him.


OVERVIEW: The prisoner was charged with maliciously and forcibly breaking into a storehouse and stealing and carrying away merchandise. The prisoner was represented by counsel and in open court waived in writing prosecution by indictment and consented to proceed upon an information filed by the prosecuting attorney. The prisoner thereafter pleaded guilty to the charge in the information. Once incarcerated, the prisoner filed a habeas corpus proceeding, arguing that the trial court did not have jurisdiction because Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2941.021, which permitted waiver of an indictment, was unconstitutional in light of Ohio Const. art. I, § 10. The court disagreed and remanded the prisoner to custody. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2941.021 was not unconstitutional because it did not remove a right afforded to a person charged with a crime, but instead, afforded him the opportunity to waive indictment. The accused still had the right to insist on an indictment.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the prisoner to custody.

 

185 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


United Engineering & Foundry Co. v. Bowers


Nos. 36471, 36472


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 279; 169 N.E.2d 697; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 525; 13 Ohio Op. 2d 240



October 13, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

The appellant in cause No. 36471, the United Engineering & Foundry Company, is engaged in manufacturing, fabricating and installing iron- and steel-making equipment on a job-order basis, from the drafting of specifications, blue prints and engineering drawings to the completed mill.

In listing its taxable property for the tax year 1956, under Section 5711.16, Revised Code, appellant computed its inventory, including engineering drawings, by taking the average of the preceding year's (1955) month-end values. In computing the value of engineering drawings, appellant excluded values for the months of January through September 1955. The Tax Commissioner, pursuant to audit, added back such excluded values and made his assessment accordingly. There was no issue as to values.

The appellant appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals from the final order of the Tax Commissioner, contending that the commissioner erred in including the value of the engineering drawings as an element of inventory valuation for the months preceding October 4, 1955, since the drawings were entitled to exemption from taxation under Section 5701.03, Revised Code, as it read [***2] prior to its amendment effective October 4, 1955, which amendment removed such property from the exempted list.

The appellant in cause No. 36472, The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, a foreign corporation, is engaged in manufacturing and merchandising foodstuffs in Ohio.

In its 1956 Ohio personal property tax return, it listed for taxation its inventory as required by law, except that it did not include therein the value of certain inventory which it claimed was held by it "for storage only" prior to September 30, 1955. Its fiscal year begins on March 1. The Tax Commissioner, upon audit of such tax return, included the omitted values of inventory in the base to determine appellant's 1956 personal property tax liability.

The appellant appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals from the final order of the Tax Commissioner, contending that the commissioner erred in not excluding from assessment those inventories held by appellant in the months preceding September 30, 1955, and which were exempted from tax as held "for storage only" by a foreign corporation, under former Section 5701.08, Revised Code, as it read prior to its amendment effective September 30, 1955, which amendment removed [***3] such property from the exempted list.

The Board of Tax Appeals affirmed the order of the Tax Commissioner in each case.

Appeals from the decisions of the Board of Tax Appeals bring the causes to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers challenged decisions by the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed appellee Tax Commissioner's orders regarding tax on personal property of the taxpayers pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5701.03 and 5701.08.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers were manufacturing companies and the Tax Commissioner determined that certain inventory or personal property of the taxpayers was subject to tax in 1956 under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5701.03 and 5701.08. The taxpayers claimed that because the statutes were amended in October and September 1955, the Tax Commissioner's use of the statutes were retroactive and unconstitutional. The Board affirmed the Tax Commissioner's tax orders. The court affirmed on appeal. The court found that the Tax Commissioner did not apply the law retroactively and was not taxing property exempted during a part of 1955. The court held that the computation of tax under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 5711.15 and 5711.16 was proper. The court held that a statute was not retroactive merely because it drew on antecedent facts for a criterion in its operation. The court found that the value of the 1955 inventories, as determined by the Tax Commissioner, was only the norm for fixing the value of the 1956 inventories.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's decisions.

 

186 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Akron v. Klein


No. 36349


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 207; 168 N.E.2d 564; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 504; 12 Ohio Op. 2d 331



July 13, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

This action was commenced in the Common Pleas Court of Summit County by the filing of a petition by the city of Akron alleging that defendant is the owner and operator of a junk yard at 333 Euclid Avenue, Akron, in an area zoned for residence only, that defendant's operation of that junk yard constitutes a nuisance, and that defendant is operating his junk yard in violation of ordinance 100-1956. The prayer of the petition is for the abatement of that nuisance and for an injunction against its continuance and against the operation of an illegal junk-yard business in a residential neighborhood, and for general equitable relief.

Defendant filed an answer denying that his operation constitutes a nuisance and alleging in effect that his operation of the junk yard constitutes a lawful nonconforming use. Defendant further filed a cross-petition alleging that the city had tried to prevent the defendant from lawfully operating his business and using his property by enacting ordinance 100-1956 and causing legal actions to be instituted against defendant and that that ordinance is unconstitutional and invalid, and praying that the city [***2] be permanently enjoined and restrained from interfering with defendant's occupancy and use of his property.

So far as pertinent, ordinance 100-1956 reads:
