"In any residential use district as established by the zoning ordinance, any junk yard or wrecked motor-vehicle yard, or used building materials yard, shall maintain an open, unoccupied space 10 feet in width on each side of any lot or plat of ground used for the storage or handling of such materials. Unless within a fireproof building as provided for elsewhere in the code * * * on each such 10 foot setback side line a solid board fence * * * must be constructed. No junk, wrecked motor-vehicle, used building material or similar salvage material shall be stored in such an enclosure to a greater height than such fences.

"In any junk yard, wrecked motor-vehicle yard or used building materials yard, in any residential use district, any other provision of law notwithstanding, the rear yard and the front yard as established by the building line of any such junk yard, wrecked motor-vehicle yard or used building material yard shall be that of the zoning ordinance provisions, but in no event less than 10 feet. Upon this rear yard line [***3] (10 feet or more inside of the rear property line) and upon the building line a solid board fence shall be built * * *.

"Any junk yard, wrecked motor-vehicle yard or used building materials yard in any residential use district shall cease operations between the hours of 6 p. m. and the following 7 a. m. and also all day on Sunday."

Defendant owns two city lots (one with 37 3/8 and the other with 48 3/4 feet frontage and both 150 feet deep) upon one of which is located a house which he rents to a tenant. Defendant's junk yard, which is enclosed by a fence, occupies these two lots behind the front building line except for the portion occupied by the house and 30 or 40 square feet behind the house which is outside the fence. There are no buildings used in the operation of defendant's junk-yard business which is apparently a one-man operation. One Ben Chapman began the operation of a junk-yard business on these two lots in 1916. In 1922, Akron enacted a comprehensive zoning ordinance. These two lots were included in a residential-use district under that ordinance and have been so included since that time. They are now located in a closely built up residential district. Ben Chapman [***4] died in 1947 and his son thereafter continued operation of that business on those lots until he was forced to leave after foreclosure proceedings brought by the Dime Bank. Defendant purchased these two lots from the Dime Bank which had bought them at foreclosure sale. Thereafter, while Chapman's son was moving his junk-yard business out, defendant moved his junk-yard business into and has since conducted it on these two lots.

By its judgment the Common Pleas Court found that defendant's operation of his junk yard constitutes a nuisance and ordered that that nuisance be permanently abated.

On appeal from that judgment on questions of law and fact, the Court of Appeals determined that "the petition of the city * * * should be * * * dismissed, * * * that that portion of * * * ordinance No. 100-1956 requiring * * * [defendant] to cease operations between 6 p. m. and * * * 7 a. m. is unconstitutional; that that portion * * * prohibiting the working on Sunday is invalid as applied to * * * [defendant]; that that portion * * * pertaining to setback lines and fence heights is unenforceable as applied to * * * [defendant];" and that court dismissed the city's petition and permanently [***5] enjoined the city "from further interfering with the occupancy and use of defendant's property at 333 Euclid Avenue."

The cause is now before this court on appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals as an appeal as of right and pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city appealed from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which found in favor of appellee, the owner and operator of a junk yard, in an area zoned for residence only, in the suit alleging that the junkyard constituted a nuisance and was in violation of a city ordinance and praying for the abatement of the nuisance and for an injunction against its continuance.


OVERVIEW: The court of appeals determined that the petition of the city should be dismissed. It found that that portion of the ordinance requiring the junkyard owner to cease operations between 6 p.m. and 7 a.m. was unconstitutional and that a portion prohibiting the working on Sunday was invalid as applied to the junkyard owner. Further, that portion pertaining to setback lines and fence heights was held to be unenforceable as applied to the junkyard owner and dismissed the city's petition and permanently enjoined the city from further interfering with the occupancy and use of the junkyard owner's property. The court of appeals erred in holding invalid the provisions of the ordinance with respect to night and Sunday operations and in failing to enjoin the junkyard owner from such operations. However, the court agreed that the portion of the ordinance that pertained to setback lines and fence heights was unenforceable as applied to the junkyard owner. Where the zoning ordinance provided that the lawful use of any premises existing at the time of its enactment could be continued as a nonconforming use, such ordinance continued the junkyard owner's right to use the premises.


OUTCOME: The judgment finding in favor of the city and granting its request for an injunction was affirmed in part and reversed in part.

 

187 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. McElroy v. A. M. Kinney, Inc.


No. 36489


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 193; 168 N.E.2d 400; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 497; 12 Ohio Op. 2d 301



July 6, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN QUO WARRANTO.

This is an original action in quo warranto to require respondent A. M. Kinney, Inc., to show by what warrant it claims to hold the right to engage in engineering under the laws of the state of Ohio.

The respondent, which has filed a demurrer to the petition on the ground that it does not state facts showing a cause of action, is a corporation organized under the laws of Ohio on February 4, 1929. Such corporation's stated purpose is to engage in activities in conjunction with mechanical, electrical, civil, and structual engineering of all kinds. Such engineering work at all times has been under the supervision of responsible licensed professional engineers.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, the Attorney General of the State of Ohio, filed a petition for a writ of quo warranto to require respondent corporation to show by what warrant it claimed to hold the right to engage in engineering under the laws of the State of Ohio. The corporation filed a demurrer to the petition.


OVERVIEW: In 1929, the corporation was organized for the purpose of engaging in activities in conjunction with engineering. In 1933, the legislature enacted Ohio Gen. Code § 1083-18, which allowed a firm, a copartnership, or an association to engage in the practice of professional engineering. In 1943, the legislature amended the statute to provide that no corporation would thereafter be granted a charter to engage in the practice of engineering. The Attorney General filed a petition for a writ of quo warranto to require the corporation to show by what warrant it claimed to hold the right to engage in engineering. The court held that all engineering corporations organized prior to 1943 could still legally engage in the practice of engineering because the 1943 amendment to Ohio Gen. Code § 1083-18 preserved and validated existing engineering corporations. The court also held that the amendment's validation of existing engineering corporations did not violate the Fourteenth Amendment because it was reasonable for the legislature to consider the positions of existing engineering corporations and to allow them to continue in practice.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the demurrer to the petition and denied the writ.

 

188 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Lakewood v. Thormyer


No. 36103


Supreme Court of Ohio


171 Ohio St. 135; 168 N.E.2d 289; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 666; 12 Ohio Op. 2d 162



June 15, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

In this action, the appellant herein, city of Lakewood (hereinafter referred to as Lakewood), questions the constitutionality of the proviso contained in the second paragraph of Section 5521.01, Revised Code, which authorizes the appellees, acting Director of Highways and Director of Highways (hereinafter referred to as director), to relocate federal aid primary highways (hereinafter referred to as f. a. p. highways) within a municipality without the municipality's consent by following a certain procedure. Lakewood also maintains that the procedure followed demed it due process of law.

The pertinent portion of Section 5521.01, Revised Code, including the proviso under scrutiny herein, is as follows:

"The Director of Highways, upon the request by and the approval of the legislative authority of a village, shall maintain, repair, and center line paint, or may establish, construct, reconstruct, improve, or widen any section of a state highway within the limits of a village. The director may establish, construct, reconstruct, improve, widen, maintain, or repair any section of state highway within the limits of a city, including [***2] the elimination of railway grade crossings, and pay the entire or any part of the cost and expense thereof from state funds, but in all cases he shall first obtain the consent of the legislative authority of such municipal corporation.

"Provided, that when a federal aid primary highway or a federal aid interstate highway is located within a municipal corporation and, in the opinion of the director, is in urgent need of repair, reconstruction, widening, improvement, or relocation, so as to accommodate the traveling public, the Director of Highways shall submit a written request to the legislative authority of the municipality for its consent to the desired improvement. The legislative authority shall within 60 days after such written request has been received from the director either grant its consent to the improvement or refuse such consent by filing in writing with the director a statement of its reasons for refusing the consent and such alternate proposals as it deems reasonable. If the legislative authority fails to act or refuses consent, the director may upon consideration of the reasons for rejection make a resolution declaring the necessity of said improvement which shall [***3] be spread upon his journal and then proceed in the same manner as if consent had been given. A certified copy of said resolution shall be served upon the municipal legislative authority which may, within 20 days from the date of said service, appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of the county in which such municipal corporation is situated, upon the reasonableness and necessity of the action provided for in the resolution. In the hearing upon appeal the director may introduce the record of his proceedings and such other competent evidence as he desires in support of his resolution, and the municipality may likewise introduce competent evidence opposing such resolution. The court may affirm or revoke said resolution. The decision of the Common Pleas Court may be appealed to the Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court as in other cases. If the court affirms said resolution the director may proceed with said improvement with or without the co-operation of said municipality."

Before 1947 there was no provision of law which enabled the director to construct a highway in a municipality or relocate the same without the consent of that municipality. In that year the Legislature amended [***4] Section 1178-42, General Code, to provide such power under certain conditions. That section, without substantial change, became Section 5521.01, Revised Code, in the Recodification Act of 1953, and in 1955 it was again amended to its present form. The director has never previously had occasion to use the same, and its constitutionality in its entirety has never been passed upon by this court.

The proposed action of the director to which objection is made is the relocation and new construction of 1.1 miles of State Route No. 2 and U.S. Routes Nos. 6 and 20 in the city of Lakewood, the construction of a new bridge across Rocky River and a relocation of said routes in the city of Rocky River, all at an estimated cost of some 5.75 million dollars.

On April 24, 1957, under the authority of Section 5511.01, Revised Code, and pursuant to notice theretofore given, the director held a hearing where arguments were presented for and against the proposed location. On July 11, 1957, the director by resolution did relocate and establish as a limited-access highway said State Route No. 2 and U.S. Routes Nos. 6 and 20 as described in the notice of hearing. On July 29, 1957, a copy of the resolution [***5] was forwarded to the city of Lakewood with a request that it pass a consent ordinance. As evidenced by a resolution of city council of September 25, 1957, this Lakewood refused to do, stating its reasons and suggesting alternate proposals. Then on November 1, 1957, the director journalized a resolution determining that in his opinion State Route No. 2 and U.S. Routes Nos. 6 and 20 were in urgent need of relocation and improvement. A copy of this resolution was certified to Lakewood, and within the time limited Lakewood appealed to the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County upon the reasonableness and necessity of the action authorized by the resolution and as provided by said Section 5521.01, Revised Code. After full hearing (the printed record consists of some 600 pages), the court refused to revoke the resolution and affirmed the same.

Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals, that judgment was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right and the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) that found for appellee Director of Highways and upheld the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code § 5521.01. The city claimed that § 55201.01 had not authorized the director to journalize a resolution, that the statute denied it due process of law, and that it was unconstitutional under Ohio Const. art II, §§ 1, 26 and Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3.


OVERVIEW: A city challenged a trial court's decision that permitted the Director of Highways to relocate highway routes. The court affirmed the trial court's decision and also upheld the director's decision to journalize a resolution as having fallen within the purview of Ohio Rev. Code § 5521.01. Journalization was permitted under § 5521.01, the court found, because otherwise the state would be deprived of several benefits. The court held that the director lawfully conducted a hearing regarding his proposed actions under Ohio Rev. Code § 5511.01. Fair administrative consideration was provided to the city under Ohio Rev. Code § 5521.01, the court found, as the city had justifiably delegated authority to the director. The court found that the city received due process of law under the general appeal process created by § 5521.01 and held the statute constitutional under Ohio Const. art. II, §§ 1, 26, because it had not delegated legislative power to the Secretary of Commerce. The court also found that Ohio Rev. Code § 5521.01 was not unconstitutional under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, because it concerned matters of greater than local interest and did not infringe on local police power.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision that upheld the constitutionality of the disputed statute. The court also found that the director's decision was justified.

 

189 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Levi v. Levi


No. 36176


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 533; 166 N.E.2d 744; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 644; 11 Ohio Op. 2d 364



April 27, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Knox County.

The facts are stated in the opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant former husband sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Knox County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the trial court in denying the husband's motion to vacate and set aside a previous order requiring the husband to pay support to appellee former wife and their children, who were residing in another state.


OVERVIEW: The wife, a resident of North Carolina, initiated a proceeding in North Carolina against the husband for support of herself and their three minor children. There was no personal service upon the husband, but that court found that the husband was responsible for his family's support and set an amount for maintenance. An order was forwarded to the Ohio trial court and assigned for trial. The father appeared with an attorney, and after trial, the husband was found liable for support, but in a lesser amount than found by the North Carolina court. The father made partial payments, but after defaulting and being cited for contempt, he filed his motion to vacate and set aside the order because he was denied due process of law. The court affirmed and held that under the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 3115, the father was not denied due process because a transcript of the North Carolina proceeding was sent to Ohio, he was given the opportunity to present evidence at a trial in Ohio, and he made payments thereunder without filing an appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court judgment.

 

190 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Ladd v. New York C. R. Co.


No. 36037


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 491; 166 N.E.2d 231; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 637; 11 Ohio Op. 2d 245; 45 L.R.R.M. 3198; 39 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P66,407



April 6, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Plaintiff, Robert S. Ladd, became employed by defendant, The New York Central Railroad Company, as a fireman in June 1941. He served in the United States Navy Seabees from the last part of 1943 into January 1946, when he returned to work with the railroad. He was promoted to a rating of engineer as of January 15, 1951, but continued his work as a fireman.

On the night of December 6, 1951, at about 11 p. m., he reported for work and later, during the early morning hours of December 7, while working on an engine pulling cars from one yard to another, he became ill, necessitating his relief from duty at about 4 a. m. He did not see a doctor at that time but returned to work that night at 11 p. m. He was voluntarily off for a funeral following that night and returned to work on the night of the 10th. On the 11th he was notified that he was temporarily relieved from duty pending a physical examination. He was examined in the office of Dr. Burkholder, the New York Central surgeon in Toledo, on the morning of the 11th and by a Dr. Nickels in the office of Dr. O'Donnell, the New York Central medical director at Detroit, on the 12th [***2] of December. He was temporarily relieved from service until December 27th or 28th when he was advised at a meeting with the road foreman of engines and the local chairman of the union that he was permanently relieved from work as a fireman on the railroad. Later, he received a letter telling him that "they had diagnosed me as an epileptic." The petition alleges that the "said C. H. O'Donnell, M. D., wrongfully and mistakenly claimed that plaintiff was an epileptic and made a diagnosis of epilepsy."

On February 25, 1952, plaintiff consulted Dr. Hopple, a neurosurgeon in Toledo, who at that time "took a complete history" and "did a complete general physical and neurological examination of him" at his office, later sending the plaintiff to a hospital for 12 days' examination in March.

Dr. Hopple's report to the local representative of the brotherhood refers to "several episodes of blacking out" during the preceding five years and his final diagnosis was "syncope [fainting] probably associated with hypoglycemia [low sugar count]."

In August 1952, by mutual agreement between Dr. O'Donnell, the chief surgeon for the railroad, and Dr. Hopple, selected by the brotherhood, Dr. Gurdjian,  [***3] a neurosurgeon in Detroit, was selected as "a third neutral doctor to carry out an examination and express an opinion about the employee's ability to return to his regular work." Mr. Ryan, general chairman of the locomotive engineers for that area, testified that the procedure of having Dr. Gurdjian examine the plaintiff "went further than the rules required."

Plaintiff spent about two weeks in Grace Hospital in Detroit in September 1952 for this last examination, and the report and recommendation of Dr. Gurdjian was that plaintiff "should not work on machinery or other moving vehicles because of the possibility of injury to himself as well as to others."

From December 1951 on there were numerous conferences between railroad and brotherhood representatives, finally reaching the stage where Mr. Peterson (Assistant General Manager for Labor Relations) was representing the railroad and Mr. Ryan, general chairman of the brotherhood, was representing plaintiff.

Following the report by Dr. Gurdjian, Mr. Peterson, as "the chief operating officer of the carrier designated to handle such disputes" (see Section 153 (i), Title 45, U.S. Code, infra), disqualified plaintiff from further [***4] service as a fireman on the basis of physical disability.

In January 1956, plaintiff instituted his action against the railroad, claiming damages for alleged breach of contract. Paragraph number 6 of the petition states:

"Plaintiff says that his disqualification by the defendant was in direct violation of his contract of employment; that plaintiff has accepted his disqualification by the defendant as a final discharge; that he is no longer an employee of the defendant and that he is bringing this action against the defendant for breach of said contract of employment by the defendant and for wrongful dismissal and permanent disqualification from service."

Plaintiff then alleges loss of earnings up to the time of filing suit in the amount of $ 20,000 and future wage impairment and loss of earnings in the sum of approximately $ 105,000.

The answer of the railroad, filed in January 1957, admits and denies certain pleadings of plaintiff and sets up rule 9 of the agreement between the brotherhood and the railroad. In plaintiff's reply filed in September 1957, the full set of rules, regulations and requirements between the brotherhood and the railroad governing physical examinations [***5] is set forth and attached as part of the reply. The plaintiff alleges in his reply that defendant railroad wrongfully and fraudulently violated these rules, regulations and requirements, causing plaintiff, "to be wrongfully discharged by defendant and wrongfully disqualified from further service by defendant as set forth in plaintiff's petition."

Upon submission of all the issues to the jury, a lump-sum verdict was returned in the amount of $ 50,000, for which judgment was rendered, and upon appeal the judgment was affirmed by a divided court. No written opinion was rendered in either the trial court or the Court of Appeals.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed a lower court's judgment entering a jury verdict was in favor of appellee employee in his action for wrongful discharge and violation of the terms of a collective bargaining agreement. The employer claimed that the employee failed to exhaust his administrative remedies as required by the Railway Labor Act, 45 U.S.C.S. § 151 et seq.


OVERVIEW: After the employee, a railroad fireman, developed health problems, the employer, a railroad company, required a medical evaluation. When the employee was diagnosed with epilepsy, the employer terminated him. The employee filed an action for wrongful discharge and breach of the collective bargaining agreement. A jury verdict was entered in favor of the employee, and the appellate court affirmed the award. Upon a motion to certify the record, the court reversed, holding that the employee had failed to exhaust his administrative remedies under the Railway Labor Act. Although an action for wrongful discharge was available to the employee in state courts, the collective bargaining agreement provided that an employment dispute be settled in accordance with the Railway Labor Act. The Act first required the employee to appeal to the National Railroad Adjustment Board and the state required that the employee first exhaust his administrative remedies. Because he did not do so, the jury award was improper, and the matter was remanded with directions to enter judgment in favor of the employer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court, and it rendered judgment in favor of the employer.

 

191 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Preston v. Ferguson


No. 36283


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 450; 166 N.E.2d 365; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 631; 11 Ohio Op. 2d 204



March 30, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This case is concerned with newly enacted Section 5501.112, Revised Code, and with an agreement created thereunder. The design of Section 5501.112, Revised Code, and of any agreements created thereunder is to provide a method for financing the cost of the advance acquisition of land to be used for highway purposes.

The 103rd General Assembly enacted Section 3309.151, Revised Code, empowering the School Employees Retirement Board to use its funds to purchase real property located within the state for the purpose of resale to the Department of Highways. Such a purchase is authorized if the board has entered into an agreement with the Departmment of Highways pursuant to newly enacted Section 5501.112, Revised Code, which is contained in the chapter entitled "Department of Highways." This section deals with the acquisition, use, and resale of such property. It sets forth the terms which must be contained in such agreements and empowers the Director of Highways to purchase in advance property which he deems will be necessary for the improvement of the state highway system.

Pursuant to such sections the Director of Highways entered into an agreement with the School Employees [***2] Retirement Board wherein the director, as agent for the retirement board, is to negotiate the purchase of certain real property which he deems will be necessary for the improvement of the state highway system. The director has negotiated the purchase of such real property and the board has drawn a requisition upon the respondent Treasurer of State as custodian of the board's funds. Respondent refused to honor the requisition, whereupon this original action in mandamus was instituted in this court. Respondent treasurer has filed his answer setting up various constitutional objections to the statute and the agreement. The relator has filed a demurrer to the answer, and the cause is presently before the court upon the pleadings.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator director of highways brought an action in mandamus asking the court to direct respondent state treasurer to disburse funds for relator's purchase of real property pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5501.112.


OVERVIEW: Relator state highway director sought mandamus to force respondent state treasurer to release funds to pay for the purchase of highway rights of way pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5501.112. The court granted a writ of mandamus and found that § 5501.112 and relator's agreement concerning the purchase did not authorize or create a debt of the state. A debt was not created because an appropriation existed to support the original agreement concerning the purchase, the agreement required a new appropriation before the agreement could be renewed and it required the obtaining of a certificate of availability of funds in compliance with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 131.17, the agreement's two-year limitation satisfied Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5501.112, and subsequent legislatures were not bound by the agreement. The expenditure for relator's advance acquisition of highway rights of way constituted an economically sound and reasonable expenditure for a statutory highway purpose and the fact that the acquisition was made before the actual contract letting for the improvement did not prevent the transaction from being properly characterized as an expenditure for a statutory highway purpose.


OUTCOME: The court granted a writ of mandamus in favor of relator state highway director because the acquisition of rights of way was a reasonable and economically sound purchase for a statutory highway purpose and the fact that the acquisition was made before the actual contract letting for the improvement did not prevent it from being a proper expenditure. The agreement and statute involved did not authorize or create a debt of the state.

 

192 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mapp


No. 36091


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 427; 166 N.E.2d 387; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 627; 11 Ohio Op. 2d 169



March 23, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Defendant was indicted for "unlawfully and knowingly" having "had in her possession and under her control, certain lewd and lascivious books, pictures and photographs."

This indictment was based upon Section 2905.34, Revised Code, which reads in part:

"No person shall knowingly * * * have in his possession or under his control an obscene, lewd, or lascivious book * * * print, [or] picture * * *

"Whoever violates this section shall be fined not less than $ 200 nor more than $ 2,000 or imprisoned not less than one nor more than seven years, or both."

The verdict of the jury found the defendant "guilty of possession of obscene literature as charged in the indictment." Defendant's motion for a new trial was overruled and the Common Pleas Court rendered judgment sentencing defendant to imprisonment in the Ohio Reformatory for Women for an indeterminate period. *


* Section 5143.05, Revised Code, reads in part:

"Courts imposing sentences to the reformatory shall make them general, and not fixed or limited in their duration. The term of imprisonment shall be terminated by the Pardon and Parole Commission * * * but * * * shall not exceed the maximum term, nor be less than the minimum term provided for such felony."

 [***2] On appeal to the Court of Appeals, that judgment was affirmed.

The cause is now before this court on appeal from the judgment of the Court of Appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgment of the trial court convicting her of possession of obscene literature pursuant to a jury verdict of guilty, and sentencing her to imprisonment for an indeterminate period.


OVERVIEW: The obscene books and pictures had belonged to the previous tenant of defendant's apartment, and defendant had packed the materials in boxes pending instructions for their disposition from their owner. The court acknowledged that there was no evidence in the record that a search warrant had been issued in contravention of state statutes and constitutional provisions requiring the issuance of a search warrant upon probable cause, and particularly describing the things to be searched for. However, the court held that evidence obtained in an unlawful search and seizure was admissible in a criminal prosecution as long as the method used to obtain the seized materials did not involve brutal or offensive physical force or otherwise offend a sense of justice. The court noted that under the applicable statute, defendant could be convicted for merely possessing the books or pictures, regardless of her intention ever to look at them again.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the intermediate appellate court affirming defendant's conviction for possession of obscene materials was affirmed.

 

193 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


S. S. Kresge Co. v. Bowers


No. 36124


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 405; 166 N.E.2d 139; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 623; 11 Ohio Op. 2d 157



March 23, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On February 21, 1958, the Tax Commissioner of Ohio issued a sales tax assessment against the appellant S. S. Kresge Company for the period of four years beginning January 1, 1952, and ending December 31, 1955, for retail sales in amounts exceeding 40 cents.

The assessment issued by the Tax Commissioner was affirmed by the Board of Tax Appeals.

An appeal has been perfected to this court on the ground that the assessment is unreasonable and unlawful.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant vendor sought review of a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which entered judgment in favor of appellee tax commissioner in the commissioner's action issuing a sales tax assessment against the vendor for retail sales.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner issued a sales tax assessment against the vendor for a four-year period for retail sales in excess of certain amounts. The Board affirmed the assessment. On appeal, the court sustained that decision. The court stated that the vendor did not maintain register tapes of keep sales slips. The court found that the vendor did not maintain an adequate record of taxable sales and the tax collected thereon as provide by the Ohio Stales Tax Act. The court also said that the period the commissioner used for the test check constituted a representative period. The vendor, by the information furnished relative to its retail sales, did not sustain the burden of proof imposed upon it by law. The court found that the decision of the Board was neither unreasonable nor unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Board's judgment.

 

194 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Columbus v. Webster


No. 35953


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 327; 164 N.E.2d 734; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 596; 10 Ohio Op. 2d 419



February 10, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This action arose as a result of defendant, appellant herein, being charged with certain parking violations contrary to the ordinances of the city of Columbus. A plea of not guilty was entered by defendant. Upon the trial of the action before the Municipal Court, the prosecution introduced evidence that on the dates specified in the affidavits an automobile registered in defendant's name was tagged for these violations.

At the trial, no evidence was introduced that defendant parked the automobile, the prosecution relying on the provisions of a city ordinance that, where an automobile is found illegally parked and the identity of the driver cannot be determined, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered is prima facie responsible for the violation. Defendant introduced no evidence but moved that the charges be dismissed on the grounds that the ordinance is unconstitutional and that the prosecution had not proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant had committed the offenses. The court upheld the validity of the ordinance, overruled defendant's motion and found defendant guilty. The defendant appealed to [***2] the Court of Common Pleas where the judgment was affirmed. Upon appeal to the Court of Appeals the judgment was again affirmed and that court certified the record of the case to this court on the ground that the Court of Appeals judgment is in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, in an unreported case, affirming the judgment in the case of McCarthy v. City of Cincinnati, 27 N. P. (N. S.), 362.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the judgments of the municipal court and court of common pleas that defendant was responsible for parking offenses, in violation of Col. Mun. Code § 27.334. The municipal court overruled defendant's motion for dismissal filed on the ground that the ordinance was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with parking offenses, in violation of Col. Mun. Code § 27.334. In the municipal court, defendant moved that the charges be dismissed on the grounds that the ordinance was unconstitutional and that the prosecution had not proved beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant had committed the offenses. The municipal court overruled the motion and found defendant guilty. Defendant appealed to the court of common pleas and to the lower court, both of which affirmed the judgment of the municipal court. Defendant sought further review. On review, the court found that Ohio Const. Art XVIII, § 3 gave municipalities the power to enact and enforce local police regulations that were not in conflict with general laws. The court concluded that a municipality, in those instances in which the identity of a parking violator could not be determined, might make the owner of the motor vehicle prima facie responsible for its being illegally parked without proof that such owner parked the vehicle himself or that it was parked with his knowledge and consent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court.

 

195 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Western Industries, Inc. v. Hamilton County Board of Revision


No. 36074


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 340; 164 N.E.2d 741; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 599; 10 Ohio Op. 2d 427



February 10, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This case involves the valuation, for purposes of taxation, of real estate with improvements thereon located in Hamilton County and known as the Kenwood Plaza Shopping Center. The appellant, owner of the subject premises, objected to the valuation placed thereon by the county auditor for the tax year 1957 and appealed to the county Board of Revision. After a hearing at which evidence was presented, the Board of Revision refused to reduce the valuation.

An appeal was taken from the decision of the Board of Revision to the Board of Tax Appeals under authority of Section 5717.01 et seq., Revised Code. Section 5717.03, Revised Code, provides that "in the case of an appeal from a decision of a county Board of Revision the Board of Tax Appeals shall determine the true value in money of the property whose valuation or assessment by the county Board of Revision is complained of."

The Board of Tax Appeals held that its duty was to determine whether the appellant had carried the burden of showing that the true value in money of the subject property for the tax year 1957 was less than the value listed on the county tax duplicate. After reviewing [***2] the evidence the Board of Tax Appeals found that appellant had not shown that either the land or the structures involved were valued in excess of their "true value in money" on the tax duplicate and adopted the valuation ascribed to the property by the county Board of Revision.

An appeal from the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals brings the cause to this court for review.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.

 

196 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


In re Appropriation of Easements for Highway Purposes


No. 35977


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 276; 164 N.E.2d 420; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 589; 10 Ohio Op. 2d 332



January 27, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County.

In the Court of Common Pleas of Muskingum County, Ohio, the Director of Highways of the state filed a resolution and finding for the appropriation of approximately 24 acres of the defendants' land for highway purposes in that county in conformity with the authority conferred by the provisions of Sections 5519.01 and 5519.02, Revised Code.

On the same day the Director of Highways deposited with the court the sum of $ 13,735, the amount he found to be the value of the property to be appropriated and the damages to the residue.

Thereafter the owners filed a so-called statutory appeal (1) upon the question of the necessity and the extent of the appropriation of land, and (2) upon the valuation and damages fixed by the director.

Over the objection of the director, the court considered the first question at a preliminary hearing and held that the director had abused his discretion by including acreage not actually needed for the proposed highway improvement.

On an appeal by the director to the Court of Appeals on questions of law, the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas on the question of the necessity and the extent of the appropriation [***2] of land was reversed, and the cause was remanded to the trial court for the purpose of having a jury determine the amount of compensation and damages to which the owners of the land are entitled.

The cause is in this court for a review by reason of the allowance of the landowners' motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owners sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Muskingum County (Ohio), which reversed and remanded the trial court's decision that appellee director of highways had abused his discretion by including acreage that was not actually needed for a proposed highway improvement.


OVERVIEW: The director filed a resolution and finding for the appropriation of approximately 24 acres of the owners' land for highway purposes. On the same day, the director deposited with the trial court the sum of $ 13,735 the amount he found to be the value of the property to be appropriated and the damages to the residue. Thereafter the owners appealed. The trial court held that the director had abused his discretion by including acreage not actually needed for the proposed highway improvement. On further review, the appellate court reversed the trial court's decision on the question of the necessity and the extent of the appropriation of land. The owners challenged the reversal of the trial court's decision. The court affirmed the appellate court's decision. The court found that in a proceeding to assess compensation for the taking of private property, the trial court could not examine the necessity of the taking. The court determined that the appellate court was not in error when it limited the proceeding to a determination of the amount of compensation and damages to which the owners were entitled.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's reversal of the trial court's decision that the director had abused his discretion by including acreage that was not actually needed for a proposed highway improvement.

 

197 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Gusweiler v. Board of Elections


No. 36335


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 273; 164 N.E.2d 407; 1960 Ohio LEXIS 588; 10 Ohio Op. 2d 331



January 20, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The relator is serving as a judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County by virtue of appointment by the Governor on December 29, 1958, pursuant to the provisions of Section 13 of Article IV of the Constitution, to fill the vacancy created by the death of Judge Joseph H. Woeste who had been elected for a full term of six years commencing January 4, 1957. Relator is now seeking to be a candidate for that unexpired term ending January 3, 1963.

Relator has tendered to the respondent board of elections the necessary filing fee, declaration of candidacy and petition for nomination for the primary election to be held on May 3, 1960. Respondents refused to accept such filing fee, declaration and petition, on the ground that the petition was not filed pursuant to the provisions of Section 2301.02, Revised Code.

The above facts are alleged in relator's petition, in which he prays for a writ of mandamus directing the respondents to accept his nominating petition as required by Section 13 of Article IV of the Constitution.

Respondents demurred to the petition on the ground that it "does not allege facts sufficient to support a cause of action or to permit the relief [***2] prayed for."



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator common pleas court judge sought a writ of mandamus directing respondent board of elections to accept his petition for nomination to the unexpired term of a deceased judge for a primary election, as required by Ohio Const. art. IV, § 13. The board, which contended that the nominating petition was not filed pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2301.02, demurred to the mandamus petition on the ground that it did not support a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The Governor of Ohio appointed the judge to fill a vacancy pursuant to Ohio Const. art. IV, § 13. The controversy that prompted the judge to initiate a mandamus action arose when he sought to be a candidate for the deceased judge's unexpired term at the next primary election. The board of elections contended that the last paragraph of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2301.02, which was added by amendment, justified its refusal to accept the judge's nominating petition because it abolished the deceased judge's unexpired term. The court disagreed and held that the statutory provision was unconstitutional because it was in direct conflict with Ohio Const. art. IV, § 13, which mandated the election of a successor to fill the deceased judge's unexpired term. As there was a patent and obvious conflict between the constitutional provision and the statutory provision, the rule of statutory construction that acts of the Ohio General Assembly were presumed valid and that it was mandatory to resolve all doubt in favor of their validity did not apply.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the demurrer to the petition and allowed a writ of mandamus.

 

198 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Curtiss v. Cleveland


No. 35649


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 127; 163 N.E.2d 682; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 507; 10 Ohio Op. 2d 85



December 16, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This action for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief was instituted in the Common Pleas Court of Cuyahoga County by plaintiff appellee, the owner of real estate improved for business purposes and located on Lake Shore Boulevard in Cleveland between Marcella Avenue and Neff Road.

The defendant appellees are also owners of real estate improved for business purposes and located on or adjacent to the same part of Lake Shore Boulevard.

This part of Lake Shore Boulevard is located and represents about one-fourth of the 7/10 mile between Nottingham and Windward Roads. The portion of Lake Shore Boulevard between Nottingham and Windward Roads had been zoned for general retail business in 1929 by defendant-appellant, the city of Cleveland. In 1945, this portion of Lake Shore Boulevard was rezoned for multifamily residences so as to make any then existing use for general retail business a nonconforming use. In 1949, the zoning ordinance was further amended so as to restrict the enlargement or expansion of nonconforming uses and so as to provide for their elimination under certain circumstances or conditions.

The Common Pleas [***2] Court (through Judge Bell, now a member of this court) held these amendments to the zoning ordinance unconstitutional and enjoined their enforcement so far as they purport to restrict the improvement or use of property located on this portion of Lake Shore Boulevard differently than it had been restricted by the original 1929 zoning ordinance.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals on law and fact, that court denied relief to those who had not asked for it and to those whose properties had not been substantially improved for business purposes prior to the foregoing 1945 amendments to the zoning ordinance. As a result, its judgment gave relief such as had been given by the Common Pleas Court only to the plaintiff appellee and the defendant appellees, hereinafter collectively referred to as the appellees, who were the only parties who had sought relief and owned properties so substantially improved for business purposes.

That judgment of the Court of Appeals was reversed by this court.

On remand to the Court of Appeals, that court found "upon reconsideration of all of the evidence in the case" that "the amendatory ordinances * * * when applied to the properties" of appellees "are confiscatory,  [***3] unreasonable and discriminatory and without relation to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare and are unconstitutional as to" their properties; and "permanently enjoined" Cleveland "from any action or conduct tending to interfere with the use and enjoyment of said premises in the same manner and to the same extent as they were, or could have been used and enjoyed prior to the adoption of said amendatory ordinances."

The city filed in this court an appeal as of right from that judgment of the Court of Appeals (claiming a constitutional question), and also filed a motion requesting this court to certify the record to this court for review. The motion to certify was overruled but a motion to dismiss the appeal, as involving no debatable constitutional question, was also overruled.



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and, as modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which held that certain zoning ordinance amendments were invalid as applied to appellee property owners.


OVERVIEW: The zoning ordinance was amended to restrict the enlargement or expansion of nonconforming uses and to provide for their elimination under certain circumstances or conditions. The record disclosed that appellees were the owners of substantially improved lands and that a substantial actual loss in value resulted from the rezoning of these lands by the amendments to the zoning ordinance. The evidence was sufficient to justify the conclusion that the decisions, which the legislative body was presumed to have made, were clearly erroneous. The evidence disclosed that appellees' properties had a substantially lesser value because of the use restrictions imposed by the amendatory ordinances. However, the injunction imposed by the lower court was too broad as it would have even prevented the enforcement of any future valid amendatory ordinance to appellees. The judgment was therefore modified to enjoin the enforcement only of the portions of the amendments complained of in the suit. As modified, the judgment was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment, which had held zoning ordinance amendments invalid as applied to appellees, and as modified, affirmed the judgment.

 

199 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


Benua v. Columbus


No. 35699


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 64; 162 N.E.2d 467; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 488; 9 Ohio Op. 2d 459



November 18, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is an action seeking a declaratory judgment and an injunction against the city of Columbus, Ohio, by a resident of another Franklin County municipality. In his amended petition the plaintiff, appellant herein, alleges that he is the owner of certain real estate located within the city of Columbus which is rented to various tenants from whom he receives rents. The testimony in the trial court developed his ownership of four Columbus properties and the details of the income produced as rentals therefrom.

The plaintiff then alleges the enactment of certain ordinances by the city of Columbus, and at the trial such enactment was stipulated and copies of the ordinances were received in evidence by agreement. The ordinances so placed in the record are No. 1030-52, No. 1209-54 (which amends certain sections of ordinance No. 1030-52), No. 536-56, and No. 1073-56. By and through these ordinances the city established and levied the Columbus city income tax.

The plaintiff next alleges that the authorities of the city of Columbus have "insisted" that plaintiff include in his individual income tax return to the city of Columbus the [***2] income received as rents from his Columbus real estate, alleges that he has exhausted his administrative remedies in "endeavoring to convince" the municipal taxing authorities that said rents are not subject to the income tax, alleges that he is threatened with "civil and/or criminal proceedings" to enforce such payment by him, and alleges that he "desires" to pay the taxes levied by the ordinances referred to if he is legally liable therefor. Plaintiff sets forth five conclusions of law to which he asks the court to subscribe and prays further for an order permanently enjoining the municipal officials from commencing or maintaining any action to enforce the income tax ordinance against him. To the extent necessary for present purposes, the propositions for which the plaintiff prays support appear hereinafter.

The conclusions of the Court of Common Pleas were directly contrary to those set forth by the plaintiff, the court finding that the rents from the Columbus properties are subject to the tax, and that they are not exempted therefrom for any of the statutory or constitutional reasons suggested in the amended petition. The court denied the injunction and rendered judgment for [***3] defendant.

Upon appeal on questions of law and fact to the Court of Appeals, that court rendered a similar judgment.

An appeal as of right and the allowance of a motion to certify the record place the cause before this court for decision on its merits.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owner challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed a judgment for appellee city finding that the rents from the owner's properties within the city were subject to tax, and that they were not exempted therefrom.


OVERVIEW: The owner held certain property within the city, although he lived in another municipality. The city enacted ordinances which established and levied a city income tax. The owner argued that the rent from his city properties could not be taxed as income by the city. The court affirmed. The owner's activities fell squarely within the definition of "business" in the ordinance. Net rentals received by an owner of real estate within the city from properties let by him under such circumstances were included within the term "net profits" as that term was defined by ordinance. Where real property within a municipality was rented under such circumstances as to constitute a doing of business under the terms of an ordinance levying a municipal income tax, the rentals were subject to such tax as net profits from the operation of a business. Rents received by the owner, a nonresident, from real estate located within the city were subject to the income tax, not exempt from such tax by reason of any pre-emption by the state, not exempt from such tax by Ohio statutes, not exempt from such tax by virtue of the state constitution, and not exempt from such tax by implication of the laws of Ohio.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

200 of 1176 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ronald, Inc. v. Willoughby


No. 35384


Supreme Court of Ohio


170 Ohio St. 39; 161 N.E.2d 890; 1959 Ohio LEXIS 477; 9 Ohio Op. 2d 386



November 4, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

The relator has invoked the original jurisdiction of this court for the purpose of obtaining a writ of mandamus to require the respondent building inspector of the city of Willoughby to issue the relator a permit for the construction of a single frame dwelling on a certain sublot owned by it in that city.

The answer admits the refusal to issue the permit and interposes the defense of a municipal zoning ordinance designating that area exclusively for a so-called limited industrial district.

The cause is submitted on the relator's petition, the answer of the respondents, the reply of the relator, and the agreed statement of facts.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator property owner sought a writ of mandamus to compel respondent building inspector to issue a permit for the construction of a house on his property.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's application for a permit to build a single frame dwelling on his premises was denied by the building inspector. The property owner commenced an action in mandamus to compel the building inspector to issue the building permit. The court denied the writ and dismissed the action, finding that the property owner was not entitled to mandamus relief because he had not exhausted all of the legal remedies that were available to him. The court found that the property owner could not employ the extraordinary remedy of a writ of mandamus as a means of circumventing the administrative and legal remedies that were available to him.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ and dismissed the petition.
